"The primordial essence of the prior heavens is empty, void, and formless. The way of replenishment belongs entirely to the Yellow Court. It is like a marionette: the strings pull, and the form moves. You must know that the mechanism of movement lies in the hand that holds it. When the hand embodies the true, you fully understand its operation and perceive things without delusion. Like a lotus floating on still water, when the treasure of life is formed, the pearl of nature shines brilliantly. Hidden and manifest support one another; being and non-being interweave.

"Spirit is fundamentally empty; the Dao is fundamentally still. Thus, emptiness is without obstruction; stillness is without desire. Preserve my life and destiny; observe transformation and know return. Within the cosmos, among the three powers, all forms accord with the Dao; all things contain numinosity. Generation upon generation, transformation upon transformation—seek within and understand for yourself. Follow the Way of heaven, and my heart does not cease. Act without contrivance; follow the Way of earth to bear all things. My body is still and does not grasp; it is the mechanism of heaven and earth’s opening and closing. The pivot of my heart’s movement and stillness—subdue body and heart, model heaven and earth.

"The Most High said: 'To honor life is to lighten death.' Only non-being surpasses valuing life. Destiny is burdened by the body and bound to life and death; nature is enslaved by the heart and subject to rising and sinking. Destiny is firm when the heart is empty; the Dao is hidden and nameless. Returning to round brightness and the origin, all kalpas are empty. When the body is stable, form is firm—firm form completes destiny. When the heart is stable, spirit is whole—whole spirit completes nature. When spirit is whole and the horn is firm, embracing the origin may be achieved.

"Severing thoughts is the essence of nurturing the fire; embodying emptiness is the work of refining the medicine. The Kun body and the Qian heart are the root of returning to life. Who guards the Flowery Pond? Who bears the Purple Palace? The double passes of the spine—able to descend and ascend—qi surges through the joints. Essence fills and spirit congeals; the valley of emptiness completes the four seasons.

"The Way of heaven and earth turns things without sentiment, penetrating unity through repeated emptiness."

The teachings of Yan [Hui] and Zeng [Shen], the coarse meal and water, the bent arm for a pillow—Confucius found joy therein. Ziyang said: *"The primal qi unfolds in creation, its true wonder boundless. Who presides over this? The work of the Uncarved."*

The deer circulates [qi] through the *weilu* to connect with the *Du* vessel; the tortoise circulates breath through the nostrils to connect with the *Ren* vessel. The crane unites through qi, the tortoise unites through spirit. Without reckless exertion, daily cultivation renews monthly—celestial stars and earthly tides form of themselves.

To guard the yang is to guard the *hun*; to guard the yin is to guard the *po*. Thus the perfected one refines the *hun* to merge with the *po*, wisdom arising from obscurity, supreme stability congealing the spirit. Golden form and jade substance arise from the completion of essence. When the great medicine ripens, the body becomes light as flight.

In leisure, celestial music—pure as bamboo’s song—wraps in swirling clouds of color, stepping steadily toward the Southern Palace. Once I received my teacher’s instruction and attained this immortal fruition.

The method of cultivation: build your elixir foundation, dig the well to seek lead, gather mercury to refine cinnabar. The stone foot’s clear spring—use no杂 impurities. One qi, two modes; the three powers shaped in the crucible. Choose renowned mountains, and good companions to aid your endeavor. Still, seek a high Daoist master to perform the rites and recite the scriptures: *The Jade Emperor’s Pivot*, *The Three Primordials of True Martial*, *The Northern and Southern Dipper Scriptures*. Recite the cavern chapters to dispel defilements and impure vapors.

At the outset of entering the chamber, change into fresh garments. Ancient immortals ascended, leaving their elixir wells as a testament. The altar’s construction and arrangement shall be instructed separately. Refine with precision and perseverance, embracing the root to return to emptiness.

This scripture endures in the world, revealing all celestial mechanisms. In silent, steadfast cultivation, the spirit ascends to the Purple Tenuity. When merit is complete and virtue perfected, the jade edict comes to bear you away.

Here now the gatha declares:
Preserve essence to guard the true—
the body at peace, free of desire.
Preserve qi to nourish the heart—
the heart still, cut off from things.
Preserve spirit to return to emptiness;
emptiness extreme, stillness profound.
Water flows and grows turbid;
water congeals and clears itself.
Movement and stillness belong to the heart—
when the heart is still, the Dao is bright.
Qi gathers like a fetus,
subdued within the mother’s womb.
After ten months, qi is released—
within the body, another body.
One morning it emerges,
parting from the mother.

Nowadays, those who refine the elixir
see black clouds veil the sky.
Without the wind of wisdom,
sun and moon are shrouded in haze.
One yin gives rise to anger;
one yang gives rise to desire.
Anger arises from qi;
desire blazes from essence.
Drawn by external objects,
they lose their north and south.
Ignorant of life and death,
all because of love and desire.
Suppress desire, halt thoughts,
curb anger, restrain the heart.
When the heart is at peace, qi harmonizes;
when qi harmonizes, spirit clarifies.
Embrace the origin, guard the One—
transcend the three realms’ emptiness,
unfettered and free,
the body ranked among heaven’s courts.
Not a thread clings,
all ten thousand miles shine clear.

The Perfected One again addressed Chang Peng:
“What I have now spoken is the *Cloudy Satchel of the Numinous Spring’s Cinnabar Edict*, the wondrous scripture of refining and transforming spirit and emptiness. To all who take refuge, it may be transmitted with a vow to heaven. If one encounters the unworthy, it must not be recklessly bestowed.”

"Together we ascend the Five Mounds, jointly perfecting the Eight Grades. Though wisdom illumines the cosmos, those of steadfast faith are few. The Youth of Crane City, named Qi Xu, deeply reveres my Way. He has gathered all my scriptures, universally uniting them as one, and has printed them to exhort others. In delivering the Xu lineage, his merit and realization are no small matter. Should he print and distribute hundreds of thousands of copies, spreading them throughout the world, across the Four Seas and Five Mounds, I shall petition the Heavenly Court on his behalf, elevating his name to the Upper Realms, and bestowing blessings through the Jade Unicorn. Wherever this scripture resides, calamities and obstacles shall not intrude, and the myriad spirits shall guard it in secret. If there are good men and faithful women who, day and night, comprehend, embody, and recite it, they shall ascend to emptiness in broad daylight, attain the sagely Dao, and avoid the netherworld’s judgment. Should any seek to destroy this scripture or extinguish its teachings, the city gods and village spirits shall investigate and report, and the Thunder and Fire Departments shall swiftly mete out retribution. The merit of this scripture is beyond measure—you must believe and receive it, and so invigorate the Xu tradition."

When the Master finished speaking, clouds drifted into the great void, incense wafted beneath jeweled canopies, cranes soared beyond the pavilion, auspicious mists filled the hall, and wondrous fragrance assailed the senses. Chang Peng bowed a hundred times in gratitude, believing, receiving, and vowing to practice. *The Eight-Grade Immortal Scripture* (Scroll Eleven), Preface.

*The Wondrous and Secret Immortal Scripture of Cultivating Immortality, Verifying Authenticity, and Returning the Elixir, Expounded by Patriarch Lü for Admonition and Transformation*

**The Supreme Cavern-Mystery Scripture of the Radiant Flower’s Ascent to the Origin**
*First Grade: Forgetting Emotions*
*Second Grade: Contemplating the Mind*
*Third Grade: Quiescing the Nature*
*Fourth Grade: Nurturing Qi*
*Fifth Grade: Forging the Crucible*
*Sixth Grade: Entering the Void*
*Seventh Grade: Shedding the Fetal Husk*
*Eighth Grade: [Title Omitted]*

**Postscript to the Engraved *Later Eight-Grade Scripture***
**Preface to the *Later Eight-Grade Scripture***

The *Former Eight-Grade Scripture* was expounded in Wuling and long since published in the world. The *Later Eight Grades* were expounded in Linjiang, but because the text contains answers regarding procreation and external elixirs, it strictly warns against reckless transmission to the unworthy, lest slander arise.

When Patriarch Lü manifested at Longsha, his intent was solely to teach people to refine the three medicinal substances—essence, qi, and spirit—to transcend birth and death and verify the fruit of Golden Immortality. Not a single word touched upon external elixirs or chamber arts, nor the heterodox teachings that deceive the people.

Yet if the warning against reckless transmission implies it should not be published, why then expound it? Thus, Xu Taiji and others chose to engrave and circulate it, recognizing that the dual cultivation of jade fluid and golden fluid, the simultaneous completion of nature and life, the departure from the Kan Palace and the Li Palace—these demand earnest study and profound reflection. Following the human path leads away from the Dao; reversing the flow to become an immortal truly grasps the One that perfects the myriad things. The Way inherently embraces both, and its techniques cannot be abandoned on one side.

As it is said: *"The superior person hears the Dao and diligently practices it; the inferior person hears the Dao and laughs loudly."* Let those who cultivate in this world not cling rigidly to words and texts, thereby breeding doubt and slander. Strive to be the diligent superior person; do not tread the path of the scoffing inferior. Only then may one read this *Later Eight-Grade Scripture*.

**Self-Preface to the Engraved *Later Eight-Grade Scripture***
Compiled by Liu Tishu, the Oblivious One of Yiling
Collated by son Liu Yincheng Qinghui and nephew Liu Yuncheng Qingxu
Revised by Huang Chengshu, the One Journey of Shaxian

How profound it is! To establish a vessel for crossing the world is to offer a guide for salvation...

To expound the profound mysteries of the scriptures is truly the Dharma-vessel that ferries one across the bitter sea. Moreover, the Great Dao of the Imperial Ultimate is possessed by all; those who seek it attain it, while those who abandon it lose it. A single truth, subtle and elusive, is set forth in these awakening texts. Those with affinity will treasure it as a supreme jewel, while those of shallow roots will treat it as mere wastepaper. Yet how many can truly comprehend and awaken?

Today’s scholars, donning tall hats and square robes, merely invoke the name of the Dao while flaunting their own abilities, falsely posing as lofty sages. They do not empty their minds, feel no shame in seeking instruction, and fail to seek the guidance of enlightened teachers. Instead, they cling to stale words on paper—how can they ever grasp the truth without the power of wisdom?

Thus, this *Eight-Grade Scripture of the Immortals* is revealed, its phrases plain and its principles unadorned, yet its subtle mechanisms fully disclosed. It clears the obstructions of later learners and points the path for those who cultivate the Real. If one embodies and practices it over time, one will naturally attain the numinous and transcend the mortal cage to ascend into the celestial vastness. Merely reciting it with the mouth, without putting it into practice—what benefit is there?

The *Former Eight Grades* has long been published in the world, while the *Later Eight Grades* remained hidden in Linjiang, secret and untransmitted. Now, disciples Xu Taiji and Wu Tailong, having formed a karmic bond, have donated funds to publish and circulate it throughout the cosmos. This is truly the affinity of future scholars and a great merit for the flourishing of our Dharma-gate!

Alas! In this world, the deluded are many, while the awakened are few. People mistakenly take illusory splendor for ageless joy, unaware of time’s swift passage or the brevity of life. With a single breath cut short, none know where they will go. The numinous essence enters another shell, transforming into all manner of strange beings. Even if one attains the highest rank and enjoys a thousand bushels of emolument, all is but the toil of dust—how can it compare to those who walk the path?

Let us exhort the virtuous: ponder the gravity of life and death, the swiftness of impermanence, the rarity of obtaining a human body, and the difficulty of encountering the true Dao. Arouse the mind of heroic vigor, exert the power of diligent progress, and contemplate this scripture day and night. Ingest this spiritual talisman, uphold these secret mantras, examine body and mind, and wash away the dust of defilement. Complete the human Dao and return to the original source.

Yet merely reading and reciting without penetrating the essence of life and destiny betrays the toil of my brush—what benefit is there?

Written on the fifteenth day of late spring in the year *yimao* of the Kangxi reign, at Yunji Pavilion.

*The Wondrous Scripture of the Immortals on Cultivating Immortality, Verifying the Real, and Returning to the Elixir, Expounded for Warning and Transformation by Patriarch Lü, the Faithful and Protective*
**First Grade: The Primordial Flower of the Cavern Mystery, Ascending to the Origin**

At that time, the Most High Lord of the Dao was in the Great Brahma Heaven, upon the nine-tiered jeweled palace, seated upon the cloud-dragon throne. Fragrant vapors of jade incense curled around him as the true immortals of the Three Realms, the sages of the Yang Valley and Water Palace, and all the holy assemblies gathered to hear the Great Dao expounded.

Then, the Faithful and Protective True Lord, together with the wondrous Daoist perfected ones, raised their tablets and respectfully addressed the Lord: *"In the beginning, when the Primordial Chaos opened the heavens, it was born from the Great Void, the Great Ultimate, and the Great Transformation. From the profound obscurity, forms took shape. The light and pure floated upward, called the 'Heaven of Qian'; the heavy and turbid settled below, and the 'Earth of Kun' bore the weight of the myriad things. The two qi intermingled, and the human Dao was born. Once humanity came into being, the Three Powers took their places, and all transformations and nurturing depended upon the spirit. The spirit can transform, stirring like thunder. The sun and moon illuminate, the constellations and stars revolve, mountains and forests, grasses and trees, birds and beasts, flying and hidden creatures—all conditioned existence relies upon the spirit. The east shines to generate wood, the west illuminates to generate metal, the south moves with the Red Bird, the north nurtures the embryo of *ren*, and the center, *wu* and *ji*, also circulates in turn."*

The Lord of the Dao said: *"Excellent!"*

"Excellent! For what reason do you speak of these matters?"

Then the Crimson Elder of the South, together with the Perfected Lord of Sincere Protection, replied: "The supreme Dao is rarely encountered, and its profound words are seldom heard. In the great transformation of human life, if one fails to cultivate the Five Relationships, one drifts in the delusions of life and death, losing one’s original true nature. This is why one decays and falls into the dark netherworld."

The Lord of the Dao said: "Your compassion moves me to reveal these subtle teachings. You expound upon virtue and power, awakening understanding of what lies ahead. What you have spoken is indeed the sacred canon. The spirit can ascend and descend, wondrously harmonizing yin and yang, dispelling and gathering the central valley, effecting transformations in perfect measure.

At the central position, clouds and frost congeal. The Seven Mansions of the Azure Dragon rise from Fusang, called 'Jia Wood.' Together they unite with the west, where the 'White Tiger' takes its place. The 'Vermilion Bird' soars; the north is guarded by the 'Dark Warrior'; and 'Wu and Ji' accompany one another. The Five Phases intermingle, moved by a single impulse. Water is yin, fire is yang; the Hall of Light embodies true virtue, penetrating and linking the Three Directions—this is called the 'King of Medicines.'

Of late, the people below have indulged in greed and desire without restraint, losing their primordial origin. Their blood and qi are exhausted, sinews and bones wither, complexion fades and withers—all because they have lost their spirit. If one wishes to nourish the spirit, one must first nourish qi. If one wishes to nourish qi, one must forget speech. If one can forget speech, it is better still to cut off thoughts. Once thoughts are cut off, all depends upon the heart.

The heart is the function of the Dao, governing the entire body—nothing is greater than this. In refining the heart’s function, sight and hearing become unaware, joy and anger do not arise, emotions are forgotten, thoughts are severed, and body and mind are awakened. Seeing, one perceives no self; hearing, one perceives no self. Detached from all realms, one enters the wondrous gate.

The spirit has its goings and comings, its summonings and arrangements. This great Dao is entrusted to those of virtue."

Only you, O Faithful Protector, have accumulated merit upon merit, manifesting transformations across the dragon-swept sands to deliver all beings. In this world, those of sincere cultivation and learning are commanded to widely transmit your teachings, rescuing the drowned and lost, ensuring the great Dao shines brightly everywhere.

Thereupon, the Perfected Lord reverently heeded the Dharma-sound, and together with all the perfected ones, bowed in gratitude and withdrew.

**Chapter Two: The Rank of Forgetting Emotions**

The Faithful Protector Perfected Lord, receiving the decree of the Supreme Dao Lord, descended in the phoenix carriage with the assembled immortals, manifesting presence at the Moonlit Waters Hermitage by the river. Addressing the great assembly, he said:

"In this world, who among those who study and inquire can truly believe and accept? Things entangle the emotions, emotions delude the will, the heart cannot remain clear, the spirit cannot be preserved—adrift in the cycles of life and death, the nature and destiny tossed and lost, unable to turn inward, thorns filling the path.

Only when one can stabilize and cease does one become clear and still. If emotions abide nowhere, how can things move them? Observe the night’s dreams: like your daily activities, all sights and sounds are but illusory scenes. When the two evils do not invade, the earth congeals true numen; when true numen does not crumble, the will encircles like a fortress.

As the *Yi* says: *'Stopping at the back, one does not encounter the self; walking in the courtyard, one does not see others.'* This is inner not seeing outer, outer not seeing inner—when both inner and outer are forgotten, empty numen naturally appears. Forget things, forget emotions, and the supreme Dao may be illuminated.

When the will stirs without, emotions tug within; the will scatters, the spirit disorders, and through emotions, ruin and collapse follow. The heavens’ movement never ceases—how can emotions abide? Through autumn’s passage, killing comes; through spring’s passage, life arises. From the qi’s resonance, the myriad transformations are completed.

I once imparted the mechanism of refining the spirit. The Lad of Guangling, through sincerity, received it—eight chapters expounded to deliver the world’s delusions, yet in Yangzhou, pride and meagerness prevail. People act recklessly, extinguishing the teachings of sages and worthies, serving a world of deceit and falsehood. Those who initiate inquiry and reverence are outwardly criticized as wrong, merely inviting slander and, in turn, stirring dust-like doubts. To speak is inadvisable; more than a year has passed. Seeing your repeated pleas, where life and destiny are at stake, I expound this numinous text—you must awaken and uphold it. Transmit it through heart’s realization, not through thought’s pursuit.

Thought yields wisdom, but clinging to sounds and weighing thoughts breeds delusion and stupidity; awakening brings awareness. The Dao does not speak emptily—embrace the One and forget emotions. Inwardly observe and retrace your steps; in stillness, return to the Great Void. From the Void, return to the Great Ultimate—here lies the mechanism of transformation. Once wisdom and awareness are attained, responding to things, one is not deluded.

As the scriptures have said: *'The Dao’s utterance from the mouth is bland, without flavor. It pivots yin and yang—only return and observe!'* When emotions are forgotten and the will is stilled, the stilled will turns the heart to ashes; the ashen heart turns things to ashes; ashen things resemble stupidity—yet in this stupidity, the spirit lives, and where the spirit lives, the Dao resides.

In daily use, what arises is the mechanism. If the mechanism is not externally defiled, the nature stabilizes and emotions return. The world does not believe and accept, thus it matches fragmented terms: dragon and tiger, metal and wood, water and fire, snake and tortoise, yellow sprout and white snow, dark maiden and infant—all boil down to two words. Inverting right and wrong, forgetting what can be forgotten, the wondrous function transforms them. Do not let them become entangled—this is the mechanism of yin and yang."

The *Book of Documents* states: *"Heaven ordains its principles, correcting what is not of the heart."* When the heart refrains from wrongdoing, things naturally forget their passions. The *Rites* say: *"As thought arises, the mechanism’s work begins."* The Primordial Sovereign of Grand Unity commands the myriad spirits with awe; the general’s stern orders—who dares disobey? In defending cities or waging field battles, the orthodox and the extraordinary follow order. Like fire boiling the sea and sun, revolving Mount Kunlun, coalescing into a precious pearl, transformations swirl in mist—when water clears, the moon appears; tides respond as qi arises. To forget passion is to harvest; the wise attain understanding on their own.

The Most High said: *"The Dao assists the king, not by force of arms."* Arms are passion; when passion stirs, things expand—how can one rely on them? Reliance lodges passion; passion pursues things, and passion enslaves the spirit. If kings and lords can hold fast, the myriad things transform themselves. When transformation gives rise to desire, suppress it with nameless simplicity. If your passion does not arise, solitary yang returns; if your passion lingers, yang severs its continuity. Respond to things by forgetting passion, and the spirit opens of itself. Internally, the transforming mechanism operates, and celestial truth finds ease.

The world is lost in blindness, chattering ceaselessly. Spirit scatters among things; passion is ensnared by form. Things surge chaotically, like ten thousand mountains and a thousand valleys. The true path is lost, and one seeks detours and byways—the farther one strays from home, the deeper passion drowns and life is cast away.

The inner path of cultivation: passion does not touch things. Guard the feminine and retain the masculine; return from black to white. To forget yet not forget—this *not-forgetting* is the mechanism! What is forgotten is the thing; the mechanism quickens, and the aperture becomes numinous. When things are forgotten, life is restored. Grass and trees meet autumn: their colors fade, their blossoms fall, and yang spreads its moisture. The hexagram of the eleventh month corresponds to *Return*. In employing things’ mechanism, observe their apertures—steal their qi and return to your own wondrousness. To be used by things is the omen of ruin!

Observe the flourishing of things, examine their decay. Turn back and seek within—there lies the Dao.

The Perfected Lord further instructed: *"You who seek—how does cinnabar arise in reversal? How do humans arise in compliance? Though you study the Dao, you know the source’s correctness but not that the ten thousand streams all return to the source! To wish for human relations is to preserve the ancestral sacrifices. The patriarchs did not speak of this, for it concerns the path of return and reversal. Since compliance gives rise to humans, one is inevitably enmeshed in worldly affairs. When forms and colors fill the eyes, passion abides in things. Reversal and compliance scatter the spirit, and life is spent in vain. You earnestly seek procreation—how can you not have heard of the beginning in husband and wife, the principle of multiplication? Guard your primordial essence, forget the passions of things. Regulate that channel, master that flourishing. Orthodox and extraordinary follow order—refine qi and nurture spirit. When spirit moves, qi coalesces; above and below unite in harmony. Without supreme stability, commands are not obeyed. Blood must not lose its defense; essence must not lose its restraint. If I am full and the other empty, yin and yang both continue. Tides must keep to their signals; yang must adhere to its return. The fire that boils the sea enables birth and nurture. Ride the lead’s splendor, match the mercury’s quality—mercury and lead unite, the two breaths conform. Yin can retain yang; yang also clings to yin. The Dao of yin and yang begins with metal and water in harmony. What need is there for force? What labor of the heart? Silently conform to it, and skill lies in celestial completion.

Transfer the father’s spirit, seize the mother’s breath. When spirit and breath receive the tally, essence and blood govern themselves. Reverse this to refine within—observe and gather the essence, return it to your primordial breath, and you may be called an immortal. Spirit is sacred fire; fire is the medicine. When the medicine’s sprout arises, it resembles a bellows. You must refine with care: golden light blazes, coalescing into a precious pearl—yin and yang do not err.

Today’s blind followers see gold as gravel—how can one speak to them? You must stabilize and awaken on your own."*

At times during the assembly, disciples bow together in supplication: "By your grace, Master, awaken us—all transformations flow as one. The world transmits both inner and outer teachings, advocating their dual cultivation. When the inner elixir is refined, the outer also reaches completion. We beseech you, Master, to broadly bestow the profound mysteries within."

The Perfected Lord replied: "Through spiritual transformation and shedding the mortal coil, the inner elixir may be cultivated. Though the outer elixir may be compounded, how can it be attained without virtue? Broadly accumulate merit and conduct, universally aiding the flow of beings. Our Dao seeks reduction—when reduction reaches its limit, the elixir is refined.

In ancient times, the Celestial Master of Han bore witness by leveling grain prices; later, the Immortal Ge, refining and aiding the netherworld, distributed talismans and dispensed medicine, universally aiding the world, sustaining the perilous and upholding the fallen, relieving the distressed and bestowing kindness. Patriarch Xu of Jingyang likewise devoted himself to prior merit. When merit is complete and conduct fulfilled, celestial spirits guard and protect, the elixir remains unassailed by demonic forces, and after ninety-nine refinements, one ascends in flight upon ingestion.

Ancient elixir wells and sites bear witness. Since you have inquired, how could I not speak? I shall continue this Dao within the chapters.

The Dao of the outer elixir, though involving action, truly distinguishes essence and function. Through function, essence is revealed; celestial nature is mutually bound. Refine lead to obtain lead, pan for gold in water. Initially one family, later divided into two natures—clad in coarse robes yet holding jade, the sun rises from the sea’s depths.

When the elixir first coalesces, the moon emerges at geng. Though likened to the moon, it is the true form of lead. The black soul does not wane; in broad daylight, gold is formed. Shedding the mortal to become immortal follows a clear path. Following the hexagrams and lines, distinctions are made between leaks and responses. Yin returns, yang revives, and the root of qi is divided. Yang refines and disperses; yin refines and congeals.

When the first yang arises, do not allow it to scatter and deplete. Plant yin to cultivate yang, and yang will arise of itself—this is called ‘true lead.’ Though your essence may be as radiant as Xi Shi, it truly nourishes the eastern household. Recognize the yellow sprout, and both inner and outer may be refined.

Now appended to the various chapters, ponder and resolve it yourselves."

**Chapter Three: Observing the Mind**

The Perfected Lord said: "Vast and undifferentiated, the primordial chaos is the supreme and most numinous. It nurtures heaven and earth, transforming the po and refining the hun. The heart is the abode of spirit, harmonizing yin and yang, governing all wonders, and responding to transformations without fixed form.

The Most High has said: *'The Dao is attained through the heart; the heart is illuminated through the Dao.'* Observe the Dao with the heart, observe the heart with the Dao. Hold the heart like a valley—responsive yet silent, embracing the Great Ultimate and circulating the Five Phases.

Mencius said: *'Benevolence is the human heart.'* One who embodies benevolence is invincible and thus transforms things. When things are transformed by it, the world returns to benevolence. Stabilize the heart to lodge the spirit; the spirit is preserved thereby. When the heart is settled, the spirit shines; when the spirit shines, things become obscure.

Still and unmoving—this is the essence of my heart. Responsive and immediately penetrating—this is the function of my heart. Extending knowledge to investigate things—this is the numinosity of my heart. Refining qi to transform spirit—first, one must cultivate the heart. Cultivating the heart means reducing desires; this is the root of the Dao. When the heart is tranquil and empty, the spirit responds naturally. The spirit’s response has no fixed abode; it responds to things and then returns, uniting with heavenly nature. Respond without attachment, lest one fall into existence. Those who speak of 'no-mind' fear trailing dust. When the heart is free of dust, dust does not arise.

The elixir is sought within the heart—how can one say there is no heart? If 'no-mind' is taken as the essence of the Dao, one may build inwardly but remain deluded by blank emptiness. The foundation of guarding the Dao is to empty the heart! When the heart is empty, things are empty; when things are empty, the heart is numinous.

Uphold the precepts, concentration, and wisdom to clarify the heart. Eat plainly and wear simple clothes to sever the yin of things. Know when to stop in fame and profit to restore harmony. Emotions give rise to things, and the heart alters them. Alteration becomes delusion, which clings to things and dust, entangling one morning and evening—ten thousand demons invade! The heart and spirit become inverted, disrupting one’s heavenly truth.

All manner of thoughts arising are called 'deluded mind.' When the heart is active, the spirit dies—hence the saying. If one speaks of 'deadening the heart,' how can the spirit be moved? The form will not follow transformation, becoming like a wooden puppet!

The heart is like a luminous pearl, round and radiant. Placed in a dish, it rolls freely without attachment. Still and free from desire, the spirit arises naturally. Guard the spirit without forgetfulness, embrace the origin to refine the form. When form and spirit are refined, the numinous returns to the Great Void.

Refining the heart is called 'yang'; clinging to things is called 'yin.' As the saying goes: *'If the slightest yin is not exhausted, one cannot become an immortal!'* You must awaken to this.

The heart is the mechanism of transformation, like the pivot of the Northern Dipper. Unstained by a single thing, one awakens to the mechanism. The body is small, but the heart is vast, equal to heaven and earth. Expand and fill it, and it can encompass heaven and earth. Break the barrel hoop, and you will perceive true emptiness.

Like a mirror reflecting things, when things depart, it becomes still. The original substance is inherently luminous, but it is deluded by things and cannot return to its source. The illness of the habituated heart: *'The human heart is perilous; the heart of the Dao is subtle.'* If the subtle governs the perilous, how can it not be dangerous?

Master Fan said: *'The subtlety of the single heart is assailed by a multitude of desires. How few are those who preserve it!'* The noble person preserves sincerity, overcoming thoughts with reverence. When the heavenly ruler is at peace, the hundred parts of the body follow its commands.

Drawing from ancient and modern discussions to align with the elixir classics: though a thousand rivers return to the source, the Dao does not differ in its discourse! The Dao is one, though its teachings vary; all ultimately return to goodness. A single room with a thousand lamps—nurturing qi and refining form—all lies within the heart!

When the heart is vast, the body is at ease—this is the sign of drawing the Dao. When the heart is still, the spirit is whole; when the spirit congeals, the nature appears. Water still, without waves, the moon’s reflection is undisturbed. When the heart stirs like water, it drowns in the current and becomes turbid. When the wind is calm and the waves are still, one’s heavenly nature remains unaltered. Stillness is like water, returning to the source and thus clear.

Conceal the spirit and nurture wisdom, master qi and store the numinous. Empty the heart to nourish the spirit, firmly grasp the root of the numinous. Abandon it, and it perishes; hold it, and it endures. The forms of heaven and earth, the numinosity of yin and yang—wondrously transforming the myriad things—value not giving rise to emotions!

If one can grasp heaven, what Dao would not be clear? It is only because of delusion by things that one becomes entangled. Refine the nature with the heart, preserve life with qi. Transforming the hun is called 'nature'; transforming the po is called 'life.' When emotions arise, return to nature; when nature arises, return to life. The mechanism of refining lead will be discussed in later chapters.

Sweet dew sprinkles the heart; when emptiness is extreme, it is perceived! Still the essence, qi, and spirit, and they will not be disordered. Forget things, self, and others to prevent gradual corruption. Be only precise and unified, holding fast to the center. Cultivate this, and your heart will naturally become numinous.

What does heaven say? Confucius said: *'Those who know me do so through the Spring and Autumn Annals; those who condemn me do so through the Spring and Autumn Annals.'* Attain the Dao and forget words—why should I linger here?

Illustrating the principles of yin and yang, embodying the inner and outer elixirs, borrowing the numinosity of the two qi—this is truly the gateway of the hun and po. When others invest with emotion, blood must flourish and qi overflow. When I unite with sincerity, essence must be firm and spirit resolute.

If essence controls qi, yang restrains one yin and gives birth to a girl—this is the Li trigram. If qi controls essence, yin embraces one yang and forms a boy—this is the Kan trigram. Spirit and qi belong to yang; without the two yin of essence and blood, they cannot abide. Essence and blood belong to yin; without the two yang of qi and spirit, they cannot be produced.

If the emotions and natures of man and woman do not align, those who give birth are few! Thus, essence arises from emotion, and blood flourishes through qi. When essence and blood congeal, they form the shape of an infant, completing the work of creation. The body relies on yin and yang, coagulating into an egg and transforming through the numinous work of the spirit.

If one can secure essence, nurture qi, and master the spirit, what worry is there of not giving life? The way of ceaseless generation begins with stilling the heart! Master the spirit without scattering it, and the union will be numinous. Follow this practice, and descendants may continue the lineage. Cherish the treasure of life and do not trifle with it!

The outer elixir’s watery lead contains the five colors. Before gold and water separate, it responds to the stillness of my heart."

When the numinous entity is born, the moon appears as a crescent, responding to the stirring of my heart. The movement of golden mercury corresponds to the hun-soul; the stillness of watery lead conceals the po-soul. Within lead, mercury is hidden—thus the po-soul conceals the hun-soul; when mercury emerges from lead, the hun-soul grasps the po-soul. The child steals the mother’s qi, gradually filling its form; the mother transmits qi to the child, gradually withering away. Through this cyclical theft and transmission, yin and yang mutually adhere. Heaven and earth sustain one another, seizing this creative power—termed "prior to heaven," unlike anything in the mundane world.

Sulfur, arsenic, saltpeter, cinnabar, and mercury—these mineral substances belong to the "posterior to heaven" realm. How can they be mistaken for the "prior to heaven"? Refining yin with yin, ten thousand elixirs will not succeed! The "prior to heaven" can transform the "posterior to heaven" into treasured use, but the "posterior to heaven" cannot transform the "prior to heaven" into the elixir’s efficacy. Just as the "prior to heaven" primordial qi, being non-action, can refine the "posterior to heaven" mortal body into sagehood, yet the "posterior to heaven" mortal body, bound by desire, cannot refine the "prior to heaven" primordial qi into truth.

Thus, the lead and mercury within the crucible are the very lead and mercury within the body. I possess a divine talisman to refine the medicine and transmit it to you. Inscribed in vermilion beforehand, each day you must reverently—whether at the hours of *yin* or *mao*—decoct the herbal medicine, then burn one talisman and ingest it. This will nurture the heart, dispel evil, refine qi, and preserve emptiness. The numinous work is unparalleled in the world; with prolonged practice, its efficacy will naturally manifest. Do not transmit this to the unworthy—guard it with care and reverence.

**Chapter Four: Cultivating the Stillness of Nature**
The Perfected Lord said: "The practice of stilling the nature is the essential means to preserve life. It revolves through emptiness and inverts life and death. Nature is bound to the heart; life is bound to the body. Lead-dragon and mercury-tiger—drive them down, raise the talisman. Forget emotions to nurture nature; empty the heart to nurture spirit.

The Most High said: *'Observe this body carefully—it comes from emptiness.'* Emptiness is nature. Nature is the true essence of the boundless and the numinous spirit of the great void. From the moment it receives form, it is called *nature*; from the Dao it receives life, thus it is called *life*. Zisi said: *'What is mandated by heaven is called nature; following nature is called the Dao.'* Therefore, one who can fully realize nature stands as an equal with heaven and earth! How can nature, life, and the Dao be three? The Dao is nature and life; nature and life are the Dao.

The mechanism of gathering and refining: nature resides at the edge of heaven; life lies at the bottom of the sea. The imagery of heaven and sea is but a metaphor! Essence and spirit are the foundation of nature and life. Thus, nature cannot stand without life, and life cannot exist without nature. When the heart is empty, nature is luminous; when life is secure, essence is born. Preserve sincerity and stabilize intention to fortify this root; cleanse thoughts and purify the heart to bathe this body.

The method of nurturing nature and the metaphor for preserving life: when nature returns to emptiness and stillness, the heart enters non-action, essence naturally transforms into qi, qi naturally transforms into spirit, and spirit naturally transforms into emptiness. People of this world have their nature enslaved by the heart, and their heart ensnared by things. Thus, when the illuminating heart remains still, it responds to ten thousand changes. In application, it moves; in its fundamental state, it remains still. The deluded heart is constantly in motion, giving rise to ten thousand thoughts; though its application may be still, its fundamental state is ever in motion.

Illumination returning becomes the Dao; delusion returning becomes things. When the heart departs from things, nature departs from dust. Thus, extinguishing the deluded heart, the celestial nature becomes true; without diminishing the illuminating heart, the celestial nature becomes pure. Life is bound to qi; nature is bound to spirit. Conceal spirit within the heart; gather qi within the body. When the heart is clear and thoughts scatter, one can know life; when thoughts cease and emotions are forgotten, one can fully realize nature. Emptiness enables the use of things; stillness enables the response to affairs.

Human nature is fundamentally good—so spoke Master Meng. When nature governs emotions, nature is settled and emotions are true. Illuminating the original state, one returns to life and reverts to the root. Directly realizing nature, one naturally realizes life. Those of shallow roots and meager capacity first cultivate life, then nature. Nature is the master of the body; the body is but a guest. The guest body nurtures this nature, yielding to it as master. When body and heart are unmoving, the tiger is subdued and the dragon descends. When emotions enter nature, this is called the homeland of the elixir.

Thus, the metaphor for refining nature is like tuning a zither’s strings: if too tight, the strings break; if too loose, there is no sound. To play the zither well, tension must be just right! Emotions arise from the heart; the heart arises from nature. The waves of emotion flow from the current of nature; nature is Kunlun. The numinous awareness of nature pervades all phenomena. To preserve it fully, see as if not seeing, hear as if not hearing, serene and without trace, ever still and ever clear. Unchanged by the passage of time, uncompeting with things, gathering and dispersing—all follow stillness! When rolled up and concealed, the numinous work unites with emptiness.

To know nature, first perceive its manifestations. In responding to a hundred matters, how can nature be obstructed? When settled and not deluded, this is called *yuan-shen* (original spirit)—the nature of the "prior to heaven." What is called *yu-shen* (desiring spirit) is the nature of the "posterior to heaven." The nature of the "prior to heaven" is the root of numinous light; the nature of the "posterior to heaven" is the form of material disposition. If the dispositional nature is absent, the original nature naturally appears. Abiding in the center and attaining harmony, desire cannot sway it; when desire cannot sway it, qi embraces the primordial. Primordial qi follows, spirit is clear, and qi is continuous.

Nature has no direction; life has no fixed position. Still the spirit and maneuver the strategy—these two will naturally meet. The virtue of the highest is non-action; it does not seek through observation. Yin and yang inwardly resonate, and one roams with heaven and earth. Thus, Mencius said: *'He who fully realizes his heart knows his nature; knowing his nature, he knows heaven.'* Nature arises from principle; life is preserved through nature. When nature is still and emotions are at ease, the heart of heaven is again seen.

Therefore, to investigate principle, fully realize nature, and reach life is like the timely rain that nurtures all things. Yao and Shun embodied nature, governing with hanging robes—governing through non-action, and the world submitted. All under heaven were settled, simply by following nature! For those who study and practice: if you can master the celestial nature, return to non-action, and unite with true emptiness, when emptiness reaches its extreme and stillness is profound, the spirit will manifest subtle workings.

The Dao encompasses heaven and earth—nothing escapes nature! Nature, oh nature! Only in stability and stillness. Without seeking encounters, without inner or outer—you must preserve it as the stem of your life."

The Qian Dao provides the origin, thus it can bestow life; the Kun Dao nurtures life, thus it can sustain it. Though it is said that essence and blood converge, in truth, they transform from emptiness into spirit. A woman must regulate her cycles so that blood flourishes; a man must consolidate his qi so that essence congeals—without a settled nature, who would not falter and collapse?

The female nature tends toward seclusion, her qi harmonious and spirit flowing, delighting in emotion; the male nature tends toward aggression, his qi restrained and spirit gathered, fortifying his heart. When tiger and dragon do not rampage, when ape and horse do not bolt—fearing stumbles and falls—all hinges on forgetting form!

Qi and timing follow their seasons, divisions adhere to their measures. The Yellow Dame guides the way, returning naturally to the nest. The tiger’s roar and dragon’s flute, the two qi unite in harmony; the turning of the celestial sphere reveals at once the workings of heaven!

Do not allow it to float, for floating scatters qi; do not allow it to sink, for sinking causes qi to fall. Follow nature in this, and yin and yang will arrive of themselves. Refine the spirit and secure essence—do not indulge in emotion. Curb desire to preserve the foundation, and practice will yield results!

Do not fear yang’s decline, but fear the division of emotion. When emotion scatters, spirit disperses, and essence follows in collapse. Thus, to preserve essence, one must first cultivate spirit. When spirit is firmly settled for long, essence too becomes steadfast and numinous.

The worldly do not understand, resorting to medicines for aid. If medicine is not inherently warming, how can yang attach? Yet they fail to see that when hot medicines enter the belly, qi scatters with the heat, and essence flees with the heat—how can this be the true Way? Such folly risks life itself. Those who study and practice must take heed and guard against it.

Within lead lies gold, within emptiness lies qi. Without knowing the mechanism of gathering, the gold scatters and is difficult to produce! Lead envelops metal and water, chaotic and unclear. When water is still, metal is born; when lead dissolves, mercury grows.

Those who settle their nature daily refine the gold so that water is exhausted. If not observed in time, though water may be exhausted, the gold will dissipate with it. Within lead, the solitary yang is the dragon, belonging to the true fire of Kan; within mercury, the solitary yin is the tiger, belonging to the true water of Li.

Yin presses, yang ascends—like the tiger descending as the dragon leaps forth, thus the moon emerges from the Geng direction. The dragon embraces the earthly net as the sun reaches the Wu position; the tiger emerges from the heavenly snare.

Deluded practitioners of the world refine lead into ash, calling it "withered lead," and use it to dry mercury. Little do they know that the golden qi within lead has already scattered—it is but dust and clamor! How then can it subdue common mercury and transform it into supreme treasure?

The song says:
*If you wish mercury to die,*
*First you must kill mercury.*
*If mercury does not die,*
*How can mercury be killed?*

What does this mean? The "mercury you wish to die" is the common mercury of the posterior heaven; the "mercury you must first kill" is the gold within the primordial lead. Lead is water, hence it is called "immortal mercury." After this immortal mercury forms the embryo, sheds its leaden body, and completes the nine transformations, its essence gathers and congeals—neither flying nor fleeing, like something dead when taken from the furnace. Common mercury, upon seeing it, dies at once.

Yet if the immortal mercury’s yin tally has not receded and its dross remains impure, there is still the danger of dissolution, flight, and loss—how then can it kill the common mercury of the posterior heaven? The worldly, ignorant of this, act recklessly and blindly, bringing ruin upon their households. How could they fathom the wondrous transformations of external alchemy!

**Cultivating Qi, Chapter Five**

The Perfected Lord said: "The Supreme has declared: *'Concentrate qi to attain suppleness, and you may become like an infant.'* The primordial qi unfolds the body, activated by spirit as its mechanism. Spirit is fire, and fire is the heart. If one pursues emotions and desires, fire follows qi in dispersion, falling into guest qi, where form is stirred and obscured. Wandering through many realms, one loses the original source, unable to master it, drowning in conditioned states.

If the scholar can turn inward, observing and stilling the self, abiding in unbroken continuity, guarding the breath of the embryo—grasping the movement of Heaven, one may circulate the myriad things. To 'cultivate qi,' as Mencius said, is the vast and unyielding *hao ran*. Nurture it directly without harm, and it fills the space between Heaven and Earth. This qi—how could it be dual? Following its path without cease, it transforms naturally. Thus, do not forget the heart, nor force its growth. Embody this refinement, and qi is attained and cultivated.

The body does not generate itself; that which generates the body is qi. Qi does not generate itself; that which generates qi is the Dao. The *Book of Changes* says: *'Not hastening, yet swift; not moving, yet arriving.'* The alchemical texts speak of the 'Three Passes'—one may know them, but how can one rely upon them?

Now, those who blindly cultivate, secluding themselves to refine qi, find their qi untransformed, and poisonous swellings follow. Observe Heaven: its movement never ceases. Spring generates, autumn gathers—this is the resonance of qi. To disregard Heaven’s movement and recklessly guess at human intention, sitting in meditation to gather spirit, grasping essence and ingesting qi—unaware that within stillness, the ten thousand dusts disturb and entangle. Closing the eyes to force tranquility, one drifts into delusion and dissolution. At the first sight of sensory forms, habitual thoughts arise again. Cultivating qi in this manner, hair gradually turns silver, and the complexion fades to yellow and withers.

Those who study the Dao must first preserve the body. In walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, let qi constantly guide spirit. When spirit departs, draw it back to secure the primordial root, returning to the heart’s aperture, circulating qi to govern essence. The *Scripture of Embryonic Breathing* says: *'The embryo is born from concealed qi; qi coalesces from the embryo's existence.'* Qi entering the body is called life; spirit departing from form is called death. Where spirit moves, qi moves; where spirit abides, qi abides. One who can master this finds spirit and qi naturally abiding.

To generate without possessing, to act without relying—within non-abiding, the true mechanism appears! With spirit guiding qi, only in stillness and emptiness, like a silkworm spinning its cocoon, qi is concealed within. Over time, it transforms into a moth. If one can conceal spirit, why would one not ascend?

When body and mind cling to illusion, one merely pays lip service. The true heart unmoved, true qi naturally stabilizes; intention not following conditions, spirit becomes numinous; the body not stirred by sensory forms, essence is preserved. Essence not generating sensory forms is preservation; qi not scattering to external things is stabilization; spirit not chasing conditions is numinosity. Qi not dispersing and transforming preserves form; if qi scatters and perishes, form immediately collapses. A lump of pus and blood—how can it have roots? With time, it putrefies, sinking into decay and dissolution.

Thus, qi is the master of form, bringing forth being from non-being. Returning to the origin, reverting to the primordial—embryonic breathing is the guard. Firmly abide in emptiness and non-being to nurture spirit and qi, returning the essence’s radiance, gathering its vital fluids. Following qi’s transformation, descending and ascending in turn. Heaven descends with yin; Earth ascends with yang. With dragon restraining tiger, tiger submits to dragon’s descent. Heaven’s heart and Earth’s kidneys—two qi mutually guiding. Dragon’s fire and tiger’s metal—two substances not running wild. In unbroken warmth and nurturance, without position yet with direction.

Qi harmonized, spirit harmonized; spirit harmonized, qi concealed. Concealed yet not indulged, it transforms into jade nectar, further transmuting into qi. Qi reaches the Three Halls—kidneys, heart, and the Hundred Meetings’ region. Qi descends, qi ascends—attaching to this as orientation. Do not seek with intention, for seeking inflames like fire; do not scatter with intention, for scattering dissolves like water.

Profound is the mechanism of the Dao—do not seek it through form! Seeking through form is not the path of the Dao. How subtle! How subtle! Silently recognize it; attain it through the Dao, not by clinging with the heart. Master Guan Yin said: *'Reverse the traces to unite with the Dao.'* The Sage Confucius said: *'Master the self to return to the body.'* Practicing thus, one understands the cultivation of qi.

Emotions returning to nature is reversal; husband singing and wife harmonizing is compliance. The flute has no sound until qi moves it; the embryo has no substance until qi coalesces it. In this human Dao, the union of two qi—do not separate from harmony, nor cling to intention. The Dao of the Elixir and the human Dao are but reversal and return.

To not lose the two qi, first regulate them. Qi continuous and unbroken, settled breath as control. First yin must yield, then yang arrives. Only when desire is full may one apply governance, subduing body and mind, not allowing reckless waste. Above, know Heaven’s timing; below, observe Earth’s principles. To align with Heaven’s mechanism, first choose the land’s advantage.

The body upright, the complexion radiant; the temperament gentle, the heart’s realm peaceful. With this foundation established, the foundation’s waters are reliable. Like excessive yang, fields and crops wither. A single morning’s rain is insufficient to restore them. If the soil is moist, crops flourish; if the soil is parched, crops wither. Morning and evening tilling cultivates the soil; abandoning it leads to desolation and ruin.

The transmitted methods speak of the *Renzi Pill*, the mechanism of Qian and Kun, the Dao of husband and wife. One who practices this may continue their descendants. But one must cultivate qi to return to the primordial. If qi is not cultivated, essence dissipates in chaos. Cherish spirit to guide qi, nurturing essence. Essence not expended externally, firmly guarded within. Guarding within without loss—this is the root of Heaven’s mandate.

Reversal leads to sagehood; compliance generates humanity. The *Book of Changes* says: *'The noble person cultivates it and finds fortune; the petty person defies it and meets misfortune.'* The body is formed by qi; qi nurtures the body. Yang is not born without yin; yin is not transformed without yang."

The mercury-dragon pertains to function, easily taking flight and becoming luminous; the lead-tiger pertains to form, readily concealing itself in obscurity. The dragon-mercury follows fire and scatters in transformation, relying on the tiger-lead to gather it with water; the lead-tiger hides in obscurity and lies concealed, depending on the mercury-fire to refine and extract it. This is what is meant by *"extracting lead and adding mercury"*—how could lead be extracted? Through prolonged refinement, it naturally returns. As yang endures and yin transforms into qi, lead does not wait to be extracted but becomes floating dust. What is called *"mercury can desiccate lead"* does not mean refining lead until it withers and mercury dies—rather, without extracting lead, lead extracts itself. As for *"adding mercury,"* from where is mercury added? Through prolonged refinement, it naturally reverts to form. As yin assists over time, yang receives it as substance, and mercury does not wait to be added but establishes its own foundation. This is what is meant by *"the mother can nourish the child"*—lead withers and mercury dries. Thus, without adding mercury, mercury adds itself. External alchemy is nothing more than the coalescence of these two qi in harmonious union. *Sixth Grade of Refined Lead.*

The True Lord said: "Lead is the foundation of life, governing within the body. When one’s nature is not purely authentic, it relies on this to perform the work. One must examine the qi and essence, gathering at the root’s sprouting. The elixir is born in the Northern Sea, corresponding to *Water Thunder Layer*; the medicinal seed is planted in the Southern Palace, matching *Mountain Water Mong*. The two qi interact and respond, and the myriad transformations arise therefrom. The true person lurks in the abyss, and only when companions are found do they follow. Kidney qi transmits to the liver, liver qi transmits to the heart, heart qi transforms into fluid, fluid gathers the essence of metal, the golden toad spits its radiance, the red serpent coils around it, the white tiger pursues things, the green dragon governs them. Lead essence has no fixed position, chasing emotions to find its corner; spirit knows no birth or extinction, yet perishes with things.

The heart is called the dwelling of spirit, the kidneys the abode of essence; the Yellow Court is the qi cavern, the names of the crucible and furnace. Threads and channels connect, steadfastly existing. Within the formed, seek the formless; through life, perceive nature, for nature is the cause of life. Within the formless, seek the formed; through nature, perceive life, hence it is called *empty the heart*. Nature is originally heaven-endowed, naturally completing itself; life is rooted in the numinous form, forging lead within the sea. Gather mercury in the heavens, moving the essence of lead; return to the midst of mercury, where essence arises from stillness and responds to movement.

Heart fluid moves fire, descending to commune with the kidney palace; kidney fire’s tranquil splendor, a single yang steams upward. Riding the qi’s ascent, following its spiraling path, the hundred bones are threaded through, spirit finds its refuge, essence gains its numinosity. As heaven sends down yin, at summer’s solstice it first stirs; from autumn to winter, yin descends to its extreme, then yang returns within the earth. Yang, long concealed, when qi fills to overflowing, bursts forth in motion, and the myriad things follow in birth. Heaven’s movement within is wondrous in its workings. Qi does not scatter outward but clings to the earth as root. The human body mirrors heaven and earth; with reverence, align within, and it may correspond.

Simply embrace tranquility, emptiness, and non-being, preserving the original true qi; guard spirit and essence in silence, and over time, it will naturally... If spirit abides in non-action, qi ascends and descends of itself. Thus, one must moderate diet, lest spirit be harmed; restrain lust and desire, lest essence be lost. When essence is still and spirit clear, qi follows the vessels’ passage, rising from the Northern Sea, gathered in the Southern Palace, returning to circulate through the Yellow Court, merging with the myriad spirits. With intention as the guide, ascend to the true void. Below the body lie the two kidneys; beneath the tongue, the two orifices. The Flower Pool’s divine water, the Purple Palace’s primordial lord.

The Most High said: *'The Flower Pool’s divine water descends to irrigate the numinous root.'* If you cultivate this, life may be long preserved. Do not cling to being, nor follow non-being. Preserve essence to transform qi, naturally congealing the spirit furnace. Spirit fire refines the turbid, essence’s splendor floats upward; the two qi unite, progressing from being to non-being. Like a dragon nurturing its pearl, use it with earnest care; listen with the horns’ acuity, like a hen brooding her eggs, covering them with gentle warmth, feathers nurturing them to completion. At the inception of gestation lies the root of restored life.

Fire refines, water arises; yin descends, yang ascends. Heart fire belongs to yang, its fluid to yin; kidney water belongs to yin, its splendor to yang. As for the *Kan* trigram, yin envelops yang; as for the *Li* trigram, yang envelops yin. Thunder rises from water, yin contains yang; water flows from mountains, yang contains yin. Water seeks the earth, so the heart communes with the kidneys; thunder commands the heavens, so the kidneys commune with the heart. The mechanism of heart and kidneys gathers the two qi. To seek with heart and kidneys is to be burdened by things.

Spirit does not leave qi, qi does not scatter essence; when spirit, essence, and qi unite, one may attain longevity. If one can forge this lead, form and spirit are both complete: spirit soars to the upper realms, form abides in the human world. If one cannot preserve it, qi scatters and form is discarded, a mere sack of pus and blood, vainly awakening to cultivation. Fire too fierce harms the elixir; water too abundant yields no achievement. Yin and yang both gathered, intention and emotion deeply entwined. Let the other be empty, while I remain full. Emptiness can respond to things; fullness can propagate life. Plant the seed, and the sprout emerges; when earth is empty, things flourish. When channels are still and blood is empty, within three days, red flies fill the ground—how can spring’s work be seen?

Heaven’s mandate is proclaimed, yin rides while yang receives. Men, swayed by excessive emotion, are like ceaseless rain—recklessly bestowed without restraint, and living things rot! Women, inclined to stubborn nature, are like scorching drought—yet when water arrives, life revives abundantly. Blood receives essence, and the fetus’s bones form; essence imparts to blood, and the fetus’s flesh takes shape. Flesh and blood are fundamentally yin; bones and essence are fundamentally yang. Yin harbors the yang body; yang enfolds yin’s radiance. Men embrace yin; women hold yang. Blood transforms, bones endure—how can essence be ordinary? If one can reverse its course, the body will not perish.

All immortals preserve essence to reach the immortal realm. Indulging in desire, letting it blaze, the po scatters and the hun stretches—willingly becoming a ghost of the dust, vainly entering delusion. *'Do not shake your essence, do not labor your form.'* The words of the Most High—who heeds them? What I now expound is not for discussing lewdness, jesting with the flowers of romance—how could my heart be tainted by dust?

The grasses and trees of the world can yet regenerate; how can the human way not be upheld, treating life as so light? Cultivate the two qi within, accumulate hidden merit without; curb anger, restrain desire, nurture spirit, store essence. Practicing thus, what fear is there of not succeeding? When yang is deficient, supplement yang; when yin is disordered, regulate the channels. The methods of regulation and supplementation rely on medicinal aid.

I gather the world’s methods to embrace all living things, preserving and guarding them carefully—do not show them to the unworthy. Metal inherently gives birth to lead; entering water, it is not drenched, rising in response to *Layer*. Earth is born from metal; entering fire, it does not scatter, acting in response to *Mong*. The Northern Sea yields lead; the Southern Palace produces mercury. Rooted in water and earth, the two qi’s wondrous workings. When water dries, metal appears; the child departs the mother’s womb, seeking its kindred, responding to the summons and coming.

Foxes and hares are not horses; swallows and sparrows are not phoenixes. The foolish of the world recklessly meddle with metals and stones."

Refining gold depends on fire to transform its qi and substance; employing both civil and martial methods, one escapes the murky cave. Nurturing gold requires a crucible to cultivate the infant, combining gentle warmth to form the sacred embryo. A golden radiance envelops all, a jeweled moon hangs in the sky—within this vision lies the work of refining lead, ten months of transformation, the river chariot turning day and night. This principle is the foundation of mercury and lead, the method of refinement and nurturance; Pengzi nearly grasped it. The Celestial Treasury’s stipends, the immortals’ emoluments—without merit and conduct, how dare one presume to hold them! Should one escape heavenly censure, lightning execution awaits; stealthily seizing fortune leads to a hundred paths and a thousand detours. One may only hear of this, never forcibly pursue it; only when merit is complete and conduct perfected will one naturally encounter guidance.

**Entering Emptiness, Seventh Grade**
The Perfected Lord says: "To enter emptiness is to empty all realms, so that realms cannot disturb; to empty all forms, so that forms do not delude; to empty all desires, so that desires do not assail; to empty all things, so that things exert no agency. Empty the body, empty the mind, to refine the foundation of spirit; empty essence, empty qi, to return to the true mechanism. Whatever is seen or heard, observe it with emptiness. The foundation within emptiness is most subtle.

The Most High has said: *'There is a thing, chaotic yet complete, born before heaven and earth. Silent and vast, it stands alone and unchanging, circulating without end. Vague and indistinct, in its indistinctness there are images; in its vagueness there are things. Dark and profound, within it lies essence.'* Within this void, the wondrous spirit is contained.

Yanzi said: *'The more I look up, the higher it seems; the more I delve, the firmer it becomes. Gazing ahead, it is suddenly behind.'* The *Book of Changes* speaks of the 'Primordial Yang,' Buddhism of 'True Emptiness.' Within emptiness lies an aperture called the Supreme Ultimate. It cannot be named, yet truly arises from non-being. The Five Phases converge, the Seven Governors align as one.

The Most High said: *'See not, hear not; embrace the spirit in stillness. Without sound, without scent, its oneness resides within.'* When the heart subtly harmonizes, danger follows dust; yet in danger without danger, one may know the subtle. The principle of subtlety can conceal or soar; the sound of subtlety is like a flute played without holes, a zither without strings. The body of subtlety allows stones to converse, wooden horses to neigh in the wind. Cultivate stillness to its utmost to know its wondrous emptiness—empty yet not empty, subtlety lies in the aperture’s mechanism.

In daily use, it may be known: the ear hears with acuity, for within the ear lies the aperture’s wonder; the eye sees afar, for within the eye lies the aperture’s marvel—this is your spirit. Yet it is not the ear or eye’s wonder that is spoken of, but the spirit entering its aperture. Your heart’s aperture can gather the spirit, so the six gates do not wander, the seven emotions do not arise. Refine the spirit to return to emptiness, restore your numinous root. This root is not a root, but the spirit of things before birth. Only emptiness can transform; only transformation can spiritualize. The spirit beyond spirit is called true spirit. Scattered, it becomes qi; gathered, it becomes the real.

Zengzi spoke of 'one thread,' Yanzi of 'emptying thoughts.' The Buddhist scriptures say: *'For immeasurable kalpas, the root of birth and death—what is called "coming" is the essence within emptiness. The wonder of empty essence harmonizes with all principles.'* The sutras state: *'Seeing does not perceive me, hearing does not attain me; transcending all extremes, this is called the wondrous Dao.'*

People lose their spirit, vainly seeking to transform things, yet failing to recognize the mechanism of transformation, they are themselves transformed into things. Thus it is said: *'The child plays with its shadow, only to be played by the shadow; the madman mocks the statue, only to be mocked by the statue.'* Without clarity of true emptiness, what benefit can there be?

Within our bodies, the arising of joy and anger, the stirring of sorrow and delight, the misperceptions caused by things—these are our illnesses. Transform the body with emptiness, let the body follow emptiness’s transformation. What joy? What anger? What delight? What sorrow? Those who cannot empty themselves obstruct themselves with dust. Qi arises from the numinousness of sound, awareness from the numinousness of dreams. Within still emptiness, one does not engage the bodily form.

Entering emptiness to its utmost, one becomes as if in a dream, without sight or hearing—this is called the spirit’s return. For days on end, one is utterly merged, then the mechanism of wisdom stirs. Inner and outer become numinously clear, the body’s form is exchanged. The body emits five colors—this is shedding the yin foundation, like a dragon changing its bones, a snake shedding its skin. With long accumulation, one becomes unshaken, unmoved. One feels qi ascending, wind and rain rustling; the tongue moistened with sweet nectar, the nose flowing with jade pillars; the eyes emitting radiance, qi warming the cinnabar pool. Gradually, it rises again, a fierce wind tearing at the earth, steaming the mud pill. One becomes dazed, as if drunk, hearing the sound of rending silk in the abdomen, thunder roaring in the ears. Pain pierces bones and penetrates sinews, a thousand battles rage, ten thousand waves surge. Fire blazes throughout the body, rising and descending in crimson, flowing through the hundred bones, circulating through the entire being. Entering emptiness, harmony is achieved—this is recorded in the alchemical classics.

Having attained this verification, proceed further. The fire times of the celestial cycle enter the body from this point. After awakening from primordial chaos, heaven and earth are reestablished. The day of soaring flight will come—do not fail in your cultivation. Having now gained this, do not treat it lightly. In the world, there is no womb that cannot be a father, no birth that cannot be a mother."

The grasses and trees have life, each thing its own kind—how could the response of the *zhongsi* be false speech? There is a saying: *"Solitary yin does not generate, solitary yang does not complete."* Without yin, yang has nothing to adhere to, and that which adheres is qi; without yang, yin has nothing to follow, and that which follows is essence. Refine essence with emptiness, and essence becomes firm; refine qi with emptiness, and qi flourishes. Though essence congeals in the kidneys, if met with emptiness it generates without the affliction of lust; though qi governs the body, if met with emptiness it flourishes without the peril of partial desiccation. Qi flourishes in blood, spirit governs essence—guard emptiness to enact it, and this is the wondrous subtlety of true stillness entering emptiness. Though passions mingle, qi is employed with external contemplation; though bodies unite, spirit rests without hasty transference. When the man’s passion is joyous and the woman’s intent is glad, gather her yin water to strengthen the yang radiance. Await the flow of fluids, the panting of nasal breath—yang operates, spirit shifts, and qi enters the scrotum. In the world, there are those whose shared passions reach their peak, whose two qi are fragrant, and thus conceive twins—this is no anomaly.

The common man, deluded and ignorant, fails to restrain and moderate, exhausting essence in greedy desire. His complexion withers to yellow, his form withers externally, his spirit languishes within. Body and spirit emaciated, burdened by turbid dissipation—if one embraces essence and nurtures emptiness, curbs desire and awaits the proper time, not only will there be offspring, but life’s foundation will also endure. You, who encounter the world’s delusions, should take this as a warning: do not cast your pearl of treasure as a clod of mud! To share together in the realm of longevity—how could this not be beautiful? To perish for such greed—willingly become a lowly ghost!

Lead is refined in the nine cauldrons, each cauldron with its pivot. Within it lies lead—true and false diverge. Thirty *wen* hexagrams govern qi, seventy *wu* hexagrams consolidate the foundation. Within them, transformations arise, and all things are generated. Without the wondrous subtlety of warm nurturance, how could the minute apertures of emptiness harmonize? The gatherer gathers true lead, like the image of a pearl within the watery lead. Thus it is said: from the kidney’s palace, the embryonic spirit transforms, becoming the yellow sprout. Thus it is called *yugui*—mercury, the serpent, readily changes, but with lead it is repeatedly restrained and does not fly. Lead, the tortoise, readily dissolves, but with mercury it is harnessed and does not flee. Merely draw and replenish, as the verification of a water clock; return and repeat, like the moon’s waxing and waning. Though the lead is true, if not severed, without the fire’s crucible the form will not shine, and it cannot be succeeded by a child—how then could it be transmitted to a grandchild?

In the previous nine cauldrons, the embryo is shed, becoming the substance of true emptiness. Each cauldron is nurtured by the mother qi, and only then is it attained.

**Chapter Eight: Shedding the Embryo**
The Perfected Lord said: "When embryonic breathing is settled, the inner light becomes spirit. Harmony of qi responds, and extreme emptiness perfects the true. Within the indistinct and vague, qi fills and becomes spirit. The yang essence manifests its form, and suddenly one feels the body lightened—surpassing lineage and ancestors, ascending together. When merit is complete and conduct fulfilled, a celestial decree descends. Mounting the wings of a flying crane, one’s name is listed among Penglai and Yingzhou.

The Most High has said: *'If one desires to cultivate the Dao, first one must abandon affairs, not cling to any single method, and the heart will abide constantly.'* Above the settled heart, all is open and unobstructed; below the settled heart, all is vast and without foundation." Mencius thus said: *"Great and transformed—this is called sagely; sagely yet unknowable—this is called spirit."* I admonish you on shedding the embryo: unite form with emptiness, recognize the profundity of stillness, and know the mechanism of non-action. Pierce the wondrousness of the three barriers, consolidate the enclosure of the Great Ultimate. With what is known, replace what is unknown; with what is recognized, replace what is unrecognized."

With what is heard, replace what is unheard;
with what is done, replace what is undone.
Before your birth, what single thing existed?
Since receiving life, you have been enslaved by form,
entangled in myriad obstructions—
love, desire, greed, and wrath.
Arrogance, extravagance, and pride
have taken root and transformed the heart.
The Confucians call it "selfishness,"
the Buddhists call it "net-like obstructions,"
the *Xian* call it "received karmic veils"—
the Buddhists also call it *received karmic veils*.
Abandon these at once,
for they are the roots of your burdens.
Originally, they were not yours—
things turn and passion is forgotten.
Sever these habitual tendencies
as a knife cuts lotus root:
one stroke, two halves,
not a single thread remains entangled—
unyielding resolve, fierce determination.
As if the body had never been born,
neither heart nor body truly exists—
what then could entangle you?
Awaken suddenly, loathe the world’s illusions:
the four great elements are but pus and blood,
like filth in a latrine—
the eye cannot bear to see,
the nose cannot bear to smell.
Only when this is severed in an instant
is it called *"comprehending the heart."*
Comprehending the heart, the burdens of qi dissolve;
the burdens of qi conceal the spirit.
When spirit submits and qi congeals,
abundant and free, it commands the numinous.
It splits open the primordial chaos,
filling the Great Clarity with light.
It overturns the ten directions,
shatters empty space.
A single staff props up heaven and earth;
a single bundle of the Infinite envelops the forms of Qian and Kun.
Bearing emptiness, bearing stillness,
neither death nor birth—
the sound of the宗 resounds across the eight wilds,
the spirit dwells in the Three Clarities.
Shedding the embryo, the spirit transforms;
refining and preserving the form,
the form remains in the world,
while the spirit transcends the Jade Court.
This is the supreme Dao,
aiding you to penetrate the real.
In years to come, when your practice is complete,
you will be lifted up in ascension.

No-thing originally arises from having-thing,
formed things originally adhere to the formless.
The formless gives birth to and nurtures the numinous essence—
father and mother unite to form a single nature.
Only because people of this age drown in desire,
they know not the work of gathering and refining.
Foolishly they cast their nature into the abyss of love,
while the resolute turn inward to observe the foundation of life.

This foundation is the father’s numinous qi,
while life is the mother’s knitting of the embryo.
The embryo’s spirit congeals, drawn from the Great Void—
first, one must refine the spirit with enduring patience.
Seize the golden essence and hold it fast,
and spring will naturally fill the courtyard steps.
To gather spring and face the scene, idly opening the heart—
fire’s dryness makes the elixir hard to bear.
The ten-month embryo’s talisman is warmed and nurtured,
within it, the method employs *zhun* and *meng*.
Each embryo’s transformation follows the same pattern—
one must nurture the nature with unbroken continuity.

After three years, the sage’s penetration silently transforms,
relieving the poor and aiding the distressed to cultivate merit.
The response to the eight trigrams is the original root—
the method carries the cinnabar script, advancing fire and retreating talismans.
How could this ever depart from yin and yang?
Yet people falsely speak of postcelestial methods,
ensnaring wealthy families in their nets.
How laughable—the foolish, lacking wisdom,
covet another’s high arts,
unaware that he claims kingship for himself—
would he ever cede his realm?
