Only with a mother can there be a child,
but how can another’s mother compare to one’s own?
Heaven distinguishes prior and posterior, yet the matter is perverse—
not like ordinary silver, which is a postcelestial yin substance.
Cinnabar and mercury—how could their bodies be purely yang?
As soon as they meet the furnace fire, they scatter and fly.
Each person is deluded, losing their home—
without a mother, lead’s qi cannot form,
yet it is called the metal beneath the water.
Taking silver as the root of the mother,
all are deceived by the elixir masters.

That which has a mother yet lacks numinosity—
this is clearly expounded in the scriptures.
Leisurely observing the golden valley, carefully weighing the discussion,
this is the ultimate principle of external alchemy.
The master’s judgment is complete.

Then, heavenly fragrance filled the air, auspicious qi floated over the hermitage,
cranes cried beyond the clouds, rosy clouds reflected the courtyard curtains.
Golden flowers and jeweled radiance spread across the seat,
a myriad of wondrous signs startled and responded.

The villagers all bowed their heads in reverence, praising the rarity and expressing gratitude before withdrawing.

Six *Xijiangyue* verses—
the first two elucidate the Way of husband and wife,
the latter four illustrate the efficacy of external alchemy,
in accord with the preceding scripture, completing eight sections in all.
Let scholars ponder them repeatedly, and they will naturally gain insight.
Treasure and keep them secret, lest my earnest transmission be in vain.

The first section is the scripture’s text,
the seventh explicates the meaning of the first—
take care never to recklessly transmit them to the unworthy,
lest slander arise.
Beware! Beware!

**Heavenly Sovereign’s Esoteric Incantation**

Heaven-born cloud and dragon, the Dao ascends from the origin.
Fierce and upright qi, resplendent in the Great Clarity.
Assisting the true Dao, walking the path of rectitude.
Six Jia pervade the primordial, nine heavens transcend form.
Blessings and prosperity for descendants—
first, cultivate one’s own authenticity;
then extend to the Human Sovereign,
that all may revere long life.
Six Ding and nine *xuan* (mysterious forces),
the esoteric truth is perfected.
Revere it, and ultimate felicity shall be yours—
the August Heaven’s noble name.
Through enduring mastery of the Dao’s subtleties,
the body remains ever full.
Whoever hears these true words
shall unite with the Dao in truth.

*Hasten! Hasten!*
As the decree of the Original Celestial Worthy. **Secret Formula.**

**Three Circles atop the talisman are called "Three Flowers Gathering at the Crown"; nine circles within the talisman are called "Nine Revolutions Returning the Elixir," also known as "Nine Dragons Bearing the Sage." The true *qi* is the qi of the cinnabar field. When inscribing this talisman, one must draw upon the primordial *qi* and spread it upon the paper. Wait until the clear dawn, when spirit is lucid and *qi* is fresh, to inscribe it—only then will it be efficacious.**

**Three Flowers Gathering at the Crown—**
**Heaven is my canopy.**
**Nine Revolutions Returning the Elixir—**
**One *qi* makes the true person.**

Recite only these four lines. Consume it for one cycle of twelve years, and the body will become light, ascending in flight.

**Eight Immortals Longevity Decoction**
*Polygonum multiflorum* (soaked in rice-washed water until soft, peeled with a bamboo knife, steamed with black beans for the duration of three incense sticks, then sun-dried): ten parts
*Lycium chinense* root bark (washed with wine, sun-dried): eight parts
*Wolfiporia cocos* (outer skin removed, washed with wine, sun-dried): eight parts
*Panax ginseng* (pure and bright, best when shade-dried): four parts
*Rehmannia glutinosa* (washed in wine overnight, sun-dried): four parts
*Prepared Rehmannia glutinosa* (washed clean with wine, sun-dried): four parts
*Asparagus cochinchinensis* (soaked in wine for one to two hours, heart removed, sun-dried): four parts
*Ophiopogon japonicus* (soaked in wine for two hours, heart removed, sun-dried): four parts

**Jinlan Temple Annotation:** The above is the aforementioned medicinal formula.

The original text is arranged vertically from right to left, differing from the web layout. The above ingredients are to be chopped into small pieces, with *Lycium chinense* root bark and *Wolfiporia cocos* as the sovereign herbs. Additionally, *Polygonum multiflorum* (doubled in quantity) serves as minister and assistant. This elixir has circulated among mortals for many years! In the second year of the Zhiyuan era, it was transmitted to Feng Xuan of Wuyi and published for the world, though it had not yet been refined with talismanic seals. This talisman severs the Three Corpses; this elixir refines the Five Qi. With prolonged use, one may attain immortality. Avoid onions, garlic, radishes, and all beans.

**Wanzi Pill**
*Magnolia officinalis* (bark), *Panax ginseng*, *Cinnamomum* (heartwood), *Commiphora myrrha* (four parts each)
*Boswellia carterii* (three parts)
*Evodia rutaecarpa*, *Acorus tatarinowii*, *Bletilla striata*, *Ampelopsis japonica*, *Wolfiporia cocos* (one part each)
*Radix achyranthis bidentatae*, *Asarum heterotropoides* (five qian each)
*Angelica sinensis*, *Typhonium giganteum* (a small amount each)

Grind the above into powder, refine with honey into pills the size of red beans, and prepare them on a *renzi* day. Take ten pills each time. For men, it replenishes and benefits; for pregnant women, it ensures twins. Take on an empty stomach with fine wine—both husband and wife will find it excellent.

**Postscript to the Original Text of the Eight Grades of Scripture**
The solitary practice of the supreme Dao depends on transmission through worthy individuals. Yet such individuals are not easily found. Those favored by Heaven’s nurturing grace, who seek the great Dao in this world, are certainly not of shallow root or capacity. Nor can those lacking sincere faith or whose source is impure hope to reach its shores!

The exalted sages, in their vast compassion, deeply lament that people remain ignorant and unaware, their understanding of truth incomplete, leading to a turbid universe where the spirit’s radiance is obscured. Is it any wonder that later generations, while propagating its name, fail to grasp its essence, losing sight of the sages’ original intent to relieve suffering in this world and guide later learners?

Master Lü’s *First Eight Grades* of profound truth and authentic interpretation have long circulated, with many adherents. The *Latter Eight Grades*, however, remained hidden in Linjiang, concealed and untransmitted. Would our patriarch’s profound intent to propagate the teachings and deliver humanity be left in obscurity? This unworthy disciple, Xu Taiji, with utmost sincerity and devotion, has roughly grasped its meaning and practiced it diligently. One night, I dreamed of a Daoist in flowing robes, exuding the bearing of an immortal. Upon waking, I gained insight and immediately resolved to combine and engrave the *First and Latter Eight Grades of the Immortal Scripture*, inscribing them in stone to make them public and accessible to all seekers of the Dao.

Fortunately, my fellow disciple Wu Tailong generously offered funds to assist in this grand endeavor. I said, “This is to propagate the true teaching, awaken the world, and guide the people—how could I keep it private?” With reverence, I chose an auspicious day in the late spring of the *yimao* year, and together with fellow disciple Zhang Tailun, we respectfully commissioned the transcription at the Jade Emperor Pavilion in Wuchang’s provincial capital. We then ordered artisans to carve and distribute it widely.

Reciting a single phrase of its profound truth will rouse the deaf and blind of ages past from their ignorance; chanting several of its abstruse passages will guide heterodox and peripheral paths back to orthodoxy. Thus, the obscure becomes manifest, the hidden becomes clear, and all will recognize the path to guidance. May the study of life and destiny no longer fall into the abyss of illusion and groundlessness. May those of like mind take heed.

We, the unworthy, do not deeply understand literature but have recorded our intent in this postscript to the combined edition.

Written on the day after the full moon of the fifth lunar month in the *yimao* year of the Kangxi reign.

**Immortal Scripture of the Five Grades** (Scroll Twelve)
Preface

**Hymn to the Scripture of the Five Grades**

**Chapter One: Observing the Mind to Dispel Delusion**
**Chapter Two: Laying the Foundation and Gathering the Medicine**
**Chapter Three: The Crucible and the Cauldron**
**Chapter Four: Emptying Form and Voidifying Life**
**Chapter Five: Shedding the Fetal Body and Emerging in Yang**
*With an appended biography of Master Fu*

**Brief Preface to the Scripture of the Five Grades**
The numbers of Heaven, Earth, and humanity do not extend beyond five: Heaven has its five stars, Earth its five phases, humanity its five senses, the five natures it is endowed with, and the five relationships it engages in. These interact through mutual generation and mutual restraint, opposing yet completing one another—the application of the number five is vast indeed!

Thus, Patriarch Lü composed this exposition of the Five Grades. When the Heavenly Lord is at peace, the hundred limbs follow its command. He first sets forth *"Observing the Mind to Dispel Delusion"* at the head of the chapters, for once the deluded mind is dispelled, one may swiftly begin cultivation. Hence, it is followed by *"Laying the Foundation and Gathering the Medicine,"* for refining the medicine requires crucible and cauldron. Thus, it is followed by *"The Crucible and the Cauldron."* Lest one misunderstand the crucible and cauldron and stray into heterodox paths, all forms and appearances must not be clung to, so it is followed by *"Emptying Form and Voidifying Life."* When form and emptiness are both forgotten, the Yang Spirit emerges—almost beyond one’s self. One awaits this in stillness, and the work of immortal cultivation is complete. Thus, it concludes with *"Shedding the Fetal Body and Emerging in Yang,"* all of which is contained within the One Mind. Though there are five grades, they are truly derived from the One, just as the five phases arise from yin and yang, yin and yang from the Supreme Ultimate, and the Supreme Ultimate from the Ultimateless.

Its structure is meticulous, its meaning profound, encompassing the essential truths of the myriad volumes of the Daoist Canon. How could it merely expound the unexpounded mysteries of the *Eight Grades*? If one has no aspiration for the Dao, so be it; but if one aspires to the Dao, how can one not devote one’s whole heart to it?

---

**Preface to the Scripture of the Five Grades**
Half a *li* east of the North Wusheng Gate of Huicheng in Chu, there stands an abbey called *"Abode of Resting in the Real."* Backing onto mountains and facing a lake, it is surrounded by dense forests and towering bamboo. Few residents dwell nearby, and visitors rarely come. Though the abbey is not large, its seclusion and tranquility surpass those of other places—truly a fine retreat for immortals and perfected beings.

Formerly, outside the city walls lived a scholar named Fu, who from youth possessed a spiritual root and a wise nature. He deeply admired Patriarch Lü and, together with like-minded companions in the vicinity, formed a Lüzu Society to invoke the planchette. In the *jiwei* year of the Kangxi reign, the Patriarch happened to wander through the lands of Chu. Seeing purple qi floating in the sky, he knew a person of attainment was present and descended via the flying phoenix. At that time, those who took refuge under his teaching seat were mostly scholars, and it was hailed as a grand gathering.

Thereafter, he expounded the *Scripture of the Five Grades*, with Fu serving as his principal attendant. The Patriarch secretly imparted the essentials and recounted past causes. Fu attained sudden enlightenment upon hearing his words. Having fully understood his root nature, he served with even greater reverence. The Patriarch thus extensively elucidated the most subtle and profound mysteries, arranging the grades according to the numbers of the five phases and the five constants, and illustrating the diagrams based on the principles of the *He* and *Luo* trigrams.

The human mind is the master of the body, and deluded thoughts are the source of obstruction to the Dao. *"Observing the Mind to Dispel Delusion"* venerates the root; *"Laying the Foundation and Gathering the Medicine"* reveals the true practice; *"The Crucible and the Cauldron"* clarifies the elixir field; *"Emptying Form and Voidifying Life"* forgets form and appearance; *"Shedding the Fetal Body and Emerging in Yang"* signifies the completion of the sacred embryo—one must then be ever more vigilant. When merit is perfected and conduct fulfilled, one awaits the imperial summons to ascend.

Though the scripture is brief, its meaning is profound, encompassing the wondrous truths of cultivating the real. From the time of attending the exposition of the *Five Grades*, with the virtuous knowledge of Scholar Fu present, we were graced by Patriarch Lü’s compassionate bestowal of the precious raft, widely benefiting the multitude. If scholars revere and believe in it, ponder deeply, and diligently investigate, they may yet attain the Dao.

Respectfully inscribed by Huang Chengshu, the One Who Walks in Sandi.

---

**Compiled by Liu Tishu, the Selfless One of Yiling**
**Collated by son Liu Yincheng Qinghui and nephew Liu Yuncheng Qingxu**
**Assisted by Huang Chengshu, the One Who Walks in Sandi**

---

**Original Preface to the Scripture of the Five Grades**
Upon the completion of the grand ritual of the *Five Grades* at the Abode of Resting in the Real, the August Emperor of Trustworthy Protection deigned to say:

*"Formerly, in places such as Piling, I expounded the* Eight Grades *to exhaust principles and investigate sources, dispelling miasmic influences and rectifying qi, so that the great Dao shone anew and the ancestral teachings spread far. Now, in Ezhou, instructing my disciples and delivering beings from suffering, I expound the* Five Grades *to reveal the unexpounded mysteries of the* Eight Grades *and disclose the unspoken secrets of the* Eight Grades. *The precious raft has now fully unveiled the most subtle of subtleties, guiding one to the ultimate aim of the ancestral gate.*

*Moreover, the numbers of Heaven and Earth operate through generation and restraint in fives. The Daoists speak of ‘metal, wood, water, fire, and earth’; the Confucians speak of ‘benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust’; the Buddhists speak of ‘birth, aging, sickness, suffering, and death.’ The* Book of Changes *also states, ‘The five positions interact and each has its correspondence.’ This exposition of the* Five Grades *precisely accords with the principle of generation and restraint, the Dao of endless production.*

*You disciples must revere and uphold it, embodying compassion and never forgetting the bodhisattva mind. Reflect thrice upon this decree."*

The Emperor’s compassion for the Three Chu regions surpasses that for the Five Tombs a hundredfold. Respectfully recorded here to share with those of like mind.

**In Praise of the Five Grades Sutra**
*Eulogy by the Perfected Lord Yuchan*
With bowed head and reverent prostration, I pay homage to the Lord Fu You,
Who descends upon white clouds, riding a crane and phoenix.
Expounding the teachings, pointing the way through the ford,
With the resonant sounds of *leng*, *qie*, and *jia*,
Awakening all the blind and benighted.

*Eulogy by the Perfected Lord Dahuan*
The Venerable One, whose wisdom shines like the sun in stillness,
Serves as the eye of the world, our guiding teacher.
In the sea of suffering, he establishes bridges and ferries,
Thus at the gate of the Dao, he proclaims the secret scriptures.
When the *Udumbara* flower briefly blooms,
The withered sprouts of the spirit, nearly broken,
Are revived by the dharma rain flying through the clear skies,
Amidst crimson clouds, purple qi, and white mist.
All sounds fall silent as the voice of Heaven resounds;
Eyes closed, hearts stilled, we listen with raised ears.
The deluded thoughts of floating life dissolve,
And upon hearing the Dharma, our hearts brim with joy.
Cranes stand in formation, phoenixes and mandarin ducks leap,
While celestial music rings like the harmony of the heavens.
Illusory blossoms seem to scatter like heavenly flowers,
And the heart-sickness of the deluded is cured by the master’s healing.
Each word of the sacred text is a red elixir,
May all beings of the ten directions
Together realize the supreme awakening of the Golden Immortals.
At the end of the kalpa, immortals are born from the master’s mouth,
Whose majestic power and meritorious deeds defy description.
If we wish to repay the master’s kindness,
We must ferry countless beings across.

*Eulogy by the Perfected Lord Taishi Before the Emperor*
Heavenly Teacher and Master of Humans,
Great Sage Pure Yang,
The profound mysteries of the Dao’s mechanism rely on his proclamation.

Amidst the vast and bewildering bitter sea,
Adrift without a vessel or guiding light,
The Immortal One reveals the bridge and ford.
From the ninefold heavens, the thunderous proclamation resounds,
Expounding the Western Perfected One’s great deliverance,
Illuminating the profound and subtle mysteries of the Immortal Canon.
*First Chapter: Observing the Mind to Dispel Delusion*

At that time, the Venerable Sovereign of Orthodox Exposition,
Seeing the mortals below lost in delusion,
Their cunning and deceit like ghosts and goblins,
Their ferocity and malice like wolves and tigers,
Committing transgressions without end,
With the world thus afflicted—none more so than Chu—
In the autumn of the *jiwei* year,
The Supreme Emperor’s wrath was kindled.
He commanded the Deities of Transgression to survey the sins of the people,
And in accordance with celestial law, to decree their karmic retribution.
The number of beings destined for calamity was beyond reckoning.

Moved by great compassion, the Sovereign wept as he petitioned:
“The mortals below are not unwilling to cease evil and cultivate goodness,
To pursue fortune and shun misfortune.
Yet the supreme Dao remains obscure, and their reckless minds are unchecked,
Thus they indulge in chaotic thoughts and disordered actions,
Entangled in the net of karma, incurring the wrath of August Heaven.
Permit this servant to descend among them,
To silently awaken the benighted,
Clearly pointing out the secrets of cultivating body and nurturing nature,
The Way of preserving principle and restraining desire.
Thus may all beings easily awaken and comprehend,
Naturally dissolving delusive thoughts and taming their reckless minds.
Not only will they escape suffering’s bonds,
But if they persist unwavering in their practice,
They may ultimately ascend as immortals and attain Buddhahood.
I humbly beseech the Sacred Lord to grant this servant’s request.”

The Emperor’s virtue cherishes all life, and he gladly assented to the master’s plea.

As the master departed, the Perfected One Liu of the Left Palace bowed deeply and said:
“From ancient times to the present, immortals and buddhas,
Moved by compassion for sentient beings,
Have expounded countless wondrous dharmas,
Hoping that beings would hear, receive, and uphold them,
And thus avoid falling into the cycle of rebirth.
Yet beings refuse to believe and accept,
Instead heaping slander upon them,
Thereby increasing their descent into evil destinies,
Plunging into the great hells.
Though the Compassionate Venerable One possesses divine powers and vows,
Even if you had a thousand hands and eyes,
How could you alone rescue all the drowning in the world?”

The master replied:
“The scriptures and teachings expounded by the immortals and buddhas
Are profound in meaning and obscure in expression.
The beings of this defiled age are dull in faculties and shallow in wisdom,
Unable to comprehend them.
Moreover, the great Dao spoken by immortals and buddhas of past ages
Still contains secrets yet unheard.
Now, as I descend,
First, I shall clearly reveal the heart-method of sages and worthies,
And second, I dare to disclose the hidden essences of immortals and buddhas.
Though I may incur the crime of recklessly divulging heavenly secrets,
If beings can thereby ascend beyond suffering,
What regret could I have for my own demotion and descent?”

Hearing these words, the Perfected One was both grieved and overjoyed.

Thus, on the auspicious ninth day of the tenth month, the Divine Lord led the host of celestial deities, perfected immortals, and sagely assemblies to descend. Addressing his foremost disciples, he declared:

“All beings turn their backs on awakening and cling to dust, living in vain and dying in futility, scorched and boiled within the burning house, drowned and submerged in the sea of suffering. This arises because beings indulge in greed, anger, and delusion, self-mutilating their own nature, allowing guest-dust to obscure their luminous pearl and delusive clouds to veil the radiant sun of primordial sound. Thus they flow into the various destinies without hope of escape.

I regard all beings as my own children—how could I bear to see you sink into the wheel of rebirth and endure every kind of torment? Therefore, I shall expound the profound mysteries of immortals and buddhas. I shall act as the King of Physicians to cure the ailments of your hearts. Listen with focused minds, for I shall now instruct you:

All beings who seek longevity must embody the great Dao.
To embody the great Dao, one must first observe the mind.
The method of observing the mind is this:
The eyes must turn inward to see,
the ears inward to hear,
the nose inward to smell,
the tongue inward to taste,
the intent inward to contemplate.
When the spirit-light shines forth, immediately return its illumination;
when deluded thoughts arise, immediately return to awareness.
As the ancients said: *‘Fear not the arising of thoughts, only the delay in awareness.’*
When a thought arises, be aware of it; in awareness, it vanishes.
Thus, at the very moment a thought begins to sprout, do not allow it to branch further—turn the light inward to illumine, and the root of delusion will instantly perish.
The Daoist Layman Youxuan said: *‘Once sent forth, promptly draw it back; once returned, you must let it go.’*
The *Scripture of the Dragon and Tiger* states: *‘The subtlest essential is first to preserve, then to forget. First preserve to empty the heart, then forget to expand its capacity.’* This is the supreme secret of the ancient sages.
Therefore, to extinguish all delusions, one must observe the mind.

The Buddha said: *‘Illuminating the five aggregates as empty, one transcends all suffering and distress.’*
Thus, when one delusion is illuminated, it becomes the truth of that delusion;
when one thought is awakened to, it becomes the bodhi of that thought.
The *Scripture of Unconscious Unison* states: *‘Hold the spirit-candle to illumine deluded passions, wield the sword of wisdom to sever craving and desire.’*
Once deluded passions are shattered, the spirit-candle may be forgotten;
once craving and desire are severed, the sword of wisdom may be set aside.
These are all methods of observing the mind.

Having understood the observation of the mind, one must then clarify the essence of the mind.
This mind, since time without beginning, is neither born nor destroyed, neither comes nor goes. It is utterly empty, utterly luminous, utterly true, utterly sincere—vast and boundless, clear and numinous.
It cannot be measured by existence or non-existence, nor perceived through form or appearance.
Trace it to the time before heaven and earth—none know its beginning;
investigate it after heaven and earth—none know its end.
Heaven and earth rely on it for their covering and bearing,
the sun and moon rely on it for their illumination,
the void relies on it for its vastness,
the ten thousand spirits rely on it for their transformations.
The sages of the Three Teachings teach people to cultivate the Dao—none other than cultivating this one mind.
When one is a being, this mind does not perish;
when one becomes an immortal or buddha, this mind does not increase.

The Buddha said: *‘The mind’s essence is thoroughly pure and all-pervading, embracing the ten directions. Its substance is like empty space, boundless and without limit—it is present here and now.’*
To move the mind is to deviate.
Alas! Beings do not recognize their original mind, mistaking the thief for their child, enslaving the master with the servant, burdening the real with the false. Thus they revolve in birth and death without respite, evoking profound compassion.”

The Immortal Master concluded his discourse.

At that moment, five-colored clouds enshrouded the chamber, auspicious hues swirling through the hall. Then the Venerable Buddha’s Disciple, Mo Lai Fo Zi, stepped forth from the assembly and extolled:

*“Expounding the sutras to cross kalpas,*
*Compassion as the heart’s core—*
*Where the flute’s notes fall, worldly dust dissolves.*
*Benevolence and mercy win reverence;*
*Immortals and buddhas alike hold in esteem.*
*Deliverance knows no hierarchy.”*

The True Buddha’s Disciple, along with the True Immortal Divine Kings, all rejoiced greatly, bowed in homage, and withdrew in faith.

**Chapter Two: Laying the Foundation and Gathering the Medicine**

Since the moment we gained this body, we have lost our nature and severed our life; the seven *po* spirits abandon their abode, the Three Corpses corrupt their dwelling, the Six Bandits clash in discord, and the Four Elements dissolve into illusion. The long-lived die young, the long-lived perish prematurely, the pure become sullied, the wise grow foolish—all having lost the *qi* of the Sacred Father and Sacred Mother, becoming wholly infused with the *qi* of ordinary fathers and mothers. Thus, in knowing only to eat and drink, we differ not from beasts with fur and horns!

Only the sages preserve their horns through the Dao and extend their lives through arts, stealing the boundless primordial *qi* to sustain their finite forms, shedding the *qi* of ordinary fathers and mothers to become wholly infused with the *qi* of the Sacred Father and Sacred Mother. Thus, refining nature and refining form, they effortlessly become buddhas or patriarchs.

Know this: before this body was born, with every inhalation and exhalation, *qi* connected to the mother. After birth, with every inhalation and exhalation, *qi* connects to heaven. If one can sit in stillness within the circle of non-action and non-delusion, turning the mind inward to illuminate, there will naturally arise—like lightning or dew—a spark of true yang, surging forth to enter the *xuan* pass, penetrating the long valley, ascending to the *niwan* palace, transforming into jade nectar. With a crystalline clarity, it descends into the five viscera, whereupon the *xun* wind is stirred, driving out all evil from the three passes and nine orifices, sweeping away all illness from the five organs and six bowels. One must then guide *qi* with spirit, stabilize breath with *qi*, letting inhalation and exhalation follow their natural movement. As the Great Ultimate and empty space merge into one, the foundation of the elixir is laid—like the spring *qi* germinating a seed, or the divine dragon nurturing its pearl.

Thus, the Perfected One of Purple Yang said:
*“The golden crucible’s broth stays warm,*
*The jade furnace’s ashes dispel cold.”*
For once the yang foundation is established, one must nurture it with intention and guard it with spirit. Hence it is said:
*“Fire cools when intent scatters;*
*Fire ignites when intent blazes.*
*Know to draw out yang from yin—*
*Fear not the medicine will not solidify.*
*Know the medicine saves the fire—*
*How could the golden elixir grow parched?”*

As for gathering the medicine, it begins with action, yet only by first knowing non-action can one achieve action. The *Nanhua Sutra* states: *“The essence of the supreme Dao is subtle and obscure.”* The *Daode Jing* says: *“Obscure! Obscure! Within it lies essence.”* This essence is most upright; true essence is the true seed, and the true seed is profoundly luminous. Though the true seed is luminous, one must apply effort to gather the medicine.

What, then, is the true seed? It may be called *“yang essence,”* *“xuan pearl,”* *“yellow sprout,”* *“true lead,”* or *“xuan-pin.”* Its names are myriad, beyond enumeration! All that has form and moves belongs to turbid dust—how could it compare?

Thus, Master Yunfang (the Perfected Lord of Cloud Chamber, styled Zhengyang) said:
*“The whole body is yin—*
*Where is the yang essence?*
*If yang essence can recognize its image,*
*Every image becomes luminous.”*

I have often said:
*“From the subtle and obscure arises the dim and vague,*
*From the dim and vague coalesces a mass.”*
This mass is *“true lead,”* called *“bodhi”* in Buddhism, *“the One Thread”* in Confucianism, and *“seed”* in Daoism.

If cultivators do not know the seed, they either become empty-handed wanderers or withered meditators, failing to return to the root! Those who follow side paths drift aimlessly, relying on their teachers’ transmissions yet lacking true guidance. They know only the narrowness of the *zi* hour, unaware of its breadth! If one knows the living *zi* hour, what fear is there that the medicine will lack the elixir?

Once the myriad spirits are harmonized, fierce dragons will inevitably wage battle. When the blood settles and the *xuan* yellow is determined—though the judgment remains uncertain, as male and female unite—amid the dim and vague, do not let it flee! This is what is meant by *“In stillness, movement arises; draw out true yang to replenish my true mercury. The *wu* earth can cause true lead to descend—seize the tender sprouts of the medicine and swiftly gather them into the high lane.”*

The Perfected One of Jade Void said: *“When true lead and mercury unite, the medicine forges vajra.”* Ancestor Chongyang said: *“The civil and martial fire phases are silently realized; the old and tender, floating and sinking, are carefully deliberated.”*

The Immortal Master concluded his discourse.

At that moment, sweet dew descended, and all the immortals bowed their heads in reverence. Then the Perfected Lord Jade Toad stepped forward, clasped his hands in salute, and extolled:

*"Parents of the Four Births,
Benevolent Sovereign Emperor,
You expound the elixir’s secrets and reveal celestial patterns,
Exhaling mist to inscribe auspicious clouds,
Shouting to disperse the swirling mists—
All travelers of the rosy clouds rejoice to hear!"*

The Perfected Jade Toad and all the immortals of the grottoes were filled with great joy. They commanded their disciples at the altar to receive the teachings with utmost reverence before withdrawing.

**Chapter Three: The Crucible and the Alchemical Furnace**

The furnace is the inverted moon, where the suspended embryo is named, where *xuan* and *pin* gather, where the infant coalesces, where the pearl-like grain forms, where the yellow sprout flourishes.

It is neither metal nor iron, neither jade nor stone, neither arsenic nor cinnabar.

The Yellow Court serves as the crucible, the qi family as the furnace. The hundred meridians intermingle and fill, the Three Origins harmoniously unite. Qian becomes the crucible and Kun the furnace, properly nurturing the immortal flower.

Moreover, without the ice soul in the crucible, yin fluids will not arise; without their arising, the spiritual root of the fire dragon will not grow. Without the jade *yong* in the furnace, yang qi will not be nurtured; without its nurturance, the life stem of the water tiger will be utterly severed.

Thus, the furnace possesses yang, by which ascent and descent are achieved; the crucible possesses yin, by which opening and closing are accomplished. With each ascent and descent, each opening and closing, the Azure Dragon and White Tiger, the Golden Crow and Jade Hare, the celestial hun and earthly po, embrace and linger, refining the supreme treasure—neither dual nor singular—only then may one be deemed a celestial perfected!

As for the fire phases, they must lie in the work itself. Ignite the fire at the navel gate, circulate the water to the crown of the skull. When driving the river chariot, depart the sea of the coccyx in the mundane world and ascend to the celestial tower, moving to the valley of Kunlun.

Before obtaining the elixir, one must rely on martial fire to smelt it and the *xun* wind to fan it, carefully ensuring the fire does not burn amiss. Once the elixir is obtained, one must rely on civil fire to nurture it and divine water to moisten it. If it exceeds, diminish it; if it falls short, augment it—decisively ensuring the fire does not burn amiss.

Thus, the Perfected Lord Ziyang said:
*"Ten months of work,
Abiding in the faint and continuous breath,
Thirty thousand years of destiny
Lie within the comings and goings."*

The Perfected Lord Haichan said:
*"When the hexagrams complete their fire phases around the celestial circuit,
An infant is conceived, guarding the sea of cinnabar."*

At that time, the Perfected Lord Mo Ding stepped forward, clasped his hands in salute, and entreated:
*"The Great Dao is wordless, the supreme image formless.
Where there are words, they must be made manifest;
Where there is form, it must be made clear.
Let not the black wind arrive and cast one into the abyss of karmic dust."*

"What is the 'Dragon'? What is the 'Tiger'? What is the 'Crow'? What is the 'Hare'? What is the 'Hun-soul'? What is the 'Po-soul'? I beseech the Master to elucidate these numinous terms."

The True Master replied:
"The Li trigram’s sun is mercury; the earth of the *ji* stem is mercury. The Dragon dwells in water, its transformations boundless; it gives life and takes life, its power unfathomable—moving like clouds, raining like showers, swift as wind, thunderous as thunder. The Buddha has his poisonous dragon, the *xuan* has its candle dragon, the cave its fire dragon. To subdue the fire dragon is to accumulate cold mercury; to subdue it is to subdue the true fire within the heart. When the fire’s nature does not fly, mercury accumulates; when mercury accumulates, the Dragon lies hidden; when the Dragon lies hidden, the fire is pure; when the fire is pure, yin is extinguished; when yin is extinguished, true lead and true mercury unite, the true Dragon and true Tiger harmonize. Thus it is said: *'Without accumulating mercury, one cannot obtain lead; without subduing the Dragon, one cannot tame the Tiger.'*

The earth of the *wu* stem has no name; we forcibly call it the 'Tiger.' The Tiger is lead, the Kan trigram, dryness, and ferocity—consuming flesh and bone, harming life and destiny. The *Book of Changes* says: *'Wind follows the Tiger.'* It also says: *'Treading on the Tiger’s tail, it does not bite the man.'* If one can tame it with nurture and guide it with reverence, then the primordial is fulfilled and the Tiger subdued; when the Tiger is subdued, lead settles; when lead settles, mercury is emptied; when mercury is emptied, the Tiger’s spirit arises; when the Tiger’s spirit arises, the Dragon appears; when the Dragon appears, the Tiger soars; when the Tiger soars, the Dragon takes flight. Thus the True Man of No-Mind said: *'Facing circumstances without mind, a single qi returns to the root. Myriad spirits pay homage to the ancestor—profound and still, reverent and abiding, serene and soaring, continuous and unbroken—only then is it true cultivation!'*

As for the Crow and Hare—though the Dao has no Crow or Hare, they are named for the formless sun and moon, borrowing their images. The *Wulou* says: *'Mercury is taken from the Golden Crow’s heart-blood; lead is sought from the Jade Hare’s brain-essence.'* The *Wuzhen* says: *'First take heaven and earth as the crucible and vessel, then gather the Crow and Hare to refine the medicine.'* The True Master of Fire Dragon said: *'Within Kan is the Yellow Boy, named the Mercury Ancestor; within Li is the Dark Maiden, the family of lead.'*

Kan is the dry father: when dryness is in chaos, two yin revolve around it, with a single yang residing at its center as the Crow of Kan—able to fly swiftly, thus ascending and descending through yang to complete Kan. Li is the Kun mother: when Kun is in murky stillness, two yang encircle it, with a single yin residing in its belly as the Hare’s den—able to run swiftly, thus ascending and descending through yin to complete Kun. Thus the Radiant True Man said: *'Man and woman in separate chambers will never conceive; lead and mercury in separate furnaces will never form the elixir.'* The True Lord of Purple Emptiness said: *'I have the Yellow Dame, who guards the proper matchmaker.'* This guides the intent: intent draws the Yellow Boy from Kan to pair with the Dark Maiden in Li. When husband and wife unite, they transform into pure Qian—this is called *'taking from Kan to fill Li, restoring my primordial body.'*

The hun-soul and po-soul refer to yin and yang. The sage moves the hun-soul with the po-soul, thus attaining longevity; the common people are controlled by the po-soul over the hun-soul, thus meeting early demise. The hun-soul dwells in the eyes by day, the po-soul lodges in the liver by night—dwelling in the eyes enables sight, lodging in the liver enables dreams. Thus the sage is awake without dreams, while the common people dream without waking. Rather than dreaming within a dream, it is better to seek wakefulness within the dream. For the po-soul has essence, essence gives rise to the hun-soul, the hun-soul gives rise to intent, and intent generates the po-soul. The po-soul, hun-soul, Dragon, Tiger, Crow, Hare—two, yet one.

Thus the True Man of Longevity said: *'When the Dragon roars and the Tiger howls in the deep night, swiftly drive the river chariot without pause.'* The *Zhixuan* says: *'Rushing to the Sea of Qi is the Crimson Steed; flying into the Muddy Pellet is the White Crow'*—this *Zhixuan* is not the *Zhixuan* of the Divine Lord. Therefore I say: *'The celestial hun-soul gives birth to the White Tiger; the terrestrial po-soul produces the Azure Dragon. Transport the treasure to dwell in the Muddy Pellet, move the essence into the Upper Palace.'*"

When the Immortal Master finished expounding the scripture, phoenixes danced and simurghs soared as auspicious clouds filled the sky. All the immortals rejoiced. Then the Perfected Lord Mo Ding stepped forward, bowed in reverence, and offered this hymn of praise:

*"In the crescent-moon furnace, flames blaze bright—
Neither firewood nor charcoal feeds their light.
No external breath is drawn for blowing’s art,
Refinement lies in nurturing the inner spirit’s part.

The Dark Maiden rides the Dragon round the crucible’s rim,
The Metal Elder straddles the Tiger to the cauldron’s heart.
Over the Sea Field, cranes search for cold jade’s gleam,
In the Western Land, the Crow smelts Dui’s gold apart.

The method follows Zhun’s tone, adding Chou’s draw,
Rotating the altar’s work in cycles of ebb and flow.
The elixir, ninefold turned, shines like a pearl’s glow,
Its light illumines a thousand mountains where jade trees grow.

On Peng Isle, the touch of stone startles feathered guests,
In the dusty world, the teaching spreads to save the masses’ quests.
May I, life after life, hear the profound and arcane,
May all transformed beings embody the sagely heart’s domain.

May the deeply ill rise, white bones restored to breath,
With a shout, break the iron locks—ghostly souls ascend from death!"*

When the hymn of praise and vows was complete, all the immortals bowed and withdrew.

**Chapter Four: The Formless and the Empty**

*"Those who begin the cultivation of the True must temporarily extinguish worldly illusions. The bustle of mundane affairs and the hundred thoughts in turmoil—when first sitting within the round enclosure, settle the mind and conceal the breath. If the work does not circulate smoothly, blockages will arise in the joints, stagnation in the blood, and qi obstruction. Though one may return the light, the illumination will fall into emptiness; though one may lay the foundation, the foundation will lack elixir’s fullness. Fullness resides in the mysterious breast—when the Mysterious Female is unobstructed, every aperture relies on it, every cavity bears its function. All who wish to cultivate the True must depart from all suffering and vexation. At the time before the sun rises in the Yang Valley, this is called 'passing the gate between man and ghost.'"*

Dragon-Brow Immortal said: *"The Great Medicine is the root of the elixir—within the body, the hour of man and ghost."* At this time, one may:
breath settles of itself,
silent and still,
the ten thousand spirits grow tranquil,
following nature’s course.
Then jade nectar fills the mouth, alive and flowing;
with intent, swallow it down,
the Tower of Nine Chambers draws it upward,
through the palate’s hum, it gradually reaches the Central Cavern,
the Middle Stomach’s tube refines the divine radiance in an instant.
The ten thousand images grow still.
Part the legs to the kidneys,
the great toes’ wheels turn,
entering the Bubbling Spring, reaching the heels,
ascending the thighs,
the Tailbone joins the root,
passing the Kidney Hall,
the spine splits in two, conveying it to the shoulders.
The shoulders’ wheels turn,
from the cheeks to the back of the brain,
pouring into the Crown,
then descending to the Bright Hall, the upper palate’s ridge to meet it.
Circulating through the palms,
all converges and halts,
the Mysterious Breast comes to rest.
One revolution completes the turning;
once the turning is sufficient,
the Supreme Ultimate merges as one.
Each revolution follows thus,
after nine revolutions, the elixir is formed.
Let me turn and turn at will—
this lies in refining the form.
Refining the form has five methods:
golden liquor refines the form,
jade liquor refines the form,
Great Yin refines the form,
Great Yang refines the form,
contemplating the mind refines the form.
Only *"One"* is not transmitted—
*"One"* is called *"True Emptiness Refines the Form."*

The Lord of the Dao said: *"Set the body aside, and the body is cultivated; forget the form, and the form endures."*
The *Classic of Purity* says: *"Inwardly observe the heart—heart is no-heart; outwardly observe the form—form is no-form."*
No-form, form is empty;
no-heart, heart is empty.
Heaven and earth are empty,
the primordial is empty,
emptiness is empty,
hell is empty,
man and ghost are empty.
Let being and non-being alternate—
nowhere to pursue or grasp.
By this, one attains long years,
life’s span boundless.

Great Master Hongren said: *"One who moves the body is like moving a jar.
Stand outside the jar, and jar and body live;
enter the jar, and jar and body die."*
For only through emptiness can the perishing be reborn;
without emptiness, the living perish.
He also said *"Shatter empty space"*—
for this empty space:
before encountering the realm, it inherently possesses the body of shattering,
no need to set intent or seek further shattering of this empty space.
After encountering the realm, if the body of shattering is lost,
simply still the heart in darkness, restoring its shattered state.
These are all secrets of *"True Emptiness Refines the Form."*

The Fourth Patriarch said: *"All afflictions and karmic obstructions are originally quiescent and empty."*
The Sixth Patriarch said: *"The ordinary being is Buddha; afflictions are bodhi.
The prior thought deluded is the ordinary being;
the later thought awakened is Buddha.
The prior thought attached to the realm is affliction;
the later thought detached from the realm is bodhi."*
An ancient immortal said: *"If you can empty the illusory body, the Vajra will not destroy the self."*
The Perfected of Purple Yang said: *"Swallow one grain of the numinous elixir into the belly, and you will know your fate is not ruled by heaven."*
He also said: *"When karmic obstructions become quiescent and empty, even Yama will let me live."*
The trouble for people lies only in this body’s failure to be empty.

A sack of pus and blood, ever departing and returning, tossed through kalpas by the howling black winds. Thus did the ancient Buddhas and former immortals—those of true attainment—speak invariably of emptiness!

Now, in Ezhou, I expound to my disciples the profound and subtle, the luminous and boundless. The great Dao of immortals and Buddhas is revealed within this scripture.

You, my disciples, must believe, receive, and delve deeply, pulverizing the bodily form and smelting the void. Know that the great Dao is none other than true emptiness!

When a thought arises, it is illusory form; when a thought ceases, it is true emptiness. What is the visage of true emptiness? Like ice melted into still water.

The Immortal Master finished expounding the scripture. At that moment, auspicious qi soared into the sky, rare fragrance filled the chamber, and the assembled immortals bowed in reverence before withdrawing.

Then the Perfected of Jade Clarity stepped forth and praised:

Dead nature gives rise to living mechanism,
Guarding life in the hidden breath of the void.
In the end, not a single thing remains—
Stillness quiets ten thousand cares.

By emptying, the yellow sprout grows long;
By voiding, the true seed of wisdom.
Dragon and tiger harmonize and unite,
Male and female form their marriage.

To seize the cold jade spirit,
Seize this moment of yin-yang harmony.
Conceive a chaos-round,
Refine it in the indistinct and subtle.

Unbroken through cold and heat,
Silent and ever thus—
Split open the Taiji diagram,
Transcend the Four Greats within.

The golden body shines resplendent,
Luminous as heaven and earth.
The true secret of immortals and Buddhas—
Who knows the delight therein?

No thing can bind,
The Five Phases cannot restrain.
Attaining immortality is no second art—
Sage and human share the same qi.

The Master now bestows this teaching,
To widely deliver the benighted.
Bowing before the Dharma seat,
May all long uphold and preserve it.

**Fifth Stage: Emergence from the Womb as a Yang Being**

When the fire-tending is complete and the true embryo is ready to be born, the infant within the womb, nurtured long and full, reaches ten months and emerges from its sac. Rising from the Great Mystery into the Heavenly Valley, this is called the "True Person"—the so-called "Master"—whom the Buddha terms the "ādept" and the Daoists call the "infant," the "true seed."

When the infant undergoes the transition of womb and cauldron, piercing the Pass of the Great Mystery, splitting open the Gate of Dryness, the divine light surges forth with thunderous roars. Turning the body, it leaps out and dwells in the mysterious qi cavern, opening yet another chaos.

This cavern is the crucial pass for immortals to shed their womb and settle their breath, the place where the infant establishes life and destiny—a familiar realm, the natural path of return.

Once the Red Child is securely settled in the quiet domain, seated in the Dao sanctuary, one must guard and nurture it with utmost care. First, it is nourished by the yellow sprout of the Kun Mother; then, it gathers the generative qi of heaven and earth to feed upon. This resonance brings near and reveals far.

Within, the Red Child—with every breath, rise, and fall, every coming and going, every movement and stillness—acts with perfect spontaneity. One must observe the mind and eliminate delusion until, at the end of water and the limit of mountains, not a trace of guest-dust or affliction remains. Then, the tranquil and luminous true constancy becomes unobstructed and free. The infant within the mysterious aperture attains great peace.

Nurturing the infant is the foremost task of immortal cultivation. Do not let it be assailed by external conditions or disturbed by inner delusion. Whether walking, standing, sitting, or lying down, never forget it for a moment; in speech or silence, movement or stillness, never neglect it in the slightest. Like a dragon guarding its pearl or a mother cherishing her child, day and night, waking and sleeping, one must vigilantly protect it. Guard the Pass of Origin strictly, never allowing it to wander lightly forth, lest it lose its way upon departure and forget to return.

After years of maturation and nine years of cultivation, spiritual penetrations and transformations will naturally arise. The yang spirit emerges, true emptiness is realized, and the indestructible Vajra body is attained—a being coeval with heaven and earth.

Having ascended the immortal ranks and mingled with the mortal dust, one bestows the Dharma-milk, extends sincere devotion, draws in later learners, and universally ferries sentient beings. When the three thousand deeds are fulfilled and the eight hundred merits complete, a decree is proclaimed in the cinnabar script, and a white crane arrives to welcome. Borne by feathered chariots, golden light dazzles, rare fragrance wafts, celestial music resounds, the Xiang River maiden plucks her zither, jade maidens play their flutes. To the left, crimson tassels; to the right, rainbow banners. Ascending the golden palace, one returns together to the Primordial Azure.

The Immortal Master finished expounding the scripture.

The assembled immortals bowed their heads in reverence, all filled with great joy.

Then the Perfected Immortal Guiying stepped forward, hands clasped in solemn respect, and praised:
*"Expounding the scriptures to cross the kalpas,
grace pervades the ten directions.
All divine immortals and celestial youths,
in ranks aligned, with one voice extol.
Cranes dance and phoenixes soar,
purple qi suffuses the vast expanse."*

When the *Five Ranks* merits were accomplished, the disciples at the altar reverently thanked the Emperor’s grace, devoutly kowtowed to the True Immortals and Divine Kings, and withdrew in faith.

---

**Appendix: The Transmission of Master Fu**

Master Fu of the Hermitage of Perfected Rest was a native of Jiangxia. Simple and unadorned, he eschewed literary embellishment. Skilled in medicine, he loved the Dao and deeply admired Ancestor Lü. Dwelling outside Wu Sheng Gate, he befriended nearby companions—Chen Yuanfang, Du Guoxiang, Liu Jiuji, and others—with whom he formed a Lüzu Society to invoke the planchette. Half a *li* east of the city walls stood a hermitage named "Hermitage of Perfected Rest," facing Sha Lake and backed by Phoenix Mountain. When the waters rose, a thousand acres turned jade-green; when they receded, one could walk beneath the willows along the embankment to reach the hermitage. Fu and his fellow devotees often gathered there for refined assemblies.

Earlier, Ancestor Lü, wandering through Chu, saw purple qi illuminating the sky above the northeastern corner of the provincial capital and knew an accomplished one dwelt there. In the *jiwei* year of the Kangxi reign (1679), the Ancestor followed the congealed purple radiance and descended upon the planchette. Fu’s karmic roots from a past life were unknown even to himself, nor had the Ancestor revealed them.

One day, as the assembly gathered, Fu was reprimanded by the altar-monitoring Master Xiong for some matter. Fu accepted the rebuke without protest. Soon after, the Ancestor arrived and had not yet finished expounding the scriptures when he was summoned by the Supreme Emperor. The Emperor addressed the Ancestor: *"I have a Dao-companion, an ancient Buddha from the Western Heaven, who has come to the Southern Continent to ferry beings across for over eight hundred years. He now attends your planchette, yet your subordinates, unaware, have mistakenly punished him. Hasten to inform them."*

The Ancestor returned to the altar and severely rebuked Master Xiong, then secretly conveyed the essentials through the sand tray. Fu instantly awakened, though his realization remained unspoken. When he descended the hall to offer thanks, the Ancestor dared not accept his obeisance, ultimately receiving but a single bow.

Later, Fu entered samadhi and traversed the universe—now in celestial palaces, now in the Western Lands—his spiritual marvels too numerous to recount. Here are but one or two examples: A member of the assembly, childless, prayed to the Ancestor and bore a son. When the boy, several years old, fell gravely ill with smallpox, the family beseeched Fu in distress. He petitioned the Ancestor: *"Having already granted them a child, why now reduce the household to wailing?"* That very night, the Heavenly Marshal Wang appeared, seized the Smallpox Spirit, and struck him. By the next day, the boy had recovered and came to the altar to express his gratitude.

Furthermore, the *Seven-Rank Immortal Scripture of the Planchette Emperor* was expounded by Emperor Wen at the Supreme Emperor’s command, with the Ancestor assisting. After each rank was completed, it was sent to Fu for review. Noting that Emperor Wen had altered some of the original phrasing, Fu remarked, *"The original text was entirely fine."* Upon hearing this, Emperor Wen immediately deleted his revisions and restored the original. Such was the reverence Ancestor Lü and Emperor Wen held for him!

Fu once told others: *"The two Buddhas of the West have manifested as commoners in the southern countryside. Whoever is destined will encounter them."* He also said: *"In the future, more Buddhist scriptures will be expounded."* Thus, Han San and other Daoist companions urgently entreated the Ancestor to petition the Buddha to reveal them. The *True Pointers of the Chan School*, now transmitted, is the result.

Fu also stated: *"In the West lies a Golden Lotus Treasure Terrace, which one may ascend only after five hundred years."* The assembly at Hermitage of Perfected Rest all took him as their teacher, and even Han San often sought his guidance.

Later, during a severe drought in Fujian, Fu, moved by the suffering, projected his spirit to bring relief. The crops sprang to life, yielding a harvest. The Supreme Emperor, deeming him to have overstepped his authority, specially petitioned Baolin Monastery to transfer him to the Western Lands. Summoned back by the Buddha, he wrote a farewell poem before departing:
*"Eight hundred autumns since entering the Southern Realm,
scarcely a moment passed—
wife and children wept in a circle,
then he cast aside his brush and departed."*

Formerly, while his physical form remained, his investiture was not included in the scriptures. After his return to the West, however, other scriptures recorded his investiture, placing it after the proclamation of the Supreme Emperor, as follows:
*"The Great Heavenly Honored One of Silent Sovereignty."*

Han San, before ascending the palace, once convened a grand assembly in Qian and Chu, returning but once more. Whenever major gatherings occurred, the Ancestor commanded that memorials be prepared to convey sincerity. Today, his descendants continue to recite scriptures at Hermitage of Perfected Rest during sacred festivals without cease.

A Traveling Daoist remarked: *"How extraordinary was Master Fu’s coming and going! Descending from the Western Lands, he passed through several lifetimes and a thousand years, yet the Golden Lotus Treasure Terrace must await a transformation five hundred years hence before ascending—how distant it remains! Is this not what is meant by the ephemeral mayfly in heaven and earth, the fleeting dawn and dusk of antiquity and modernity? My friend Song Ticheng once followed Master Fu and observed that in life, he was utterly unassuming, no different from any other man. Yet therein lay his distinction!"*

*The Three-Rank Immortal Scripture* (Scrolls 13, 14, 15)

**Preface to *The Supreme Three-Rank Dao of Qingwei, the Mysterious and Wondrous Canon of Unified Harmony, the Mahāyāna Sutra of Transcending Kalpas* (Upper Scroll)**
Sections One through Six

**Preface to *The Supreme Three-Rank Dao of Qingwei, the Mysterious and Wondrous Canon of Unified Harmony, the Mahāyāna Sutra of Transcending Kalpas* (Middle Scroll)**

**Preface to *The Supreme Three-Rank Dao of Qingwei, the Mysterious and Wondrous Canon of Unified Harmony, the Mahāyāna Sutra of Transcending Kalpas* (Lower Scroll)**

**Brief Preface to the Three-Rank Scripture**
I had never before studied the books of the Two Teachings [Daoism and Buddhism]. In the year *jiayin* [1614], I first obtained *The Three-Rank Scripture* as expounded by Ancestor Lü and read it with a deep sigh: *"Without this, I would have idly passed my life in vain!"* The scripture comprises three scrolls, every line composed in four-character verses. Even in longer passages, when divided, each segment remains a four-character phrase—like a boundless spring gushing forth wherever it flows, or the waters of the Yellow River, rising from the heavens, winding through a thousand bends, yet surging straight into the sea. Such a work could scarcely be the product of mortal effort. Its profound exploration of heaven and humanity, its synthesis of Confucianism and Buddhism, and its revelation of the Three Clarities within the human body—these are its most wondrous truths. Formerly, Master Song [Zizhen] prefaced *The Doctrine of the Mean*, saying: *"Among all the books of the former sages, none so clearly and thoroughly grasp the essential principles and unveil the profound mysteries as this."* I say the same of *The Three-Rank Scripture*.

**Preface to the Qingwei Three-Rank Scripture**
*The Three-Rank Scripture of Qingwei* was expounded by Ancestor Lü. Gu Xingshu, a scholar of Jiangxia, along with his fellow student Song Ticheng, and friends Wu Yishu, Qiao Yishu, and Gongshu, had long been close companions. They had often gathered to invite planchette divination and earnestly sought Ancestor Lü’s presence. As Xingshu was skilled in playing the zither, one day, as his melody neared its end, a transcendent descended. Upon inquiry, it was revealed to be Ancestor Lü. His poetic verses were ethereal, free from the dust of the world, and his brush moved as swiftly as flight. When tested with matters of verification, all present were astonished and convinced. Soon after, he issued a decree to expound *The Three-Rank Scripture*, which commenced at the upper chamber of the Song residence. At that time, those drawn by the Dao who arrived included the prefectural scholars Lu Sishu, Yu Shenshu, and Yelü Jinshu; fellow student Yang Chuanshu; the scholars of Hanyang, Fu Jingshu; the scholars of Jiangxia, Yin Youshu and Tongshu, along with their younger brother Weishu; and later, Lu Xunshu, Wang Zunshu, Ma Mushu, and An Yicheng, who all gathered to assist. As the Song residence proved too cramped, they relocated to the Qiao residence. However, the expounding of sacred scriptures was a weighty affair, and the cloud chariot’s majesty was solemn. The noise and dust of a private dwelling risked impropriety, so they selected a site for an altar in the northeast corner of the city, securing the former residence of Chen Taishi Dazhang of Xiling. Chen, being a relative by marriage to the Yin family, heard of the matter and joyfully offered his support, contributing the original funds to aid in the construction. Those who assembled at that time—such as An Hengshu, Li Wushu, Song Zhenshu, Wang Xingshu, Qian Nengshu, and Chen Chongcheng—all vied to donate, gathering labor and materials. Within a year, the halls and pavilions were completed in succession, known as *"The Three Palaces Embracing the Dao."*

When the upper scroll was being expounded, the regulations were not yet established. Only after relocating the altar to the palace were rules and precedents instituted: some served as officiants of the altar, some recited scriptures at the imperial altar, some managed memorials and petitions, some collated the meanings of characters, and some attended to incense, candles, and alms for the poor and destitute—all diligently fulfilling their duties. From the year *renwu* [1622] to *jiashen* [1644], the sacred text was finally completed. Two sets of woodblocks for printing were carved: one sent to Mount Wudang, the other stored in the palace. In the year *renchen* [1652], the printing was completed, and the celestial work was brought to fruition. Thereafter, the immortal scripture spread far and wide, and none failed to revere it as a model. After Prefect Sun Shoushu of Shangyuan, numerous others commissioned re-carvings in convenient formats.

Formerly, the Buddha told Śāriputra: *"Such a wondrous dharma is spoken by the Tathāgatas only when the time is ripe. It was not spoken before because the time had not yet come."* Confucius said: *"When the time is to stop, stop; when the time is to act, act. In movement and stillness, if one does not lose the proper time, the Dao will be luminous."* Truly, the expounding of scriptures by immortals and buddhas, and the establishment of teachings by sages, are never apart from the proper time. I fear that the names of the good and faithful who first undertook this work for *The Three-Rank Scripture* may fade into obscurity over the long passage of time. Thus, I have recorded these details in full to preface the scripture.

Respectfully composed by Huang Chengshu of Shayi, a Traveling Daoist.

**Decree of Appointment for Ancestor Lü’s Advancement to the Rank of Supreme Mystery**
The Lord of Myriad Celestial Stars, the Northern Pole Purple Tenuity Great Emperor, by the command of the Primordial Beginning, decrees:
*"We regard you, the Pure Yang Daoist, Perfected Lü Yan, who has endured three thousand arduous practices and accomplished the ninefold mystery of merit. You have broadly extended your compassion to save beings from kalpas and universally ferried them across on the vessel of mercy; you have opened the transformation of awakening the world and frequently bestowed the precious raft of teachings. In the southeast, you have propagated the Dao and its methods, elucidating the secrets of prior heaven; in the region of Ying and Zhen, you have expounded scriptures and revealed the essence of the Supreme Ultimate. Now that this sacred task is complete, We hereby confer upon you this decree of honor: We specially advance you to the rank of True Sovereign of the Jade Clarity, where the Dao attains its ultimate non-action, and you are most mysterious and sagely, holding the balance of the ten thousand kalpas. As the Perfected of Universal Response and Transformation, you are the patriarch of the Three Teachings, the Supreme Mystery Vast Law Heavenly Worthy, the Perfectly Penetrating Literary Vimalakīrti True Buddha. Receive this appointment and redouble your efforts in the mystery of merit. We further bestow upon you this auspicious decree: We appoint your attendant, the Willow Banner of the Guardians of the Dao, to assist in your mysterious merit and attend to the expounding of sacred tasks. We advance and appoint you as the Left Assistant of Primordial Transformation, the Supreme and Unsurpassed August One, the Jade Pivot Right Minister, the True Lord of Vast Teachings. We further confer this decree of honor: We appoint your Supreme Dharma Protector, Ge Mingyang; We advance and appoint him as the Nine Heavens’ Propagator of Transformation, the Supreme Controller of the Five Thunders, the Overseer of Immortal Registers who examines merits and demerits for promotion and demotion, the Commander-in-Chief of the Dragon Kings who bring rain over rivers and lakes, the Divine Lord who assists in transformation and propagates the Dao, the Heavenly Worthy of Myriad Dharmas Penetrating the Mystery. These two ministers together aid in the work of Primordial Transformation. Alas! Perfected Lü, your merits are boundless, and your transformations extend to distant lands. May you further manifest the ancestral wind of virtue and power, and may you ever uphold the supreme rank of the mystery. Obey this decree!"*

**Preface to the Three Grades of the Qingwei Scripture**
*Compiled by Wuwozi Liu Tishu of Yiling; collated by his son Liu Yincheng and nephew Liu Yuncheng Qingxu; jointly proofread by Shaxian Yixingzi Huang Chengshu*

I have heard that the Great Dao is wordless, and the supreme words are without ornament. Words that are adorned with ornament are mere ornament, not the supreme words of the world; the Dao that is spoken is mere speech, not the supreme Dao of the world. The Dao originally has no use for words, and words originally have no need for ornament. Ornament serves to adorn words, and words serve to express ornament—what has this to do with the Dao? What purpose do words serve? What use is ornament?

Yet words without ornament cannot travel far; the Dao without words cannot be transmitted through the ages. To transmit the Dao, one must employ words; for words to be transmitted, one must rely on ornament. Ornament cannot be dispensed with, nor can words.

However, when words are adorned with ornament, and ornament proliferates into myriad sounds, the ornament loses its substance, and the words become hollow and empty, devoid of truth. To speak of the Dao with empty words is to obscure the Dao through speech; to adorn words with insubstantial ornament is to obscure the words through ornament. Thus, words cannot do without ornament, nor can the Dao do without words. What is detestable about words is speech that deviates from the Dao; what is detestable about ornament is writing that departs from the classics. If ornament departs from the classics, the supreme words are obscured; if speech deviates from the Dao, the supreme Dao is concealed!

Today, the Great Dao of the world is unclear, and a swarm of words has arisen. Those who cling to sects and schools, stealing names and titles, all employ absurd and baseless words, crafting abstruse and convoluted texts to adorn their vulgar and ignoble heterodoxies—impossible to fathom or refute. As a result, sagely teachings go unheeded, and the Great Dao is obstructed. I grieve deeply over this!

To refute heterodox teachings and propagate sagely words, to reject perverse conduct and defend the true Dao, one must rely on those who illuminate the Dao. Only those who have thoroughly grasped the essence of the Great Dao and penetrated the subtleties of supreme words can correct the errors of perverse speech with their words and rectify the wrongs of heterodox ways with their Dao. Who am I? Who am I?

How dare I shoulder such a task! Yet with the prevailing malady grown deep and the moral current daily declining, I have fortunately glimpsed but a fraction of this Dao—how could I not expound its subtle words to illuminate the Way, rather than allow the raging torrent of heterodoxies to swell ever stronger, leaving the Great Dao obscured? Though my words be crude and unadorned, insufficient to radiate the splendor of the supreme Dao, in spreading the imperial grace, regulating the mechanisms of transformation, and reversing the course of kalpas, they may yet offer some small aid.

Thus, in the year *renwu*, I chanced upon the summer solstice and descended upon the Han San Altar. There, I took my own humble discourse, harmonized the essential principles of the Three Teachings, and expounded this text to guide later learners.

I have peered into the origins of the Dao: at the first stirrings of the primordial, when the Supreme Polarity first divided, movement became yang and stillness yin. One yin, one yang—thus the Great Dao is named; root yin, root yang—from them the Five Phases arise. Only humans and things are shaped by the formless transformations. The principle of the Supreme Polarity, the essence of the Two and Five, intermingles and fuses—all transformations are wondrous thereby.

Confucianism follows this Dao, Daoism follows this Dao, Buddhism follows this Dao—how can they be divided? Grasping this purport, the Two are One, without rank or hierarchy.

Moreover, those who enter the world serve as the assistants of Heaven and Earth, establish destiny for all beings, uphold the moral order, and embody the heart of creation. Thus, those who transcend the world rely on these worldly ones for protection. Yet those who transcend the world unfold the primordial transformations, preside over kalpas, save and deliver the deluded masses, and adorn the supreme governance—so too do worldly ones depend on the transcendent to harmonize and regulate. They cannot be viewed in isolation, nor mocked, nor discarded. Why then erect barriers and raise banners, only to turn kin against one another?

The ancient sages and worthies transmitted secret texts—profound in their Dao, pure in their words, and wondrous in their phrasing—all of which I fall short of. Yet while each expounded their own path, none synthesized them into a unified discourse. Thus, I have gathered the essential principles of the Three Teachings to compose these words. Is this Dao? Is this literature? It is merely the discourse of one school.

You, scholars, who apply your minds to inquiry and directly perceive the wondrous Dao of the beginningless, may proceed from what my words have touched upon to seek what they have not; from the Dao that can be spoken, to awaken to the Dao that cannot. Do not merely regard my words as literature, nor view them as mere text. Do not merely seek the Dao through words, nor confine my Dao within language and script. May the most wondrous and subtle Dao flourish thereby, and all perverse conduct, licentious rhetoric, and heterodox teachings fade away without need for refutation. In clearing the thorns from the ancestral gate and sweeping the overgrowth from the Great Dao, shall not the merit be great? This is the original intent of my words, and the fundamental purpose of this teaching—may you scholars reverently uphold it.

---

**The Supreme Wondrous Scripture of the Three Grades of Qingwei, the Peerless and Mysterious Canon of the Great Vehicle for Deliverance from Kalpas, Volume One**

At that time, the Wondrous Primordial Vast Dharma Heavenly Worthy, in the Jade Clarity Sacred Realm, within the Qingwei Palace, together with the various Great Heavenly Worthies, the Limitless Divine Kings, and the Flying Celestial Great Saints, approached the seat of the Primordial Beginning. There, they reviewed the kalpas and examined the wondrous charts.

The Heavenly Worthy, pitying the sentient beings below whose evil karma was excessive and whose kalpic destiny was grave, sighed deeply. Then, with resolute demeanor, he stepped forth from the ranks, bowed reverently, and addressed the Primordial Beginning Heavenly Worthy, saying:

"Below, sentient beings are ruled by guest qi, erecting barriers and establishing factions, slandering and attacking one another. As a result, all the ignorant and foolish follow suit without restraint, so that successive kalpic calamities persist unceasingly. Your servant now wishes to expound subtle words repeatedly to enlighten the followers of the Three Teachings, that they may all understand the principle of different paths converging in the same destination. Perhaps then these beings will cease to create obstacles and slightly preserve the true lineage.

Moreover, those who cultivate the Dao err in clinging to stale doctrines, employing misguided and erroneous practices that confuse their numinous minds, ultimately losing their root. Your servant has now, in accordance with my own understanding, gathered and selected past teachings to compose the *Three Grades* of wondrous truths, serving as a single lamp in a pitch-dark room, that ascending as immortals or attaining Buddhahood may be realized in an instant of awakening. I humbly inquire whether this is the opportune moment to present it. May the sagely compassion descend a jade decree."

The Primordial Heavenly Worthy said: "Excellent! Excellent! As you have spoken, you now vow with such resolve to expound the Dharma widely for all beings—this is truly unparalleled, the supreme merit and virtue. I shall now expound for you; listen carefully.

All these beings cling to their fixed views. Only through repeated and detailed elucidation, guiding them with patience and care, can each being come to clearly understand the causes and conditions within. In accordance with your request, I shall send down to the lower realms those who are sincere and tireless in their efforts, who collaborate to achieve success. Thirty kinds of beings shall be delivered and attain the supreme wondrous fruit, ranked among the celestial hosts, sharing the same station as the Golden Immortals in the Great Veil. Those who exert themselves and render service shall each receive blessings, so that in the beginning they remain unstained, and in the end they bear no burdens, all attaining their desires as they wish. You must strive diligently in this."

Thereupon, in the year of *jiashen*, the Heavenly Worthy opened the altar and established the precepts, expounding the sacred scriptures to all disciples. The Heavenly Worthy said:

"Within the human body, there are only essence, qi, and spirit—these three are called the Three Treasures. All attainment of the sagely and the effortless arises from them. Though these Three Treasures originate from the postnatal, few understand their inconceivable nature. Even in the prenatal, none may lose them. To lose these Three Treasures is to be unable to embody the effortless, thus obscuring the prenatal.

What is meant by the prenatal? It is not merely the effortless, nor the effortless effort, nor the utmost non-effort, nor the non-effort of non-effort, but the non-non-non—only such non-non is the prenatal. Yet this prenatal pervades all things. With the prenatal, the postnatal arises. Every thing’s prenatal is the one prenatal; this one prenatal becomes the prenatal of each, and each distinct prenatal forms the postnatal. Once the postnatal is formed, the Three Treasures are obtained, and thus the human being is complete.

Now contemplate the Three Treasures:

The first is called *essence*.
What is essence? In heaven, it is the Milky Way, the radiance of the sun, moon, and stars, rain and dew, hail and sleet, snow and frost, and mist. On earth, it is water, rivers and streams, the vast seas, springs and wells, reservoirs and pools, the veins of mountains and marshes, and the marrow within stone. In humans, it is essence—the root of life and nature, the blood and flesh of the body, the gums of the teeth.

The second is called *qi*.
What is qi? In heaven, it is substance, form, and appearance, yin and yang, the movements of the sun, moon, and stars, their waxing and waning, the five-colored clouds, rosy clouds and mist, the dense and the ethereal, the heart of living things, transformation and nurturance. On earth, it is virtue and power, the foundation that sustains all, the stem of the myriad things, the origins of mountains and waters, generation and destruction, emergence and concealment, the rise and fall of worldly kalpas, the sprouting of buds and shoots. In humans, it is qi—the movement of the limbs, actions and bearing, voice and brightness, scent and hearing, the commands of the body, the threshold of life and death.

The third is called *spirit*.
What is spirit? In heaven, it is the pivot, the true sovereign, the silent operation, the numinous essence of the sun, moon, and stars, the wind that stirs all things, thunder and lightning, compassion and awe, the work of creation, the origin of living things. On earth, it is potential, contraction and expansion, the forms of the myriad kinds, mountains and rivers, tranquility and stillness, the stabilizing foundation, peace and benevolence. In humans, it is spirit—the light in the eyes, the thoughts of the heart, wisdom and insight, innate knowledge and ability, the embryo of cinnabar and mercury, the governor of essence and qi, awakening and realization, the origin of the bodily frame, the basis of longevity or early death.

Such are the Three Treasures—difficult to obtain. Since they are not easily gained, how can one fail to cherish and protect them? To protect and cherish them, the work lies in purity and stillness: do not agitate the essence, nor allow it to leak; abide in the original dwelling, truly thus and unchanging. In the span of a day and night, it circulates 360 degrees and returns to the original dwelling, unchanging and unmoving, serving as the resource for elixir and lead.

Yet what is called *essence* is all gathered by *qi*. If qi scatters outward, essence will dissipate. Thus, to secure essence, one must guard qi. How to guard qi? It is essential to be desireless, clear and empty, tranquil and still, without contrivance. What is called *qi* resides only within the square inch of the *xuan* pass. Nurture it with tranquility, always at ease; its qi will be vast and boundless, chaotic and undifferentiated, pervading without gap—thus, thus.

Only then, below, will it unite with essence without obstruction, merging like water and milk into one. The great elixir’s ingredients gradually become complete. Then, apply the fire and timing, enter the crucible, and achieve the work.

What is *fire and timing*? It is the spirit. For essence cannot be gathered without qi, and essence and qi cannot be moved without spirit. Thus, to secure essence and nurture qi lies in preserving the spirit. The work of preserving the spirit lies in cutting off thoughts: within, nothing arises; without, nothing enters. All omens are abandoned; silent and empty, one is serene and fused, utterly still and without cause. Preserve it thus, and the spirit abides in its palace.

What is the *spirit palace*? It is only the cinnabar palace. Once the cinnabar palace is secured, the spirit becomes still and focused, governing essence and qi to congeal the great elixir. Its form is like an infant, returning to one’s own appearance, with skin, hair, and body all perfectly complete. Then, one exits through the gate and roams the Three Realms. In a single breath, one traverses the ten directions without obstruction, at ease and self-content, beyond all conception.

Yet if one clings to this alone, without hearing the great Dao or encountering a true person, the three disasters will come to erode and consume."

Should one fail to awaken, all accomplishments crumble to naught.

What are the three disasters?
The first is the *"Gale of the Celestial Axis."* This gale is sharp as a blade, keen as an awl. It pierces the gate, and in but three moments, threads through every joint, straight to the *Yongquan* point. Limbs and body, hair and skin—all dissolve at once, unraveling into drifting filaments, adrift without anchor.

Yet even this gale cannot erode one who has attained such power.
Then comes the *"Poison Fire,"* rising from below, surging through the crown gate, scorching the viscera, searing the limbs, singeing hair and pores. In a single breath, all turns to ash.

Even this fire and wind bring no harm to one of such attainment—such mastery may indeed be called supreme.
But without hearing the Dao, the *"Five Thunders"* arrive, each leading their legions, clashing in mutual assault. Before the Dao is heard, in an instant, spirit scatters to the four directions, never to coalesce again.

Thus, the great Dao cannot be left unplumbed. Without plumbing the Dao, one cannot escape the three disasters! All Three Treasures become as naught.
