Only the enlightened adept, knowing these words, takes up gourd and straw hat, traversing mountains and rivers to seek the perfected ones, that they may expound the great Dao and forever evade the three disasters.

Yet this great Dao is most difficult to speak of. Precisely because it is difficult to speak of, one must peer into the beginningless. The beginning of the beginningless, the utmost *wu* (non-being) of the beginningless, the *wu-wu* (non-non-being) of the beginningless—this is the *xiantian* (prior Heaven). The Dao of prior Heaven cannot be conceived or discussed. If it cannot be conceived or discussed, how can it be spoken of? Yet though it cannot be spoken of, it is spoken of. To whom is it spoken, and from what does it arise?

That which can be spoken of pertains only to *youwei* (deliberate action). What is *youwei*? It is to attain through *wu* (non-being). For this *wuwei* (non-action) is the beginning of *you* (being).

What is meant by *youwei*? How does one cultivate it?
To cultivate it, one must consult the *Heart Monarch*.
The *Heart Monarch* possesses great awakening.
Observe yin and yang, their movements and transformations:
Emulate the sun, modeling its firmness and motion;
Emulate the moon, mastering its waxing and waning.
Extending this to the four seasons, one grasps their cycles, silently aligning with the *Taiji* (Supreme Ultimate).
Tracing back to their origin, through such broad observation of all creation, one sits in profound stillness, where only the *ming qi* (luminous qi) remains, and in that stillness, it alone abides.

Then, within the heart, nothing remains—all that was nurtured, the great elixir congealed, the infantine self, is in communion with Heaven and Earth.
Yet one must widely seek the guidance of the perfected. Without encountering a true person to reveal the subtleties, the great Dao remains obscure. Even if some clarity arises, it is but skin-deep! The profound mysteries within remain unattained. Without grasping these mysteries, how can one claim to understand the great Dao?

Thus, the great Dao must be sought through true transmission.
This true transmission has its lineage. A single touch in the dark—suddenly, all becomes lucid. Once lucid, one penetrates the profound. Having penetrated the profound, one knows the great Dao.

To name this knowing is to have attained it. Attaining this utmost profundity, one may then abide in *wuwei*.
Yet even when mastery is achieved, one must accumulate merit:
Some perform three thousand deeds, some fifteen hundred, some a thousand, some five hundred—when such rounds are complete, each attains their rightful fruit.
After accumulating merit, one must then establish merit:
Some establish a thousand deeds, some eight hundred, some five hundred, some three hundred, some a hundred and fifty, some a hundred—when such merit and deeds are complete and fulfilled, each attains their rightful fruit.

Those of great merit and deeds attain great karmic fruits:
Some become golden immortals, ranked among the celestial hosts;
Some remain in the world of men, masters of the ten thousand dharmas;
Some dwell in the Three Isles, enjoying pure and tranquil blessings.

Those of lesser merit and deeds may still abide in the *Daluo* Heaven as *wuwei* immortals, carefree and joyous, or dwell in famous mountains, or wander the impure realms as patriarchs of the Dao.

Those of shallow merit and deeds remain among springs and stones, beyond birth and extinction, forever free from the three disasters.

Thus, though the hearing of the Dao may differ in timing, there is no distinction of difficulty or ease. The rightful fruit attained depends solely on one’s merit and deeds. Each accumulates merit and deeds according to their capacity and attains their corresponding fruit.

Yet to attain fruit, one must hear the great Dao.
To hear the great Dao, one must revere the Three Treasures.
Without the Three Treasures, long life cannot be secured.
With limited years, if one’s cultivation is not deeply rooted, one may never hear the great Dao in this lifetime. Without hearing the great Dao, what has been accumulated? All such accumulation is not of great merit. Without establishing grand works or fulfilling great deeds, to suddenly aspire to sagehood and attain the great Dao is as if one had gained nothing!

Observe those who enter the Dao: they hasten with urgency, as if fearing they may not succeed, seeking the perfected ones far and wide to expound the profound mysteries. They brave perilous obstacles without fear, endure hardships without trembling, face water and fire without dread, confront demonic obstructions without confusion, and undergo all manner of trials and tribulations without regret.

Through such sincerity, the perfected ones above are moved to reveal the essentials, enabling complete awakening without hindrance. Returning to seated meditation, they silently cultivate their profound practice, gazing upward and downward, penetrating the profound, yet never ceasing. Though mingling in the dust of the world—amidst bustling markets and crowded streets—they perform myriad deeds, establish myriad merits, yet reflect that such deeds and merits may still be shallow.

Thus, they make grand vows, performing boundless deeds, establishing boundless merits, wishing that through countless kalpas, all sentient beings—knowing and unknowing—may hear the great Dao and reach the other shore. Such merit and deeds may require a thousand or ten thousand kalpas, yet remain inexhaustible. Only when such merit and deeds are fully accomplished does one attain the supreme, reaching *wuwei*, the utmost *wu-wuwei* (non-non-action). In this *wuwei*, one is coeval with Heaven and Earth, never to perish with them.

For this Heaven and Earth are both of *youwei*—of deliberate action. Where there is action, there must be an end. Heaven acts, and so Heaven ages; Earth acts, and so Earth decays. The Perfected One is of *wuwei*—since they are of *wuwei*, how could they decay or age? Before Heaven and Earth existed, this Perfected One endured; once Heaven and Earth arose, this Perfected One emerged. Though Heaven and Earth decay and age, this Perfected One remains at peace. Subtle! Subtle indeed! Such a Perfected One—even I cannot name them. Yet when one reaches the ultimate, every person is thus. Why is this so? Because of the Prior Heaven.

This Prior Heaven is possessed by all. Yet though people have it, most remain benighted—why is this? Because alongside Prior Heaven, there is also Posterior Heaven. Once Posterior Heaven arises, the Six Roots follow. With the Six Roots come the Six Consciousnesses.

What are the Six Roots?
The first is the eye-root: through it, one beholds forms and appearances, giving rise to manifold thoughts, thus obscuring the Prior Heaven.
The second is the ear-root: through it, one hears sounds, giving rise to manifold thoughts, thus obscuring the Prior Heaven.
The third is the mouth-root: through it, one utters right and wrong, giving rise to manifold thoughts, thus obscuring the Prior Heaven.
The fourth is the nose-root: through it, one smells scents and odors, giving rise to manifold thoughts, thus obscuring the Prior Heaven.
The fifth is the tongue-root: through it, one savors sweet and bitter, giving rise to manifold thoughts, thus obscuring the Prior Heaven.
The sixth is the body-root: through it, one encounters realms and conditions, giving rise to manifold thoughts, thus obscuring the Prior Heaven.

These Six Roots are called the Six Thieves. To hear the great Dao, one must first eliminate the Six Roots. If the Six Roots are not eliminated, they give rise to evil consciousnesses.

How, then, are the Six Roots to be eliminated? There was once a realized person who knew the path of elimination: regarding all perceptions and encounters, the conditions of the senses, they dwelled nowhere. They saw without the eyes, heard without the ears, sealed the mouth and restrained the tongue, passing the day like a fool. They breathed through the heels, rendering the body useless. All movements were directed by spirit. Thus, though the Six Roots remained fully intact, they were as if nonexistent. With no Six Roots, how could evil consciousnesses arise? Without evil consciousnesses, how could one fall into evil destinies?

Freed from consciousness and destiny, one is without obstruction; being without obstruction, the sovereign of the mind abides in perfect peace. When this sovereign of the mind is truly unstained, one may then set up the furnace and cast in the Three Treasures, thereby conjoining the Great Elixir. In this refining, one employs the Water within Kan, sprays the Wind of Xun, and moves the Fire of Li, uniting the Three Treasures—these three become one, and the Great Elixir is accomplished.

Once the Great Elixir is formed, Dragon and Tiger submit, yin and yang settle into their places. Yet one must also seek the guidance of exalted immortals, receiving their secret and subtle instructions to verify the fruit. As for those of lesser attainment, ignorant of the cause, they recklessly engage in fabrication, manipulating and refining with all manner of heterodox arts, drifting ever further from the Dao! Such misguided efforts invite manifold demonic obstructions, provoking the wrath of Heaven above and violating the laws of men below.

Even those who withdraw into seclusion, dwelling in mountain springs and among rocks, knowing these principles and refining qi to calm the spirit, gathering the Three Treasures to forge the Great Elixir—if their guidance is not true, they will ultimately suffer the Three Calamities. Thus is the great Dao most difficult to speak of. If even such as these cannot escape, how much less the common multitude!

Unaware of the great Dao, they disregard the Three Treasures. The Six Roots blaze ever brighter, the Seven Emotions stand fully revealed, and they treat the Three Treasures as if they were not their own.

Within the human body, there are only essence, qi, and spirit:
If one does not cherish essence, squandering it at will—like a leaking vessel into which a ladle of water is poured, bringing no increase, gradually draining away—before a single breath has passed, not a drop remains.
If one does not cherish qi, letting it scatter recklessly—like a petal of incense placed in a red-hot furnace, left to burn, with coals added—before a single breath has passed, it is reduced to ashes.
If one does not cherish spirit, letting it dissipate wantonly—like a lone lamp set before the wind, left to flicker without shelter—before a single breath has passed, it is extinguished.

Perilous! Perilous indeed!

Losing these Three Treasures is to lose one’s life, to fall into evil kalpas, revolving endlessly in cycles without cease. For us sentient beings, this Dao is expounded. If there be a virtuous person who follows what I have said—whether retreating to deep mountains, dwelling in the dusty world, residing in a Daoist abbey, or constructing a thatched hut—refining these Three Treasures without laxity, then true persons will surely appear to reveal their essentials.

Yet these sentient beings, through the six roots, give rise to the six consciousnesses; through the six consciousnesses, the Seven Emotions arise. How would they know that the Seven Emotions delude and confound the original true nature? Once the original true nature is lost, the Seven Emotions rage wildly. Now, these Seven Emotions invariably gather around love. Why is this so? For love is the root of emotion. Without attachment to love, there would be no desire; without desire, what cause for joy? Without joy, what cause for aversion? Without joy or aversion, what cause for anger? Without anger, fear does not arise; without fear, sorrow and omen are cast aside.

Thus, know that love is the seed of all emotions. If one does not sever the root but forcibly restrains it, what is restrained are but its branches and leaves. Like torrential waters, surging and swelling, their force reaching the heavens—if the source is not blocked, if the flow is not cleansed, and one merely builds dikes at will, they will ultimately breach and drown all. Like raging flames, blazing and fierce, their heat piercing the nine skies—if the fuel is not withdrawn, if the path is not cut off, and one merely attempts to extinguish them at will, they will instead feed the fire’s might, and wherever they touch, they will swiftly subdue. Like ocean tides, vast and boundless, surging and swelling—this recedes as that rises, that subsides as this rages, with no end in sight. All that is summoned or provoked follows the heart, growing through causes and conditions.

Only the perfected person knows this seed’s origin, establishes great vows, and arouses a courageous mind. Wielding the sword of wisdom, they sever its roots and shoots, exterminate its vile kind, allowing the Seven Emotions no foothold to arise. For these Seven Emotions are a great barrier, and love and desire are the barrier’s key. Sever the key, seize the barrier, leap beyond its threshold, and with hands unbound, walk freely without obstruction. Illuminating the supreme Dao, one ascends to the ranks of the lofty immortals.

I grieve for sentient beings—because of this one love, they give birth to manifold demons, raise manifold obstacles, deluded and inverted from the moment they leave the womb until death, rarely awakening to remorse! Even if a noble person were to seize them by the ear and admonish them face-to-face, it would be like drumming to a deaf man or shining a light before the blind, with no effect. Alas! Alas!

Yet some grow reckless and absurd, vainly longing to hear the Dao, begging for longevity, studying immortality or Buddhism—like a blind scribe tracing the tip of a brush, like a butcher sharpening his blade to honor the gods, like a thief praying over a stolen casket for blessings. Though they may gain something, their excesses only deepen.

Yet if one truly wishes to hear the subtlest mysteries of the supreme Dao, without severing love and cutting off the Seven Emotions, it remains but empty delusion. I shall explain these causes and conditions to you—listen carefully.

How can these Seven Emotions be eradicated? The way to remove them lies in contemplating *non-self*. What is *non-self*? The self is not truly the self; this self is not the self—what then is there to love? Yet once there is a self, one clings to it as the self. Clinging to the self as the self, nothing is not the self; nothing is not this self. Without the self, nothing is loved; yet kingdoms are not mine, yet I love and perish for them; families are not mine, yet I love and perish for them. All things—those with sound and scent, form and color, every external object—are not truly owned, yet I perish for them, like flies chasing stench, like ants swarming fat, like bees battering at windows, drawn to the light, scraping and scrabbling, greedy and ravenous, rushing like a runaway cart, craving like a moth to flame, seizing and grappling, jostling like wild ducks, flocking to the reeds, never resting.

But consider: before this self existed, what was it like? One should feel a sudden emptiness. Not only this—time passes like a white colt flashing past a gap, like morning dew, vanishing in an instant. The self becomes nothing. If the self is not the self, what is there to love? I press my hand to my heart and laugh soundlessly. With this inquiry, how can love not be removed? Once love is removed, nothing remains unremoved. Desire, aversion, joy, sorrow, fear, anger, selfishness, attachment—all vanish with love in a single stroke.

Yet people cling to love like glue, like lacquer, scarcely able to break free. Drowning in love is like falling into a vast abyss, struggling to swim upward, lost in boundless depths. I grieve deeply and offer a precious raft to ferry the drowning, yet sentient beings have sunk too long—without a ladder to my boat, how difficult it is for them!

For your sake, I have a method. What is it? First, one must cultivate endurance. How to endure? By reflecting deeply and awakening sharply. I have heard of those in the past who enjoyed utmost wealth and honor, their chambers filled with children, their halls crowded with kin and friends, every luxury—embroidered silks and fine foods—arrayed before them, their high halls and broad mansions adorned with carved beams and painted pillars, delighting the eye. Yet in an instant, all vanished. What they loved, they held in their hearts—then came demonic obstacles: plaintive wails, tender pleas, dissuasion and slander, even tears and embraces, clinging to prevent their departure. But these noble ones turned away, unmoved, regarding it all as a shattered pot, casting it off like worn-out sandals. In the depths of remote valleys, in the silence of secluded places, they sat in stillness, unseen and unheard, ensuring not a single seed of emotion remained. Only then, with minds as vast and bright as the open sky, did they mingle again with the dust and clamor of the world, passing through myriad circumstances, observing myriad phenomena, moving freely among things. Only when utterly unstained did they seek the secret gate of the supreme Dao and cultivate the Three Treasures.

Yet in this cultivation, one must first eliminate emotion, and above all, master the heart. How to master the heart? I offer the milk of the Dharma—nourish yourself well with it.

What is mastering the heart? The heart is fundamentally pure, fundamentally still, vast and at ease—this is its true nature. In mastering the heart, one must return to this nature: pure as flowing water, utterly unstained; still as a deep gorge, utterly silent; boundless as heaven and earth, unfathomable in its depth.

At ease as the boundless desert, its limits unknown.
Such is this heart—utterly empty of things.
Now like dead ashes, now like still water:
dead ashes may be kindled, still water may reflect;
now like a bright mirror, where forms pass without trace;
now like bodhi, the root of the Dao.
The bright mirror must ever be polished, bodhi ever moistened;
the bright mirror’s gall chilled, bodhi’s heart-seal imprinted.
When gall is chilled, all things flee;
when the heart-seal is imprinted, all Dao arises.
I know as unknowing, I see as unseeing,
without ear, without eye, without thought, perception, or consciousness.
Thus empty, reaching the utmost void of non-being—
only then is this heart unshakable by things.
That which cannot be shaken is called “sitting in forgetfulness.”
Only when one can forget may the Dao be transmitted,
the passes penetrated, dragons harmonized and tigers tamed,
foundations laid and mercury refined.
If one merely forgets things, one may overpower them,
but cannot pacify them.
Should one seek the secret within the Dao,
it would not only be futile, but harmful.
Know this: to hear the Dao, first slay the ringleaders.
What are the ringleaders?
The seven emotions.
Above all, sweep clean their thieves’ den,
restore the original clarity, stillness, emptiness, and vastness,
lest the six thieves gain the slightest foothold.
Why say this?
To master the heart.

To govern this single heart by eliminating the seven emotions and nurture the Great Elixir with a unified heart—yet should one employ improper methods, not only would this obscure the Dao, but also blind one’s nature.

For what is called *nature* is bestowed by Heaven. Thus, those who govern the heart do so for the sake of this nature. If the heart must be governed, how could nature be blinded? Yet the cultivation of nature cannot be delayed. How then is nature nurtured?

This nature originally arises from the beginningless, stealing from the Supreme Ultimate. After the division of the postcelestial, postcelestial nature possesses both principle and qi. Principle divides into true and false; falsehood loses the original truth. Qi divides into pure and turbid; turbidity obscures what is inherently so. Once obscured and lost, it cannot be called "nature," but is termed "postcelestial."

As for that Supreme Ultimate, principle and qi are undifferentiated, without falsehood or turbidity—this is the nature of Heaven. As for the beginningless, it cannot be called nature, nor is it destiny. Neither nature nor destiny, how then can it be termed "nature"? Originating from the beginningless, know that the beginningless is neither nature nor destiny—it is the Great Void. A single seed-point, this seed-point is the root of the utmost. From it arises destiny, and thus nature is formed.

To nurture this nature is to nurture this seed. Yet this seed is dim and indistinct, subtle and obscure, without sound or scent, without shadow or form. Where then to begin? In applying effort to nurture it, the Way of nurturing first tends to the postcelestial. Postcelestial nature possesses principle and qi, pure and turbid, true and false—none can be treated equally. How then can it be nurtured? By governing and refining it, eliminating falsehood and clarifying turbidity. Yet eliminating falsehood is not easy, and clarifying turbidity is most difficult.

I pity sentient beings and point out this Way: begin here. How to begin? Only by purifying desirelessness. Desireless, it is true; true, it is without falsity; without falsity, it is pure. Pure, it can illumine; true, it can embody. How to illumine and embody it? When purity and truth reach their utmost, nothing is not illuminated. The clarity of illumination—what Dao cannot be embodied?

Yet how to eliminate these falsehoods and turbidities? In the lower realms of Jambudvīpa, falsehood and turbidity intermingle. I point the way: one must rise high, aloof from worldly entanglements, sitting cross-legged, seeing nothing, hearing nothing. This heart, pure and unstained, can then eliminate falsehood and clarify its inherent turbidity. Once turbidity is clarified, this heart is pure, and no defiling dust can contaminate it further.

Yet humans possess a heart, and thus this nature. With this nature, how can there be no emotions? Therefore, those who govern the heart must eliminate the five senses to remove the five hindrances, thereby illuminating the five natures and penetrating the five perils.

What are the five senses?

**First: The causeless sense.**
When one sits in stillness, all sounds cease, all forms vanish. The ears receive nothing, the eyes perceive nothing. Profoundly silent, utterly undifferentiated, dull and vacant, yet suddenly a thought arises—rampant and unrestrained, like a startled deer dashing forth. It overflows the lunar cavern, extends to the celestial roots, beyond restraint or rescue. Its harm to the Dao is most severe. Thus, those who study the Dao must first eliminate this sense. How to eliminate it? By eliminating falsehood and preserving sincerity.

**Second: The anticipatory sense.**
Before encountering circumstances or events, one should let go, allowing this heart to be limpidly clear and profoundly still. Clear and still—these are the roots of the Dao. Why then, without cause, generate thoughts before circumstances arise, stir before events occur? A hundred anxieties seize and wrestle, a thousand thoughts assail and disturb. When one actually encounters circumstances, engages with events, and responds to things, it proves otherwise. Even if one’s thoughts align with reality, they exhaust essence and labor the spirit, depleting qi most severely. How much better to be without sense, yielding to spontaneity.

Thus, those who study the Dao—if this sense is not eliminated, they cannot hear the Dao. To eliminate this sense, forget circumstances and abandon affairs, stilling this heart like the Great Void.

**Third: The sense of sound and form.**
What the ears hear, what the eyes see—beauty and ugliness, myriad attitudes. From my perspective, they are like dreams and illusions. Yet, failing to awaken, one clings to them, anticipating and scheming, restless and chaotic, bustling and confused. The original substance is obscured, its brightness dimmed. Like a fool, none can remain clear. How then to seek the great Dao? Better to perish utterly.

Thus, those who study the Dao must close their ears and dim their eyes, allowing the master within to remain ever vigilant. If this sense persists, it is called affliction. Affliction and delusion know no end. Restless and uneasy, the heart’s sovereign abandons its abode. It must be eliminated, leaving the spirit bright and clear, without cause or condition. Inner and outer are at peace, the ears become eyes, the eyes become ears. Even amid extreme sounds and forms, one sees nothing, hears nothing.

**Fourth: The sense of the past.**
Virtue and misfortune, regret and shame—emotions follow circumstances and are forgotten. What is gained or lost, what is weak or strong? The deluded do not know, entangling themselves in needless affairs. Hesitant and stagnant, the heart finds no peace. Confused and anxious, without cause they act madly. To embody the Dao thus is like sailing a cup on the Eastern Ocean, boundless and unsupported, dangling a single thread over an abyss of a thousand fathoms. Not only is attainment impossible, but it invites future calamity.

Thus, those who study the Dao must eliminate this sense, avoiding attachment and stagnation. Vast and boundless, all things transform—no false sense remains to confuse true awareness.

A single private awareness, self-proclaimed cleverness—thus one strays from the true Dao. How could one know that private knowledge harms the Dao most severely? Mired in obscurity, tossed and turned, one’s qi cannot stretch forth. This not only harms the Dao but truly severs one’s nature and life.

Therefore, those who study the Dao must eliminate this awareness. If this awareness is not removed, even if other senses are abandoned, one remains ignorant of true awareness. This great Dao is like a level road—without true awareness to tread it, one falls into side paths, left-hand ways, and branching trails. Amidst a thousand streams and a hundred schools, though the rod strikes and the shout resounds, few can repent and awaken; though a compass is given, none follow it again. To forget the four senses yet retain this one is to ultimately lose one’s very form—how can one not be warned!

I grieve for such scholars and thus expound these words: be still and serene, follow nature alone, and do not contrive or act, lest you lose your original state. What is this original state? It is the nature of this heart, the awareness within that nature—this is called true awareness. The awareness of true awareness is named right awareness; the awareness of right awareness is called great awareness. This great awareness is the primordial awareness, not dependent on calculation, not reliant on principle, free from intention, certainty, fixation, or self. Following one’s original truth, yielding to nature, it ascends to the Three Heavens and descends to the Nine Abysses, luminous in the beginningless, penetrating the endless.

Subtle! Subtle indeed! In Daoism, it is called sagely wisdom; in Confucianism, communion with the divine; in Buddhism, tranquil illumination—all are true awareness, right awareness, great awareness, primordial awareness. Awareness that is not this awareness is called deluded awareness. If deluded awareness is not removed, true awareness is obscured.

Yet to eliminate the five senses, one must also dispel the five obstacles. What are the five obstacles?

**First: The obstacle of demons.**
This demonic obstacle may arise from the heart, adhere to circumstances, be stirred by things, or belong to the body. When it arises from the heart, it takes the form of views of self and others, honor and disgrace, gain and loss, right and wrong, strength and weakness, fame and profit, and the desire to prevail. The spirit terrace is thus clouded, and one cannot attain liberation. When it belongs to the body, illness and suffering assail, hunger and cold assail, success and indulgence assail, joy and sorrow assail, sloth and indolence assail, and deception and entanglement ensnare, causing constant friction and conflict. When one encounters circumstances, there is fortune and misfortune—fortune seems easy, misfortune seems difficult. Entering the world is easy; leaving it is hard. Then, when one meets things, beauty and delight fill the eyes, pleasing the heart and gratifying the will, captivating the mind. Such demonic obstacles are inherent in all people. If those who study the Dao do not remove this obstacle, they will find it difficult to hear the Dao even in death. Yet even if this demonic obstacle is removed one by one, another arises—the obstacle of doubt, which one must not remain ignorant of.

What is the **obstacle of doubt**? The great Dao is easy to know, simple to practice. A true teacher’s single point is like a lamp in a dark room, bright and clear as a crystal vase. Alas! The roots of doubt take hold: when one person speaks of the Dao, a clamor of voices drowns it out, confusion arises, and one turns from right to wrong, allowing the false to disrupt the true. It is like standing atop a tall tree, only to fall into a dark ravine. How profound are the sage’s words: *"The valley spirit does not die; it is the gate of all wonders."* How vast is the sage’s Dao: *"Emptiness responds to causes, purity and tranquility are its essence."* Why indulge in divergent theories, letting them proliferate in chaos? This is the obstacle of doubt, self-inflicted distress. Pitiable is the one who does not awaken, ultimately falling into karmic entanglement.

I tell those who cultivate: you must follow a true teacher, not be misled by heterodox teachings or stray into side paths. Cultivate clarity, emptiness, tranquility, and stillness; nurture essence and spirit. The mysterious pass and the female gate, the Yellow Mother and the infant, yin and yang, water and fire, Kan and Li, Qian and Kun—all reside within the square inch of the heart. What use are all these names? When all forms vanish, how can doubt remain? If this obstacle is not removed, confusion will multiply.

Yet even if this obstacle is dispelled, another arises—the **obstacle of principle**, which harms the Dao even more. Each clings to partial truths, none attaining a comprehensive view. The Confucian obstacle lies in the real, the Daoist in the void, the Buddhist in emptiness.

Those obstructed by the real cling to their partial principles, treating illusory realms, illusory affairs, and illusory forms as truly existent. They exhaust their wills and labor their spirits, wearing out their bodies and depleting their qi, believing all this to be in accord with principle—unaware that such words are themselves obstacles. As for human life—*"benevolence, righteousness, kindness, wisdom, loyalty, filial piety, integrity, and chastity"*—these are all the vast qi of Heaven and Earth. To act upon them with sincerity is not to treat them as empty! Yet if one’s understanding is not comprehensive, clinging to partial principles, one falls into evil karma. The warmth of benevolence, the rigidity of righteousness, petty loyalty, and foolish filial piety are scorned even within the Confucian school—how much more so for those who study the Dao? Alas, the multitude of beings, obstructed by the real, constantly fall into the pit of fire, with none to awaken them.

I expound the Dharma for them: be still and reflect. The mind-seal of sages and worthies is to silently comprehend, thoroughly penetrate, and awaken without the slightest gap.

Those obstructed by the void cling to their partial principles, sitting rigidly in meditation, purifying dust and defilement, and even claiming, *"This is where the Dao lies!"* They do not seek secret teachings, nor nurture the Three Treasures. Though they speak of attaining emptiness, this is not the Dao! For this supreme Dao does not lie in the real, nor does it reside solely in the void. Only when emptiness and reality are harmonized does one grasp the mysterious essential.

Those obstructed by emptiness cling to their partial principles, ignorant of true nature, merely discoursing on emptiness. What they call emptiness is not true emptiness but a stubborn void. In the end, they remain ignorant of the original true suchness and freedom.

How muddled they are!

All these obstructions, failing to harmonize, give rise to disparate schools and divergent paths, where adherents turn against one another with scorn, viewing each other as irreconcilable as ice and fire. Confucians dismiss the Dao as hollow, Daoists dismiss Buddhism as empty, and Buddhists dismiss both Confucianism and Daoism—endless cycles of mutual reproach. They do not realize that though the teachings of heaven and earth are divided into three, they share a single root. It is only because of obstructive attachments to partial principles that they regard one another with division.

Alas! Alas!
Obstruction by the real leads to delusion, and delusion makes awakening difficult.
Obstruction by the void leads to desiccation, and desiccation leaves no substance.
Obstruction by emptiness leads to stillness, and stillness veers toward annihilation.

The sages of antiquity were real yet able to be void, void yet able to be real. They perceived emptiness as non-empty, and emptiness as having no fixed emptiness—this is the supreme Dao. Only when these are harmonized and grasped does one transcend obstructive attachments. Yet none understand this.

Students of the Dao, take heed!
If obstructive attachments to principles can be removed, one obstruction remains: the root of this obstruction arises from *texts*. This "obstruction of texts" is truly an obstruction of the mind. The five thousand secret words all stem from mysterious realization, yet when viewed merely as texts, their essence is lost. Failing to awaken, one falls into this obstruction, giving rise to all manner of heretical words and twisted doctrines—novel and pleasing, seeping into the heart and marrow, harming nature and injuring form.

Even the ancient perfected ones, in establishing true principles, often employed allegories: some spoke of *kan* and *li*, some of the furnace and crucible, some of the maiden, some of the infant, some of the dragon and tiger, some of yin and yang, some of the Mysterious Female, some of *wu*—all allegories. Those obstructed by texts engage in endless manipulation, unaware that the great Dao lies in essence, qi, and spirit! To nurture these Three Treasures is to nurture the seed. This seed is the root of all roots. All those teachings are but manifestations of this single qi; the origin of this qi is the seed itself. Recognize the seed, and the myriad doctrines—all become dregs. Feeding on these dregs, what purpose does it serve?

Thus, texts are not the true explanation of the Dao. To embody them is to cast all aside. Having cast aside texts, one must also beware of "lineage transmission." This lineage transmission is the very source of obstructions—examine it closely.

Seeking out perfected masters to receive their subtle guidance, if one fails to find the right teacher, the obstructions to body and mind may last a lifetime. For beginners, the Dao remains a vague dream. A single misstep in choosing a teacher, and one is taught heterodox ways—endless confusion, no hope of thorough awakening. Taking these as guiding principles, they follow them for life, their body and mind bound in confinement. Even if a true person points the way to correct awakening, their hearts may reject it, their bodies may turn away, clinging instead to superficial words. With falsehood selling falsehood, falsehood believing falsehood, all manner of obstructions arise.

Thus, students of the Dao must carefully select wise teachers to remove the obstructions of body and mind. Once this obstruction is eliminated, all others dissolve in turn. With all obstructions cleared, the numinous terrace becomes pure—then one may illuminate the wonders of the five natures.

What are the five natures?
The first is the nature of water,
the second is the nature of fire,
the third is the nature of wood,
the fourth is the nature of metal,
the fifth is the nature of earth.

The nature of earth is often turbid, and turbidity leads to thickness.
The nature of metal is often decisive, and decisiveness leads to resoluteness.
The nature of wood is often compassionate, and compassion leads to benevolence.
The nature of fire is often firm, and firmness leads to impatience.
The nature of water is often yielding, and yielding leads to dissipation.

Dissipation inclines toward indolence,
impatience inclines toward harshness,
benevolence inclines toward gentleness,
resoluteness inclines toward boldness,
thickness inclines toward obscurity.

Obscurity leads to foolishness,
boldness leads to chaos,
indolence leads to deceit,
gentleness leads to entrapment,
firm harshness leads to cruelty.

Thus, when the five natures are imbalanced, their efficacy lies in mutual regulation:
Yielding overcomes firmness,
firmness overcomes yielding.
Benevolence is tempered by resoluteness,
resoluteness is tempered by benevolence.
Earth’s obscurity lacks wisdom—clarity overcomes it.
If clarity fails to overcome it, the use of yielding is lost.

Yet these five natures originate from the five phases.
These five phases are all present within the human body:
The first is water, the virtue of the kidneys;
the second is fire, the virtue of the heart;
the third is wood, the virtue of the liver;
the fourth is metal, the virtue of the lungs;
the fifth is earth, the virtue of the spleen.

Life resides in the spleen,
qi is stored in the lungs,
the *hun* dwells in the liver,
the spirit resides in the heart,
the *po* is attached to the kidneys.

Thus, those who cultivate the body cultivate these five virtues to fully realize the five natures. However, the climates of the five directions differ, and endowments vary accordingly:
Those born with the nature of water tend toward yielding, and yielding leads to indolence.
Those born with the nature of wood tend toward benevolent foolishness, and foolishness leads to obscurity.
Those born with the nature of fire tend toward firmness, and firmness leads to harshness.
Those born with the nature of metal tend toward resoluteness, and resoluteness leads to obstinacy.
Those born with the nature of earth tend toward obscurity, and obscurity leads to ignorance—ignorance leads to separation, and separation leads to turning away from the Dao.

Yet these five phases all originate from yin and yang:
The nature of water is yin,
the nature of fire is yang.
Greater yang is wood,
lesser yin is metal.
Earth contains both qi but is essentially yin.

Yet water is yin but rooted in yang—thus the nature of water is inwardly bright and outwardly dark, outwardly yielding and inwardly firm.
Fire is yang but rooted in yin—thus the nature of fire is outwardly bright and inwardly dark, inwardly yielding and outwardly firm.
Wood is greater yang but born of yin—it bends and straightens: bending is yin, straightening is yang.
Metal is lesser yin but born of yang—it follows and transforms: following is yin, transforming is yang.
Earth is the qi of harmony and is true yin.

All four are attached to it, and thus their natures each lodge in their respective flourishing phases. Know that the five phases:
Their essence clings to heaven,
their substance is formed by earth,
their spirit is attached to humans.
Water is called wisdom—its form is the hidden dragon.

Fire is called propriety—its center is the crouching tiger.
Wood is called benevolence—it is named the Mother of Wood.
Metal is called righteousness—it is called the Duke of Metal.
Earth is called trustworthiness—its name is the Yellow Matriarch.

These five natures do not transcend the five phases, and these five phases do not depart from yin and yang. As for yin and yang, they are rooted in the Great Ultimate, and the extremity of the Great Ultimate is the Ultimateless. Thus, by illuminating the five natures, one may penetrate the five *xuan*.

How is this to be understood?
Through generation and restriction:
Water can generate Wood, and the Mother of Wood is preserved;
Wood can generate Fire, and the tiger is empowered;
Fire can generate Earth, and the root of life is secured;
Earth can generate Metal, and the Duke of Metal follows;
Metal can generate Water, and the dragon’s body ascends.

Yet without restriction, there would be no control.
Thus, Water restricts Fire, and the tiger’s ferocity is tempered;
Fire restricts Metal, and Metal does not flow;
Metal restricts Wood, and the Mother does not decline;
Wood restricts Earth, and Earth does not sink;
Earth restricts Water, and the dragon does not fly.

Generation gives way to restriction, restriction gives way to generation—generation and restriction, endlessly cyclic like a ring without seam. Only then are the five phases free from imbalance, the five phases interpenetrating, and the five natures complete. One who understands this truly fathoms the ultimate principle. Through this, the subtlety of the "five *xuan*" may be inwardly realized.

What are the five *xuan*?
Some call it the *Xuan of Heaven*,
some the *Xuan of Earth*,
some the *Xuan of Dharma*,
some the *Xuan of the Dao*—
all are collectively called *xuanxuan*.

Yet these five *xuan* do not transcend yin and yang, and this yin and yang do not depart from the five phases. Thus, by illuminating the five phases, one knows the five natures; having known the five natures, one penetrates the five *xuan*.

By penetrating the *Xuan of Heaven*, one knows the Way of Heaven, follows its spontaneity, and thus attains non-action.
By penetrating the *Xuan of Earth*, one knows the principles of Earth, follows its hardness and softness, and thus achieves interpenetration.
By penetrating the *Xuan of Dharma*, one knows cause and response, endlessly transforming, with no trace to measure.
By penetrating the *Xuan of the Dao*, one harmonizes the postcelestial with the precelestial; those who act and those who do not all grasp its subtleties.
By penetrating *xuanxuan*, from heaven above to earth below, the profundity of the Dao and its methods is boundless—nothing is unknown. To know yet be without knowledge, to be without knowledge yet know all, to know all yet truly be without knowledge—this is called attaining the Dao.

For those who study the Dao and wish to penetrate the five *xuan*, first illuminate the five natures. To illuminate the five natures, first remove the five obstacles, eliminate the five senses, sever the seven emotions, expel the six thieves, and purify the six roots. Only then can one penetrate them. Yet one must seek the guidance of a perfected master to reveal the subtleties within the *xuan*, thereby knowing how to lay the foundation, establish the furnace and cauldron, gather the Three Treasures, and restore one’s original nature.

Once the original nature is established, one traverses the three realms, bestows the Dharma-milk, and universally delivers the deluded. When the three thousand practices are fulfilled and the eight hundred merits accomplished, the rainbow banner and crimson tones will descend to welcome one, ascending to the Jade Palace to attest to the rank of a perfected being.

O all you learners, strive diligently in practice.

*Eulogy by the Jade Cauldron Perfected:*
The Great Dao is empty and void, all phenomena are insubstantial;
The precelestial abides within the postcelestial.
The Three Powers weave together past and present;
The Two Qi cyclically generate, parting the primordial chaos.
When the six senses are purified, the six paths are emptied;
The Three Spirits manifest, governing the Three Teachings.
Jade liquid and golden essence congeal into wondrous forms;
The cinnabar talisman and vermilion script reveal the *xuan* vault.
The precious grove’s subtle truths open the primordial beginning;
The numinous treasure’s subtleties propagate the Dao’s wind.
A single word proclaimed is like a thunderous shout;
The three seals unsealed awaken to the sameness of emptiness.
Vastly guiding sentient beings, a great canon is formed;
Through ten thousand kalpas of rebirth, one enters the scroll of emptiness.
The embroidered ridge’s jade blossoms contain wondrous understanding;
The green forest’s azure birds sing the lineage’s work.
Where the heart of heaven is seen, boundless vastness appears;
When the earth’s axis turns, the ten thousand dharmas are mighty.
The *xuan* origin’s true principle is fully revealed;
The Dharma drum resounds universally, awakening the deaf multitude.

*Central Scroll of the Great Vehicle Scripture of Salvation from the Kalpa, the Wondrous Canon of the Three Grades of the Pure and Subtle, the Ultimate of the Dao’s Profundity, the Concordance of the Xuan*

I have heard that heaven and earth are a single qi, intermingling and nurturing, giving birth to the ten thousand things. Among them, humans alone are numinous, possessing the fullness of principle, the correctness of qi, nobly endowed with celestial nobility, richly endowed with innate capacities, exalted above the ten thousand things, and the womb of all life. To lose this near-imperceptible essence is to forfeit one’s original nature, becoming unlike the ten thousand things and falling from one’s proper rank.

To preserve it is to become a sage; to maintain it is to remain human. To stabilize it is to become great; to transform it is to become spirit. In comparison with heaven and earth, the Three Powers are triply divided. Thus, know that this body is exceedingly difficult to obtain and exceedingly easy to lose—not only easy to lose, but once lost, forever lost, falling into the cycle of rebirth without a day of respite.

I, as one who practices the Dao, reveal the five *xuan*—listen carefully to their truth:
The azure of heaven, vast and all-encompassing, has form yet no form, has image yet no image. All these forms and images originally possess fixed colors—this is their reality. Yet when discussing form and color, they are indistinct and vague, truly without fixed image, empty and traceless—how void they are! Only the void is numinous; only the real can obscure. Void and real, real and void—transformation reaches the divine.

Thus, by penetrating the *Xuan of Heaven*, one knows the void and the real, without stagnation or coagulation, following its spontaneity. Circulating transformation at will, ceaselessly revolving, the Great Elixir is accomplished.

The Way of Earth is honest and profound, boundless and bright. Above it is void, below it is real—thus the ten thousand things are nurtured. Above it is real, below it is void—thus the ten thousand things return to their root. Void and real, real and void—abiding with heaven for eternity. Its essence is steadfast stillness; its function is flowing movement. Mountains reveal wondrous substance; water manifests its spirit. Substance bears things; spirit gathers numinosity. Without spirit, there is no substance; without substance, there is no spirit. Spirit moves, substance receives; substance moves through spirit. Void and real interpenetrate, wondrously uniting as one.

Learners of the Dao who thoroughly awaken to this principle harmonize hardness and softness, mutually generating void and real.

Thus, penetrating the celestial mystery and re-illuminating this cause, with Qian and Kun fixed in their positions, the Great Elixir is achieved.

As for the Dao’s mystery—it is not attained through mere discourse. If one takes it as real, what reality is not void? If one takes it as void, what void is not real? Should one attempt to speak of void and real, where does the real reside? Where does the void become manifest? The real within the void cannot be named as real; the void within the real cannot be called void. Real is not merely real, void is not merely void—yet nothing is not void and real, yet nothing can be said of void and real.

Subtle, oh so subtle! What cannot be called void is truly void; what cannot be called real is fundamentally real. Though one cannot speak of void and real, in truth, nothing lies beyond void and real.

Profound is the Dao’s mystery—without form or image, its depth unfathomable, its essence difficult to fathom. Thus, awakening to this mystery, the elixir completes its nine revolutions.

As for the method of this mystery, it is received through transmission from a master, originating in the mandate of heaven and flowing through the earth. Once the Great Dao is accomplished, its principles reach divine subtlety, transformations arise from the heart, and spiritual powers become unfathomable.

Heaven and earth are but a sack; sun and moon, a flask within. A mustard seed contains Mount Sumeru; the great chiliocosm, a hair’s tip. Wielding gold across the eight directions, the six directions are but dust. Now joined, now parted; now fleeting, now eternal; now hidden, now manifest—void and emptiness dissolve into obscurity. Commanding spirits and dispatching ghosts, thunder and lightning intermingle.

Call it void—what is not present? Call it real—what is not absent? Obtaining the mind’s response in the hand, mind and hand imprint upon each other. When the mind is no-mind, what does the hand gain? Not grasped by the hand, it moves with the heart—endless transformations, with heaven and earth as witness.

Subtle, oh so subtle! Endlessly generating, only by penetrating the Dao’s mystery can one attain this principle.

Thus, to penetrate the Dao’s mystery is to achieve the Way. Of its first mystery: no words can speak it, all thought and deliberation must cease. Subtle and elusive, it fades into the imperceptible, vanishing beyond sound and form. For a thousand, ten thousand kalpas, none have transmitted it.

Now, for the world, I expound this principle—you, my disciples, listen in stillness.

This mystery, of old, the Primordial Heavenly Worthy spoke. I have secretly heard its teaching: from heaven above to the boundless multitudes, among them are perfected beings who delve ever deeper into mystery. Heaven is their steward, earth their attendant. All beings—seen and unseen—converge at the utmost limits. They govern the transformations of past and present without trace or track, presiding over kalpas without beginning or end.

The sacred cannot be made sacred; the numinous cannot be made numinous.
No-no-no-no—yet in no there is being;
Void-void-void—yet in void there is reality.
The sage gains nothing; the fool loses nothing.
Heaven abides at the center, yet heaven knows it not;
Earth bears its flow, yet earth does not recognize it.
All things reach their extremity, yet move unaware.
Its presence is not presence; its passing is not passing.
Such is its mystery—how can it be conceived? How imagined?
If one penetrates this principle, mystery upon mystery unfolds.

These five mysteries are not easily mastered. Those who study the Way must thoroughly investigate its meaning, cast aside all distractions, and delve in silent inquiry. Only then can understanding transcend, and dark enlightenment be uniquely grasped. Profound and subtle, one begins to perceive the original truth. Seeking the hidden key, cinnabar and lead are self-sufficient; furnace and fire require no external instruction. Yin and yang settle into place, dragon and tiger harmonize in exchange—no need for manipulation, for it arises naturally.

If this is not understood, the dust of the senses clings, the six roots seize control, the seven emotions blaze fiercely, and one falls into the burning house—how then can the subtleties of mystery be fathomed?

Now I reveal this teaching—who among you can awaken?
Then myriad divergent doctrines arise, factions divide, each clinging to one corner, turning to scorn and ridicule. At first, they grasp at principles, debating and exhorting; each holds to a single view, establishing theories and teachings. Though all claim to serve the Way, defending it left and right, their words may grow excessive, yet their intent to clarify the Dao remains sincere.

As the tradition drifts further, private corruptions multiply. They strike at one another, rallying factions, claiming to defend the Way—yet in truth, they defend themselves! Tracing their origins, all are outsiders to the gate.

Alas! Alas!

Such people—among the Confucians, they are rot; among the Daoists, they are thieves; among the Buddhists, they are offshoots of delusion—what difference do their muddled dreams make?

Yet do they not know that the Three Teachings originally sprang from one source? If one grasps this unifying principle, all distinctions may dissolve. Before Fuxi’s time, what divergence was there? When the Sage Confucius was born, the Most High manifested transformation, and their teachings resonated in mutual accord. As the Dao of human nature flourished, one path emerged outward, another inward.

The teaching of worldly engagement first upholds human relationships: the dignity of ruler and father, the loyalty of minister and filial piety of child, the fraternal affection of siblings, the shared Way of husband and wife, the procreation of offspring—thus the cosmos endures through the ages, nurturing all beings. Heaven and earth serve as complements, the transformative mechanism never fails, and creation is thereby assisted. If this teaching were obscured, the world would be deaf and blind for ten thousand generations. When the earth was full and the land abundant, at the dawn of primordial chaos, the world was indistinct, above and below lost their support—thus we know this teaching is the pillar of the Dao. Yet deluded about its origins, how could one even begin to discuss it?

Alas! This supreme teaching, long since distorted, now yields only the distinctions of success and failure, nobility and baseness, wealth and poverty, high and low, great and small, strong and weak, many and few, self and other. Bound by the snares of fame, profit, and temporal power, souls drift through the cycles of birth and death, trapped in endless inversion. Strife, plunder, and theft arise; deceit proliferates; a hundred schemes emerge to dupe the people. Treacherous heroes appear intermittently, muddying human relationships. They forge alliances through power, vie with one another through ability, unleash the blades of their tongues, and blur right and wrong. Debates rage back and forth; those of the same kind attack one another. Each raises its red banner, a single principle splintering into chaos. One view deems this right, another deems that right; those who agree flock together, those who differ mock. Without distinction or clarity, gain and loss, right and wrong, their essence and subtleties remain unfathomed.

Do they not know that within difference lies sameness, within sameness lies difference, and within both difference and sameness, further distinctions arise? Right and wrong intermingle, gain and loss diverge. They indulge their arbitrary opinions, heedless of reason. Even within the same teaching, they treat one another like sworn enemies, ceaselessly attacking, never at peace. Who among them remains impartial, their judgment unclouded? Alas! Who can awaken to these essential words? If even those of the same school are so treacherous, what of others?

Moreover, there is this saying: the corruption of the human heart begins with the corruption of writing. Those who study writing excel in externals; all their words are adorned with embellishment, their polished phrases fixated on outward display. A heart turned outward must neglect what lies within; a heart bent on pleasing others must forget itself; a heart set on transmitting to posterity forgets self-cultivation; a heart seeking victory forgets self-restraint; a heart boasting of breadth forgets to return to simplicity; a heart enamored of ornate beauty forgets to uphold sincerity. Craft and pretense grow daily, while the true essence withers.

Since the rise of writing, the principles of nature and destiny have grown obscure—can one not be wary? Can one not be cautious? I have heard it said: the patterns of heaven shine brilliantly in the Milky Way; the patterns of earth dazzle in the transformations of grasses and trees; the patterns of humanity gleam in resounding music and refined ritual. All emerge naturally, without contrived adornment. The highest writing is no writing at all; true writing arises from reality. Writing that arises from reality is the highest. Later generations produce much writing, yet it is as if there were none. Writing that is not writing, writing that is not truly writing—such writing is no writing at all.

What is even more lamentable is that, through the habit of writing, nothing remains unheard, yet what is heard is not what should be heard. They amass vulgar knowledge, boasting of their wild erudition. The most revered lack true writing; the most intimate lack true writing. All conduct is performed through writing, and craft and pretense arise. What is not loyalty or filial piety is made to appear so through writing; what is not friendliness or respect is made to appear so through writing. They indulge in the inner chambers, composing ornate speech. All their actions transgress propriety and abandon restraint. Adorning them with writing only deepens the corruption, leading to calamity—like the hammer of Zui or the decay of Lu—all are tainted. When substance is disguised with ornament, falsehood replaces truth; when simplicity is abandoned for artifice, machinations flourish. Beings lack constancy, becoming not only disloyal, unfilial, undutiful, unkind, and unrighteous, but worse. Fraud, theft, deceit, and pretense openly defy the law; cruelty and malice, whether fierce or cunning, secretly hatch venomous schemes. The ancient Way is lost, and people of this age remain unawakened. The river flows downward—none can turn it back.

Confucianism, having lost its substance, grows ever more tangled and false the further it spreads. Yet its followers remain unaware, forming societies and forging alliances, mutually praising one another while slandering others. They fabricate accusations against the Supreme, revile the Buddha, and curse the ancestors; they deny the existence of ghosts and spirits, mocking Buddhism and Daoism. The true teachings and orthodox lineages they dismiss as heterodoxy; the scriptures of immortals and the sutras of the Buddha they condemn as heresy. They claim that Daoism and Buddhism abandon human relationships—yet do they not know that such people not only abandon them but also bring calamity upon this world and its people? Why is this so? Because these Confucians are the people’s exemplars; if their standard is crooked, their shadow will be even more so.

Yet these are but petty Confucians, rotten and deluded. The great Confucians are not like this. The great Confucians see directly to the root, knowing that the Confucian Dao, the Daoist Dao, and the Buddhist Dharma share a single thread, with no division. Confucianism and Buddhism both originate from the Dao; the Dao is rooted in human nature, and nature in turn is rooted in Heaven. Heaven has no dual principles, and humanity has no Three Teachings. The division into three arose from later perspectives; tracing back to their origins, they are one without distinction. The great Confucians understand this and make no divisions. Each fulfills their Dao in their own way: serving their lord with loyalty, exhausting their allotted role; serving their parents with filial piety, exerting themselves to the utmost; brothers being friendly and siblings respectful, adapting to their station.

At the inception, husband and wife establish order to guard against licentiousness. In serving the spirits, sincerity is paramount; in governing people, benevolence is key. Love extends to plants and trees, kindness blankets insects and all creatures. Revering Heaven’s bright mandate, treading upon earth with caution, one remains without shame in solitude, humbly upholding virtue.

Those who understand the transformations of the Dao do not confine teaching to a single method; they merely discern right from wrong, refraining from reckless criticism—such are the sages and worthies. The Dao culminates in Heaven, serving as both sovereign and teacher. In grand governance and assisting creation, the positions of ruler and minister are fixed; father and son observe strict distinctions; the Way of friendship and respect is established among peers; the bond of brothers is unbroken; the Dao of husband and wife is upright, with yin and yang free from error.

Heaven and earth assume their positions, and the myriad things flourish in tranquility. Wind and rain are harmonious, cold and heat arrive in due season. Auspicious omens and blessings gradually appear, while inauspicious sounds and perverse qi dissipate. People and creatures enjoy benevolence and longevity—how do immortals and buddhas differ from this?

Born to honor the world, one ultimately returns to the Supreme Clarity, establishing the ultimate for heaven and humanity, enduring with heaven and earth.

The Buddhist teachings of the Pure and Subtle originated in the vast kalpas. Contemplating emptiness through emptiness, they attain the stillness of extinction. Long ago, there was a perfected one named Dipamkara, who arose in the middle antiquity and turned the great Dharma wheel, teaching and liberating countless beings, marking the flourishing of the Buddha’s transmission.

Later, a buddha appeared, known as Śākyamuni. Descending from the Tuṣita heaven, he incarnated in Jambudvīpa in the year of *Jiayin* during the reign of King Zhao of Zhou. In the western Indian kingdom of Kapilavastu, ruled by King Śuddhodana, the prince was born on the eighth day of the fourth month, adorned with thirty-two marks and eighty excellences. Due to his past vows, he renounced his kingdom to cultivate the Dao.

For six years on Snow Mountain, he engaged in intense meditation and ascetic practice. A magpie nested upon his head, vines pierced his shins, and on the eighth day of the twelfth month, upon seeing the morning star rise, he suddenly attained supreme enlightenment. Possessing the six supernatural knowledges and the strength of a great being, he opened the path for the future and continued the past, expounding the teachings in the western regions.

First at Deer Park, then in Jetavana Grove—where gold was spread upon the ground—the Buddha’s teachings flourished. For forty-nine years, his manifestations and teachings were manifold. At that time, bhikṣus and bhikṣuṇīs, along with upāsakas and upāsikās, numbering in the thousands, all gathered to hear the Dharma, and none failed to attain liberation.

Among them was Śāriputra, foremost in wisdom, through whom the Buddha often expounded the essentials of the Dharma. There was also the great disciple Mahākāśyapa, who received the Buddha’s mind-seal and transmitted the Buddha’s true lineage. The Buddha personally bestowed upon him the prediction, making him the first patriarch. Another disciple, Ānanda, foremost in learning, after the Buddha’s parinirvāṇa, transmitted the Buddha’s scriptures, disseminating them among humanity. The present Buddhist canon derives entirely from his teachings.

Later came Bodhidharma, who with great spiritual powers in a single night subdued thirty-six places of heretical and external paths, making vast vows. From western India, crossing the Ganges’ sands, he arrived in Jambudvīpa, expounding the Dharma and propagating the teachings. The Chan school flourished, imparting secret instructions to those who attained sudden enlightenment, illuminating the mind and seeing their nature.

The Buddha’s Dharma is not extensive—all is swept away. A single word or phrase suffices to penetrate the original nature. All cleverness, knowledge, and learning are discarded; in profound silence, one nods in understanding of the essential principle. Awakening to the truth of causes and conditions, one realizes that where there is nothing, there is no nothingness, and where there is emptiness, there is no emptiness.

Inwardly observing this mind, it is like the vastness of space, like the moon reflected in a thousand rivers, like a mirror or a bubble, like fragrance within a flower. Thus, in this emptiness of emptiness, with nothingness of nothingness, there is nothing to grasp. The wonder of a single word is unobstructed and boundless. Before nothingness, there is no before; after nothingness, there is no after. Not through hearing or seeing, but in an instant of sudden transcendence, one lets go of all perceptions and knowledge, collapsing into self-oblivion.

Through causes and conditions, one attains the causeless; thus, the Chan school flourished. There were also many great Dharma masters through the ages, well-versed in the sūtras, vinaya, and śāstras, who drew from the great Dharma treasury. They elucidated and translated texts, uncovering their profound meanings, and transmitted them throughout the three thousand great thousand worlds and all of Jambudvīpa. For the sake of sentient beings, they expounded boundless causes, resolving afflictions and burning heat, transforming them into a realm of cool purity. They rescued beings from suffering and distress, delivered them from the peril of the burning house, saved wandering spirits from the hellish realms, and liberated the six paths, granting the joy of heavenly and human existence. Their benefits were immeasurable, and the Buddhist teachings prospered.

As the transmission endured, its essential meaning faded. Among the monastic community, few received the true transmission. They plagiarized from east and west, making language their foundation, engaging in verbal sparring and contests of wit. The so-called "Chan" was meant to expound profound mysteries and recognize one’s original face, without relying on superficial adornments. Yet if one examines its flaws, it harms later generations, causing them to lose the true lineage and burdening the host of beings.

Some, leaving their homes, enter into nothingness, drifting in vagueness, falling into wild-fox Chan, deluded and reckless, scolding buddhas and reviling patriarchs, yet posing as great teachers. Even worse are those who, utterly deluded, falsely transmit and inherit, passing on their errors in turn. The Tathāgata’s Dharma—what Dharma is there in all dharmas? To investigate the root, all dharmas are emptied. Texts are not established, yet not because texts are to be discarded—lest later learners, seeking within texts, lose their original nature. Thus, texts are abandoned. Yet who realizes that texts are difficult to entirely discard? Those who discard texts—have they ever followed the current? Clinging to texts, viewing them as texts, not relying on texts to fathom the Buddha’s secret essence, they lose the true lineage—this is the obstacle of texts, which harms the Dao!

Even more pitiful are those who, unaware that these sūtras are the Buddha’s mind-seal, transmit them among humanity to broadly expound the Dharma for sentient beings, enabling some to gain understanding. Even the dull and ignorant, who cannot comprehend, rely on these sūtras for repentance. The purpose is to inspire reverence in such beings, so that through daily recitation, they may eventually awaken, relinquish thoughts of life and death, cultivate virtuous deeds, escape the cycle of rebirth, or penetrate the profound and ascend to the supreme vehicle. It is not merely through recitation, without a repentant heart, that sins can be absolved.

Even when merely reciting with the mouth, one still gains benefit. For in that moment of recitation, great joy arises, and with resonant chanting, all beings—whether unseen or manifest, demons or alien kinds, lingering spirits or remnant offshoots—hear this sūtra and universally receive its sublime advantage, all attaining deliverance.

Yet it is not that merely reciting with the mouth, without a mind of receptivity, without a heart of reverence, without a heart of sincere faith, without a heart of exultation, without a heart of equitable benefit, without a heart of selflessness, truly constitutes sūtra-recitation or yields merit.

As the current flows downward, day by day it decays. All Buddhist scriptures are treated as mere means for clothing and food. Those who recite sūtras seek only empty words; those who chant sūtras respond with empty words. Because of these empty words, all beings belittle this sūtra, and the Buddhas’ Dharma comes to have no place of abiding.

Know that this sūtra possesses great liberation: like the *Guangling San*, it transforms all vexations; like the wish-fulfilling jewel, it transforms all afflictions; like the prajñā boat, it ferries the drowning; like the pāramitās, it generates all vital essences; like the lamp in a lacquered chamber, it illumines all darkness. Endowed with these and countless other benefits without measure.

Merely treating the text as empty words, skimming it carelessly—such is like chaff, of what use could it be? For this reason, the Chan school has swept all such aside. Turning the mind inward in dark contemplation, voiding both inner and outer forms, sitting in silent stillness, grasping the single point of inquiry, exhaustively probing its purport—there is a return to emptiness. Yet emptiness is no-emptiness; precisely because there is no emptiness does this purport become clear. As when one lights a torch in a dark room, nothing remains unseen, nothing fails to shine forth; no obstructions remain, and with no obstructions, the essence of mind is fully possessed, the celestial nature complete. One moves with heaven and earth, unconfined by things, not possessed by things. This is called *Brahman*—its sound pure and penetrating, uniting darkness and light. This is called Chan—its principle profound and subtle. When gods and humans fully fathom it, they become seeds of Buddha-bodhi. Just so, just so: such is the great intent of the Western advent. Thus is the Buddha-Dharma exhausted.

As for the Dao, it opened with the Primordial Beginning, revealing its secret purport, flowing forth in silent constancy, from which the Dao gave birth to the Dharma. The Dharma was transmitted as the *Lingbao*, manifesting boundless responses—golden precepts and jade statutes governing heaven and earth, commanding gods and humans. Yet among those multitudes of beings, none obtained the hearing of the Dao; the Dao-Dharma went untransmitted. Then the Most High descended in birth, exhibiting many divine marvels. His sacred mother bore him from beneath her left armpit, emerging from the womb’s numinous chamber beneath an auspicious plum tree. In an instant, his beard and hair turned white, and he took "Plum" as his surname. Though eighty-one years had passed since he left his mother’s womb, he appeared at the same time as the Sage of Ni Mountain and the Buddha of Snow Mountain, together becoming the three ancestral teachers of the teachings. A model for all humankind, he transmitted the Dharma without limit. His five thousand and more words, each a wondrous truth, were hidden among the annals of the historiographers, yet none grasped them. Purple qi came from the east; a blue ox crossed to the west. There was one, Shanshi, the Keeper of the Pass, who had long awakened to the true constancy but had not yet grasped its purport. Beholding these numinous traces, he knew an extraordinary person was near. Leaving his post, he pledged his sincerity, kneeling to the ground, bowing his head toward the seat, and begged for the teaching. The secret texts of the *Dao* and *De* were personally transmitted to him, passed down to later generations as the essential purport of the Dao. Entering or leaving the world, those who hear these words receive boundless benefit. Grasping its essential purport, they attain long life with heaven and earth, endure through all kalpas, transcend the destinies of the six paths, and ascend beyond the realms of humans and gods. Following the positions of heaven and earth, their years cannot be reckoned; they are one with heaven and earth yet do not share in their decline.

Then, in later propagation of the teaching, there were eighty-six transmissions, through which many perfected ones transcended to grasp the principle of constancy. The Dao-Dharma spread widely, becoming a ladder and ferry for all immortals. Those who awakened to it dwelt in the round harmony of the celestial sphere, in purity, emptiness, stillness, and tranquility. Penetrating to the root-source, they regarded all contrivances—manipulations and substitutions—as beneath their notice. They attained the true teaching, thereby rectifying gods and humans and reaping boundless fruit.

Later, the Dao was transmitted as the Gate of Purity and Stillness, yet none succeeded it. Thus arose the teachings of cultivating life: harmonizing yin and yang, exchanging water and fire, drawing from *kan* to fill *li*, piercing the gates of constancy, establishing the foundation and stirring the mercury, setting up the cauldron and kindling the furnace, refining qi and smelting essence, rousing the spirit and primordial origin, congealing the golden elixir, nurturing and gestating it, thereby receiving the numinous embryo and completing one’s true form. Through these postcelestial practices of every kind, one returns to the precelestial true body. Though this falls short of the Most High’s true essence of the *Dao* and *De*, it remains a correct Dharma-eye treasury of cultivation. Yet as its transmission grew distant and its branches multiplied, there arose all manner of heterodox byways and left-handed paths. Stealing fragments of its teachings, they fabricated perverse doctrines, clogging the true path. Some took true yin to nourish the cauldron’s lead, or true yang to augment the cauldron’s mercury; others practiced stealing yin to exchange for yang, inhaling moonlight and exhaling essence to aid its growth. Thus, wicked persons falsely attached themselves to these evasions, setting up cauldrons to harm others for their own gain. Even more outrageously, they committed all manner of evil deeds, cunningly deceiving the ignorant, leading them to fall into wicked arts, lose the true teaching, and forfeit their lives and natures, forever trapped in the wheel of rebirth—deeply pitiable indeed.

There were also those who, deludedly aspiring to the great Dao, knew these to be evil causes yet pursued right awakening without obtaining the true transmission. Seeking on paper, they took all stale words as the Dharma’s milk, mistaking chaff for nourishment. Thus, they sat in stillness, holding their breath and concentrating their spirit, adjusting the fire-timing between midnight and noon. Little did they know that the gate of constancy’s single true aperture remained unlocated—how could they pierce it? Attempting to raise water, they found water could not be raised; striving to lift true yang, they drew it from its original abode, never to recover it. Compared to mere dry sitting, which accomplishes nothing, their calamity was far more dire. Little did they know that the great Dao lies solely in purity and stillness—any contrivance breeds endless ills!

This great Dao originally resides in the Non-Ultimate, the root of the Supreme Ultimate. It generates yin and yang, creates and transforms the ten thousand things, nurtures and sustains living beings. Its functions are vast and boundless; its fundamental substance is thusness—formless and imageless, colorless and soundless, without scent, taste, or dharma. Because it is nothing that can be nothing, it requires nothing to be done. In purity, emptiness, stillness, and tranquility, it is unobstructed in its fundamental substance. Because it is unobstructed, it is undamaged; because it is undamaged, it suffers no loss; because it suffers no loss, the Dao-body is complete. Its fundamental substance is perfectly luminous; its wondrous functions manifest and operate, transforming in ways beyond measure. Responding without intention, it pervades darkness and light, contains heaven and earth, spans past and present, illumines all humankind. Without beginning or end, without large or small, it is nowhere absent, nowhere inactive. Emerging from being, entering non-being, it is the ancestral root of all things.

Thus, to trace the current is not as good as seeking the source. One who attains the source will thereby clarify the current. Though one may trace the current to reach the source, if the current is exhausted, the effort will only multiply complications.

Thus the perfected person expounds the teaching of purity and quiescence, revealing the true mystery within the Jade Chamber, with no other purpose. Solely pointing to the original source, they enable one to transcend from the mystery, sweeping away all else so that the Great Dao becomes luminous.

One who illuminates the Great Dao employs no deliberate mind, yet this mind is truly realized. Because it is without deliberate use, nothing is not attained, and in attaining nothing, there is nothing not penetrated. Through this all-penetration, one becomes a true person. Awaiting such a true person, the wondrous Dao unfolds.

Alas, the prevailing winds of the age gradually dilute its purity and dull its clarity. From these winds arise such people; from such people arise such teachings. Those who adhere to the Confucian teaching dismiss Buddhism and Daoism. Though they engage in debate, they merely discuss its branches, never fully grasping its origin. Thus, their refutations are often flawed and incomplete.

In their ultimate purport, Confucians speak of this life, this mind, this nature; Daoists do the same, and Buddhists likewise. In their initial endowment and reception, there is no difference. Only in their cultivation and attainment may there be divergence.

For Confucians, to be sincere is to first extend one’s knowledge, yet the extension of knowledge is fundamentally empty. Thus, one seeks it in things, making the investigation of things substantive. Once the nature of things is clarified, the original knowledge is thereby extended. With the substance of knowledge thoroughly penetrated, one is pervaded by luminous harmony. The governance of the five senses is as if illuminated, with no obscuration. The lord of the mind is at peace, and the Mandate of Heaven resides within me.

This nature and life are one across the Three Teachings. Not only Confucians can clarify their virtue; Buddhists do likewise. Yet their methods of cultivation differ according to their respective lineages.

The Buddhist teaching speaks of emptiness. Thus, the lesser śrāvakas, through their hearing, fall into the second level. Why is this so? Because the śrāvaka’s awakening plays with spiritual penetrations, attained through cleverness and insight. If such practices are misapplied, one easily strays onto other paths, losing one’s original nature. Even without misapplication, as one follows the tracks, one remains bound. In the Dharma of the Buddha, to be transcendentally and profoundly attuned, without the slightest attachment or hindrance, is not their ultimate purport. Thus, they sweep away all written words to seek the true essence alone. Once the true essence is thoroughly penetrated, the myriad transformations are all pervaded.

The śrāvakas’ investigation is none other than the extension of knowledge; their insight and realization are none other than sincerity and rectitude. When sincerity is achieved, clarity naturally follows—what need is there for the labor of extending knowledge? For the extension of knowledge belongs to the Dao, serving as the threshold between dream and awakening. Sincerity and rectitude distinguish between humans and ghosts.
