The capital assembly is this body’s numinous and wondrous palace, the source of responsive adaptability. Master Ziyu said, *"All things are complete within me—what else could this be if not the capital assembly?"*

Moreover, the Upper Prime’s nine qi are the yang qi of nine: in conduct, they correspond to wood; in time, to spring. Thus, the Upper Prime’s birth in the first month rides the qi of spring. In constancy, they correspond to benevolence, and benevolence governs compassion and love—hence its function is to bestow blessings. In the human body’s generative spirits, they are the qi of the Embryonic Life Origin.

The Middle Prime’s seven qi are the yang qi of seven: in conduct, they correspond to metal; in time, to autumn. Thus, the Middle Prime’s birth in the seventh month rides the qi of autumn. In constancy, they correspond to righteousness, and righteousness governs decisiveness—hence its function is to pardon sins. In the human body’s generative spirits, they are the qi of the Ethereal Soul’s Life Origin.

The Lower Prime’s five qi are the yang qi of five: in conduct, they correspond to water; in time, to winter. Thus, the Lower Prime’s birth in the tenth month rides the qi of water. In constancy, they correspond to wisdom, and wisdom dispels obstructions—hence its function is to resolve adversities. In the human body’s generative spirits, they are the qi of the Corporeal Soul’s Life Origin.

These Three Primes, within the human body, govern the palaces of the Mud Pill, the Cinnabar Field, and the Cavern Chamber. Whenever a person conceives a thought, they immediately know it, for their numinous brightness is interpenetrating. Those who attain the Dao are all recommended by the Three Primes to serve as the Supreme Lord’s privy councilors, officials in charge of the retribution of good and evil, weighing the merits of cultivators, demoting or promoting immortals, and overseeing all spirits. Their merit is great, their authority weighty.

Yet though the immortal scriptures have long been transmitted in the world, and many uphold them, their purport has never been fully elucidated, leaving people unaware. Now, I do not begrudge revealing these secrets, offering earnest and incisive instruction, so that all may recite and uphold them according to the method. When my heart aligns with the Emperor’s heart, the Three Prime Emperor Lords respond in accord with the mind: prayers for blessings bring blessings, supplications to avert misfortune dissolve misfortune.

Formerly, Fada recited the *Lotus Sutra* until he had completed three thousand copies. One day, he visited the Sixth Patriarch, who asked him about the sutra’s meaning. Fada could not answer. The Patriarch said, *"Your name is Dharma-Penetrating, yet you have not penetrated the Dharma."* The Patriarch then expounded the Buddha’s insight, and Fada awakened on the spot. He presented a verse:

*"Three thousand copies of the sutra recited,
Yet Cao Stream’s single phrase was forgotten."*

The Patriarch said, *"Previously, your recitation was merely turned by the sutra; you did not turn the sutra. Only now may you be called a monk who recites the sutra!"*

All you disciples present here, and all sentient beings of the future, when reciting any scripture, must be able to turn the scripture and not be turned by it—then it will be well.

**Chapter Thirty: Revering the Sacred Teachings**

The ancients composed books and established teachings to instruct later generations. When their intent was not fully expressed and words could not make it manifest, they employed parables to elucidate their meaning, allowing people to grasp what lay beyond words and speech. The Buddhist sutras say, *"All those with wisdom must understand through parables."* Thus, the texts of the Three Teachings abound in analogies. Yet their implied meanings are profound and distant, and people often misconstrue them.

Take the *Book of Changes*, for instance: the sage established images to exhaust meaning, and the *Appended Judgments* clarified fortune and misfortune. But its analogies are subtle and far-reaching. For example:
- To warn against yang reaching its extreme above, where fullness cannot last, it says, *"The dragon soars on high—there will be regret."*
- To warn against yin reaching its extreme above, leading to conflict with yang, it says, *"Dragons battle in the wild."*
- Its blood is dark and yellow; to warn against indecision, it speaks of *"a cartload of ghosts."*
- To warn against failing to see things through to the end, where success is rare, it says, *"The fox wets its tail."*

The words of the sixty-four hexagrams are largely analogical. Had the supreme sage not composed the *Image Commentaries* to illuminate their meaning, how would later Confucians have understood them?

Long ago, Lord Wen Shi gazed upon a purple vapor moving from east to west and knew an extraordinary person was near. He then encountered the Most High, who composed the two chapters of the *Dao and Virtue*, unfolding its secret principles—embracing the vast and omitting nothing, however small. Yet much of what it says about governing states and deploying troops is couched in metaphor. Even the Buddhist sutras adorn the Buddha-land as the pure ground of the mind.

When the Most High speaks of governing the state, he refers to ordering this body and mind. Even his references to warfare are metaphors for battling and repelling the demons of yin, overcoming the harms of selfish desires. As the *Changes* says, *"In the shock of campaigning against Gui Fang, after three years, reward comes from a great state."* The *Classic of Yin Convergence* states, *"Cut off profit at its source, and military strength is tenfold; reverse the cycle of day and night, and it is a hundredfold."* The meaning is the same!

As for the passage in the sutra:
*"To gather it, first expand it;
To weaken it, first strengthen it;
To abolish it, first promote it;
To seize it, first give it."*

This is the natural workings of heaven’s movement—like the sun casting a final glow before setting, the year turning suddenly warm before the cold, a person rallying strength before death, or a lamp flaring before going out. There is no difference in principle! Yet this principle is the most difficult for people to grasp, hence it is called *"subtle illumination."* It urges people to foresee impending fortune or misfortune in such matters and to first examine their incipient signs.

Worldly Confucians, failing to perceive this, mistake it for the affairs of rival states and the tactics of vertical and horizontal alliances—is this not a gross error? It also says, *"To reconcile great resentment, there will inevitably remain residual resentment. How can this be considered good?"* This is a sharp rebuke for those who grow complacent in petty peace and forget long-term prudence. It aligns entirely with the *Changes*, which says, *"The noble person reflects on calamity and guards against it beforehand."* Take the case of Zhou and Zheng exchanging hostages, only to later become enemies—is this not clear proof?

Worldly Confucians attribute this to the affairs of Goujian and Wu, unaware that this sutra was composed before the enmity between Wu and Yue arose. To misinterpret its words on reconciling resentment as referring to Wu and Yue is a mistake!

Later, the teachings of the *Dao and Virtue* degenerated into the Legalist school, and the words of the Most High were misconstrued as schemes and deceit—is this not a slander? Long ago, the Supreme Sage inquired about ritual from the Most High. Upon leaving, he said to his disciples, *"I observe that Laozi is like a dragon!"* Even one as sagely as the Supreme Sage praised him as *"like a dragon."* Yet later Confucians, with their narrow views, disparage him—are they not inferior even to the Supreme Sage?

In the past, Shu Sun Wu Shu slandered Confucius, and Duanmu Ci reproached him for not knowing his own measure. Those who today attack the Most High and denigrate the *Dao and Virtue* are likewise merely ignorant of their own limits. In the end, this does no harm to the Most High.

Yet among the dozens of commentators on the *Dao and Virtue*—even the eminent Master Kumarajiva, whose talent and insight surpassed others—his commentary on the *Dao and Virtue* still faulted it for not discussing the mind. How much more so for the rest? However, the sutra’s words, *"Do not display what may be desired, so the mind will not be confused,"* precisely warn against the deluded mind and urge guarding the true mind.

*"The sage has no constant mind; he takes the people’s mind as his mind."* Does this differ from the ancient Buddha’s verse, *"The mind is fundamentally unborn; it arises due to conditions"*?

The Most High also said, *"Ritual is the thinning of loyalty and trust, and the beginning of chaos."* This does not refer to the essence of ritual as thin or chaotic. Loyalty and trust are the foundation of ritual; what the world calls ritual is merely the superficial trappings of form. The *Book of Documents* says, *"The offerings are abundant in ceremony, but the ceremony does not extend to the substance."* This is what is meant by the thinning of loyalty and trust.

Wang Mang was humble and deferential to scholars, yet he usurped the Han throne—is this not the beginning of chaos? The Most High’s words serve as a mirror for later generations! Yet worldly Confucians accuse him of abandoning ritual and righteousness—is this not excessive?

In the past, I read the *Dao and Virtue* and deeply lamented my inability to fully penetrate its meaning. Though there were many commentaries, from Master He Shang onward, each clung to a single perspective, and few could reveal its depths. Fortunately, since attaining the truth, I have daily discussed it with the assembled sages and only now have I grasped its wonders.

Today, in expounding this teaching, I have briefly explained a few points to you, my disciples here present. Do not imitate worldly Confucians, recklessly slandering without restraint. As for the sutra’s passages that remain unexhaustively clarified, each of you should comprehend them through their meaning, not being bound by words and letters.

If one merely clings to the written words without grasping the fundamental intent of the Most High in establishing this teaching, it is no wonder that phrases like "the absolute teaching is without sorrow" are so often misconstrued. The Buddhist school misinterprets it as "no learning," while Confucian scholars slander it as the abandonment of poetry and books—nearly equating those who follow the Way with beasts of burden! You, my disciples, must revere and trust my words, free from the slightest partial knowledge or biased views. Rely on meaning, not on language; rely on wisdom, not on mere cognition. Through such inquiry, you may pervade the scriptures of immortals, penetrate the treasures of the sutras, and find no contradiction with the books of the Confucians.

**Chapter Thirty-One: Revering the Stars and the Dipper**

Within the cosmos, human life is endowed with the qi of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang, formed from the essence and blood of father and mother. Regardless of wealth or poverty, nobility or lowliness, all possess a luminous, awakened nature—the seed of kalpas past—while their fate is truly bound to Heaven. Heaven’s seven luminaries govern all celestial bodies, ordering creation and serving as the master of the human body. Longevity or early death, prosperity or adversity, fortune or misfortune—none are beyond their measure.

Yet the seven luminaries depend on the Jade Pivot and Jade Balance to maintain their proper course, for the marvel of this pivot and balance turns the four seasons and governs the kalpas. Thus, the sage emperors of old first commanded Xi and He to observe the celestial patterns, scrutinize the Jade Pivot and Jade Balance, and align the seven luminaries. Later sages established divine teachings for transformation, giving rise to rites of revering the stars and worshipping the Dipper, as well as ceremonies to avert calamity and resolve misfortune. The *Jade Pivot Sutra* teaches: *"To escape the three disasters and nine perils, bow in stillness at night to the Northern Asterism."* The Most High, in the Shu capital, transmitted the *True Sutra of the Five Dippers* and the *Heart Sutra of the Dipper Mother*. Thereafter, those who devised rites for the Dipper’s altar numbered in the dozens. Yet each based their rules on where they perceived divine transformation and response, resulting in varying degrees of detail.

For instance, the method of *"Revering the Two Stars of the Three Primes"* is exceedingly concise, but people often find it too brief and few practice it. Works like the *Great Brahma Unifying Chapter* are overly verbose, lacking profound subtlety. The *Dipper Rites* expounded by Emperor Wen suit scholars but fail to benefit the common folk. Thus, the gates of Dipper reverence are many, and throughout the ages, those who cultivated reality and attained the Dao—ascending to immortality through Dipper rites—are beyond count.

Yet, surveying the treasuries of scriptures, the Buddhist rites of reverence surpass those of our tradition. Even the path of Sanskrit sounds is more esoteric than our own rituals. Thus, in the Chan school, there are those who practice and attain clarity of mind and vision of nature. As for the Dipper rites transmitted in the world, they consist only of bowing ceremonies, lacking secret oral instructions. I once composed a verse:

*Many are the gates to Dipper rites,*
*Yet all converge like a needle’s thread.*
*Silent and still, in profound quietude,*
*In darkness, one meets the Star Lords.*

*Within the altar’s hush,*
*Let no chaos intrude.*
*First from the Sea of Origin’s cavity,*
*Then ascend to Kunlun’s height.*

*The Dipper Mother’s and Jade Emperor’s decrees,*
*When fused, reach the supreme vehicle.*
*Thus is the Golden Elixir attained,*
*And the Infant formed in an instant.*

This Dipper formula has been transmitted for ages, yet none practice it. For people know only of the Northern Dipper in the Palace of the Jade Pivot, unaware that within their own bodies lies a Jade Dipper, which daily circulates through the entire form, flowing through the hundred vessels from midnight to the hour of the pig, never ceasing for a moment. Only those of superior insight first recognize their life-star’s Dipper, never departing from its movement within the body, and thus attain the Dao and achieve reality.

Yet this can only be spoken of to those of the highest capacity, for only they can practice it. Why is the Northern Dipper within the body? The White Jade Tortoise Terrace is the numinous terrace of the heart, and the divine Xiezhi’s precious seat is the heart’s spiritual transformation. The Jade Pivot’s treasury is the heart’s emptiness and numinosity, through which the five qi are mobilized! As the alchemical classics say: *"Why seek midnight at the edge of the sky? Within the body, the yang arises of itself!"* Thus, at midnight, when the first yang stirs, it is no different from the Dipper’s handle turning. At this hour, one who reverently worships the Dipper, riding the initial arising of yang, emulates Heaven’s ceaseless movement, and practices in accordance with meaning.

Now, for those who revere the Dipper, I proclaim a swift, essential, and secret method: Before the rite, fast and purify with utmost sincerity. At night, first enter the Dipper chamber, still all thoughts, and strike the teeth nine times. Stand upright, facing north, and bow in reverence. Envision the golden countenance of the Heavenly Mother descending from above, the Nine Emperors and Two Sovereigns standing to her left and right, and the assembled sages arrayed around. Empty all distractions and abide in silent concentration.

Then rise to perform the rites. The mind must be utterly focused, the spirit utterly still, the qi utterly solemn, the demeanor utterly dignified, the appearance utterly reverent, the voice utterly even, the tone utterly harmonious, the resonance utterly clear. Speed and slowness must follow measure, advance and retreat must follow rule, kneeling and bowing must follow rhythm, and rising and pausing must follow decorum. Whether at home, in a temple, alone, or in a communal gathering, all should proceed thus. Discipline body and mind, allowing no disturbance.

First bow to the august titles, then recite the Sanskrit sounds. Now, the Sanskrit sounds of the Dipper Mother, as found in the Buddhist and Daoist canons, number over a dozen, making them difficult to recite in full. Among those recorded in the treasuries, none are more essential than the *Heart Mantra*. You, my disciples, listen carefully, as I shall recite it:

The *Heart Mantra of the Dipper Mother* begins with *"Namo,"* drawn out slightly longer. Two Sanskrit syllables are rendered as two Chinese characters, yet chanted as one flowing sound.

The *Heart Mantra of the Northern Dipper* states:

Chant the characters beside the "mouth" radical in sequence, with *lo*, *ju*, *hong* following the same pattern. Exclude the "mouth" radical when chanting, with characters such as *na* and others following likewise. This is the *Great Brahman Heart Mantra of the Northern Dipper*, the hidden name of the great demon lords of the Three Realms. The Most High proclaimed it to instruct those who cultivate the true Dao. If one recites it without ceasing, all demon hosts will submit in awe, the hundred evils will flee, malevolent ghosts will be annihilated, and no calamity shall arise.

This Sanskrit sound is most wondrous and subtle, capable of curing all chronic and stubborn illnesses, and of averting all baleful stars and malignant influences. Should one’s life palace or fate be in disarray—whether afflicted by yearly misfortune, monthly calamity, clashes, conflicts, or punitive encounters—recitation of this mantra may dissolve and dispel them. The key lies in sincerity and reverence, for then the marvel of resonance will be most efficacious and divine.

The human face and head possess seven apertures, which inwardly correspond to the heart. The seven *zhen*-spirits of the *po* receive their vitality from the Dipper. Thus, the apertures of the Dipper originally connect with the apertures of the heart, and the human heart is none other than the celestial heart. Above every person’s head shines the Three Terraces and the Northern Dipper, which record their transgressions. For above the crown of every person’s head, there exists an inherent luminosity of self-nature—whether red, purple, yellow, or white—its hue varying. Only those of the Dao possess a light that is lofty and vast. Those who do good emit red or yellow light, while evildoers reveal black qi above their crowns, their nature-light obscured and unable to manifest. Thus, the Northern Dipper, observing the presence or absence of this light above their heads, determines the goodness or wickedness of each person. Yet this crown-light is known only to the divine; mortals remain unaware of it.

The method of worshipping the Dipper, though not equal to the refinement of the Golden Elixir, may still—if practiced alongside it—lead to liberation from the cycle of rebirth and attainment of immortality. Thus, the *Heart Sutra of the Dipper Mother* states: *"For those who refine the Great Elixir of Nine Returns and Seven Reversions, recitation of this mantra brings sudden awakening to the subtle barrier, the numinous light appears before them, and vitality naturally flourishes."* This is akin to the Buddhist practice of reciting *"Amitābha Buddha"* to seek rebirth in the Pure Land, both yielding wondrous fruition. Is this not a swift and joyous path to transcendence and realization?

*Chapter Thirty-Two: On the Unification of Cultivation and Attainment*

The Heavenly Worthy says: "What I now expound are the daily, constant classics—the essential Dao of cultivating truth and the stepping-stones to sagehood. They are neither abstruse nor recondite, nor do they contain anything strange or uncanny. The superior person may practice them, and even those of middling or lesser capacity will find nothing difficult in them. Yet though the matter is not inherently difficult, from the human perspective, it is ever deemed not easy. Long ago, Chan Master Wu Chao said of the words *'Refrain from all evil, practice all good'*: a three-year-old child knows them, yet a hundred-year-old elder cannot put them into practice. Precisely this—what is not difficult in itself—is what no one finds easy to do. As Gongsun Chou said: *'Lofty and splendid, it seems like ascending to heaven.'*

But for those who uphold these teachings, the first requirement is to generate the *'mind of right faith.'* Knowing that the three karmas must be purified, one is cautious in demeanor, circumspect in speech, and purifies through faith to its utmost. Knowing that heaven and earth must be revered, one rises at dawn without daring to jest or waver, and reverence gives rise to faith. In serving one’s lord, one should be loyal: steadfast in one’s duties, loyalty becomes the vessel of faith. In serving one’s parents, one should be filial: rising early with devotion, filial piety perfects faith. Through faith, husband and wife achieve harmony; through faith, kinship is deepened. In the way of friendship, profound faith fulfills human relationships. In following a teacher’s instruction, one reverently obeys with faith. Though ghosts and spirits are subtle, faith must not deceive them; though cause and effect are minute, faith must not treat them as false. The words of sages must not be slighted with faith; the teachings of buddhas and immortals must not be taken lightly with faith.

The second requirement is to generate the *'mind of steadfastness.'* Do not begin with diligence only to slacken in the end. Do not, upon seeing something different, think of changing course. Do not, fearing others’ ridicule, alter your original path. Do not, swayed by frivolous opinions, abandon your pure integrity. Do not, deeming good too small to be beneficial, fail to practice it. Do not, deeming evil too small to cause harm, fail to cast it aside. Do not draw boundaries to limit yourself. Do not advance sharply only to retreat swiftly.

The third requirement is to generate the *'mind of perpetuity.'* The *Book of Changes* says: *'If one does not maintain one’s virtue constantly, one may incur shame.'* Thus, a rope a thousand fathoms long can sever wood, and a stream a yard long can pierce stone—all through duration. As the saying goes: *'A trickle unceasing becomes a river; a hair’s breadth unremoved will require an axe-handle.'* Is this not the result of long perseverance? If one can generate these three minds—from beginning to end without interruption, ever mindful and unwavering—then bodily diligence and enduring effort will transform the dull into the enlightened and the weak into the strong. With this, entering the Dao is not difficult; with this, aspiring to immortality is not difficult! One may save the kalpa, dispel calamities, pray for blessings, resolve adversities, preserve life, prolong existence, realize truth, and attain sagehood—all through this scripture!

Yet this scripture gathers the essence of Confucianism and Buddhism, embodying the principles of the Three Teachings. Some pedantic scholars may falsely accuse my words of conflating Confucianism with Buddhism or Buddhism with Daoism, giving rise to ridicule or slander, for they do not comprehend the principle that the Three Teachings share a single source. Therefore, I have cited Confucian classics, Buddhist sutras, and Daoist scriptures side by side, uniting the three into one, to leave behind these instructions and admonitions. You, my assembled disciples, and all sentient beings of the world and future ages—if you can deeply believe my words, savor their meaning, and engage in true cultivation and realization, not only will my wish be fulfilled, but even the sagely heart of the August Emperor who expounds the Dao will not be disappointed."

Thereupon, the assembled immortals, having heard this, bowed their heads in reverence and praise, and recited a verse:

*"How wondrous!"*

The Great Preceptor of Primordial Origin
Expounds the grand canon of cultivating the true,
With a compassionate heart widely delivering all in the final kalpa—
The Dharma-wheel turns across the Ganges’ sands of worlds.

Its origin traces back to the primal chaos,
Where the Dao of Heaven shines bright and its principle most manifest.
Serving Heaven relies wholly on a reverent heart,
Loyalty and filial piety unfold from the mind’s core.

Brothers and kin share the same qi in mutual affection,
Husband and wife should harmonize the home, as the *Odes* esteem.
Trust and friendship embody the virtue of shared illumination,
Honoring teachers and revering the Dao are human relations’ norm.

The Five Constants, unmarred, form cultivation’s foundation;
Within, preserve the true origin, stabilizing essence and qi.
If one further accumulates merit and piles up deeds,
Doing good brings the greatest joy—this each must reflect.

The Three Teachings have ever sprung from one source,
For the nature of mind originally belongs alike to sage and fool.
Cease saying cause and effect lack evidence—
Has good or evil ever lacked its fortune or misfortune?

Evil brings its own calamity, good its own blessing,
Ghosts and spirits’ retribution unfolds layer upon layer.
The immortals’ scriptures and Buddhist sutras make this abundantly clear—
Do not imitate fools who, knowing no taboos,
Slander Buddhas and immortals with reckless tongues,
For the hells’ bitter retribution is the worst of destinies.

Those who awaken should swiftly change their strings and alter their course,
Following and believing the Heavenly Worthy’s words.
With fervent diligence, strive earnestly to cultivate—
Seek the Great Elixir’s Dao with wholehearted devotion,
And delve diligently into the jade-classics’ depths.
The work is not distant—it lies within the mind’s core.

I have heard the Transcendent Master’s profound teaching,
And unconsciously leap with joy in my heart.
May all beings in the final kalpa who wish to escape rebirth
Hold fast to these words,
Reciting and upholding them unceasingly, day after day.
When the nature of mind is realized, all matters are complete.

This scripture encompasses all the Daoist canons—
To transcend the mundane, only the mind’s practice suffices.
When practice perfects the wondrous truth, it becomes like a bright mirror,
Returning to the origin and restoring the One Supreme Ultimate.
Even if the void were shattered, what would remain?
In truth and emptiness alike, the Dao is but One.

Thereupon, the assembled immortals having finished their verses, the Heavenly Worthy again addressed the gathered disciples:
“All of you, my children, should each follow these teachings and practice them, widely propagating them.”

The Heavenly Worthy having finished expounding the scripture, rose from the Dharma seat. Thereupon, celestial blossoms rained down, fragrant jade incense wafted through the void, phoenixes and cranes soared, and auspicious mists filled the chamber. The assembled disciples bowed their heads in reverence, received the teachings with faith, and withdrew to practice accordingly.

**Eulogy:**
The wondrous essence of the Three in One,
Encompasses all scriptures in its scope.
Tracing the source to its root, it points the way of practice—
Sincere and pure, one worships the stars.
Rescuing the kalpa, dispelling misfortune,
Far and near rejoice in ascending peace.

**Yixingzi’s Heart Mantra of the Dipper Mother**
The Heart Mantra of the Northern Dipper, expounded:

The Dipper Mother, a native of India during the Dragon Han Primordial Kalpa, transmitted Sanskrit mantras akin to those of the Buddha, all belonging to the Sanskrit sounds and script. As the people of the Eastern Land did not recognize Sanskrit characters, earlier masters and perfected ones transcribed them using Confucian characters. Yet these transcriptions, unlike Confucian texts, proved difficult to pronounce correctly. Often, the same sound was rendered differently—
for the Sanskrit tones are identical, while the annotated characters may vary slightly in length.
A "combined sound" refers to a single original Sanskrit character translated into two Chinese characters, yet still chanted as one continuous sound.

When Patriarch Lü later expounded this mantra, he revealed the Dipper Mother’s dharmic form, saying:
“She has four heads and eight arms, with the countenance of a celestial being. Clad in a celestial azure cloud-brocade Dharma robe, atop her head rests a golden pagoda of nine tiers. From its summit blooms the *manyu-pātāla* flower, called the ‘Flower of No Sorrow,’ whose hue surpasses the *udumbara* and whose fragrance is unmatched. Her two central hands form a mudra, while the other six hold: one the sun, one the moon, one a halberd with a banner inscribed in gold with ‘Supreme Thunder Ancestor Great Emperor,’ one a vajra, one a bow, and one an arrow. Seated upon a lotus throne, beneath her is a white jade tortoise dais. To its left and right stand the Heavenly Kings *Yufan* and *Miaofan*, attended by ten thousand sages and a thousand perfected ones.”

Here, for clarity in Sanskrit pronunciation and phrasing, the above account is appended.

**Preface to the *Hán Sān Yǔ Lù* (Record of Han San’s Words), *Complete Works of Patriarch Lü* (Volume 28)**
Of old, the Confucians had their *Yǔ Lèi* (Classified Sayings), and the Buddhists their *yǔ lù* (recorded sayings), wherein disciples recorded their masters’ answers to questions—every word and phrase cherished, lest they be forgotten, to aid in their studies. Yet few such works endure. The *Hán Sān Yǔ Lù*, though but commonplace words of daily use, fully embodies the profound and subtle Dao. For the Dao is complete within oneself, thus its teachings are intimate and savory. Its discourse resembles the *Yǔ Lèi* of the Luoyang and Min schools, yet no other preacher or lecturer could approach even a fraction of its depth.

The Emei Immortal Master remarked: “Each drop is sweet dew, seeping into the heart and spleen. What distinction is there between scripture and recorded sayings? Truly, these are words of wisdom!”

The recorders were: Gentleman Huang Chengshu, Gentleman Wu Yishu, and Gentleman Li Wushu.
The compilers were: Gentleman Sun Shoushu and my nephew Yun Cheng.
The continuator was myself, along with Gentleman Huang.

In recent years, in Qian (Guizhou), we gathered the accumulated teachings and scriptural expositions from Chu (Hubei), combining them with the earlier records into one volume. Yet the *Hán Sān Yǔ Lù* contains countless such sayings, most now scattered and lost, never fully compiled—what a pity!

**The *Hán Sān Yǔ Lù***

Patriarch Lü said:
“The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao.
The Dao that cannot be spoken, yet is spoken, is called the *Dao-fu* (Enclosure of the Dao).
The Dao that cannot be practiced, yet is practiced, is named the *Dao-du* (Moth of the Dao).
Subtle! Subtle!
Before heaven and earth existed, where did the Dao reside?
Once heaven and earth came to be, where is the Dao found?
It enters the nine abysses, penetrates the nine heavens, encompasses the six directions, and revolves through the two poles.
The wise have no use for their brightness, the skillful no place to apply their strength.
With clumsiness, one conceals it; with foolishness, one guards it; with clarity, one contains it; with stillness, one nurtures it—then, with spirit, one illuminates it.
Thus, to reach the utmost in spirit, one must nurture it.
To attain nurturance, one must contain it.
To achieve containment, one must first have steadfastness.
The more steadfast the guard, the deeper the concealment.
Only through concealment can one guard it; only through guarding can one contain it.
When nurturance is complete, the spirit becomes unfathomable.
Yet this great Dao truly lies in non-action.
It cannot be called void, nor can it be called real—void and real alike are the supreme Dao.
When lesser scholars hear these words, they mock their profundity.
What recourse is there against their mockery?
Those who know not the void—how can they embody the real?
Those who know not the real—how can they embody the void?
Clinging to traces without transformation, grasping at forms in pursuit,
some practice unlawful arts, veering into heterodox paths,
stuffing their chests with delusions, failing to awaken to the Great *Tai Xu*.
How could they know that the subtle and profound lie not apart from the lord of the heart?
The cunning play with deceit, seeking shortcuts for swift attainment;
the clever flaunt their private knowledge, imagining divergent paths to the realm of truth.
Thus they devise all manner of alchemical and refinement techniques, drifting ever further from the Dao!
Though they may speak of subtle words to seek the heart’s truth,
if true effort is lacking, it is but empty talk—how does it touch the Dao?

You, my disciples, must bring forth utmost sincerity, eradicate self-interest, and let cunning and cleverness perish.
With clumsiness, conceal it; with foolishness, guard it; with clarity, contain it; with stillness, nurture it—then, with spirit, illuminate it.
Over time, as familiarity grows, the Great Elixir will form, and you will share the merit of the highest sages!
But if profit and desire remain unabandoned, the ego unremoved,
and you recklessly discuss the great Dao, you will only create obstacles.
That lesser scholars do not practice this is deeply lamentable!”

The Dao—I cannot know it, nor can I speak of it.
Since I cannot know it, my knowledge is of no use;
since I cannot speak of it, my words are of no use.
My knowledge is of no use, for there is nothing to know;
my words are of no use, for there is nothing to say.
Since there is nothing to say, there is truly nothing to be said;
since there is nothing to know, there is truly nothing to be known.
Yet if one still seeks to know where nothing can be known,
what one knows are but the Dao’s peripheral branches;
if one still forces words where nothing can be said,
what one says are but the Dao’s superficial layers.
Subtle indeed! Subtle indeed!
Form yet no form, image yet no image.
It cannot be known, yet nothing is not known—this is true knowing.
It cannot be spoken, yet nothing is not spoken—this is the ultimate word.
Without knowing, without words, the Dao is thus realized.
If the Dao is thus realized, what more is there to say?
What more is there to know?
No knowing, no knowing; no words, no words—this is the wondrous Dao.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Sincerity begets clarity; clarity begets sincerity.
The wondrous secret of the Golden Elixir—
a single, unbroken, and steadfast essence.
Nurture your spirit,
in purity, stillness, emptiness, and silence.
Vast and undifferentiated,
never forget your original face.
Mountains green, waters clear—all share the same principle.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

For those who study the Dao, first cultivate qi.
If qi is coarse, the heart becomes restless;
if the heart is restless, courage swells;
if courage swells, human desires run wild;
if desires run wild, the heart of Dao is unsettled;
if the heart of Dao is unsettled,
all manner of evil causes and conditions converge.
Thus, cultivating qi is the essential work of entering the Dao.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

The Great Dao is utterly impartial, its workings subtle and wondrous.
Even those burdened by form and qi may awaken and comprehend.
Yet if one indulges in self-interest and cunning,
obstacles arise, and confusion deepens.
To penetrate that single point of the pass—
the Three Treasures are but husks;
to break free from the thousand layers of entanglement—
the six senses are but karmic bonds.
Turn sharply back—
the vast sea stretches on, yet one reaches the other shore;
act swiftly—
the boundless void clears, and the azure sky appears.
Only knowing to fret over the body’s future,
heedless of compounding errors!
Striving to build foundations for descendants,
like oxen and horses toiling,
accumulating grave transgressions in the mortal world,
amidst clashing blades and spears.
Know this: a hundred years is but a fleeting span—
how can the body endure for a thousand ages?
Best to rein in the mind-steed and heart-ape,
and apply effort to subdue the dragon and tame the tiger.
If one does not focus the mind,
all polishing is in vain;
even if one recites scriptures daily,
it is but wasted breath!
From here, each must seek the upward path—
do not remain lost in the common. Strive on,
for I shall not speak again.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Master Xiao Xiu-shu admonished:
“A boundless expanse—where is the shore?
Where is the place of death?
You fear you cannot reach that place of death!”

"What use is abandoning the body? Better to seek the True Person at this very moment! Barren Chan is of no benefit—you must first sit in stillness for three months, passing a hundred days and nights here. Only then may you see how it is, and only then can you reach that place of death.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Master asked Liu Shou-shu, “Can you grasp even one or two points from my words? Then speak of one or two.”

Shou-shu replied, “Is it the Primordial?”

The Master answered, “The One is not the Primordial. Has the Primordial ever been confined to the word ‘One’? Since the first stroke cleaved the heavens, it has already fallen into the lesser vehicle. Do you also understand the meaning in my writings? Speak of it in terms of skin and flesh.”

“Strip away the skin and flesh, and the bones and marrow appear.”

The Master further asked Shou-shu, “Explain the meaning of emptiness and fullness!”

Shou-shu replied, “Emptiness is the Primordial.”

The Master said, “Where does the Primordial stand?”

“This is the foundation of the Primordial, not the Primordial itself. Only when essence, qi, and spirit are set aside does the Primordial arise. Refining the Three Treasures is the work of the posterior heaven—when one reaches the Primordial, such efforts are no longer needed! The Primordial is a state of utter forgetfulness and nothingness, where not even a trace of thought can intrude. The moment a single thought arises, it is no longer the Primordial!”

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

"If any among you remain unclear, present a question on a single point."

Wu Yishu responded, "When first beginning practice, how should this heart-mind be employed?"

The Master answered, "At the very outset, this heart-mind must be singular, its attention fixed upon the crucial pass. Once practice has begun, however, one attains its subtleties. Then this heart-mind must be empty, with no object of attention. Such is the secret of the Great Elixir—thus, thus!"

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

The Master asked, "After the Infant is formed, what stage has been reached?"

At that moment, Shoushu mistakenly replied, "That is not what I asked you!"

"After this formation, what stage is attained?"

"After its formation, one has already departed from the posterior heaven and glimpsed the time of the Primordial—do you understand? The Primordial is non-doing. Once the Infant is formed, it is the Primordial, and one must practice non-doing. If the heart-mind does not reach the state of utter forgetfulness, thoughts will arise at the slightest touch—this is not non-doing! If it is not non-doing, the Three Calamities will arise."

Shoushu asked about "the principle of movement and stillness." The answer was: "Without movement, there is stagnation; without stillness, there is chaos. In every movement and every stillness, what is precious is spontaneity! Yin and yang are the spontaneity of movement and stillness. The cyclical progression of the four seasons is also the spontaneity of movement and stillness. As for the Supreme Ultimate, it is the spontaneity of movement reaching its extreme and turning to stillness, and stillness reaching its extreme and turning to movement. Only the Non-Ultimate is without movement or stillness!"

Shoushu further inquired about the teachings from the *Three Grades*, seeking guidance from the lofty perfected ones. The answer was: "How could the Infant, once formed, still not comprehend the state of utter emptiness? However, once the Infant is formed, one must not hastily allow it to leave its dwelling. It may be nurtured for ten or twenty years, or even thirty or fifty years—only then is it permissible. As for the method of nurturing, it lies solely in non-doing. Otherwise, it will be difficult to escape the Three Calamities! You disciples may cross-reference my words with this text."

The Great Dao is nameless, the Great Dao is formless.
Seek it in the midst of nearness and distance,
Attain it between intention and non-intention.
Forget the self, forget things,
Without sound, without scent.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Our gate is vast, our precepts most strict;
Our Way is impartial, our commandments most solemn!
Those who follow the dharma-bridges of our gate,
Who uphold the precept-practices of our teaching,
Must make heart and mouth as one.
With the Dao-mind firm and true,
Retire to secluded dwelling,
Uninvolved in worldly affairs,
Free from self-imposed toil and disturbance,
Loosening bonds and casting off fetters.
Do not seek glory only to invite disgrace,
But strive to abandon the perverse and return to the upright.
Abide in the feminine, nurture the primordial,
And the Dao will attain true stability.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

To the monks of Ling Shan Monastery, it was asked:
"Where lies Ling Shan?
Do you know the dharma-gate of your own tradition?"

"Neither bound to place nor confined by thought—
Ling Shan is not within the city,
nor in the Western Regions,
nor even within the heart!"

"Do you dwell in the place of Ling Shan?"
"Dwelling in Ling Shan, yet not knowing Ling Shan!"

"Where then does Ling Shan dwell?"
"Within white jade light, pavilions appear—
Dust upon dust, realm upon realm, vain to pursue.
In the tip of a brush, mountains and rivers lie vast—
Where else may Ling Shan be cherished?

Speak not idly, make no contrivance:
Before your eyes, fragrant blossoms and jade candles—
All is the Western Paradise."

"I shall tell you—listen well!
Your gate is fundamentally empty; my Dao even more so.
Empty of what is empty—what is there to investigate?
Know this: this Dao emerges from one source,
returns to one cave.

Seeking life in stacks of old paper—
how different from a fool recounting dreams!
Thus, my Dao attains perfection in non-attachment of mind;
your gate exalts non-attachment to phenomena.
Yet to know non-attachment to phenomena
is still to harbor mind.

Why not empty this mind as well?
Would that not be most excellent!

Of late, Chan monks and seekers of learning—
how do they differ from those who toil in side gates,
wasting spirit in vain?
No true fruit is borne!

I tell you: ancient Buddhas and immortals of old
all applied effort in the real!
Had the Snow Mountains lacked six years of ascetic practice,
how could the sight of a star evoke a smile?

Today’s cultivators merely sit upon meditation cushions,
repeating one or two phrases—
the dregs of wild foxes’ spittle—
indulging in reckless thought!
The simple and sincere pass their lives in emptiness;
the sharp-tongued and clever sport nimble jaws.
They fabricate a few phrases of ‘mouth Chan,’
deceiving later students with sermons and Dharma halls,
thus corrupting the ancestral gate of the ancient Buddhas.
Alas! Alas!"

Such matters are self-evident to the enlightened, yet obscure to the benighted. Even within our own Daoist tradition, those who speak endlessly of "cultivation" fill the world—yet how many truly grasp the principle of emptiness and fullness? You have entered my gate solely to become a vessel of the Way. If you serve with sincere reverence, you will find your own path to mastery—no need to blindly endure another’s painful blows!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

When the spirit is not empty, it grows rigid and inert, like a stagnant canal. If it does not decay, it will soon turn foul in color and taste. Only through emptiness does it remain unobstructed; unobstructed, it clings to nothing, flowing freely and vividly as an empty valley: a single cry echoes, and a chorus answers. Thus, the human spirit must be empty yet undying—only then can one penetrate the profound secrets of the mysterious pass and attain the wondrous transformations of spiritual communion.

From ancient times to the present, those who study the Dao have achieved the coalescence of the infant and the manifestation of the yang spirit—yet all ultimately prove useless! They fail to comprehend the meaning of *"the valley spirit does not die."* The five thousand words of the *Daodejing* distill their subtlety into this single phrase. What profundity lies in mere "refining nature and refining form"? They are but dregs!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Someone asked about "water and fire, Kan and Li."
I replied: "What is water? What is fire? What are Kan and Li? If you say, *'The sun and moon are the great elixir forged by heaven and earth,'* then ponder this: what are the sun and moon? Let me clarify for you.

The sun is the Great Yang, yet within the Great Yang resides a single speck of yin essence. Without this speck of yin, the sun’s warmth would fail to nurture life, scorching all things to ruin. The moon is the Great Yin, yet within the Great Yin lies a single spark of yang qi. Without this spark of yang, the moon would have corporeality but no spirit, unable to illuminate the world. Thus, though the moon is pure yin, it does not depart from yang.

The sun and moon, divided into yin and yang, with yang uniting with yin and yin intermingling with yang—all arise from the qi of heaven and earth, intertwined and harmonized. Therefore, Daoists model the elixir upon the sun and moon, take heaven and earth as their furnace, yin and yang as their firing times, and the primordial Great Ultimate as the original essence of the self.

The meaning of Kan and Li is the same. Why speak not of Qian and Kun but of Kan and Li? Qian is solitary yang, Kun is solitary yin; solitary yang cannot generate, and solitary yin cannot grow. Thus, Daoists do not refer to Qian and Kun as the *head of the elixir*, but to Kan and Li.

Within Kan, a single yang resides amid two yins—yin envelops yang, yielding the power of generation. Within Li, a single yin resides amid two yangs—yang envelops yin, yielding the capacity to accomplish. Therefore, Daoists first employ Kan and Li to align the primordial elixir, then extract the single yang from Kan and merge it with the single yin within Li, transforming it into pure Qian and restoring the original primordial state.

Yet people only know Kan as water and Li as fire, taking their interaction as the secret of the elixir—unaware that it is nothing other than the single qi of the self. Qi possesses both yin and yang; the unenlightened fail to distinguish their intermingling. Thus, those who study the Dao must first discern the boundaries of yin and yang, then borrow from one to supplement the other.

Essence and spirit are not separate from qi—hence Daoists speak not of *essence and spirit* but solely of *qi*."

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Someone asked, "How does one distinguish yin and yang qi?"
I replied: "In detail: the clear is yang, the turbid is yin; exhalation is yang, inhalation is yin; ascent is yang, descent is yin; above is yang, below is yin; left is yang, right is yin; heart qi is yang, kidney qi is yin; liver wood is yang, lung metal is yin. In summary: the entire human body is yin, save for a single speck of yang essence!"

Another asked, "Where does this speck of yang essence reside?"
I replied: "This is the true seed of immortality and Buddhahood, the true face, the true lifeline. Such matters are not to be lightly discussed."

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Someone asked about the essential meaning of *xing* (nature).
I replied: "Before heaven and earth existed, this *xing* already was. With this *xing*, there came this *qi*. Thus *xing* is the heart-mind of heaven and earth, and *qi* is the body of heaven and earth. How could there be *xing* without *qi*? Or *qi* without *xing*? Yet in heaven and earth, one cannot speak solely of *xing*, nor solely of *qi*. If one says heaven and earth are nothing but *xing*, then what are the high and the low? If one speaks of heaven and earth only in terms of *qi*, then what governs their ceaseless movement, their balance without collapse or fall? Thus when speaking of heaven and earth, one can only say *Dao*. In this way, both *xing* and *qi* are encompassed.

Man receives the *qi* of heaven and earth to be born. With this *xing*, there comes this *qi*; with this *qi*, there comes this form. Without this *qi*, the form dissolves. But without this *xing*, what would govern the *qi*? *Qi* is like a dwelling, *xing* like its master. Once you find the master, there is no need to inquire further about the dwelling. Thus to see *xing* and clarify the heart-mind, there is no need to speak further of refining *qi* or cultivating form.

For beginners, however, who have not yet recognized the dwelling, how can they know the master? Thus to seek the master, one must first visit the dwelling. Once the dwelling is found, one will naturally encounter the master. Yet there are those who find the dwelling but do not recognize the master, or whose master does not respond. This is why I sweep away all else to reveal the *xing* of heaven as the highest aim.

But for beginners, one must first preserve the form. If one does not investigate the vital mechanisms, nurture *qi*, and refine the form, then when the dwelling collapses, the master will have no place to stand. For those disciples who seek a swift path, once my *Three Grades* is completed, follow its methods in practice: the form will be stabilized, the *qi* made whole, and *xing* revealed. Without the labor of nine cycles, the infant spirit will naturally emerge, with wondrous transformations beyond measure."

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Stillness of sound is not as good as stillness of body; stillness of body is not as good as stillness of heart-mind. When the heart-mind is still, all sounds are forgotten; when the heart-mind is still, all sounds are silenced. If the heart-mind is not still, even if one sits in meditation all day, hearing no sounds, the heart-mind has already entered the midst of a myriad sounds and cannot attain a moment of clarity.

Thus those who cultivate the Dao must first cultivate the heart-mind. To begin cultivating the heart-mind, one need not be in a quiet room—it is precisely amid the bustle of activity that one can make an effort, testing the movement and stillness of the heart-mind. If one who cultivates the heart-mind does not start from the midst of activity but seeks only in stillness, then when encountering movement, the previous stillness of the heart-mind will unknowingly be lost. Moreover, when in life is there ever a truly still day? It is best to silently simulate stillness amid the tumult and clamor.

In daily life and eating, one should follow conditions as they come, without deliberate contrivance, lest the heart-mind of the Dao be disturbed."

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Generally, those who cultivate the path do not go beyond cultivating the heart-mind, which governs essence, *qi*, and spirit. The worthy who aspire to sagehood do not go beyond this heart-mind; Daoists who study immortality do not go beyond this heart-mind; Buddhists who seek Buddhahood do not go beyond this heart-mind. The sages of the Three Teachings, in transmitting their teachings to later students, have taught nothing but the cultivation of this one heart-mind.

The heart-mind is the Supreme Ultimate, containing both movement and stillness. Before movement arises, it is the primordial; after movement begins, it falls into the posterior. Thus in utmost stillness, emotions and perceptions are extinguished, and one is truly in the state of the Limitless. But the more one moves, the further one strays, and all guest dust becomes thieves through the six senses.

Thus whether Confucian, Daoist, or Buddhist, though they establish different schools, none depart from the heart-mind in their teachings. My own practice lies in gathering the Three Treasures to form the numinous embryo and opening the five mechanisms to explore the secrets of the Three Pure Ones. Yet in tracing its origin, it all comes down to this heart-mind.

If the heart-mind is not still, it is not empty; if not empty, it is not numinous; if not numinous, it is inert and dull, no different from external things. How then can one form the numinous embryo and complete the Great Elixir?

The Most High taught that the root of practice is clarity and stillness—guarding the feminine, closing the self, and letting the empty valley give birth to spirit. A thousand words, ten thousand phrases, all teach nothing but the cultivation of the heart-mind. All the manipulations and techniques are the inventions of later generations, ever more contrary to the Dao and ever further from it.

Now, in expounding this text, though I dare not claim to have fully revealed the subtleties of the Great Dao, I speak from the heart-mind, uniting the Three Teachings in a single return. May later students not mistake the source of the Dao, and may they not be left without a starting point. Perhaps this may offer some small benefit."

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

The *Three Grades* is a wondrous text I leave to the world, a Dharma-eye for the Three Teachings, encompassing immortals, Confucians, Buddhists, and Daoists. There is no need to seek another path—this alone is the bridge. Alas, in this vast universe, there are none who inquire of the Dao, for they do not know to study it closely.

If there are those of sincere seeking, with pure karmic roots and firm Dao-qi, what need have they for a teacher? At the utterance of a word, they will awaken. One may know that the merit of this text is equal to the *Jade Scripture*. Even the Heavenly Sovereign would treat it with reverence. Thus its circulation and wide dissemination will bring boundless blessings, penetrating earth and heaven, and all will receive its benefits—not merely to pass through the calamities of an age."

Moreover, by widely cultivating good affinities, one may rely upon this text to transcend and realize liberation across ten thousand kalpas—truly a sacred writ for the salvation of the world and all future generations. You must not regard it lightly or treat it as common.

---

The perfected one does good as the great void does: upon passing, it dissolves without residue.
The worthy one does good through diligent effort, unwavering over time, and may thus attain utmost sincerity.
The middling one does good as bubbles or illusions do: now arising, now vanishing, now appearing, now concealed.
The lesser one does good only for blessings, yet when turned inward, the heart knows this is not so.

You, my disciples, heed these words:
Cultivate your minds and intentions, and do not indulge in greed or delusion.
Examine yourself and take responsibility; be sincere and steadfast.
Follow my teachings, and you will naturally attain your time.

---

Good arises from the heart, and so does evil.
When the heart does good, do not seek karmic reward.
When the heart does evil, likewise do not invoke karmic retribution.
For to seek karmic reward is to plant the root of evil.

If one performs one good deed, or ten, or a hundred, and secretly thinks, *"Will Heaven reward me?"*—should no reward come, they will deem good deeds futile and abandon them.
If one commits one evil act, or ten, or a hundred, and secretly thinks, *"Will Heaven punish me?"*—should no punishment come, they will deem evil harmless and abandon repentance.

When one wishes to do good, they must not do good *as* good; if they see it as good, their heart is not truly good. What they do as good resides solely in the heart.
Examine your heart: if an act harms neither human feeling nor principle, it is good; if it harms either, it is not.
Good and evil need not manifest in deeds—a single good thought is inexhaustibly good!
A single evil thought is inexhaustibly evil!

Thus, the method of seeking goodness lies in turning inward to the heart. When the heart is still, wisdom’s light arises of itself—what need is there for other schemes?

---

The heart of the Dao must be firm; the heart of cultivation must be sincere. If it is neither firm nor sincere, external demons will entangle you, and even if you have affinity with the Dao, obstacles will multiply.

---

On the qin, Xun Qiao was instructed in forbearance:
*"The Way of the qin is replete with wondrous subtleties!
When playing, the heart must be still and vast, the qi harmonious and peaceful, the fingers at ease.
Detach from the body, from things, from circumstances—even from the qin itself.
Silently extend this heart to merge with the great void, and whatever your fingers play will become the sounds of primordial antiquity!
If you merely perform new tunes to please the ear, the music becomes decadent and wanton—far removed from the true Way of the qin."*

Bodily illness may be cured by medicine, but the sickness of the heart is difficult to heal. External demons may be subdued, but inner demons are hard to control. If one mistakenly believes in heretical words, delusions arise at once; from delusions spring causes, and from causes arise obstacles. When obstacles persist unchecked, demonic forces take form. Once demons long abide in one’s dwelling, they toss and toy with it, inducing dreams and fantasies, confusion and disorder—now stirring wrath and resentment, now inciting curses, now defaming the true Way, now indulging in perverse doctrines. In great matters, one may lose one’s home; in small, one may destroy one’s nature. Even if one awakens to repentance, soon delusion returns, and such cycles have no end.

I pity sentient beings and act as the King of Physicians, healing their heart-sickness and subduing their inner demons. When the sickness of the heart is cured, bodily illness vanishes; when inner demons are purged, external demons cannot invade. If one does not attack the heart, the illness penetrates to the region between the heart and diaphragm. When demons blaze within, external demons become glaringly manifest. You all should reflect in stillness—thus may you attain goodness together.

Only through forging in fierce flames does one become iron-willed; only by leaping from deep waters does one emerge as a hidden dragon.

Within this gate, one must achieve liberation in all matters and yield a step in all encounters—only then is one a vessel of the Dao. If even a trace of self-view clings or a shred of pride lingers, how can one enter the Dao?

Between heaven and earth, a human life is but a mayfly’s span! Not only ordinary mortals—even the immortals and buddhas of past, present, and future are no different. Yet while life is bounded, spirit knows no bounds. Viewing heaven and earth through my life, my life is but a mayfly; viewing heaven and earth through my spirit, heaven and earth are but a mayfly.

Alas! I see this mayfly: each day it lives and dies, each day it transforms. Gathered across ten thousand years, all is but this one life and death, this one transformation. People know the mayfly’s birth but not its death; they see its death but not its transformation. I see this mayfly—heaven and earth share its beginning and end.

Day is the mechanism of movement: all things move, and I move with them. Night is the mechanism of stillness: all things rest, and I rest with them. In this alternation of movement and stillness, waxing and waning with all things, lies the natural qi-mechanism of heaven and earth, the ceaselessly generative Dao.

Yet世 people often turn day into night and night into day, violating the natural qi-mechanism of heaven and earth, defying the principles of human life, and severing themselves from the power of transformation. Thus, rise with the day and rest with the night; consolidate essence and nurture spirit. Compete not with things, reduce desires, and purify the heart. Knowing stillness and restraint, one may hope for longevity.

My Dao takes "clarity, stillness, and emptiness" as its foundation, "longevity and deathlessness" as its urgency, "aiding others and benefiting beings" as its heart, and "carefree ease" as its desire. Many in remote mountains and secluded valleys yearn for this, yet alas, lacking a true teacher’s guidance, they waste their years in vain. Below them, the multitudes of the impure realm vie for fame at court and profit in the marketplace, drowning in the sea of desire and topsy-turvy in the river of attachment. Though they clearly fear death and seek life, they recklessly covet wealth and forget their lives. They overlook the gate of true awakening without entering, and see the swift and expedient path without walking it. Truly astonishing! Truly pitiable!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Someone asked: "Now, let us speak of this character ‘heart-mind.’ Do you all possess a heart-mind? And if you do, where does it reside?"

There were those who answered, "I do not know."

The reply came: "Excellent! Excellent! It is precisely in these three words, ‘I do not know.’ ‘Not knowing’ means ‘no heart-mind toward objects.’ Just as at this moment, your heart-mind is here. When the moment passes and you encounter another circumstance, your heart-mind is there—so elusive and intangible, how can you know where it abides?

The *Dao*-heart-mind is awareness. Awareness is knowing; knowing is not-knowing. Not-knowing is non-action; non-action enables action, and through action one may attain non-action. Non-action is the original substance of precelestial existence. If the original substance is non-action, then how can the original face be known? Thus, ‘not knowing’ is true knowing! You have nearly spoken to the subtlety of it!"

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Someone asked: "When a person has awareness, that is the heart-mind. The heart-mind’s comings and goings have no fixed abode—where, after all, does it reside?"

One answered: "The heart-mind abides before the sage."

The reply came: "Alas! The reason people fail to attain the true *Dao* is that they have a heart-mind! That their heart-mind has somewhere to abide! As you say, ‘The heart-mind is before me’—this heart-mind then clings to my form. Once it clings to my form, your heart-mind is no longer your heart-mind, but mine! How can my heart-mind become yours? Thus, the perfected person has no heart-mind—not that there is no heart-mind, but that the heart-mind is like the great void, without any abode. You must understand: if the heart-mind has no abode, then what is this heart-mind? It is said: the heart-mind is like the great void, yet the great void is not mere inert emptiness.

At Huangmei, one who ‘acts without abiding yet gives rise to the heart-mind’ could suddenly awaken. Now I have dissected and clarified this—why are you all still so benighted?

To shatter empty space—is this so or not?
Before the unclinging, what doubt remains?
Like stars at dawn, the sky grows bright—
The shadow falls on the cold pond, faint and dim."

Alas, all sentient beings!

I declare to you: consider this flower—untouched by defilement, its fragrance and hues resplendent. Once stained, it sinks into the mire; yet if one preserves its celestial purity, its scent and essence remain pristine and distant. I grieve for sentient beings, expounding the wondrous Dharma, that they may steadfastly follow these words, embody their form and restore their nature. Just as planting lotuses in fire is to seek coolness amid heat, do not, like burying blossoms after rain, inter their innate radiance in vain.

If you trust this, springs will surge from rock crevices, flowing into the great sea; if you do not, groping for doors in a darkened chamber, you shall find no exit. Let others doubt as they will—this old Daoist seeks only to save the world. Wait and see how their endings unfold, and you will know these words are not false.

In all things, one must keep the gaze lofty and the heart vast: receive favor as if startled, endure humiliation with forbearance, measure as boundless as the sea, heart as the great void. Thrones and riches, if they are mine to accept, I accept without deeming it glory; a single bowl or gourd, if mine to refuse, I refuse without deeming it affectation. The sages of old possessed the world yet did not cling to it, casting it aside like worn-out sandals—how could their hearts ever be swayed by wealth or poverty, honor or disgrace?

Yet most today are ensnared by such thoughts, bound to the heart-mind and unable to transform. If one day high rank and lavish emoluments were bestowed upon them, I know not what manner of creature they would become. Are they not the obstinate, petty men of this world?

Those among ordinary people who can comprehend the Dao are not few, yet though they know it, they fail to put it into practice—thus the Dao remains obscure in the world! Now, when one speaks of seeking the Dao, what words can the Dao offer? There is but one method: proceed step by step, without idle thoughts, without straying into side paths. To "lay the foundation" or "refine mercury" is all empty fame! The Dao abides in heaven and earth, advancing with the four seasons.

Heaven and earth have day and night,
Sun and moon wax and wane.
If one can harmonize yin and yang,
A single principle gathers within the cosmos.

Yet within it lie all manner of sufferings,
Each demanding dissolution into the boundless.
The five senses guide the nine orifices,
The six thieves lure the seven emotions.

Above, one ascends to the thousand-fathom peak;
Below, one plunges into the hundred-fathom abyss.
Dragons churn the vast sea’s waves,
Tigers roar and ten thousand peaks topple.

By what method can this be governed?
Wield the sword to sever the roots of karmic hindrance,
Bind demons and fetter spirits,
Slay ghosts and dispel malevolent vapors.

In cultivation, sweep the dwelling clean,
And the Yellow Court becomes pure and still.
Bright as the moon in the azure sky,
Vivid as clouds atop the mountain ridge.

Forget scheming, forget appearances,
Be without self, without name.
A mass of true and ultimate principle—
All lies in guarding the empty and numinous.

---

The meaning of giving life to a body, explained from the very beginning:
Ten months of pregnancy, with the agony of childbirth;
Three years of nursing, with ceaseless care and toil.
Illness, pain, itching—before the child speaks, the mother already worries;
Coming and going, rising and resting—before the body moves, the heart is already mindful.
Seeing the child laugh or cry, she is moved to sorrow or joy;
Watching its first steps, she is struck with alarm or delight.
She endures hunger to feed her child,
Bears cold to clothe her son.

Longing for the child’s success, her eyes grow weary with waiting;
Yearning for its marriage, her heart finds no rest.

Some brave wind and rain to establish a foundation;
Others surmount peril and hardship to renew their ancestral enterprise.
Day after day, they toil without rest—all for the sake of posterity;
Deep into the night, their hearts remain troubled—all for their children’s sake.
How could one ever repay such boundless virtue?
As children, if we wish to requite our parents’ kindness,
we must exhaust our strength and devote our hearts,
never faltering in filial devotion, ever sincere and reverent.
We should provide them with warm food and clothing to nourish their bodies,
speak softly and gently to gladden their hearts,
obey their wishes and attend to their every inclination.
As the ancient saying goes:
*“To see what is unseen, to hear what is unspoken—
only then is one truly filial.”*
Yet if, at life’s crucial junctures, we fail to do our utmost,
and instead merely perform rituals, make offerings,
or aid the poor and needy—
though we accumulate a hundred thousand acts of goodness,
it all amounts to nothing.
To neglect the great moral bond is to be worse than birds and beasts.
In life, one is despised by others;
in the state, one is beyond the law’s tolerance.
Above, the gods grow wrathful;
below, the spirits turn hostile.
One may be struck by flood, fire, plague, or malevolent spirits—
disasters inescapable.
Worse still, lightning may shatter the corpse, reducing the body to ashes,
unclaimed by earth or flame.
Such retribution—how can one not fear it?

Plowing shallowly, one cannot expect a bountiful autumn harvest.
How can mere numbers suffice as proof?
Lose your heart, corrupt your conduct—
though fate may grant wealth and rank, you remain base.
Cultivate your heart, nurture your nature—
even if fate is adverse, brighter days will come.

The admonition to Song Zhen Shu states:
*“If your strength is truly sufficient for good,
why exhaust yourself as an ox or horse for your descendants?
The savor of officialdom,
the treacheries of the world,
the storms of human sentiment—
you have witnessed them all.”*

The苦海 is boundless, yet to turn one’s head is to reach the shore.
Look at those who toil in ceaseless pursuit—
at the end of their feasts, they may not part well.
Plain pickled greens and simple rice are no less than fine meats,
coarse cloth and hempen shoes can match embroidered silks.
Only if you rein in when spurred, rest when at ease,
will you find inexhaustible enjoyment!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

As a father, one must not be overly indulgent,
nor excessively harsh.
Only with a worthy father can there be a filial son;
only with a kind father can there be an obedient son.
How many in ancient times became accomplished without teaching?
How many acted rightly without urging?
How many embodied their father’s heart and carried on his will without learning?
Let fathers take heed.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

The admonition to Wu Yishu states:
*“There are no unfilial immortals in heaven!
You must return to serve your parents, sit in quietude, and hold your tongue.
Do not fritter away the years in the bustling marketplace!
The perfected one has no fate, for he has no self.
Embody these words.”*

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

You, my disciples, must not be overly self-serving, nor seek only your own gain; neither be excessively stern, nor excessively indulgent.
Those who follow my teachings, I shall not reject;
those who turn from my teachings, I shall not pursue.
Those who embody my intent, Heaven shall surely bestow blessings upon them;
those who secretly defy my instructions, Heaven shall surely bring calamity upon them.
To speak of the Dao and virtue with one’s lips while harboring deceit in one’s heart—
though you may deceive others in the light, how can you deceive the gods in the dark?
In sum: maintain integrity in solitude, feel no shame before your shadow beneath the quilt, and advance without cease.
Thus may you aspire to sagehood, thus may you partake in the workings of Heaven and Earth.
Those petty concerns of wealth, rank, and longevity—how can mere fate ever govern them?
Let my disciples take heed.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Now that you have returned to my teachings, you must undergo a thorough cleansing, a profound awakening.
For those who cultivate blessings yet encounter misfortune, I shall answer their cries and deliver them;
for those who accumulate evil and refuse to change, I shall silently correct them.
Wu Yishu, in his conduct, has long practiced hidden virtues:
though his parents did not show him deep affection, he served them with ever-greater filial devotion;
though his brothers were not always harmonious, he never wavered in fraternal duty.
In his dealings with others, he bears a heart of warmth; in his approach to the world, he holds a spirit of sincerity.
He understands the principles of Chan and upholds them in silence;
he also grasps the subtleties of my Dao and embraces them deeply.
Compared to those whose words belie their actions, who parrot hearsay without true understanding—how vast the difference!
Thus do I rejoice in him.

Wu Yishu is steadfast in his nature, his heart free of deceit.
In his conduct and interactions, he leaves no trace of impurity, adapting to circumstances and speaking as the moment demands.
His mind is as boundless as the heavens and earth, as fluid as clouds drifting and mists dispersing.
Moreover, he sets his aspirations high, breaking free from the cage of worldly constraints—truly a man of resolve!
Thus do I rejoice in him.

Yet both of you must continually examine and refine yourselves, advancing step by step.
Do not fall behind, do not descend—then all shall be well!
Beware lest my words lead you to slacken or grow reckless, lest you squander a most promising future.
Ponder this deeply, and stand in awe of it.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

In this human life, nothing is more fearful than wavering.
If one can act with resolute decisiveness, what Dao cannot be heard? What immortality cannot be hoped for?
Yet I fear that though my words are earnest, your conduct may still betray them!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Alas for those sentient beings who commit so many unrighteous acts:
Disloyal and untrustworthy, unkind and ungenerous.
Some as sons are undutiful, some as elder brothers unfraternal, some as younger brothers irreverent, some in friendship insincere.
In their own conduct, they harbor much secrecy, treachery, and cruelty; in their dealings with others, they lack righteousness, benevolence, wisdom, and courage.
They seize the flesh and blood of others to fatten their own bodies;
They destroy the lives of others to nourish their own forms.
They show no reverence for Heaven and Earth or the spirits, but lightly heap upon them scorn and contempt;
They hold the sacred scriptures and canonical texts in no esteem, but recklessly revile and denounce them.
They utter curses and maledictions, consort with the wanton and the wicked, commit many evils, and indulge in licentiousness and defilement.
The divine bureaus record their deeds, weigh their gravity, and impose punishments accordingly:
Some suffer the calamities of war, flood, fire, or pestilence;
Some endure the miseries of hardship, adversity, lowliness, or disgrace—each reaps what they have sown, their retribution measured by their deeds.

If you enter my gate, be loyal to your lord and filial to your parents,
Reverent to your elder brothers and fraternal to your younger,
Let your heart and mind be sincere and free of deceit,
Conduct yourself with uprightness and kindness in all dealings.
Bathe and fast to reverently worship Heaven, Earth, and the deities;
With wholehearted devotion, recite and complete the scriptures of the Great Treasury.
Should there be one who endures the severance of love and desire,
Who seeks the supreme Dao,
I shall transform my form to guide them,
Appearing in dreams or encounters, whether seated or walking,
That they may early grasp the essentials and cultivate the golden immortal’s path.

If not, yet you heed my teachings and apply them earnestly in the world,
With unblemished goodness and no arising of evil thoughts,
Should you seek great fortune, I shall bestow it;
Should you seek long life, I shall grant it;
Should you desire worthy sons and virtuous grandsons, or abundant success and renown,
If you persist in cultivation without slackening, beginning and ending with constancy,
I shall raise you to the Southern Palace, where you may wander carefree in joy,
And in time ascend to the rank of upper immortals,
Forever free from the dust’s defilement, beyond the reach of calamity.

My words make clear the tally of merit and transgression, the certainty of karmic retribution.
You, my disciples, listen with wholehearted attention and return to uphold them:
Do not linger in complacency or carelessness,
Do not grow indolent or seek ease,
Do not defy the true teachings,
Do not follow perverse doctrines.
Let each walk their own path, each pursue their own merit.
If you are truly sincere and steadfast in observance, you shall naturally obtain auspicious blessings.
Understand this well, and stand in awe of it.

Merit in saving the world lies not in magnitude, nor in quantity—only in the uttermost sincerity of the heart. Even if you save but a single insect or cherish a single plant, acting within your capacity, boundless merit shall accrue.

Hearken, all you disciples, to the decree of this solemn admonition. From this day forth, each of you must awaken with urgency!

Be loyal and filial without shame as child or subject; be reverent and sincere, that the Dao may shine forth. To be human yet lacking in kindness and grace, to treat others without generosity and benevolence, to profit oneself at another’s expense, to take life to sustain one’s own, to worship spirits without reverence, to recite scriptures without faith, to begin with zeal yet falter in the end, to appear sincere while harboring deceit, to measure strength against peers, to divide fellow practitioners into "us" and "them," to resent the virtuous or conceal one’s faults—all such thoughts that dwell in partiality and inequity, all such stances that lack uprightness and magnanimity, though common among the mediocre, mark one as a transgressor against the moral order.

Each of you must reflect deeply in solitude. If any of these faults reside in you, correct them swiftly. Harness sincerity and reverence to rein in the wandering mind, and rely on the divine to dissolve transgressions and errors. Whether performing a single good deed to relieve another’s hardship, uttering a single kind word to untangle another’s grievance, or lending an arm to steady one on the brink of peril—let each act be as it may. For those with parents, exert every effort in devoted service; for those with siblings, uphold fairness, harmony, and goodwill in your dealings.

By such conduct, what begins as effort will gradually become second nature, and you may ascend into the realm of sages and worthies

A steadfast resolve must anchor the human heart, for once it wavers, one cannot apply it to the path of uprightness and luminous clarity. Instead, one clings stubbornly to private views, rejects wholesome counsel, manipulates with cunning schemes, contends over strength and weakness, divides self from others, and refuses to tame the reckless mind, allowing it to unify with the upright and luminous—thus creating self-contradiction. Though such a person may occasionally perform a minor good deed, the heart is the great root; if the root is flawed, what benefit do small virtues bring? Those afflicted by this failing must exert themselves to reform it thoroughly. Let no private cleverness prevail, no partial views persist. Purify the depths, free from obstruction and attachment. Bare your heart and courage, become a person of uprightness and luminous clarity, and act accordingly. With every step, ascend ever higher, and wherever you go, all shall prosper. Seek it within yourself, exhausting only your sincerity. The thousands of sages, the ten thousand sages—all converge in the One. A single moment of awakening brings boundless blessings.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

I laugh at those multitudes: their devotion to the Dao flickers like bubbles on water! Their pleas for mercy burn like flames! Why not redirect this fervor toward devotion to the Dao? Then, without striving for blessings, blessings will grow of themselves; without seeking merit, merit will expand of itself; without pursuing profit, profit will spread widely. What need is there to ask for it?
