With my boundless compassion, I guide and lead, wishing only to ferry all beings to the other shore. Yet if people come without accumulated sincerity, they regard this as mere play. Better to bar the gate entirely than to have them enter the Dao only to falter in the end. Some are diligent at first but slacken later; others are lax at the start but strive afterward. May the diligent never grow weary, and may the lax rouse themselves to effort—then all shall be well! Disciples, you must redouble your sincerity from this point on. The slightest slackening, and transformation through teaching becomes impossible.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

In solitude and shadow, conduct yourself as though under the scrutiny of divine clarity. How much less, then, when standing before the gods, dare you act with abandon! The transgressions of beings arise from a single moment of recklessness, which, left unchecked, swells into madness and rebellion, ensnaring them in the web of sin. How can one not take heed!

In the pursuit of the Dao, value gentleness above all, and hold forbearance in the highest regard. If one can remain tranquil and refrain from contention, the benefits shall not be slight. Not only will this leave no cause for shame before others, but even when proclaimed before ghosts and spirits, none shall fail to receive its witness with favor.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

In all undertakings, one need not inquire into others’ right or wrong—what matters is inward reflection. If my conduct is beyond reproach in every respect, I must still reproach myself for my inability to move others toward reform and goodness, and deeply shame myself for failing to guide the foolish and obstinate. Even if I have fully realized the Dao and feel no unease before others, when faced with those who do evil, I must still meet them with softness and engage them with harmony. To turn even one evildoer toward goodness is a deed of the greatest merit. Even if they have sunk deeply into depravity, lost all sense of shame, and hardened in their wickedness—making transformation difficult—still, I must treat them with kindness. In short, I must fulfill the Dao with reverence and sincerity, neither overbearing nor servile, standing firm in the mean. In all encounters, I must respond with an empty and receptive heart: then, even the most unruly will, in time, come to hold me in awe and dare not indulge their recklessness. What external humiliation need one fear? What demonic obstacle could possibly threaten?

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Good arises from a single thought, and evil likewise from a single thought. In the hidden and subtle moments of solitude, the division between good and evil is made. Even those who do evil were once close to the nature of goodness. But through a single moment of carelessness, they drift into recklessness, and in the end, across countless kalpas, they cannot awaken their original bright nature. Violent and unrestrained, they stop at nothing, provoking the wrath of the gods and incurring heavenly retribution from which there is no escape. Thus, I pity these lost souls with a heavy heart and spare no effort in expounding the Dharma to them with compassion. From this day forward, when you observe the karmic consequences of their evil deeds, you must hold a heart of mercy, not one of delight; you must hold a heart of vigilance, not one of emulation. Then, your resolve to turn from evil will be strengthened, and your commitment to goodness will grow firm.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

This impure world of ours passes like a fleeting shadow in the crack of a door! Once a misstep is taken and time slips by, regret comes too late. The midnight temple bell rings—awaken with a start! All the schemes, the tricks, the clever ploys of the past—so many illusions. What was done in dreams seemed so wild and perverse. If you do not swiftly purify your heart and begin anew as a good person, striding toward the heavens on the path of virtue, you will sink ever deeper into filth, falling into the苦劫, from which escape is difficult even after countless lifetimes. Moreover, calamity will extend to your descendants, bringing ruin across generations. For evil has its time of fulfillment, and retribution differs only in its swiftness or delay. If one does not awaken, is this not a pity?

In this world, good deeds are endless to perform; meritorious acts are endless to establish. The sages and worthies, the higher their virtue, the humbler their hearts—seeing goodness, they feel they can never reach it; gazing upon the Dao, they feel they have yet to perceive it. Though they have accomplished many great works and built many merits, their hearts still feel a sense of insufficiency. How much more so when their goodness and merits remain incomplete—how could they dare to be arrogant and self-important? The ancients said: *"Fullness invites loss; humility brings gain."* This is the Way of Heaven. If the Way of Heaven is thus, can the Way of Man be otherwise?

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

A person who does good becomes a good person; one who does foul deeds becomes an evil person. Whether one becomes good or evil, whether one takes two different paths—it all hinges on that single point: the heart!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

People say that in all things, there is fate and there is destiny.

Yet the sages say: *"The perfected person possesses the learning of establishing destiny, and thus takes the workings of creation as their own—how could fate constrain them? How could numerical destiny confine them?"* As for those who, though they have not a single good deed or virtuous trait in their lives, yet do not lose their prosperity, emoluments, or nobility, this may stem from the accumulations of their ancestors or the cultivation of their past lives. Nevertheless, if evil deeds persist without cease, the root from which descendants enjoy wealth and nobility will be severed. If one’s personal blessings and grace extend only to oneself, then they will be diminished or revoked in accordance with one’s conduct. Are the words of the Most High on karmic retribution mere deceptions?

Strive, all of you, to do good deeds, each examining and cultivating yourselves, and do not betray this old heart’s earnest concern!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Good and evil each bear their own karmic consequences. If doing good brought no evident effect, then why bother with goodness? If committing evil incurred no fault or blame, then why not indulge in great wickedness? Reverence for the divine is not pursued for the sake of reward; it lies in offering sincere devotion and faith. This heart itself is the seed of goodness—no need to await results, for results will surely come.

I have studied the various classics, which speak emphatically of the merits of reciting scriptures—these are not empty words. For in reciting scriptures: a single moment of sincerity suffices to dispel all past delusions; a single hour of goodness already marks a great departure from former wrongs. To cast off delusion and preserve sincerity, to reform wrongs and follow goodness—who could say there is no karmic retribution? Yet it is lamentable: a moment of sincerity may, with the next thought, turn to arrogance; an hour of goodness may, in the next instant, be abandoned for wrongdoing. In such a case, how can one summon Heaven’s blessings and invite good responses?

Thus, the sacred scriptures and worthy traditions of antiquity, the Buddhist sutras and Daoist registers, all employ fine words to inspire the hearts of those who do good, urging them ever onward in virtue, so as to guide and welcome auspicious qi. It is not that mere recitation of scriptural words—without sincerity or reverence, with the mind wandering and thoughts frivolous—can erase transgressions and secure blessings! Only when the heart is wholly devoted to reverence, unwavering from beginning to end, is it truly good.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

The method of writing the classics is uniform in size and proportion, balanced in weight, with the left side solid and the right empty, and lengths aligned. If the brush precedes the intent, the characters will lack unity; if the intent precedes the brush, the calligraphy will be fitting. Where there is form, return to emptiness; where there is emptiness, make it substantial. Hasty or forced brushwork loses both balance and wonder. Follow my words: without striving for skill, proceed with reverence and correctness, and let vigor be your aim. Do not favor coquettish postures; let strength and tension press forward. Better slow than rushed—always wield the brush with dignity.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

*Further Records of Master Han’s Three Teachings*

I often observe that those in the world who claim to pursue the Dao seek nothing more than divine immortals to guide them, or they study the refinement of cinnabar and mercury, or the practice of absorbing yin to supplement yang, all in hopes of attaining longevity and preserving wealth and status. As the saying goes: *"A hundred thousand strings of cash at the waist, riding a crane to Yangzhou"*—such are their aspirations. Yet few truly cherish or yearn for the pure emptiness, the quiescent extinction, the ever-abiding great Dao. Few exhibit the unwavering resolve of one who *"loves beauty with unshakable devotion,"* as the classics describe. Even those who have long studied the Confucian path hold the gates of Buddhism and Daoism in contempt!

Yet now, some among you—having begun with Confucian learning in youth, later donned the cap and sash of office, and now govern the people—still thirst for the wind of immortality, earnestly seeking the assembly of true dragons upon the sands. This must not be dismissed lightly! Know this: the Dao is entered through sincerity. From one sincere act, extend it until nothing remains insincere, and the Dao is no longer distant. Thus, the scriptures say: *"Before cultivating the Dao of immortality, first cultivate the Dao of humanity. If the Dao of humanity is not cultivated, the Dao of immortality remains far indeed!"*

What, then, is the cultivation of the Dao of humanity? The great Dao is fundamentally empty yet substantial, filling the cosmos. Only by embodying the Dao in action can one’s heart-mind expand to encompass all things. Vast, it embraces heaven and earth; within its scope, all beings—sentient and insentient—reside. This is the Confucian ideal of *"bringing peace to the old and care to the young,"* the Buddhist vow to *"liberate all beings,"* and the Daoist practice of *"expedient guidance"*—all arising from this single heart-mind.

Yet one must also delve deeply into the roots of wisdom and innate nature, constantly turning inward to illuminate the self, questioning the heart: *"Does this action accord with the Dao? Does that action not?"* In serving the people, let not a single duty go unfulfilled. This is the essence of the Confucian *"assisting transformation and nurturing life,"* the Buddhist *"radiance of inherent nature,"* and the Daoist *"forgetting form to merge with emptiness."*

Thus, the Great Compassionate Guanyin once manifested as a magistrate to expound the Dharma, and the Most High Laozi served as the Archivist of Zhou. Those in office are not barred from pursuing the Dao of purity and emptiness. If you can follow my words, conducting every affair with utter sincerity—sincerity in benefiting the people, that they may receive its blessings; sincerity in fostering culture, that customs may become pure and beautiful; sincerity in self-discipline, that governance may be free of harshness; sincerity in cultivating the Dao, that essence may be preserved and spirit guarded—then the paths of immortals, Buddhas, and Confucians need not be sought outside a single heart-mind.

My profound hopes for you lie in embodying the Most High’s heart of cherishing life, the Buddhist spirit of compassion, and the sages’ teachings of *"gathering without hoarding"*—not merely to bring luster to my own gate.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

For all who study the Dao, the essence lies in single-minded devotion. Silently activate the subtle mechanism, inwardly illuminate with a tranquil heart-mind, attain emptiness and preserve stillness, harmonize with the world while remaining untainted—thus wandering through life while embracing the One in self-cultivation. Let no stray thoughts arise, nor covet fame or profit. Forget the heart within, forget the form without; guide qi with the heart-mind, unite spirit with qi, merge with emptiness through spirit, until nothing remains to be forgotten, returning to the pristine, tranquil, and effortless Dao of the Great Void.

To comprehend this is to *"understand"* the Dao; to diligently practice it is to *"walk"* the Dao. As for the methods of the Southern Palace, though called orthodox, they do not constitute the great Dao of liberation from birth and death, of transcending the world through non-action. Thus, the Most High said: *"Purity and stillness are the norm of the world."* And again: *"Preserving spirit and securing qi are the roots of longevity."*

As for talismanic writing, though not the true gateway of the One, many are drawn to it. Some scholars, even at life’s end, may have their refined essence attach to others, revealing the learning they cultivated in life. But external alchemy—furnaces, crucibles, mercury, and lead—are nothing but deceptions that delude the people. The foolish who are deceived by such things are beyond counting. Never has an immortal used these to liberate the world.

In the past, Zhengyang transmitted to me the art of transmuting base metals into gold, but I feared it would mislead later generations. Through this single thought of discernment, I was delivered and ascended as an immortal. Now, what you have requested of me—I deeply lament it!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Scholars born into this world—who among them can remain rooted in one corner? Thus, a man’s life is meant to embrace the four directions as his aspiration. Yet what is truly meant by this aspiration for the four directions? It is to seek the Dao and follow a teacher: Confucian scholars carry their satchels a thousand *li*; those who study Buddhism or strive for immortality wear through straw sandals. Until their learning is complete and the Dao is realized, they will not rest!

Later generations, however, chase after fame and profit, scrambling for power and influence—some as traveling officials, some as wandering scholars, some as distant merchants—all driven by the pursuit of name and gain. There are also those who crave landscapes and mountains, undeterred by hard travel, even abandoning aged parents with white hair. Yet such far journeys remain confined within the bounds of the four directions.

The true person, however, roams the spirit through the void, covering a thousand or ten thousand *li* in a single breath, traversing the six directions and the Three Mountains in an instant. Departing, none know where they go, as their spirit wanders the cosmos; returning, none know whence they come, as they settle back into emptiness and stillness. Only such wandering can be called the ultimate journey.

Across the vast seas and heavens, how few—scarcely one in a hundred—can attain this!

The Pavilion of Descending Virtue and Forbearance addressed the assembly, saying:

"Thirty years ago, I descended in spirit to the shores of E, alighting my carriage here to sow the good causes of the *Three Grades*, gathering a grand assembly of ten thousand karmic connections. Upon this very ground, the foundation of this pavilion was laid to inaugurate the great enterprise. Later, I moved to the tower of the Song family, first bestowing the name *Encompassing the Three*, then relocating to the residence of Master Qiao to complete the upper scroll of the immortal canon.

Now, in retrospect, it all seems but the affair of yesterday! Yet the fruition of my transformative work owes entirely to your assistance, and to the tireless devotion of those who first undertook the task. Though the great work is now accomplished and all have received vast blessings, my heart remains ever mindful of those initial disciples. Feeling their labors have not been fully requited, I linger still within these halls, reluctant to vanish without a trace—such is the reason."

With a heart moved by worldly compassion, I spare no toil or trouble. Lingering still in the dusty realm, I do so solely to embody the heavens’ virtue of cherishing life above

The character *Dao*—this single word—is the secret mechanism of heaven and earth, the essence of yin and yang. It establishes the axis of the cosmos, unfolds transformation through the ages, most subtle and hidden, formless and nameless. It gives rise to the images of creation, roots the myriad things. At its inception, the primordial chaos was divided by the Great Potter’s Wheel—Buddhahood is this Dao, immortality is this principle, and the sagely wisdom of the Confucians admits no distinction. Tracing its origin, all spring from the Jade Purity; branching into streams and diverging into schools, each of the Three Vehicles opens a teaching, each founds a gate. What is solid is the principle of the Confucians; what is empty is the Chan mind. Emptiness and solidity, the two and five congeal into essence, preserving nonbeing while guarding being. Vast and indistinct, dimly discerned—it dwells within the navel wheel, ever more elusive, its aperture wondrous and hard to find. Above, it reaches the lunar cavern; below, it treads the root of heaven. In leisure it comes and goes, ever still, ever pure. What is solid is thus; what is empty abides forever. Divergent paths converge on the same track, returning to the undifferentiated. The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao. One forgets one’s person; I forget my self. To forget even forgetting is true forgetting—this is called true forgetting, beyond all comparison.

Those of discernment first establish sincerity. With sincerity comes clarity; with clarity, form manifests. Manifesting within and without, the great Dao may then be practiced.

Practicing the Dao admits no division of difficulty or ease, for it is wholly pervaded by sincerity.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

In this age, spirit-writing has spread widely, and many follow its currents. Yet within it, true and false inevitably intermingle, and gatherings dissolve as readily as they form. Most take those who speak of fortune and misfortune as genuine, and those who compose poetry and verse as worthy of assembly. Yet at this altar where I have presided over the flying phoenix for decades, I have never swayed others with omens of good or ill, nor have my disciples sought responses through the mechanisms of blessing or calamity. Though no striking words or texts may be observed, there is much in ritual, music, dignity, and decorum to cultivate. Thus, it remains constant and unchanging, ever renewing with time—far removed from those gatherings that flicker in and out, startling the world with their spectacle.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Some fear that my gate harbors strange sights and strange sounds, enough to unsettle others. Yet when I observe myself, I find nothing so extraordinary in what I hear or see! But I wonder: are the things others hear and see truly strange? Or are they not?

For if they are not strange, then they are merely ordinary—and the term "ordinary" encompasses much. Human life, standing on earth and beneath heaven, amounts to nothing more than clothing oneself to be clothed, eating to be fed, daily rising and resting—nothing out of the ordinary! This is what "ordinary" means.

Humans possess the five senses and four limbs, all endowed with eyes that see and ears that hear, faculties of perception and clarity—these are shared by all, nothing strange here! From childhood through elementary learning, to maturity and the understanding of human relations, all efforts—from cultivating the self to ordering the family, governing the state, and bringing peace to the world—follow the teachings of the former kings and the conduct of the sages, aiming to reach the realm of sageliness and worthiness. Yet all this stands firmly within the central Way, utterly ordinary, nothing strange!

Then there are the two paths of Buddhism and Daoist transcendence: one clarifies the nature to its source, seeking liberation from birth and death; the other refines nature and spirit, aspiring to longevity. Though their claims may seem fantastical and unverifiable, and their practitioners elusive and hard to examine, when viewed through the lens of the ordinary, neither Buddhism nor Daoist transcendence abandons the fundamental nature in their cultivation. Neither do they stray from the central guard to speak of subtleties. The roots of loyalty, filial piety, benevolence, and righteousness are never absent from their thoughts; the practices of yielding, reverence, and mutual respect are never neglected in their conduct. Thus, one who is filial to parents may be called a filial immortal; one who is loyal to their lord may be deemed a loyal transcendent. Extending this principle, all who fulfill their roles and exhaust their ethical duties are seeds of immortality and sprouts of Buddhahood! Even without aspiring to transcendence or Buddhahood, they naturally attain it.

The reason lies in the three teachings taking different paths yet converging in the Supreme Ultimate, without division into sectarian gates. In my *Three Ranks* canon, this principle is thoroughly elucidated with great precision. Yet petty scholars of the world, entirely ignorant of this unifying truth, recklessly criticize and slander it. I do not question the nature of their thoughts, but merely smile at their pedantry and rigidity!

When people come seeking the Dao, whatever they may hear or see—even if I do not fully comprehend it—I do not regard it as strange or extraordinary. Even those of great discernment, if they truly turn to my gate, should view it as nothing more than an ordinary affair, for only then do they embody the demeanor of a true adept. Since their hearts are earnestly devoted to my Way, I teach them only the great Dao—and the greatness of the Dao amounts to nothing more than these two words: "ordinary."

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

My gate is vast, harboring compassion and kindness within the boundless, radiating light within the indistinct. All who sincerely pledge their faith, without doubt, will inevitably experience divine resonance. Yet if one regards me as dispensable or negligible, I cannot respond to their demands for immediate answers—the unfathomability of spiritual thought and principle confirms this.

If one can serve parents with love and respect, treat elder siblings with harmony and deference, engage friends with sincerity and trust, conduct oneself in the world with fairness, cultivate the self and overcome selfishness, and honor ethical duties and fundamental principles—then one stands daily before my face and hears my words. In the silent communion between us, I naturally affirm them.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

To understand the death of the living, why not observe the life of the dead? The death of the living is commonly seen as the exhaustion of one’s allotted span. Yet regarding the life of the dead, some say, “Death is but rebirth.” Others claim, “Death is unfathomable—how can its rebirth be certain?” Still others assert, “There is no evidence for life after death.” Such debates are endless, unaware that the ancients declared, “The meaning of life and death is vast!” In truth, it cannot be casually explained.

By right principle, humans receive life by inheriting the qi of yin and yang, taking form through the clear and turbid qi. Their coming is vast and indistinct, like the morning sun rising in the east. People see only the sun’s ascent—how can they witness its true emergence from Fusang, or know whether it is real or not? In death, the qi retreats into darkness, the body withers away, like the western sun plunging suddenly below the horizon. People see only the sun’s descent—how can they behold its true setting at Yanzi, or know whether it is real or not?

Thus, those who grasp principle concern themselves only with the body presently before them, acting with unwavering sincerity. Whether in life or death, they simply accept what is right. Destiny may be known, but not spoken of; fate has its limits, yet it is better to abide by it. The great scholars clarify life and death before their own existence, comprehending them through insight; they follow life and death after their own existence, returning to reality and embracing emptiness. Their subtlety is profound beyond measure—none of this can be spoken of by ordinary people.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

The world speaks of seventy-two ritual forms for the Dipper, yet thirty-six of these conceal its true essence—all else serves merely to transmit teachings through ceremonial observances. Little do people realize that the rite of worshipping the Dipper is not only abundant in my tradition’s liturgical teachings but also widely practiced in the Tathāgata’s school, where celestial rites abound. Though their categories differ, the central scriptures of the Buddhist canon surpass Daoist liturgy in excellence, for they possess the sounds of Sanskrit and include methods of spiritual attainment, profound and wondrous.

Even among the Chan school, some use this practice to perceive their nature and illuminate their mind, like a single lamp of wisdom casting light everywhere, leaving no corner unillumined. In this dark chamber where no flame has yet been kindled, all remain as figures of black lacquer, unable to see one another’s faces. But when suddenly a torch appears, the space above and below becomes utterly transparent, its radiance shining in all directions—such joy is beyond compare. Likewise, those who worship the heavens, though dull and ignorant, if their sincerity is steadfast and their devotion unwavering, following the Sanskrit teachings and performing the rites with faith, may one day awaken in clarity, all attaining enlightenment. Just as when our Tathāgata beheld the morning star and laughed, holding up a flower to the assembly—so too is this truth.

Know then that the divine sounds of Sanskrit possess the six supernatural powers, unmatched in their efficacy; their merit and power are truly beyond discourse. Even the secret manuals of my esoteric tradition, revered by the highest immortals and celestial lords, are held in veneration, observed in accordance with the celestial cycles of heaven and earth. Yet if one’s roots are not fully ripened or their cultivation uneven, they may not easily receive the sacred teachings of the Supreme Perfected’s *Lingbao Taiwei* liturgy.

For the Dipper is the lord of all stars, dwelling among the celestial worthies; its vows are deeply rooted, its compassion vast, its Dharma boundless. Even the nine grades of fruition cannot fathom its depths. The five Dipper scriptures transmitted are all liturgical texts, each containing hidden mysteries not revealed to lesser practitioners. Unless one is a vessel of the Nine Heavens, they shall not hear these words. Yet one may still study these liturgical forms, cultivate with utmost sincerity, and pray with earnest devotion, following the meaning in practice—each will experience divine responses in their own way: some may witness the descent of the Purple Palace, others the silent manifestation of arm or face; some may see celestial flowers scattering, others the display of immortal offerings, all unfolding as desired and fulfilling every wish.

The superior practitioner, aspiring to immortality, may thereby escape suffering; the middling practitioner, making prayers, shall see all their wishes granted. Even the smallest karmic rewards from such supplications are but minor fruits! Those who attain great wisdom and great liberation through this practice are beyond counting. Still others, having personally received the true arts of the *Wei* and *Ling* from the Three or Five Perfected, transcend ordinary cultivation to dwell in the supreme truth—all by virtue of this power. Just as those who recite “Amitābha Buddha” and are received into the Eight Meritorious Pools, transforming into lotus blossoms, so too is this subtle and wondrous. As the sacred scriptures say: *“Though foolish, they shall become enlightened; though weak, they shall become strong.”* So it is with those who worship the heavens.

Where there is no supreme truth to be grasped, that is the supreme truth. Within the formless, the forms first arise—only to ultimately return to formlessness. Marvelous indeed!

The character "scripture" (*jing*) is fundamentally meant to teach people to uphold constancy without change, ever reverent and ever awed. The profoundly wise contemplate it and inwardly sense its resonance; those of middling capacity regard it and know what to guard against; even the common folk, upon knowing it, all feel reverence and fear. Thus, when I establish teachings to instruct others, this single character contains manifold admonitions—it is no mere pretense of language or text to dazzle the eye.

Yet the essence of such admonition lies first in "gathering the heart-mind." When the heart-mind is alert, then whether revering the gods or serving others, one acts as though in their presence, ever respectful and ever cautious, vigilant at every moment, diligent all day long. In approaching the divine, one must be especially circumspect. From the smallest matter to the greatest, from a single task to a hundred—gather the heart-mind within the breast and never let it stray. Gradually, through practice, it will attain purity, and in time, the heart-mind will have its master, so one does not dare to grow reckless, brash, or wantonly unrestrained.

This method of gathering the heart-mind is the guiding principle of my foundational teachings, the governing force of my scriptural expositions, and the very essence of what I have always called the wondrous truth of cultivating immortality or Buddhahood! As for those of the lowest capacity, even if they cannot inwardly grasp profound mysteries or align with the distant spirit, when confronted with these regulations, they should at least, in serving Heaven and revering the gods, exercise some restraint—taming this wild and unruly monkey-spirit to prevent its rampancy. Yet such people, in their daily lives, utterly neglect the study of gathering the heart-mind, merely indulging in habitual tendencies, vainly giving free rein to desires. Their ignorance burns fiercely, their consciousness is hard to discipline, and in all things, they act wantonly, forming deep-seated habits of reckless and unrestrained conduct. Enmeshed in the delusions of the mundane, they do not awaken to the thunderous voice of warning. Thus, in their approach to the divine, they behave with reckless abandon, transgressing propriety and overstepping bounds—conduct for which they cannot even answer to themselves.

Such people are called "the unprincipled" in human relations, "the insolent and arrogant" in worldly affairs, "the unworthy" in Confucian teaching, "those who defile the pure rules" in the Buddhist tradition, and in my Dao, "the mad and perverse." What value do they have? The word *jing* means reverence—without reverence, why speak of scripture? Scripture teaches people through the heart-mind—if the heart-mind is scattered, why establish scripture? Only when scripture seals the heart-mind does the heart-mind become the essence of scripture. Scripture is not merely entrusted to language and text.

Alas! I cannot help but feel sorrow for them.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

In all matters of serving the divine, one faces the numinous with solemn reverence, as though the gods were present before one—whether to the left or right, awe and deference must prevail. Not only must attire be impeccable, but one’s bearing must also be upright; with vigilant reverence, every movement of hand and foot should be composed. In morning rites, prostrations, and invocations, the ritual forms must be measured, the demeanor unhurried and refined, the gravity in accord with the proper sequence.

When the exalted deities turn their gaze upon one’s central place, their scrutiny is severe—one dare not slight them. Such reverence and awe resemble a subject’s devotion to a sovereign, where every propriety must be observed. Yet in the service of superiors or the audience with a ruler, there may be those whose reverence is not born of true sincerity. But if the heart harbors awe, no pretense of devotion can arise.

Serving the divine, however, surpasses even the reverence due to a sovereign, for the gods’ radiance is resplendent, their responsiveness swift—breath and echo move in unison, so immediate that one cannot but feel awe, cannot but dare to feel awe. This is due to the gods’ manifest presence, which defies all measure.

Those who approach with the intent to serve the divine must already align their hearts with reverence—how could they dare to jest, to trifle, to act irreverently, treating the sacred as child’s play? Though I possess little worth, once the heart is set on serving the divine, whether the gods exist or not, one must fully devote one’s heart and fulfill one’s rites.

If this Way remains obscure, how can one be human? How can one serve the divine? Between gods and humans, resonance arises from sincerity—sincerity moves Heaven, and Heaven’s virtue is fragrant. A thousand rites and a hundred forms all hinge upon the heart; whether the heart is true or false depends on one’s own resolve. To exhaust one’s loyalty is to be true in substance; responding to things with sincerity, one cultivates understanding, refines the self, orders the family—all extending from the heart. The governance of peace and harmony rests upon utmost sincerity; all participation in creation and nurturance stems from this root.

O you disciples, strive diligently in this practice!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

The difficulty of wielding the planchette is no ordinary matter—some achieve it through celestial endowment, others through human effort.

To become a planchette medium requires innate wisdom, a penetrating intelligence, a nature harmonious in qi, and a heart and spirit serene and detached—at odds with the ways of the world. One must have long cultivated good faith, never deceiving others, never chasing externals, reverent and single-minded, embodying tranquility, ever cautious and vigilant, unwavering and unhesitating, free from doubt or deceit. Only then can heart and hand respond in unison, spirit and person merge as one, and divine insight flow unimpeded, never obstructing the will of the gods.

Those who naturally embody stillness and ease, whose intent is gentle and harmonious, effortlessly refined—these are the "heaven-made" mediums. Those who progress from novice to mastery through disciplined cultivation, attaining perfection only after rigorous refinement—these are the "human-effort" mediums. In all cases, the foundation lies in daily sincerity, where words and deeds are never careless, and one’s inner disposition aligns with the divine. When the moment arrives, one must gather spirit and concentrate qi, still the heart and calm the nature, so that qi abides and spirit abides, the mechanism is fluid and the heart is nimble—this is the essence.

For the planchette medium serves as the vessel for the divine; any flaw in speech, any lapse in conduct, any trace of vanity, deceit, or doubt—these the gods reject. If they reject the person, how can they dwell within? Even in the midst of practice, if the mind wanders outward, if the seven emotions arise, if one wavers in doubt or falters in diligence, the divine mechanism is obstructed, and the connection cannot endure. This is why true planchette mediums are rare, why those who serve *my* transmission are rarer still, and why those who can expound scriptures and preach the Dharma are the rarest of all.

My work of enlightenment begins with finding the right vessel: one whom the gods may possess must also possess virtue and spiritual roots. Thus, the term "planchette medium" is not lightly spoken.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

In the prime of youth, one must first discipline the nature—this is the foundation of virtue, and it cannot be cultivated without warmth and generosity.

Thus, what the Confucian tradition calls "preserving the mind and nurturing nature" is precisely what my tradition terms "refining qi and refining spirit." Those who study the Dao must first learn not to live, but to die; if they cannot die, how can they attain life? Concealing the mechanism of life within the aperture of death—this is for each person to realize for themselves. Otherwise, the more one seeks life daily, the more one hastens toward death. This is the profound subtlety of the Way of perpetual generation. Do not be swayed by habitual defilements or deluded by worldly dust. A single spark of enlightenment in a person is like a torch kindled in a dark room, instantly illuminating all—do not squander your wisdom on useless pursuits.

Truly, being entangled in mundane affairs is an inescapable part of human nature. Yet you differ from the common crowd and should not cling to vulgar perceptions. Though I now offer you manifold confirmations, I cannot augment what is absent nor diminish what is present. Even if I wished to reshape your destiny, how could I alter what is already fixed? Today, I speak to you with this hope: that you may awaken to the truth that "all conditioned dharmas are like dreams, illusions, bubbles, shadows."

You need only follow your allotted path and abide in the present, seeking to realize the wondrous fruit to come. Then, when the day arrives for me to expound and unfold the teachings, it will suffice to awaken your inherent wisdom—this will be the fruition of seventy years of gathering karmic conditions. From now on, you must gradually shed worldly burdens, cast off secular attachments, undertake a thorough rectification, and gather your spirit, awaiting the ripening of conditions. Then you may assist me in expounding the teachings, bringing boundless benefit to all.

Moreover, in your past lives of cultivation, you would have long since attained perfect penetration and swift realization!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Having taken refuge in my tradition, you must embody my intent. Let reverence govern your mind, and harmony guide your dealings with others. Do not exalt yourself with arrogance, nor display haughtiness toward all things. Even if alluring temptations surround you, recall the steadfastness of Master Xia Hui, who remained unmoved. Though others may subject you to unjust treatment, you must emulate the noble person who reflects thrice and finds no fault.

Do you not know the words of the *Book of Zhou*: "August Heaven shows no partiality—it aids only those who possess virtue"?

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

When my disciples lead their families to take refuge, it may seem an expression of sincerity toward the Dao. Yet many of you assume that merely receiving a Daoist name constitutes refuge—how far this is from its true meaning! You do not understand that "refuge" (*gui*) means taking the Dao as your return, while "dependence" (*yi*) means taking the Dao as your sovereign master and relying upon it.

Only when you faithfully accept and practice the teachings, uphold the precepts, avoid transgressing the rules of the Daoist community, and maintain the moral order of human relations—only when your mind is upright, your sincerity unwavering, and your actions aligned with principle—can you truly embody the meaning of refuge and be called one who has taken refuge. If you seek only a Daoist name to fulfill your notion of refuge, it is utterly meaningless! How much more so for those women and children who lack understanding and insight!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

If you aspire to follow my Dao, you must cultivate reverence and faith, grounding all things in their fundamental essence.

If you willingly abandon yourself, you will daily sink into the filthy and base; if you can act with unyielding vigor, you will daily ascend to the lofty and luminous. As for nurturing essence and fostering purity, harmonizing nature and regulating emotions—this fundamentally depends on possessing the learning of self-cultivation and serene stillness, and preserving a mind of emptiness and profound obscurity, only then can you achieve success! If you fail to restrain yourself, you will daily grow coarse and superficial; the failure to connect with the spirit is a minor matter, but the karmic retribution for transgressions is most severe!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

To Hong, the Sincere and Earnest:

Have you also heard of my doctrine of "Encompassing the Three" (*Han San*)? Since the primordial bifurcation of the Two Modes, the Three Powers have been distinguished. Yet heaven possesses the Three Lights to illuminate all things, and earth possesses the Three Teachings to sustain the human heart. However, as people differ in their endowment of qi, the Buddhist canon speaks of the Three Vehicles, the elixirs of immortality are ranked in Three Grades, and even the Confucians acknowledge differences in the upper, middle, and lower qualities of qi. Tracing back to their origin, their allotment was uniform, fundamentally belonging to the One Qi, and containing within it the One Principle. Thus, though the Three Teachings are distinct, they emerge from a single source. If you penetrate the principles of the Three Teachings and perceive no difference between them, you will naturally return to the essence of the Supreme Ultimate!

The Supreme Ultimate is precisely what is called the "Primordial One Qi" (*xian tian yi qi*). From it, the Two Modes were divided, and the Three Powers were distinguished. As for the Three Teachings, they are but tributaries and divergent streams of the Supreme Ultimate; in their origin, they are nothing other than the One Principle. Therefore, my altar was specifically named "Encompassing the Three," for it unites the Three into One, and within the One Dao, it embraces the Three Teachings!

In the practice of our school, there are both heterodox and orthodox methods: the heterodox speak of techniques for prolonging life and extending years, while the orthodox discourse solely on the Great Dao of the Golden Elixir. The Golden Elixir is what the Buddhist Dharma calls "perfectly luminous awakened nature." It is neither metal nor stone, yet metals and stones cannot compare to its firmness; it divides into yin and yang, yet yin and yang cannot capture its subtlety! Its numinous responsiveness is boundless, its spiritual transformations beyond comparison. Cultivate it, and the inch-field and foot-dwelling can attain longevity; a hundred years, a thousand years, can be perpetually preserved. Those methods of medicinal substances, fire times, the two eights and one catty, the midnight and noon withdrawals and additions, the ascent of water and descent of fire—these are but peripheral words! In truth, to exhaust the essence of nature and life, to subdue the deluded mind, the Dao is right before your eyes! In my earlier *Pointers for the School*, I once revealed this meaning to instruct others.

Some say in admonition to those who study the Dao:
*"Grasp well the hairless fierce tiger!"*
This hairless fierce tiger is the heart-mind.
What the heart-mind does is called intention—
intention is what the *Pointers for the School* calls the "Yellow Dame,"
in the human body, the "Spleen-Earth."

Water below is hard to ascend;
fire above is hard to descend.
When intention becomes utterly single-minded,
qi naturally follows.
Thus a cinnabar formula says:
*"The Yellow Dame leads and draws into the center."*
For metal is the mother of water,
wood the mother of fire.
With this Eastern King and Western Queen united,
they give birth to the two—water and fire, male and female.
Yet only through intention’s refining and tempering
can accomplishment be achieved.
Thus another cinnabar formula says:
*"Originally through Wu and Ji as matchmakers,
husband and wife come to rightful joy."*
Though the cinnabar classics abound with such names and forms,
all are provisionally established.
If this heart-mind is subdued and settled,
then all becomes empty.
The Most High said:
*"A Dao that can be spoken is not the constant Dao;
a name that can be named is not the constant name."*

Just as the intent to "contain the Three" implies—yet the Three cannot be named, what then is there to contain? If containment itself cannot be named, how can the Three be distinguished? Thus the One is the Three, and the Three is the One. One who awakens to this Dao is a true cultivator.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

The original heart-mind and nature remain unenlightened, thus karmic entanglements bind one to the endless cycle of rebirth. This kalpa not yet exhausted, another arises; evil retribution not yet dissolved, karmic debts mount anew. The longer one sinks, the deeper one drowns! In the boundless netherworld, no path leads out; through endless years, when shall one ascend?

The human body is hard to obtain, rebirth in the Pure Land harder still. Keen senses and bright eyes are the virtue of Heaven’s bestowal; ample clothing and food are the merit of past-life cultivation. Wealth, fame, and honor cannot be forcibly seized! Longevity or early death, poverty or prosperity—none come by mere luck!

If one fails to repay the grace of Heaven and Earth above or the kindness of nurture below, one trivializes life and forgets its root, already incurring immense transgression! Worse still, some disrupt moral order, corrupting the very foundation, scheming with cunning and deceit, treating others with cruelty and malice. They show no reverence for the Three Lights, scorn the Three Teachings, defile the human realm, and lose their original nature. In life, they suffer grievous illness and die untimely; in death, they cannot escape hell’s punishments and are cast into the underworld. Are not such multitudes pitiable?

Know this: the path to heaven lies in a luminous heart-mind. Let go today, and today all is empty; turn back tomorrow, and tomorrow all is resolved. One laughs at life’s fleeting dream—who can seek truth within it? One sighs at the world’s countless illusions—who can find reality amid the void?

While alive, they knew no reflection; in death, their souls are benighted! Clinging to ephemeral things, where does their original spirit reside? Lamenting to earth and heaven, who pities their cold grave? Once they lose their human form, sinking through ten thousand kalpas with no escape—is this not terrifying?

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Since time immemorial, people have lost their true nature, failing to take refuge in the Three Treasures, seeking only to nourish the illusory body. Yet the illusory body is false and will decay. The Great Dao of the Golden Elixir, however, is everlasting and undying—neither born nor destroyed.

But this "Golden Elixir" is not like the heterodox paths that burn cinnabar and refine mercury, deluding the world and deceiving the people, driving them to ruin their families and waste their fortunes, achieving nothing while bringing harm. The immortals’ elixir is the cultivation of the heart-mind. Everyone possesses this Golden Elixir—only they refuse to refine it, thus remaining trapped in the cycle of kalpas, forever without liberation!

One must vow with fervor, first repenting past transgressions and taking refuge in the Three Treasures. In Buddhism, the Three Treasures are the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha; in Daoism, they are the Dao, the Scriptures, and the Master. Though the names differ, the principle is one. From this moment on, devote yourself to the Dao, and you may realize the pure Dao-body.

Awakening lies in the heart-mind alone. When the heart-mind is like the vast emptiness, unobstructed and free, one who awakens can liberate themselves. Otherwise, sinking through countless kalpas, even boundless compassion cannot save them!

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Since ancient times, all must die. Yet some die before their past-life good roots have ripened; others die before their evil karma has manifested. Some, practicing Buddhism or Daoism, change course midway, leaving their good fruits unripened while their evil karma grows, and thus they die. Others, though wicked all their lives, repent at life’s end—this single thought of remorse can transform their fate, turning them toward goodness and the true Dao.

Thus, in this life, disparities in gender, wealth, poverty, longevity, or early death are not Heaven’s arbitrary distinctions but the natural consequences of one’s own good and evil! If in past lives one delighted in goodness and the Dao, and in this life does the same, heavenly blessings will come, and heaven’s gates open. If not, the path to heaven is barred, with no entrance, and hell’s retribution offers no escape!

First, one must arouse the "mind of faith." By venerating the Three Treasures, one can dissolve kalpas of transgressions, emerge from the sea of suffering, and realize the Great Dao of immortality. Second, one must arouse the "mind of repentance." Repent for kalpas of ignorance, failing to cultivate the original heart-mind and nature, which have been obscured by ignorance and afflictions, sinking into the ghostly realms. This mind of repentance generates boundless merit—like polishing a mirror: once dust is removed, its body shines brilliantly.

Thus, life and death have their root in the heart-mind. To seek immortality, one must honor goodness. Goodness is the foundation of fortune; evil is the harbinger of misfortune. All good and evil arise from the heart-mind! A single good thought is like fertile soil yielding fine grain—nurtured, it flourishes, and the harvest is bountiful. A single evil thought is like clouds veiling the sky—sunlight dimmed, its radiance fades. Yet if one awakens and reforms, it is like wind scattering the clouds: the sky clears, and emptiness shines resplendent!

The nature of the Dao-cultivator is empty and luminous—just so. People ignorant of the true method of cultivation dismiss it as beyond the reach of foolish mortals—how could they ever practice the Dao?

How could the Dao’s root lie elsewhere, apart from one’s own heart-nature? If there were another Dao to cultivate, all buddhas and immortals would be deceiving the world. In truth, to cultivate the heart-mind is to cultivate the Dao. Let one but repent and cultivate oneself with wholeheart, and the Dao is not far off!

Listen to the recitation of scriptures: though their words and phrases be many, they all reveal this one heart-mind. The heart-mind is fundamentally firm, strong, centered, and upright, pure and refined, without a trace of selfish human desire. What is human desire? It is whatever each person craves—wealth or rank, sensual pleasure or fine food—all the manifold greedy and deluded thoughts, all called “desire.” Once this desire sprouts, one strays from celestial nature, becoming lost in illusion and chasing falsehood, descending through countless stages. Thus it is no longer called celestial nature but human desire. Moreover, each person’s desires differ, each unique, not the principle of great unity, not the heart-mind of perfect impartiality—hence they are called “selfish.” From now on, simply remove this selfish heart, eliminate deluded thoughts, and let the entire body shine with light, restoring celestial nature—then the Dao is near at hand! If one awakens to this nature in an instant, that is the great Dao of the Golden Elixir. Daily investigating one’s original nature, one naturally attains liberation from the realm of suffering.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

At the beginning of human life, there is only this one nature, nothing else. This nature is the primordial qi of precelestial origin. Heaven attains clarity through it; earth attains tranquility through it. Humans receive the clear and tranquil qi of heaven and earth to form their bodies, and thus there arises the division of yin and yang, purity and turbidity.

Yet this qi of heaven and earth originates in the Supreme Ultimate. The Supreme Ultimate is the primordial qi of precelestial origin; because heaven and earth are born from it, it is called “precelestial.” In humans, this qi is called “nature.” Before a person is born, this single speck of true nature enters the mother’s womb, where it takes form through the father’s essence and the mother’s blood. Yet this essence and blood also arise from the clear and tranquil qi of heaven and earth. Once there is essence and blood, form appears, and from the formless realm of pure yang’s original emptiness, one falls into the realm of form. Thus the precelestial qi becomes mixed and formless.

As the *Laozi* says: “Descending from the root, flowing to the branches, it gives birth to the myriad things.” This is what is meant. While still in the mother’s womb, hidden in formlessness, nature and life are as yet undifferentiated. But with the first cry at birth, the vast, luminous, and expansive body of the Great Void is shattered. At that moment, nature is revealed, and life follows, giving rise to the inequalities of poverty and prosperity, long life and early death. Yet the nature itself is fundamentally good.

After birth, the light of nature becomes hidden and unseen, and thus it is called “heart-mind.” Yet nature is the substance of the heart-mind, and the heart-mind is the function of nature. The two are divided like heaven and earth: nature is called “celestial nature,” and the heart-mind is named “the field of the heart-mind.” As for the function of “intention,” it falls to a third stage, flowing ever further, ever more distant, ever more lost—what is meant by “water flowing from Kunlun is no longer clear.”

Once there is form, there arise the disparities of the five senses, the four limbs, the hundred bones, and the six roots. As the *Laozi* says: “Within non-thing, there is thing; within non-being, there is being.” This is precisely what is meant. Only immortals and buddhas deeply comprehend this principle and directly investigate their original nature. Thus the immortals’ “seven reversals and nine returns” are merely refining the emotions to return to nature—returning to nature is what the *Laozi* calls “returning to the root and recovering life.” And the myriad methods of Buddhism are nothing but cultivating and illuminating this nature!

Since time immemorial, humans have been deluded by the nature of ignorance, losing the true source. How can this ignorance also be called “nature”? It is like the vast ocean: both the deep sea and its surging, unfathomable waves are called “sea.” The waves are of the same water as the sea; one cannot say the deep sea is water while the waves are not! If the waves calm and the surges cease, the sea’s clear and tranquil body is restored. If one can subdue the heart-mind, eliminate deluded thoughts, and return the emotions to nature, then the true origin of the Supreme Ultimate, the entire body of creation, will unite with heaven in virtue and with the sun and moon in brightness!

Thus the sages’ practice of “enduring nature” is enduring this ignorance, and my school’s practice of “refining nature” is refining this ignorance. Yet the root of transgression lies in mistakenly identifying the physical body as the self, making all manner of calculations to nourish this body. Though clothing and food may fill the mouth and body, one still feels it is not enough.

Therefore, in the *Laozi*’s scriptures, the first teaching is the method of cutting off obstacles, instructing one not to give rise to greed and anger: greed leads to actions that harm others for personal gain, while anger breeds envy of others’ possessions and resentment of one’s own lack, leading to blame and grievance against heaven and others—sins that accumulate day by day. When the celestial bureaus examine one’s deeds and the earthly courts reduce one’s blessings, and when the great reckoning arrives, one must let go and depart.

Where do all the wealth and emoluments of a lifetime go?
Before the Mirror of Karma, every deed is revealed in truth.
Though one had a mouth on every limb, none could explain—
Only then does one regret the misguided use of the heart-mind in the past.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

In the past, when expounding the classics and discussing scriptures, divine dragons appeared at Longsha: the *Eightfold Scripture* was revealed in Piling, costing tens of thousands; later, to greatly revive the ancestral teachings, the *Fivefold Scripture* was proclaimed, costing thousands more. When propagating the Three Teachings and expounding the *Pure Subtlety Canon*, the scale was somewhat reduced, amounting to over a thousand. Later, when expounding Chan Buddhism, guided by the Buddha’s compassion, all was done frugally to hasten completion. Thus, in all the past expositions of classics and discussions of scriptures, there has never been a lack of great generosity.

Yet as the world’s customs decline and few cherish the Dao, all later teachings and expositions have been scaled to the times and circumstances, avoiding excessive expense. Now that I have taken up this duty, the merit is no small matter. I do not seek to make do with meager means out of stinginess, but rather out of consideration for the modest salary of an official, which leaves little surplus. Thus, I act with frugality—not to slight the sacred teachings, disrespect the revealed texts, or defer to others. Still, the ritual implements required must not be skimped on; the rites are of great importance and demand solemn dignity. Moreover, when unfolding the numinous scriptures, the assembled immortals and attendant deities are no trifling matter—moderation is most fitting.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

Managing the rites while also accumulating recitations of the scriptural treasury is no easy task. Yet you must instruct all disciples well, lest their sincerity scatter or their initial diligence slacken—only then will there be benefit. I spare no effort in guiding you, for I truly wish you to embrace the Dao with earnest faith, arising naturally. This alone is merit. If you can serve the Dao with unwavering devotion, resonance will arise everywhere: blessings will come unbidden, and recompense will abound without seeking. The response between heaven and humanity is swifter than an echo—strive on, my disciples.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

This borderland is barren, its people impoverished, and it has just endured disaster. As a parent to the people, you must cherish them as you would an infant, attending to their every pain and distress with care. Share in their joys and sorrows—this is the duty of a just official. Heaven cherishes life above all, and nothing is weightier than the people’s lives! Those who govern must not only exercise caution in punishment; if they fail to instruct and transform the people, fostering a sense of shame, it is their failing. If they merely cultivate a hollow reputation for broad compassion while allowing rewards and punishments to blur, actions to be misplaced, and the people to lose all reliance—leaving them helpless—this is an even graver failing! When redressing grievances and resolving disputes, deciding cases on a single word; when sparing lives or condemning them, ruling on the finest detail—utmost care is required, and negligence is unforgivable! The ancient worthy officials, like the father of the Duke of Literary Loyalty, earned blessings for their descendants, as the historical records attest. Their merit arose from a heart devoted to preserving life, thereby accumulating boundless good. You must embody this principle of forbearance: cherish the people’s lives, nurture their strength, bestow kindness, and guide them with righteousness. Govern with impartiality, and your blessings will be vast and enduring.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

The Book of Documents states: “The Dao of Heaven shows no partiality—it ever aligns with the good.” Simply set your heart on goodness, be loyal to the sovereign and compassionate toward the people. For the Miao and Yi tribes, the ignorant and the foolish, govern with authority and soothe with kindness, balancing firmness and gentleness. The *Book of Songs* says: “Neither too rigid nor too yielding, governance flourishes, and all blessings converge.” If you cultivate such a heart and act accordingly, Heaven will surely protect you! Your wishes will naturally align with your heart, and all you seek will be fulfilled. Heaven will not oppose you—how much less will people or spirits?

The children of the frontier commanderies suffer greatly from poverty and hardship; they deserve particular care and compassion. In rooting out hidden wrongs, one must proceed with caution and prudence. The people of the borderlands are quick to embrace civilization, yet also quick to resist it—all depends on the balance of kindness and authority.

※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※　　　※

*Postscript to the Record of Han San’s Discourses*

What need has the Dao of words? The Dao cannot be spoken. Why then five thousand characters? For the Dao that pervades the cosmos has already distilled its essence in the transmission at the Pass! What need is there for even a single word beyond this?

Yet since its westward crossing, its moral influence has gradually waned. Later doctrines, like the clamor of reed pipes and drums, have mostly taken the remnants of the Five Thousand Words and spat forth their own drivel. As time passed, later generations have gathered this spittle only to spit it back, turning it into a war of tongues—each side attacking the other—far more bewildering and chaotic than the original din.

Our Most Revered Imperial Preceptor, moved by compassion for the deaf and blind, has sounded the bell and rung the clapper to awaken them—no less than the Blue Ox crossing again, raising his voice in urgent cry. Thus, he established the altar at Ezhou, opened the Jade Bureau to scatter golden sands, and expounded the *Mahāyāna Three Grades True Sutra*, expanding what the Five Thousand Words contained and releasing it, gathering what the Five Thousand Words dispersed and uniting it. He fully revealed its subtle meanings, penetrated its true essence, imprinted the sages’ minds, and harmonized the Dao of immortals and buddhas—creating anew a radiant scripture for the world!

In the intervals of expounding the canon, he would occasionally discourse on profound principles or examine passages, all for the sake of the world’s moral order and the human heart. Within these teachings, he exhorted the cultivation of human relationships and the refinement of mind and nature—every word, every character, sufficient to awaken one’s original nature and enlighten later learners. Truly, it is a bridge for saving the world and a raft for ferrying others across.

Those who once basked in his presence privately recorded his words, treasuring them in their collections but failing to circulate them. Now, fortunately, Master Sun of Jinling, while publishing the *Three Grades Sutra* in a convenient format, has compiled these records into a single volume, titled *Record of Han San’s Discourses*, to be printed alongside it as an appendix.

In truth, the Master deeply deplored the obstacle of written words, for they obscure wisdom and delude the foolish, harming the human heart. They incite falsehood and confuse truth, endangering the moral order. If not urgently corrected, the confusion of truth and falsehood will perpetuate the cycle of spittle without end. Though this *Record* may seem a mere remnant of the *Three Grades Sutra*, is it not the very essence of that spittle?

With the Master’s spittle, he awakens the world’s spittle—each drop a sweet dew, seeping into the heart. Those of true nature will savor its essence within the spittle! What then is the difference between scripture and record?

Let the world take it as a record if they wish, as a remnant of the *Three Grades* if they prefer—even as the *Three Grades True Sutra* itself, if they so choose.

This is the record.

Respectfully inscribed on the mid-spring day of the yimao year by Wang Zhen, disciple of the Manifested Perfected One.

*Preface to the* Complete Works of Patriarch Lü: *On Cultivating Truth and Transmitting the Dao*

Of old, the sixteen characters of the Yu Court served as the ancestral transmission of the heart-mind. Thereafter, the transmission of the Kong lineage was confined to a single thread in one word. If this be so, then the transmission of the Dao surely requires no further elaboration.

Yet Zengzi said, "The Master’s words on human nature and the Way of Heaven cannot be heard." The *Doctrine of the Mean* records many of Confucius’ sayings not found in the *Analects*, suggesting that teachings on nature and Heaven were once detailed but later concealed and not transmitted.

It is said that Patriarch Lü received the Dao from the Perfected Sovereign of Zhengyang, who, with the words "lest I mislead those five hundred years hence," had already perfected his three thousand meritorious deeds—how forthright indeed! Yet upon reading the *On Cultivating Truth and Transmitting the Dao*, one finds the principles of Heaven, humanity, nature, and destiny expounded in exhaustive detail, with intricate repetitions, a far cry from the sixteen characters of the Yu Court or the single thread of the Kong lineage. What then is the reason for this?

The *Collection* was transmitted to Shi Jianwu of Huayang, who, having passed the imperial examinations during the Yuanhe era of the Tang, retired to Mount West in Hongzhou, vowing never to serve in office. He once wrote a poem: *"Qi is the elixir of longevity, the heart its guide; / When qi and spirit know their course, the master becomes immortal."* From this, one may discern his cultivation!

When Patriarch Lü wandered to Mu, he saw Shi’s aspiration for the rosy clouds and bestowed upon him the Great Dao of the Returned Elixir. Thus did the *Collection* come to be transmitted. However, in those days of oral instruction, there must have been secret oral formulas too sacred to commit to writing—what was called "mouth-to-mouth transmission, unrecorded in text"—which are now lost to us.

The original text contained many errors; those that were corrupt or mistaken have been corrected here, while the rest remain unresolved. The eighteen chapters are divided into two scrolls.

**On True Immortals (I)**

Patriarch Lü said: When a person is born, how may they dwell in peace without illness, remain robust without aging, live without dying? By what Dao can this be achieved?

Master Zhongli said: Human life begins when father and mother unite, and the two qi converge, forming the embryo from essence and blood. After the Great Beginning comes the Great Substance: yin receives yang to generate life, and qi follows the transformation of the fetus. After three hundred days, the form is complete, and the numinous light enters the body, separating from the mother. After the Great Simplicity, there is already ascent and descent, and the Yellow Sprout grows. After five thousand days, the qi is full, its measure naturally reaching eighty-one zhang. At fifteen, one is called a "youthful lad." At this time, yang is half within yin, comparable to the light of the eastern sun. Beyond this, one loses the primal yang, dissipates the true qi, and with qi weakened, illness, aging, and death follow.

Foolish in life, one harms their own numinous light; wicked in a lifetime, one erodes their allotted years. Thus, in future lives, bodies differ in rank, lifespans vary in length, and after birth comes extinction, after extinction rebirth—endlessly deluded, life after life they fall, losing their form to other species, their spirit to alien shells. The root-nature of the utmost truth no longer returns to humanity; they revolve in the byways of samsara, forever without liberation. If they encounter a true immortal or perfected being who absolves their karmic retribution, they may shed their skin and shell to regain a human form. Yet they remain in stupor and ignorance, accumulating merit over a hundred kalpas to ascend to the Land of Blessing, still not free from hunger, cold, and lingering suffering. Gradually, they rise, their form slowly restored, yet they dwell among slaves and servants in lowly stations. Should they repeat past transgressions, they will, like a ball rolling down a board, re-enter the byways of samsara.

Patriarch Lü said: Born in the Central Kingdom, fortunate to live in an age of peace, with clothing and food sufficient and time not yet lost—those who love find peace, while those who resent fall ill; those who covet live, while those who fear die.

Today, having the honor to meet Your Reverence face to face, I bow again and again to implore: considering the gravity of life and death, dare I hope for an exposition of the principle of freedom from illness and death, that this poor scholar may receive instruction?

Patriarch Zhong said: If one wishes to escape the wheel of rebirth and avoid entering the shells of other beings, ensuring that the body remains free from the sufferings of illness, old age, and death—standing firm beneath heaven, embracing yin while holding yang—then one must be human. As a human, one should not become a ghost; among humans, one cultivates to become an immortal; among immortals, one ascends to become a celestial.

Patriarch Lü said: When a person dies, they become a ghost; when the Dao is accomplished, they become an immortal. Immortals are of one rank—why then speak of ascending from immortality to become celestial?

Patriarch Zhong said: Immortals are not of one kind. Those purely yin without yang are ghosts; those purely yang without yin are immortals; those with mixed yin and yang are humans. Only humans may become ghosts or immortals. If in youth one does not cultivate but indulges in passion and desire, they fall ill and die to become ghosts. If one awakens and cultivates, transcending the mundane to enter sagehood, shedding the mortal form to become an immortal—immortals have five ranks, and the Dao has three degrees of accomplishment. Cultivation lies with the individual, while attainment follows one’s allotted portion.

Patriarch Lü said: You speak of "three degrees of accomplishment" in the Dao and "five ranks of immortals"—what does this mean?

Patriarch Zhong said: The three degrees of accomplishment are the distinctions between minor, intermediate, and major attainment. The five ranks of immortals are ghost immortals, human immortals, earthly immortals, divine immortals, and celestial immortals—all are immortals, yet not equal. Ghost immortals do not depart from ghosts; human immortals do not depart from humans; earthly immortals do not depart from earth; divine immortals do not depart from spirits; celestial immortals do not depart from heaven.

Patriarch Lü said: What is meant by "ghost immortals"?

Patriarch Zhong said: Ghost immortals are the lowest of the five. They transcend within yin, their spirit-images unclear, their names absent from the ghostly registers, unrecorded in the three sacred mountains. Though they do not enter the wheel of rebirth, they struggle to return to Penglai or Yingzhou, ultimately finding no refuge but to reincarnate in borrowed vessels. Such is their fate.

Patriarch Lü said: By what arts and through what efforts do such ghost immortals attain this state?

Patriarch Zhong said: Those who cultivate yet fail to awaken to the great Dao, seeking swift attainment, become like withered wood, their hearts as dead ash. Their spirit and consciousness turn inward, their will undivided. From deep meditation, they project a yin spirit—a ghost of pure clarity, not a being of pure yang. Because their will remains fixed in yin clarity, they are called ghost immortals. Though termed immortals, they are in truth ghosts. Many followers of Buddhism who practice to this point claim to have attained the Dao (in their tradition, those who truly master it are called *golden immortals*), which is truly laughable.

Patriarch Lü said: What then are "human immortals"?

Patriarch Zhong said: Human immortals are the second lowest of the five. Cultivators of the Dao who do not awaken to the great Dao may grasp one method within the Dao, one technique within that method, and with steadfast faith and unwavering resolve, persist without deviation for a lifetime. The qi of the five phases harmonize and unite, their form and substance stabilized, the eight perverse influences unable to harm them. They enjoy good health with few ailments—this is called a human immortal.

Patriarch Lü said: By what arts and through what efforts do such human immortals attain this state?

Patriarch Zhong said: Those who cultivate may initially hear of the great Dao. Yet burdened by heavy karma and meager blessings, beset by demonic obstacles, they abandon their original intent, settling for minor attainment. Their practice bears fruit, but they remain fixed for life, unable to progress, their methods unchanging with the seasons. Those who renounce the five flavors—how would they know of the six qi? Those who forget the seven emotions—how would they know of the ten precepts?

Those who practice rinsing and swallowing (pron. *yàn*) mistake it for the art of exhalation and inhalation; those who cling to sexual arts deride purity as foolishness. Those who delight in wresting qi from things rather than from heaven and earth refuse to abandon grain; those who prefer visualization to draw the essence of the sun and moon refuse to practice daoyin. Sitting alone in breath-holding—how would they know of spontaneity? Bending the body and straining the form—how would they recognize non-action? Those who absorb yin by taking women’s qi differ from those who shrink the golden turtle; those who nurture yang by consuming women’s milk differ from those who refine the elixir. Extending this by analogy, such methods are countless, yet all belong to the Dao. Unable to embrace the great Dao in its entirety, they settle for one method or one technique within it, achieving success and peace, prolonging life—this is what is called a human immortal.

There is another class: those who delight in fleeting moments, weary of perseverance, practice carelessly, err in timing, and disrupt their days. Instead of prolonging life, they invite illness—such cases abound in the world.

**Patriarch Lü said:** What is meant by an "earth immortal"?

**Patriarch Zhong said:** An earth immortal stands halfway between heaven and earth, possessing the talent of an immortal. Failing to awaken to the great Dao, they halt at minor attainment. Though their progress is not outwardly visible, they achieve longevity and dwell in the world without dying—this is an earth immortal.

**Patriarch Lü said:** How does one begin the path to becoming an earth immortal?

**Patriarch Zhong said:** First, one must grasp the principle of heaven and earth’s ascent and descent, and the numbers of the sun and moon’s generation. Within the body, one employs years and months; within the day, one employs hours and moments. First, recognize the dragon and tiger; next, pair Kan and Li. Distinguish the clarity and turbidity of the water’s source, discern the early and late of the qi’s seasons. Gather the true One, observe the Two Modes, array the Three Powers, divide the Four Images, distinguish the Five Movements, stabilize the Six Qi, assemble the Seven Treasures, order the Eight Trigrams, and traverse the Nine Provinces. With the five phases inverted, qi is transmitted from mother to child, and fluids circulate between husband and wife. The Three Fields are reversed, the elixir is refined through firing, and forever anchored in the lower field. The body is tempered to dwell in the world, achieving immortality and becoming a land-bound immortal—this is called an earth immortal.

**Patriarch Lü said:** What is meant by a "divine immortal"?

**Patriarch Zhong said:** A divine immortal is one who, weary of dwelling in the dusty world, persists in cultivation without cease. Their joints interconnect, lead is drawn and mercury added, refining golden essence to the crown; jade liquid returns as the elixir, tempering form into qi, and the five qi ascend to the origin. The three yang gather at the crown, merit is fulfilled, and form is forgotten—the fetal immortal transforms spontaneously. Yin is exhausted, yang is pure, a body exists beyond the body, and one sheds the mortal frame to ascend as an immortal. Transcending the ordinary to enter sagehood, they bid farewell to the mundane, returning to the Three Mountains—this is called a divine immortal.

**Patriarch Lü said:** What is meant by a "celestial immortal"?

**Patriarch Zhong said:** When an earth immortal, weary of dwelling in the dusty world, persists in cultivation without cease and achieves liberation, this is called a divine immortal. When a divine immortal, weary of dwelling on the Three Isles, transmits the Dao among humans, accumulating merit in the Dao above and conduct among people below, their merit and conduct fulfilled, they receive the celestial writ to return to the Grotto-Heavens—this is called a celestial immortal. Once a celestial immortal, if weary of dwelling in the Grotto-Heavens, they may assume office as an immortal official: the lower are water officials, the middle are earth officials, and the upper are celestial officials. Having rendered great service to heaven and earth and great conduct through past and present, they are promoted through the ranks, serving in the thirty-six Grotto-Heavens before returning to the eighty-one Yang Heavens; having served in the eighty-one Yang Heavens, they return to the realm of the Three Pure Ones—void, spontaneous, and natural.

**Patriarch Lü said:** Ghost immortals are surely beyond pursuit, and celestial immortals are not yet dared to be hoped for. Might I hear of the methods for human immortals, earth immortals, and divine immortals?

**Patriarch Zhong said:** Human immortals do not transcend minor attainment; earth immortals do not transcend intermediate attainment; divine immortals do not transcend major attainment. These three levels of attainment are, in truth, one. Employing methods to seek the Dao—the Dao is not difficult. Employing the Dao to seek immortality—immortality is also quite easy.

**Patriarch Lü said:** From ancient times to the present, those who cultivate life have not failed to seek longevity or ascension as immortals. Yet why do so few achieve longevity or ascension?

**Patriarch Zhong said:** Their methods do not align with the Dao. Overly reliant on extensive learning and forced memorization, they cling to minor techniques and side doors, yet still succumb to illness and death, falsely claiming "corpse liberation" (*shijie*, pron. *jiǎ*), misleading the world and mutually praising one another, thereby obscuring the great Dao. Even those with sincere faith and steadfast resolve, who practice diligently for years, ultimately see no results, their seasons passing into the Yellow Springs. Alas!

**On the Great Dao, Part Two**

**Patriarch Lü said:** What is meant by the "Great Dao"?

**Patriarch Zhong said:** The Great Dao is formless and nameless, unasked and unanswered. Vast beyond all bounds, minute beyond all measure. It cannot be known, nor can it be practiced!

**Patriarch Lü said:** From ancient times to the present, those of profound understanding first study the Dao, then attain the Dao, then master the Dao, then perfect the Dao.
