They leave the dusty world for Penglai Isle, ascend to the Grotto-Heavens, rise to the Heaven of Yang, and finally ascend to the Three Pure Realms—all are those who have perfected the Dao. Yet today, Master, you alone say the Dao cannot be known or practiced. Does this mean the Dao remains hidden from us?

**Patriarch Zhong said:** In truth, I have concealed nothing of the Dao. But those in the world who claim to follow the Dao possess only the name of loving it. They hear of the Great Dao yet lack faith; they have faith yet lack perseverance. They change their minds by evening from what they resolved in the morning, forget what they sit to do the moment they stand. They begin with diligence but end in slackness. Thus, I say the Great Dao is difficult to know and difficult to practice.

**Patriarch Lü said:** What is the principle behind the Dao being difficult to know and difficult to practice?

**Patriarch Zhong said:** Because minor techniques and side doors yield quick results, they are passed down endlessly, and even at death, practitioners remain deluded. This has become a common custom, corrupting the Great Dao. Some practice fasting, some abstain from grain, some gather *qi*, some rinse and swallow, some leave their wives, some forsake flavors, some meditate in *dhyāna*, some maintain silence, some visualize, some absorb *yin*, some ingest *qi*, some uphold purity, some calm the mind, some cut off thoughts, some open the crown, some retract the genitals, some sever desires, some read and recite, some refine through fire, some regulate breath, some practice *daoyin*, some exhale and inhale, some take and replenish, some give alms, some make offerings, some perform acts of salvation, some retreat to mountains, some recognize their nature, some remain unmoving, some uphold precepts. The minor techniques and side doors are too numerous to recount.

As for those who gather the essence of sun and moon, seize the *qi* of heaven and earth, fix their minds and thoughts in hopes of congealing cinnabar, or exhaust their bodies in pursuit of liberation—if they take in more than they release, it may cure illness; if they consider it true "embryonic breathing," cutting off thoughts and forgetting speech, it may nurture their nature; if they mistake it for the *qi* of the Great One or the "unfailing golden spear," the "reversed flow of the Yellow River," it is but a lesser method for preserving life. To make the body like withered wood and the mind like dead ashes is but a minor art of gathering spirit. Alas! Why do those who follow the Dao, past and present, cling so stubbornly to these misguided pursuits?

Swallowing saliva as medicine—how can one attain the workings of creation? Gathering *qi* as elixir—how can it be made to abide? Calling the liver a dragon and the lungs a tiger—how can they unite? Taking *kan* as lead and *li* as mercury—how can they be refined and replenished? Watering through the four seasons in hopes of growing the yellow sprout; fixing the mind unwaveringly to seek the great medicine; mistaking years and months, wasting days and disrupting hours. Without knowing the root of the five phases, how can one comprehend the creative transformations of the Three Powers? Seeking branches and plucking leaves, they mislead later generations. Thus the Great Dao grows ever more distant and neglected, while heterodoxies arise and become custom, losing the original intent of the early masters. This is truly due to learning from hearsay and street-corner talk, mere oral transmission, passing finger gestures to the ignorant, teaching one another in succession, until they descend into the springs below—it chills the heart.

Not that I do not wish to expound the Great Dao, but the world’s people bear heavy karma and meager fortune, disbelieving in the celestial mechanism, prizing wealth over life, content to become lesser ghosts.

Master Lü said: "The lesser methods and side doors are now understood. As for the Great Dao, may I hear of it?"

Master Zhong said: "The Dao originally has no questions; questions originally have no answers. Yet when the true source divides, the great simplicity scatters. The Dao gives birth to the One; the One gives birth to the Two; the Two gives birth to the Three. The One is essence; the Two is function; the Three is transformation. Essence and function do not depart from yin and yang; transformations all arise from their union. Above, middle, and below are arrayed as the Three Powers; heaven, earth, and humanity share in the one Dao. The Dao gives birth to the two *qi*; the two *qi* give birth to the Three Powers; the Three Powers give birth to the five phases; the five phases give birth to the myriad things. Among the myriad things, none is more numinous or noble than humanity. Only humanity can fathom the principles of the myriad things and fulfill its own nature. To fathom principles and fulfill nature to the point of destiny, to preserve life in its entirety and merge with the Dao—this is to stand firm with heaven and earth, sharing their longevity."

Master Lü said: "Heaven and earth endure eternally, spanning millennia without end. Human life lasts a hundred years, and even seventy is rare. Why is the Dao so near to heaven and earth yet so distant from humanity?"

Master Zhong said: "The Dao is not distant from humanity; humanity distances itself from the Dao. The reason it distances itself from the Dao is that it does not know the method of nurturing life. The reason it does not know the method is that its lesser practices fail to recognize the proper time. The reason it does not recognize the proper time is that it does not grasp the mechanism of heaven and earth."

**On the Mechanism of Heaven and Earth, III**

Master Lü said: "What is meant by 'the mechanism of heaven and earth'? May I hear of it?"

Master Zhong said: "The mechanism of heaven and earth is how heaven and earth employ the Great Dao, ascending and descending without cease, acting tirelessly to attain their enduring firmness. They have never lightly revealed it to humanity."

Master Lü said: "How does heaven and earth’s employment of the Dao constitute their 'mechanism of operation'? How does their 'mechanism of action' manifest? How does operation begin? How is efficacy seen?"

Master Zhong said: "Once the Great Dao divides and takes form, form gives rise to number. Heaven embodies the *qian* Dao, taking the One as its essence, light and pure above—what it employs is yang. Earth embodies the *kun* Dao, taking the Two as its essence, heavy and turbid below—what it employs is yin. Yang ascends and yin descends, mutually uniting. *Qian* and *kun* act without departing from the Dao, their beginnings timed, their efficacy manifest in due course."

Master Lü said: "Heaven embodies the *qian* Dao, employing yang. Yang governs ascent—how then does it unite with earth? Earth embodies the *kun* Dao, employing yin. Yin governs descent—how then does it unite with heaven? If heaven and earth do not unite, how can yin and yang merge? If yin and yang do not merge, how can *qian* and *kun* act? If *qian* and *kun* do not act, though there be a time for beginning and a day for efficacy, how can the Great Dao be attained?"

Master Zhong said: "The Dao of heaven takes *qian* as its essence and yang as its function, accumulating *qi* above. The Dao of earth takes *kun* as its essence and yin as its function, accumulating water below. Heaven’s enactment of the Dao is *qian* seeking (*suo*) *kun*. At the first seeking, it produces the eldest son, the eldest son called *zhen*; at the second seeking, the middle son, the middle son called *kan*; at the third seeking, the youngest son, the youngest son called *gen*. Thus heaven unites with earth, *qian* Dao seeking *kun* Dao to give birth to the three yang. Then earth’s enactment of the Dao is *kun* seeking *qian*. At the first seeking, it produces the eldest daughter, the eldest daughter called *xun*; at the second seeking, the middle daughter, the middle daughter called *li*; at the third seeking, the youngest daughter, the youngest daughter called *dui*. Thus earth unites with heaven, *kun* Dao seeking *qian* Dao to give birth to the three yin. The three yang unite with the three yin, and the myriad things are born; the three yin unite with the three yang, and the myriad things are completed. The union of heaven and earth fundamentally arises from *qian* and *kun* seeking one another, operating within the Dao. *Qian* and *kun* seeking one another give birth to the six *qi*; the six *qi* unite to divide the five phases; the five phases unite to give birth to and complete the myriad things.

When the *qian* Dao descends, the three seekings conclude, and its yang ascends again, yang concealing yin within, returning above to heaven. When the *kun* Dao ascends, the three seekings conclude, and its yin descends again, yin concealing yang within, returning below to earth. Yang concealing yin—its yin does not dissipate, and is called true yin. When true yin reaches heaven, it is born through yang, so when yin descends from heaven, can yin be without yang? Yin concealing yang—its yang does not perish, and is called true yang. When true yang reaches earth, it is activated through yin, so when yang ascends from earth, can yang be without yin? Yang concealing yin—its yin does not dissipate, and returns to earth; yin concealing yang—its yang does not perish, and returns to heaven."

Revolving in endless cycles, its movement ceaseless. When their union never strays from the Dao, this is how they endure, steadfast and enduring. Master Lü said: The mechanism of heaven and earth moves within the Dao, thus attaining longevity—this is the workings of heaven and earth. Yet man, though endowed with intelligence and a nature inclined toward purity, may aspire to follow the Great Dao: in small measure, to enjoy peace and prolong life; in moderate measure, to attain immortality; in great measure, to shed the mortal form and ascend as an immortal. How then does one apply this work, moving the Great Dao to activate the celestial mechanism, thereby also achieving enduring steadfastness and eternal existence through the eons?

Master Zhong said: The Great Dao is formless, taking form through what it bestows; the Great Dao is nameless, acquiring names through what it possesses. Heaven and earth receive it and call it the *qian* Dao and *kun* Dao; the sun and moon receive it and call it the yang Dao and yin Dao. When man receives it in the court, it is called the Dao of ruler and minister; in the inner chambers, the Dao of husband and wife; in the village, the Dao of elder and younger; in the school, the Dao of friends; in the household, the Dao of father and son. Thus, all that appears externally is pervaded by the Dao.

As for the union of father and mother: the father’s yang advances first, while yin follows behind, true *qi* meeting true water. The fire of the heart and the water of the kidneys unite, refined into essence. Once this essence is released, encountering the mother’s yin, water advances first, cleansing the useless places; encountering the mother’s yang, blood advances first, received before the womb. Essence and blood form the embryo, containing true *qi*, entering the mother’s womb. Over days and months, true *qi* transforms and shapes the person, just as heaven and earth follow the Dao, *qian* and *kun* seeking one another, giving rise to the three yins and three yangs. True *qi* is yang, true water is yin. Yang conceals water within, yin conceals *qi* within. *Qi* governs ascent, and within *qi* lies true water; water governs descent, and within water lies true *qi*. True water is true yin, true *qi* is true yang.

True yang follows water in its descent, like *qian* seeking *kun*: above is *zhen*, in the middle is *kan*, below is *gen*. Comparing this to man, taking the center as the standard, from above to below: *zhen* is the liver, *kan* is the kidneys, *gen* is the bladder. True yin follows *qi* in its ascent, like *kun* seeking *qian*: below is *xun*, in the middle is *li*, above is *dui*. Comparing this to man, taking the center as the standard, from below to above: *xun* is the gallbladder, *li* is the heart, *dui* is the lungs. Once the form is complete and the term is fulfilled, the child departs from the mother.

After birth, primordial yang resides in the kidneys. From primordial yang arises true *qi*, and true *qi* ascends to the heart; from true *qi* arises true fluid, and true fluid returns to the origin. Ascending and descending in cycles, if nothing is depleted, one may naturally prolong life. If one knows the timing without error and regulates withdrawal and supplementation with precision, one may naturally attain longevity. If one practices without weariness and cultivates without cease, yin will be exhausted and yang purified, allowing one to transcend the ordinary and enter sagehood. This is the profound principle of the celestial mechanism, a matter not transmitted through the ages.

If you hold faith without hesitation, regard fame and profit as shackles, love and affection as enemies, avoid illness as one fears death, guard against losing the body to another shell, and contemplate the escape of the spirit into other forms—then, with a mind of purity, you must first sever the root, preventing the loss of primordial yang and the dissipation of true *qi*. When *qi* is abundant, the hun-soul is free of yin; when yang is robust, the po-soul contains *qi*. In ascent and descent, one takes heaven and earth as the model; in waxing and waning, one follows the sun and moon.

**On the Sun and Moon, Fourth Discourse**
Master Lü said: The principles of heaven and earth are now roughly understood. Can the celestial movements and conjunctions of the sun and moon be compared to man? I wish to hear of this.

Master Zhong said: The Great Dao is formless, giving birth to heaven and earth; the Great Dao is nameless, moving the sun and moon. The sun and moon are the essences of great yang and great yin, silently recording the degrees of heaven and earth’s union, aiding in the work of generating and completing the myriad things. Rising and setting in the east and west, they divide day and night; moving north and south, they determine cold and heat. Unceasing in their cycles, cold and heat spur one another on. Within the po-soul, the hun-soul is born; within the hun-soul, the po-soul is born. Advancing and retreating in due time, they do not stray from the reckoning of *qian* and *kun*; coming and going with measure, they do not err from the timing of heaven and earth.

Master Lü said: Rising and setting in the east and west to divide day and night—how is this so?

Master Zhong said: When the primordial chaos first divided, darkness and light settled into place. The forms of heaven and earth resemble an egg; the six directions converge at the center, round as a sphere. The sun and moon rise and set, moving above the heavens and below the earth. Above and below, east and west, they revolve like a wheel. When the sun rises in the east and has not yet set in the west, it is day; when it sets in the west and has not yet risen in the east, it is night—this is how the sun’s rising and setting divide day and night. The moon’s rising and setting differ from the sun’s. It receives its po-soul in the west and its hun-soul in the east, shining its light by night while its hun-soul is concealed by day. Over days and hours, it rises and sets, moving from west to east. At first, within the po-soul, the hun-soul is born, appearing like a drawn bow, its light shining in the west at early night. Next, the po-soul contains half the hun-soul, corresponding to the first quarter, its light shining in the south at early night. Then, the po-soul is full of the hun-soul, facing the sun, its light shining in the east at early night. Next, within the hun-soul, the po-soul is born, appearing like a broken mirror, its hun-soul concealed in the west at early day. Then, the hun-soul contains half the po-soul, corresponding to the last quarter, its po-soul concealed in the south at early day.

Next, the hun-soul is full of the po-soul, facing away from the sun, its po-soul concealed in the east at early day. This is how the moon’s rising and setting divides day and night.

Master Lü said: "The south-north movement determines cold and heat—why is this?"
Master Zhong said: "After the winter solstice, the sun rises at the initial fifty *fen* of *chen* and sets at the final fifty *fen* of *shen*. From this point onward, its rising and setting shift from south to north, reaching the summer solstice as its limit. After the summer solstice, the sun rises at the final fifty *fen* of *yin* and sets at the initial fifty *fen* of *xu*. From this point onward, its rising and setting shift from north to south, reaching the winter solstice as its limit. From south to north, from winter to summer, cold transforms into heat. From north to south, from summer to winter, heat transforms into cold. The summer day is the winter night; the winter day is the summer night. After the winter solstice, the moon rises from north to south, corresponding to the summer day. After the summer solstice, the moon rises from south to north, corresponding to the winter day. This is how the sun and moon’s movement determines cold and heat."

Master Lü said: "The mechanism of Heaven and Earth, the ascent and descent of yin and yang—it is no different from a person’s cultivation. If the sun and moon’s rising and setting, their cyclical movements and conjunctions, can they be compared to humans?"
Master Zhong said: "The mechanism of Heaven and Earth lies in the ascent and descent of yin and yang. One ascent, one descent—Taiyi generates itself, generation and completion following one another in endless cycles, never deviating from the Dao, thus attaining longevity. Those who cultivate the Dao, if they take Heaven and Earth as their model, may likewise achieve immortality and never die. If compared to the sun and moon’s cyclical movements and conjunctions, it is merely the moon receiving the sun’s hun-soul, transforming yang into yin. When yin is exhausted and yang is pure, the moon’s brilliance becomes flawless, dispelling the dark po-soul like the sun’s radiance illuminating the earth below. At this time, it is like a person’s refinement—using qi to perfect spirit, shedding the mortal form to ascend as an immortal, forging a body of pure yang."

Master Lü said: "For those who cultivate the Dao and uphold its principles, in applying the principles of Heaven and Earth’s yin-yang ascent and descent, and the sun and moon’s essence in conjunction—where should one begin?"
Master Zhong said: "First, emulate the mechanism of Heaven, using the principle of yin-yang ascent and descent to unite true water and true fire, refining them into the great elixir, eternally guarding the *dantian*, enduring through eons without death, and matching the lifespan of Heaven and Earth. If weary of the mundane world and continuing one’s practice, one should then take the sun and moon’s conjunction, using yang to refine yin so that yin does not arise, and using qi to nourish spirit so that spirit does not scatter. The five qi gather at the origin, the three flowers converge at the crown, cutting ties with the vulgar world to return to the Three Isles."

Master Lü said: "If one’s merit and verification deeply grasp this purport, the only concern is missing the proper timing!"
Master Zhong said: "The ascent and descent of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang conjoin once a year. The sun and moon’s essence come and go, conjoining once a month. A person’s qi and fluids conjoin once a day and night."

**On the Four Seasons, Fifth Section**

Master Lü said: "Regarding the conjunctions of Heaven and Earth and the sun and moon—can you explain their timing in years, months, days, and hours?"
Master Zhong said: "There are four types of seasons: For a human lifespan of a hundred years, from one to thirty is the time of youth and vigor; from thirty to sixty is the time of maturity; from sixty to ninety is the time of old age; from ninety to a hundred, or even a hundred and twenty, is the time of decline—this is the first type, the seasons within the body. If one takes the twelve earthly branches as a day, five days as a *hou*, three *hou* as a *qi*, three *qi* as a *jie*, and two *jie* as a season, then the seasons are spring, summer, autumn, and winter. When the season is spring, yin contains half of yang, its qi transforming cold into warmth—this is the time of spring. When the season is summer, yang contains yang, its qi transforming warmth into heat—this is the time of summer. When the season is autumn, yang contains half of yin, its qi transforming heat into coolness—this is the time of autumn. When the season is winter, yin contains yin, its qi transforming coolness into cold—this is the time of winter. This is the second type, the seasons within a year.

If one begins with *lü* in the middle of the pitch pipes and *lü* in the middle of the pitch standards, then in one month of thirty days, there are three hundred and sixty *chen*, three thousand *ke*, and one hundred and eighty thousand *fen*. From the new moon to the first quarter, yin contains half of yang; from the first quarter to the full moon, yang contains yang; from the full moon to the last quarter, yang contains half of yin; from the last quarter to the dark moon, yin contains yin. This is the third type, the seasons within a day and month.

If one takes sixty *fen* as a *ke*, eight *ke* and twenty *fen* as an hour, and one and a half hours as a hexagram, then the hexagrams determine the eight directions, and their proper divisions are the four positions. From *zi* to *mao*, yin contains half of yang, with *taiyin* giving rise to *shaoyang*; from *mao* to *wu*, yang contains yang, with pure *shaoyang* giving rise to *taiyang*; from *wu* to *you*, yang contains half of yin, with *taiyang* giving rise to *shaoyin*; from *you* to *zi*, yin contains yin, with pure *shaoyin* giving rise to *taiyin*. This is the fourth type, the seasons within a day.

That which is hard to gain yet easy to lose is the season within the body. That which departs swiftly and returns slowly is the month within the year. That which is fleeting as lightning, swift as a spark struck from stone, is the *chen* within the day. Days accumulate into months, months into years—years and months pass in haste, time flies swiftly. Yet one remains ensnared by the pursuit of fame and profit, the restless mind unchecked, bound by affection for children and grandchildren. Even if one turns back to the Dao, alas, age has advanced and qi has declined, like spring snow or autumn flowers—only a fleeting glimpse remains."

As the evening sun and morning moon, their light cannot endure long. For those who follow the Dao, what is hardest to attain is the season within the body. Bright sun and gentle breezes, a hundred flowers in bloom, waterside pavilions and lofty towers, refreshing winds and carefree moments, moonlit conversations and snowy-day drinking—indulging in endless pleasures, they fritter away their fleeting emotions. Even if one turns back to the Dao, one is already bound by illness like a broken boat yet to cross the river—who would not seek rescue? A leaky roof repaired once over, who could bear to abandon all thought of mending it again? For those who follow the Dao, what is idly wasted is the season within the year. The cock has not yet crowed, yet stepping out the door feels too late; the street drums resound everywhere, yet returning home seems too soon. Greed and delusion—when will they ever pause? Vain thoughts and endless worries—gold and jade fill the hall, yet when illness strikes, what can withstand it? A single glance at children and grandchildren, and with one breath gone, who can take their place? Day and night unceasing, yet the world does not awaken. For those who follow the Dao, what is most lamentable is the *chen* within the day.

Master Lü said: "The season within the body, the season within the year, the season within the month, the *chen* within the day—all are seasons. Yet the Venerable Master singles out the season within the body as hardest to attain, and the *chen* within the day as most lamentable. Why is this?"

Master Zhong said: "For those who follow the Dao, youth is hardest to attain. In youth, the root and origin are whole and firm, and all things are easily accomplished—with just a thousand days, great achievement is possible. For those who follow the Dao, middle age is also hard to attain. In middle age, cultivation begins with replenishment and completion, then proceeds to progress in practice. First, one returns from old age to youth; later, one transcends the mundane and enters sagehood. If one does not awaken in youth or reflect in middle age, one may turn to purity of mind only after disaster strikes, or aspire to the subtle and tranquil only after falling ill. In old age, cultivation begins with rescue and protection, then moves to replenishment, and only then to the lesser-perfection method, accumulating merit to reach the middle-perfection. With the middle-perfection method, merit accumulates only to the point of returning from old age to youth and refining the form to abide in the world. Yet the five *qi* cannot ascend to the origin, the three yang cannot gather at the crown, and shedding the mortal frame to ascend as an immortal remains unattainable. Thus, what is hardest to attain is the season within the body."

Master Lü said: "The season within the body is indeed hard to attain. But why is the *chen* within the day most lamentable?"

Master Zhong said: "A single day for a person is like a month for the sun and moon, like a year for heaven and earth. The Great Dao gives birth to heaven and earth, which take their positions, separated by eighty-four thousand *li* above and below. After the winter solstice, yang within the earth ascends. For each *qi*, fifteen days pass as it rises seven thousand *li*. After one hundred eighty days, yang ascends to heaven, and the Supreme Ultimate generates yin. After the summer solstice, yin within heaven descends. For each *qi*, fifteen days pass as it descends seven thousand *li*. After one hundred eighty days, yin descends to earth, and the Supreme Ultimate once more generates yang. Thus it cycles endlessly, operating without cease, never straying from the Dao, and so heaven and earth endure in their movement.

The sun and moon take form, each with a circumference of eight hundred forty *li*. After the new moon, the six within gives rise to the nine. For each day, twelve *chen* pass, and the *hun* within the *po* advances seventy *li*. After fifteen days, one hundred eighty *chen* pass, and the *hun* within the *po* advances eight hundred forty *li*. After the full moon, the nine within gives rise to the six. For each day, twelve *chen* pass, and the *po* within the *hun* advances seventy *li*. After fifteen days, one hundred eighty *chen* pass, and the *po* within the *hun* advances eight hundred forty *li*. Thus it cycles endlessly, operating without cease, never straying from the Dao, and so the Great Dao is made firm and all things are nourished.

Among all things, the most numinous and noble is the human. Between a person’s heart and kidneys, above and below are separated by eight *cun* and four *fen*. The ascent and descent of yin and yang are no different from those of heaven and earth. Within *qi*, fluid is born; within fluid, *qi* is born. *Qi* and fluid generate each other, following the same path as the sun and moon. Heaven and earth seek each other through *qian* and *kun*, and yin and yang ascend and descend, exchanging once a year without straying from the Dao—thus after one year, there is another year. The sun and moon generate each other through *hun* and *po*, and their essence and brilliance come and go, exchanging once a month without straying from the Dao—thus after one month, there is another month.

Yet for humans, though the exchange occurs within a single day and night, they do not know the time of exchange, nor the method of gathering and refining. When it is time to reduce, they do not know how to supplement; when it is time to increase, they do not know how to gather. When yin exchanges, they do not know how to nurture yang; when yang exchanges, they do not know how to refine yin. They do not understand reduction and increase within the month, nor do they practice cultivation within the day. Thus, after a year passes, there is no new year; after a day passes, there is no new day. Sleeping in drafts and dampness, braving heat and cold, unwilling to cultivate, they willingly invite illness. Idly passing the hours, they sit and await death."

Master Lü said: "Those who follow the Dao are not unaware that the years pass in vain, that the months slip away, that illness clings to the body, and that the limit of death approaches. Yet because they do not know the method of refinement or the time for practice, yin and yang exchange amiss, and the timing of their cultivation is imprecise."

Master Zhong said: "Within the body, use the year; within the year, use the month; within the month, use the day; within the day, use the *chen*. For the *qi* of the five viscera, the month has its waxing and waning, the day its advance and retreat, the *chen* its exchanges. As the *qi* moves through the five phases, it transmits through the six periods. Metal, wood, water, fire, earth—arranged without error. East, west, south, north, center—generated and completed by number. Refine essence to generate true *qi*; refine *qi* to unite with the yang spirit; refine spirit to unite with the Great Dao."

Master Lü said: "What is meant by 'the *qi* of the five viscera'? They are metal, wood, water, fire, earth. What is meant by 'the positions of the five phases'? They are east, west, south, north, center."

"How does one achieve mutual generation and completion, with exchanges occurring at their proper times? When does one gather and refine? I wish to hear this explanation."

Master Zhong said: "Once the Great Dao divided and gave birth to Heaven and Earth, Heaven and Earth separated and arrayed the Five Emperors: in the East is the Azure Emperor, who executes the spring mandate, initiating yang within yin to make the myriad things grow; in the South is the Vermilion Emperor, who executes the summer mandate, ascending yang within yang to make the myriad things flourish; in the West is the White Emperor, who executes the autumn mandate, initiating yin within yang to make the myriad things mature; in the North is the Black Emperor, who executes the winter mandate, advancing yin within yin to make the myriad things perish. Each of the four seasons lasts ninety days, with the Yellow Emperor presiding over the final eighteen days of each season. Thus, in spring, one assists the Azure Emperor in engendering life; in summer, one follows the Vermilion Emperor in nurturing growth; in autumn, one aids the White Emperor in bringing fruition; in winter, one restrains the Black Emperor to enforce severity. The Five Emperors govern in turn, each ruling seventy-two days, totaling three hundred sixty days to form one year, assisting Heaven and Earth in executing the Dao.

The Azure Emperor’s offspring are *jia* and *yi*, *jia-yi* being the wood of the East; the Vermilion Emperor’s offspring are *bing* and *ding*, *bing-ding* being the fire of the South; the Yellow Emperor’s offspring are *wu* and *ji*, *wu-ji* being the earth of the Center; the White Emperor’s offspring are *geng* and *xin*, *geng-xin* being the metal of the West; the Black Emperor’s offspring are *ren* and *gui*, *ren-gui* being the water of the North.

Manifest in time as symbols: wood is the Azure Dragon, fire the Vermilion Bird, earth the Curved Array, metal the White Tiger, water the Dark Warrior. Manifest in time as living things: when *yi* and *geng* unite, in spring there is the elm, green and white, preserving the colors of metal and wood; when *xin* and *bing* unite, in autumn there is the jujube, white and red, preserving the colors of metal and fire; when *ji* and *jia* unite, at summer’s end and autumn’s beginning there is the melon, green and yellow, preserving the colors of earth and wood; when *ding* and *ren* unite, in summer there is the mulberry, red and black, preserving the colors of water and fire; when *gui* and *wu* unite, in winter there is the tangerine, black and yellow, preserving the colors of water and earth. By analogy, one may infer the countless manifestations of the Five Emperors’ exchanges in time and their generation in things."

Master Lü said: "The Five Phases operate in time as such, but how do they function within a person?"

Master Zhong said: "Only in humans: the head is round and the feet square, bearing the image of Heaven and Earth; yin descends and yang ascends, possessing the mechanism of Heaven and Earth. The kidneys are water, the heart is fire, the liver is wood, the lungs are metal, and the spleen is earth.

In terms of mutual generation among the Five Phases: water generates wood, wood generates fire, fire generates earth, earth generates metal, metal generates water. The generator is the mother, the generated is the child. In terms of mutual conquest: water conquers fire, fire conquers metal, metal conquers wood, wood conquers earth, earth conquers water. The conqueror is the husband, the conquered is the wife.

Speaking in terms of mother and child: kidney *qi* generates liver *qi*, liver *qi* generates heart *qi*, heart *qi* generates spleen *qi*, spleen *qi* generates lung *qi*, lung *qi* generates kidney *qi*. Speaking in terms of husband and wife: kidney *qi* conquers heart *qi*, heart *qi* conquers lung *qi*, lung *qi* conquers liver *qi*, liver *qi* conquers spleen *qi*, spleen *qi* conquers kidney *qi*.

The kidneys are the husband of the heart, the mother of the liver, the wife of the spleen, and the child of the lungs; the liver is the husband of the spleen, the mother of the heart, the wife of the lungs, and the child of the kidneys; the heart is the husband of the lungs, the mother of the spleen, the wife of the kidneys, and the child of the liver; the lungs are the husband of the liver, the mother of the kidneys, the wife of the heart, and the child of the spleen; the spleen is the husband of the kidneys, the mother of the lungs, the wife of the liver, and the child of the heart.

The heart’s internal manifestation is the pulse, its external manifestation is complexion; its gateway is the tongue. It is subdued by the kidneys and driven to serve the lungs—such is the principle of husband and wife. It flourishes with the liver and wanes with the spleen—such is the principle of mother and child.

The kidneys’ internal manifestation is the bones, their external manifestation is the hair; their gateway is the ears. They are subdued by the spleen and driven to serve the heart—such is the principle of husband and wife. They flourish with the lungs and wane with the liver—such is the principle of mother and child.

The liver’s internal manifestation is the sinews, its external manifestation is the nails; its gateway is the eyes. It is subdued by the lungs and driven to serve the spleen—such is the principle of husband and wife. It flourishes with the kidneys and wanes with the heart—such is the principle of mother and child.

The lungs’ internal manifestation is the skin, their external manifestation is the body hair; their gateway is the nose. They are subdued by the heart and driven to serve the liver—such is the principle of husband and wife. They flourish with the spleen and wane with the kidneys—such is the principle of mother and child.

The spleen’s internal manifestation is the viscera, nourishing the heart, spleen, liver, and lungs; its external manifestation is the flesh; its gateway is the lips and mouth. Its breath regulates the ebb and flow. It is subdued by the liver and driven to serve the kidneys—such is the principle of husband and wife. It flourishes with the heart and wanes with the lungs—such is the principle of mother and child.

This is how the Five Phases within a person mutually generate and conquer, forming husband and wife, mother and child, transmitting *qi* in waxing and waning—all manifest herein."

Master Lü said: "The heart is fire—how can fire descend? The kidneys are water—how can water ascend? The spleen is earth, and earth at the center supports fire to flourish; does it not then conquer water below? The lungs are metal, and metal above, when near fire, is damaged—how can it generate water?"

The generating phases alternate in succession, while the conquering phases remain intimately bound and immutable—thus do the Five Phases inherently damage and restrain one another. What is to be done?

Master Zhong said: The Five Phases return to their origin, where a single *qi* draws them forth. Primordial yang ascends to engender true water; true water transforms to engender true *qi*; true *qi* transforms to engender the yang spirit. At first, the Five Phases are fixed in their positions, forming one husband and one wife.

The kidneys are water, and within water lies metal—metal being the mother of water. At the outset, one must recognize the metal within water. Water naturally resents earth, yet after gathering the medicine, earth must return to water.

The dragon is the emblem of the liver; the tiger, the spirit of the lungs. The yang dragon emerges from the Li palace; the yin tiger arises from the Kan position.

When the Five Phases proceed in sequence, *qi* is transmitted from mother to child—from *zi* to *wu*, this is called "yang born within yang." When the Five Phases are inverted, fluid circulates between husband and wife—from *wu* to *zi*, this is called "yang refined within yin."

Yang cannot be completed without yin, yet in the end, there is no yin that does not perish. Yin cannot be generated without yang, yet in the end, when yin is exhausted, longevity is attained.

Master Lü said: The Five Phases arise from the single *qi* of yin and yang. What is meant by "single *qi*"?

Master Zhong said: The single *qi* is this: when father and mother unite, their essence and blood transform to form the body. The kidneys generate the spleen; the spleen, the liver; the liver, the lungs; the lungs, the heart; the heart, the small intestine; the small intestine, the large intestine; the large intestine, the gallbladder; the gallbladder, the stomach; the stomach, the bladder. Thus does yin, through essence and blood, transform to form the body. Yet yang resides only at the very beginning of generation—a single point of primordial yang lies within the two kidneys.

Now, the kidneys are water, and within water there is fire. When fire ascends, it becomes *qi*; as *qi* rises, it pays court to the heart. The heart is yang; when yang unites with yang, the Supreme Ultimate generates yin. Thus, accumulated *qi* engenders fluid; fluid descends from the heart and, as it flows downward, returns to the kidneys.

The liver is the mother of the heart and the child of the kidneys, conveying the *qi* of the kidneys to the heart. The lungs are the wife of the heart and the mother of the kidneys, conveying the fluid of the heart to the kidneys.

The ascent and descent of *qi* and fluid resemble the yin and yang of heaven and earth. The transmission between liver and lungs is like the alternation of the sun and moon.

Each of the Five Phases has its number, yet in their union and generation, primordial yang and the single *qi* are fundamental. Within *qi*, fluid is born; within fluid, *qi* is born.

The kidneys are the root of *qi*; the heart, the source of fluid. When the numinous root is firm, in the midst of vagueness and obscurity, true water arises spontaneously within *qi*. When the heart’s source is pure, in the midst of profound darkness, true fire arises spontaneously within fluid.

From fire, recognize the true dragon; from water, discern the true tiger. When dragon and tiger unite, they transform into the yellow sprout. When the yellow sprout is conjoined, the great medicine is formed—this is called the "Golden Elixir." Once the Golden Elixir is achieved, it is called "immortality."

Master Lü said: When the Golden Elixir is accomplished and one sheds the body to ascend as an immortal, returning to the Ten Isles—this is well understood. But what is meant by the "yellow sprout"?

Master Zhong said: It is the true dragon and the true tiger.

Master Lü said: What are the "dragon and tiger"?

Master Zhong said: The dragon is not the liver—it is the yang dragon, which emerges from the true water of the Li palace. The tiger is not the lungs—it is the yin tiger, which arises from the true fire of the Kan position.

**On Water and Fire, Chapter Seven**

Master Lü said: For one who attains long life, the Golden Elixir is refined.

To refine the Golden Elixir, first gather the yellow sprout.
To obtain the yellow sprout, one must secure the dragon and tiger.
The true dragon emerges from the Li palace, the true tiger arises from the Kan position.
Within Li and Kan lie water and fire—what are water and fire?

Master Zhong said: In the body, when speaking of "water," it encompasses the Four Seas and Five Lakes, the Nine Rivers and Three Isles, Hua Pond and Yao Pond, Phoenix Pool and Heavenly Pool, Jade Pool and Xuan Pool, Yuan Abyss and Lang Garden, divine water and golden waves, nectar and jade springs, yang suet and white snow—such names cannot be fully enumerated.
When speaking of "fire" in the body, there are sovereign fire, ministerial fire, and civilian fire.
The three fires take primordial yang as their root, generating true qi. When true qi gathers, peace is attained; when true qi weakens, illness arises. If true qi is dissipated and primordial yang lost, primordial yang exhausted, pure yin prevails, and the primordial spirit departs the body—this is called "death."

Master Lü said: Within the human body, a single point of primordial yang ignites the three fires. The three fires arise amid the multitude of waters and yin, easily dissipated yet difficult to kindle. If yang is weak and yin abundant, fire scant and water plentiful, one swiftly declines and cannot attain long life—what is to be done?

Master Zhong said: The heart is the sea of blood, the kidneys the sea of qi, the brain the sea of marrow, and the spleen and stomach the sea of water and grain—thus are the "Four Seas." The five viscera each possess fluids governing their positions—east, west, south, north, and center—thus are the "Five Lakes." The small intestine, two zhang and four chi in length, curves nine times up and down—this is the "Nine Rivers." Below the small intestine lies the "Yuan Abyss"; such is its explanation. The head is the "Upper Isle," the heart the "Middle Isle," the kidneys the "Lower Isle"—within the Three Isles lies the "Lang Garden." "Hua Pond" resides below the Yellow Court, "Yao Pond" emerges before the Cinnabar Gate, "Xuan Pond" connects above to the "Jade Capital," "Heavenly Pool" directly pierces the inner courtyard, "Phoenix Pool" lies between the heart and lungs, and "Jade Pool" is within the lips and teeth. Divine water arises within qi, golden waves descend from heaven, and where the red dragon dwells, "nectar" and "jade springs" naturally appear. Only after the fetal transformation does one witness "white snow" and "yang suet." Watering at the proper time nourishes the blazing fire—first called "jade liquid," then "golden liquid," both of which can return the elixir. With measured withdrawal and addition, aligning with the bath, first the "middle field," then the "lower field," both can refine the form. Jade buds and golden blossoms transform into a body of yellow and white; ghee and sweet dew refine into wondrous fragrances—such are the efficacies of "water." As for the civilian fire ascending to assist kidney qi in generating true water, and kidney fire ascending to merge with heart fluid in generating true qi—on a small scale, they subdue demons and dispel illness; on a grand scale, they refine the body and forge the elixir. Employing the celestial cycle, fire arises to incinerate the body; restraining the yang pass, it returns to refine the medicine. Distinguishing the terrain of the Nine Isles to nurture the yang spirit, burning away the burdens of the Three Corpses to eliminate yin ghosts—ascending, it strikes through the Three Passes; descending, it dissolves the Seven Po. Refining form into qi, one becomes light and soars like flight; refining qi into spirit, one sheds the fetal husk like a molting cicada. Such are the efficacies of "fire."

Master Lü said: At first, I heard your instruction and feared that scant fire and abundant water would lead to swift decline. Now, having listened to your profound discourse, I see the wondrous efficacies of water and fire. Ultimately, how does one transform this so that the few can overcome the many, and the weak can become strong?

Master Zhong said: When the two eights of yin dissipate and the nine threes of yang grow, the radiant Golden Elixir can be accomplished in days. With seven returns and nine reversions, the fetal immortal naturally transforms. True qi resides in the heart, and the heart is the source of fluid; primordial yang dwells in the kidneys, and the kidneys are the sea of qi. The bladder is civilian fire—without civilian fire, it cannot be employed, yet the bladder is also the repository of fluids. If one fails to grasp the celestial mechanism and fathom the mysterious principle, even those who uphold the Dao will struggle to achieve transformation and cannot escape illness and death.

Master Lü said: What is meant by transformation, where yang grows and yin dissipates, the Golden Elixir is accomplished, and the fetal immortal naturally transforms?

Master Zhong said: The heart and kidneys in the human body are separated by eight cun and four fen—this mirrors the fixed positions of heaven and earth. The generation of qi and fluid from the Supreme Ultimate mirrors the union of yin and yang. The twelve hours of a day mirror the twelve months of a year. The heart generates fluid, yet not of itself—it is because lung fluid descends that heart fluid flows. The fluids of husband and wife descend from above to return to the lower field—this is called "the wife returning to the husband’s palace." The kidneys generate qi, yet not of themselves—it is because bladder qi ascends that kidney qi flows. The qi of mother and child ascends from below to pay homage to the middle origin—this is called "the husband returning to the wife’s chamber." Liver qi guides kidney qi upward to reach the heart. The heart is fire; when the two qi merge, they steam the lungs. Lung fluid descends from the heart, originating from the heart’s generation of fluid. As this fluid arises from the heart without dissipation, it is called "true water." Lung fluid transmits heart fluid downward to the kidneys. The kidneys are water; when the two waters merge, they moisten the bladder. Bladder qi ascends from the kidneys, originating from the kidneys’ generation of qi. As this qi arises from the kidneys without dissipation, it is called "true fire."

True fire emerges from within water—dim and indistinct, yet within it lies a thing: invisible when sought, unattainable when grasped. True water arises from within fire—profound and obscure, yet within it lies an essence: glimpsed but not detained, detained but not held.

Master Lü says: The kidneys are water; from water, qi is born—this is called "true fire." But what is the *thing* within fire?
The heart is fire; from fire, fluid is born—this is called "true water." But what is the *essence* within water?
The thing within fire and the essence within water—having no form to seek, even if sought, they are hard to obtain; and even if obtained, what use are they?

Master Zhong says: The ancient perfected ones who attained the Dao did not depart from the union of these two things, which transform into the yellow sprout. When the count is fulfilled and the embryo complete, the great medicine is formed—these are the true dragon and true tiger.

**Chapter Eight: On the Dragon and Tiger**
Master Lü says: The dragon is the image of the liver; the tiger is the spirit of the lungs.
Yet this fluid born from heart-fire is true water, and within this water—profound and obscure—lies the hidden true dragon. Why does the dragon not reside in the liver but emerge from the *Li* palace?
And this qi born from kidney-water is true fire, and within this fire—dim and indistinct—lies the concealed true tiger. Why does the tiger not reside in the lungs but arise from the *Kan* position?

Master Zhong says: The dragon is a yang thing—ascending and soaring in the heavens, roaring to summon clouds, receiving moisture to nourish the myriad beings. In imagery, it is the Azure Dragon; in direction, *jia-yi*; in substance, wood; in season, spring; in the Dao, benevolence; in the hexagrams, *Zhen*; and among the five viscera of the human body, the liver.
The tiger is a yin thing—running upon the earth, howling to summon wind, gaining mountains to overawe the hundred creatures. In imagery, it is the White Tiger; in direction, *geng-xin*; in substance, metal; in season, autumn; in the Dao, righteousness; in the hexagrams, *Dui*; and among the five viscera of the human body, the lungs.

Now, the liver is yang yet resides in a yin position. Thus, kidney qi transmits to liver qi, moving as mother and child—water generating wood. When kidney qi is sufficient, liver qi is born; once liver qi is born, it severs the kidney’s residual yin, and pure yang qi ascends.
The lungs are yin yet reside in a yang position. Thus, heart fluid transmits to lung fluid, moving as husband and wife—fire restraining metal. When heart fluid arrives, lung fluid is born; once lung fluid is born, it severs the heart’s residual yang, and pure yin fluid descends.

The liver pertains to yang; in severing the kidney’s residual yin, one knows that when qi passes through the liver, it becomes pure yang. Within pure yang qi lies the hidden true unity of water—dim and formless—called the "yang dragon."
The lungs pertain to yin; in severing the heart’s residual yang, one knows that when fluid reaches the lungs, it becomes pure yin. Within pure yin fluid lies the carried true yang qi—profound and unseen—called the "yin tiger."

Qi ascends and fluid descends, inherently unable to merge. Yet within qi lies the true unity of water, which sees fluid and unites with it; within fluid lies the true yang qi, which sees qi and gathers with it.
If, during transmission, one applies the method to restrain it—preventing kidney qi from scattering and gathering the true unity of water within qi, and preventing heart fluid from dissipating and harvesting the true yang qi within fluid—then mother and child meet, gazing fondly upon each other. Daily, a grain of millet grows; after a hundred days, the medicine’s power is complete without flaw. After two hundred days, the sacred embryo hardens; after three hundred days, the immortal fetus is perfected—its form like a pellet, its color like a red tangerine. This is called the "elixir medicine," eternally anchoring the lower field, preserving form and abiding in the world, enduring eons of long life—this is the earthbound immortal.

Master Lü says: Kidney water generates qi, and within qi lies the true unity of water—called the yin tiger, which sees fluid and unites with it.
Heart fire generates fluid, and within fluid lies the true yang qi—called the yang dragon, which sees qi and unites with it.
Things gather by kind, beings assemble by group—this is the natural principle.

When qi is born, fluid also descends; does not the true unity of water within qi follow the fluid downward to transmit through the five viscera?
When fluid is born, qi also ascends; does not the true yang qi within fluid follow the qi upward to emerge from the *Chonglou*?
True water follows fluid downward—the tiger cannot unite with the dragon.
True yang follows qi upward—the dragon cannot unite with the tiger.
If dragon and tiger do not unite, how can the yellow sprout arise?
Without the yellow sprout, how can the great medicine be formed?

Master Zhong says: When kidney qi is born, it is like the sun emerging from the sea—mist and dew cannot obscure its light.
Fluid descends like a parted curtain—how can it withstand the qi?
When qi is robust, the true unity of water naturally flourishes.
When heart fluid is born, it is like the severe sky slaying beings—breath cannot resist its cold.
Qi ascends like a jade screen—how can it withstand the fluid?
When fluid is abundant, the true yang qi may be strong or weak—its certainty is uncertain.

Master Lü says: Qi and fluid are born each in their time. When it is the time for qi to be born, if qi is abundant, the true unity of water naturally flourishes. When it is the time for fluid to be born, if fluid is abundant, the true yang qi also flourishes.
Yet why is their flourishing or decline not assured?

Master Zhong says: Kidney qi is easily dissipated—what is hard to obtain is the true tiger.
Heart fluid is hard to accumulate—what is easily lost is the true dragon.
The ten thousand volumes of elixir classics discuss nothing beyond yin and yang.
Within these two matters of yin and yang, the essence is nothing but dragon and tiger.
Among those who uphold the Dao, perhaps one or two in ten thousand understand.
Some are widely learned and well-versed, knowing the principles of dragon and tiger, yet do not recognize the time of their union or the method of their harvesting.

Thus, the accomplished scholars of past and present, though they cultivate with white-haired devotion, attain only minor accomplishment, prolonging life for generations but never hearing of transcendence—this is because they cannot unite dragon and tiger in copulation or harvest the yellow sprout to refine the elixir.

**On the Elixir, Ninth Discourse**

Master Lü says: The principles of dragon and tiger are already known—may we now hear of the "Great Medicine of the Golden Elixir"?

Master Zhong says: That which is called "medicine" can cure illness. All illnesses are of three kinds:
When one lies in drafts or dampness, endures heat or cold, overworks or overindulges, eats or fasts untimely, and suffers irregular discomfort, this is called *affliction*—an illness of the seasons.
When one refuses cultivation, indulges the passions, scatters original yang, and depletes true qi, growing aged and withered, this is called *aging*—an illness of the years.
When qi is exhausted and the body hollow, the hun-soul fades and the shen-spirit scatters, a long sigh escapes, the four elements lose their master, and the body lies in the wilds—this is called *death*, an illness of the body.

Now, seasonal illness arises as spring, summer, autumn, and winter cycle through cold, heat, warmth, and coolness. When yang is excessive and yin insufficient, it must be treated with coolness; when yin is excessive and yang insufficient, it must be treated with warmth. The aged tend to cold, the young to heat; the stout have excess phlegm, the emaciated excess accumulations. Men’s illnesses arise from qi, women’s sufferings stem from blood. One supplements the deficient and reduces the excessive, preserves the weak and diminishes the surplus—mild cases with acupuncture and moxibustion, severe cases with medicinal decoctions. Though irregular discomforts and seasonal afflictions may arise, entrusting them to a skilled physician who prescribes remedies according to the ailment will ensure recovery.

But how is the illness of aging to be cured?
And how is the illness of death to be treated?

The ancient masters of medicine who could purge the intestines and replenish the flesh—who could restore youthful complexion to wrinkled faces and white hair—remain incomprehensible to all! The ancient masters of medicine who could replace the crown of the head and extend the limbs—who could preserve one’s shadow and abide in the world to attain longevity—remain incomprehensible to all!

Master Lü said: "Irregular discomforts and seasonal afflictions may arise, but with a skilled physician and renowned remedies, they can certainly be cured. Yet how is the illness of decrepit old age to be treated? And how is the suffering of qi’s exhaustion and life’s end to be remedied? Are there no medicines for these?"

Master Zhong said: "All illnesses fall into three categories. Seasonal afflictions heal themselves with herbal remedies. For bodily illnesses and the ailments of age, there are two types of medicines: the first is the *Inner Elixir* (内丹), and the second is the *Outer Elixir* (外丹)."

Master Lü asked: "What is the *Outer Elixir*?"

Master Zhong replied: "In ancient times, the Most High Primordial Lord transmitted the Dao to the world, expounding the principles of heaven and earth’s ascent and descent, the proper cycles of the sun and moon. Since then, elixir scriptures have filled the world, and people have come to hear of the Great Dao. The Venerable Guangcheng taught the Yellow Emperor, who, in the intervals of governing, practiced the method diligently, yet after a long time saw no results. Guangcheng then revealed that between the heart and kidneys lies true *qi* and true water, and between *qi* and water reside true yin and true yang. When combined, they form the great medicine, comparable to the hidden treasures within metals and stones.

Thus, in the Kongtong Mountains, he took the inner method as his guide and refined the great elixir. Among the eight minerals, only cinnabar was used, from which mercury was extracted; among the five metals, only black lead was used, from which silver was drawn. Mercury corresponds to the yang dragon, silver to the yin tiger. The heart’s fire is like cinnabar’s redness, the kidneys’ water like lead’s blackness. The yearly fire follows the seasons, never deviating from the strategies of heaven and earth; the monthly fire adjusts its additions and subtractions, naturally distinguishing the proper balance of civil and martial. A three-tiered furnace was erected, each tier nine inches high, square on the outside and round within, gathering the *qi* of the eight directions and aligning with the seasons of the four times. The golden crucible, containing lead and mercury, is no different from the fluids of the lungs; sulfur serves as the medicine, harmonizing with the numinous cinnabar, comparable to the Yellow Dame.

After three years, the lesser accomplishment is achieved, and its ingestion can eradicate all illnesses. After six years, the middle accomplishment is attained, and its ingestion can naturally prolong life."

After nine years, the great accomplishment is achieved, and its ingestion allows one to ascend and move freely, stretching one's arms to traverse thousands or tens of thousands of miles. Though one may not return to Penglai, one will not perish even in the great kalpas of the mortal world.

Master Lü said: "Since ancient times, many have practiced alchemy, yet few have seen success. Why is this?"

Master Zhong replied: "There are three reasons why alchemy fails. First, those who cannot distinguish the authenticity of medicinal materials, who do not understand the subtleties of fire timing and adjustment, may reduce the most precious substances to smoke and ash in an instant, wasting time and effort without achievement. Second, though the medicinal materials may be fine, if one does not know the fire timing—or knows the fire timing but lacks the materials—the two will not align, and no accomplishment will be achieved. Third, though the materials may be excellent and the fire timing appropriate, with no miscalculations in years, months, or days, and with precise additions and subtractions at the proper times, the *qi* may be sufficient and the elixir formed, yet if one’s external conduct is lacking, the elixir may transform into a transcendent crane and soar into the void, leaving no means to ingest it—thus failing in the end.

Moreover, medicinal materials are the essence and fruit of heaven and earth’s purest *qi*, while fire timing is the art of cultivation by which immortals attain the Dao. In the time of the Three Sovereigns, the Yellow Emperor refined the elixir, and only after nine transformations did it succeed. After the Five Emperors, the Primordial One refined the elixir, and only after three years did it succeed. By the Warring States period, baleful *qi* congealed in the sky, corpses filled the fields, and things could no longer receive the purest *qi* of heaven and earth—thus the world lacked medicinal materials. Even those who had obtained the proper methods fled calamity and died in mountain valleys. Though some alchemical formulas and immortal arts may have been recorded on bamboo and silk, they decayed over time, and the world no longer possessed them. Had medicinal materials existed in the mortal world, the First Emperor of Qin would not have sought them on the islands of the sea. Had elixir formulas existed in the mortal world, Wei Boyang would not have delved into the *Book of Changes*.

Yet some, through extensive learning and strong memory, have misled later generations, causing countless families to be ruined without a single success—seeking externally has thus been a grave error.

Master Lü said: "The principles of external alchemy originate from Guangchengzi, who took internal practices as his model. Even if one achieves success, it requires nine years to complete. Moreover, medicinal materials are difficult to obtain, and elixir formulas are hard to come by. In the end, one may only ascend but not transcend the mundane to enter sagehood, nor return to the Ten Isles."

Dare I ask about the internal elixir—may I hear of it?

Master Zhong said: "External elixirs are not without use. For those who follow the Dao but awaken late in life, their foundational roots may not be deeply established. The kidneys are the root of *qi*; if the root is not deep, the leaves will not flourish. The heart is the source of fluids; if the source is not clear, the flow will not be long. Thus, one must rely on the five metals and eight minerals, accumulating days and months to refine the three grades, each with three ranks—this is called the 'Nine-Rank Dragon-Tiger Great Elixir.' It assists in connecting the true *qi*, refining the form to abide in the world, and ascending lightly as if flying.

Yet if one cultivates the internal practice, recognizing the time of union and knowing the method of gathering, the fetal immortal will be accomplished, and transcendence may be achieved in days. Those who fail to comprehend this cling to external elixirs, adding fire and extending time, hoping through ingestion to ascend to the celestial realms—truly laughable!

Since they do not investigate the source of external elixirs, I shall now expound in detail the principles of the internal elixir. The medicinal materials of the internal elixir arise from the heart and kidneys—something all people possess. The medicinal materials of the internal elixir originally reside in heaven and earth, and heaven and earth manifest them daily. The fire timing follows the cycles of the sun and moon, and the refinement emulates the harmony of husband and wife in union. When the sacred embryo is formed, true *qi* is born; within *qi* there is *qi*, like a dragon nurturing its pearl. When the great medicine is completed, the yang spirit emerges; beyond the body there is a body, like a cicada shedding its husk. This internal elixir fundamentally arises from the union of dragon and tiger, transforming into the yellow sprout, and when the yellow sprout is achieved, lead and mercury are distinguished.

**On Lead and Mercury, Tenth Chapter**

Master Lü said: "The internal elixir does not transcend dragon and tiger. The tiger is born in the Kan palace—it is the water within *qi*. The dragon emerges from the Li palace—it is the *qi* within water. External elixirs take mercury from cinnabar, likening it to the yang dragon, and silver from lead, likening it to the yin tiger. Yet lead and mercury are external elixirs—how then do dragon and tiger unite to transform into the yellow sprout? And how, once the yellow sprout is achieved, are lead and mercury distinguished? What, then, are lead and mercury in the context of the internal elixir?"

Master Zhong said: "That which embraces the quality of Heavenly One and stands as the chief of the five metals is black lead. Lead gives birth to silver, and lead is the mother of silver. That which receives the *qi* of the great yang and stands as the chief of all minerals is cinnabar. Cinnabar gives birth to mercury, and mercury is the child of cinnabar. What is difficult to extract is silver from lead; what easily scatters is mercury from cinnabar. When silver and mercury combine, refinement naturally produces the supreme treasure. Such is the principle of lead and mercury as seen externally.

Yet regarding internal practice, ancient and modern discussions vary. Taking the most profound explanations, it begins at the moment of parents’ union, when essence and blood merge, enclosing true *qi*, entrusting the substance to the mother’s womb—a palace of pure yin—hiding the spirit within the unseparated yin and yang. After three hundred days, the fetus is complete; after five thousand days, the *qi* is sufficient.

In terms of the five phases, the human body is fundamentally essence and blood—water comes first. In terms of the five viscera, essence and blood form the physical image—the kidneys come first. Within kidney water, concealed from the moment of conception, lies the true *qi* of the parents. This true *qi* is hidden within the internal kidneys of the person—this is what is called lead. The kidneys govern *qi*, and within *qi* lies the true water of the One—this is called the true tiger, and this is what is meant by silver within lead.

Kidney *qi* transmits to liver *qi*, and liver *qi* transmits to heart *qi*. The heart *qi* reaches the Supreme Ultimate and generates fluid; within this fluid is the *qi* of true yang—this is what is called cinnabar, the fluid of the heart. What is called mercury is the *qi* of true yang within the heart’s fluid. Accumulated *qi* and fluid form the fetal sac, conveyed within the Yellow Court. With precise fire timing, the fetal immortal naturally transforms."

Thus, lead and silver merge with mercury, refined into a treasure.

Master Lü states: Among the five metals, silver is extracted from lead; within the eight minerals, mercury emerges from cinnabar. Placed in the crucible and paired with medicinal elixirs, mercury naturally becomes cinnabar, and silver naturally becomes treasure. Yet how is silver drawn from the lead within? How is mercury drawn from the cinnabar within a person? How does mercury become cinnabar, and how does silver become treasure?

Master Zhong says: Lead is originally the true *qi* of the parents, merged as one, pure and indivisible. After form is established, it is concealed within the kidneys. The two kidneys face each other, their *qi* ascending together—this is called the primordial yang *qi*. Within *qi* lies water—this is called the true water of the One. Water ascends with *qi*; when *qi* abides, water abides; when *qi* scatters, water scatters. Water and *qi* are like mother and child, never parting. The discerning see only *qi*, not water. If this true water of the One unites with the heart’s true yang *qi*, it is called the dragon and tiger mating to transform into the yellow sprout, which becomes the great medicine. The material of the great medicine is fundamentally the true water of the One as its embryo, internally containing true yang *qi*—just as the parents’ true *qi* once formed the fetal sac from essence and blood. After three hundred days of cultivation, the embryo is complete, *qi* is full, form is perfected, and spirit arrives. Separating from the mother, form and spirit unite, and union gives birth to form.

For those who uphold the Dao, kidney *qi* merges with heart *qi*. Within *qi* is concealed the true water of the One, bearing true yang *qi*. When *qi* unites with true water, it forms an embryo like a millet grain, nurtured without depletion. First, yin retains yang; then yang is used to refine yin. *Qi* transforms into essence, essence into mercury, mercury into cinnabar, cinnabar into the golden elixir. Once the golden elixir is achieved, true *qi* arises spontaneously. Refining *qi* into spirit, one attains liberation, riding the fire dragon out of the twilight realm and mounting the dark crane to enter Penglai.

Master Lü says: When form unites with form, union gives birth to form; when *qi* unites with *qi*, union gives birth to *qi*. The count does not exceed three hundred days. After the division of form, how do the differences between male and female arise? What is the color and luster of one’s own cinnabar?

Master Zhong says: When the forms of father and mother unite, the father’s essence enters first, and the mother’s blood follows. If blood envelops essence, a girl is born—a girl is inwardly yang and outwardly yin, resembling the mother, for blood lies externally. If the mother’s blood enters first and the father’s essence follows, essence envelops blood, and a boy is born—a boy is inwardly yin and outwardly yang, resembling the father, for essence lies externally. What is called "blood" originates in the heart and lacks true yang *qi*. What is called "essence" originates in the kidneys and contains true yang *qi*—this is the root of mercury, the true water of the One. Harmonized, it enters the Yellow Court. Lead broth is used to boil it, and mercury water to refine it. Without mercury, lead cannot activate the true water of the One; without lead, mercury cannot transform into pure yang *qi*.

Master Lü says: Lead resides in the kidneys, generating primordial yang *qi*. Within *qi* lies the true water of the One, invisible to the eye. When lead obtains mercury, and mercury possesses true yang *qi*, this true yang *qi* refines the lead. Lead’s *qi* flourishes, activating the true water of the One, enabling it to ascend. Yet mercury is fundamentally true yang *qi*, the true water of the One forming the embryo, conveyed to the Yellow Court. This is the dragon and tiger mating, yin and yang in balance. It is also refined with lead broth. If yin is excessive, it dissipates true yang—how can the great medicine form, and *qi* generate *qi*?

Master Zhong says: When kidney *qi* enters heart *qi*, *qi* at its peak generates fluid. Within fluid lies true yang *qi*, uniting with the true water of the One—this is called "the dragon and tiger mating." Daily, it grows to the size of a millet grain, called "the great medicine of the golden elixir," conveyed to the Yellow Court. The Yellow Court lies below the spleen and stomach, above the bladder, north of the heart and south of the kidneys, west of the liver and east of the lungs. Above is clear, below is turbid; externally, it corresponds to the four directions. Its capacity is two *sheng*, its pathways connect to the eight waters. The medicine obtained resides within it day and night. If medicine is gathered but fire is not applied, the medicine will dissipate and cannot abide. If fire is applied but medicine is not gathered, yang within yin cannot abide, merely activating kidney *qi* to strengthen and warm the lower origin. If medicine is gathered at the proper time and fire is applied in due measure, one must first borrow *qi* from lead to apply fire, solidifying the great medicine and permanently anchoring it in the lower field—this is called "the method of gathering and supplementing." Refining mercury to supplement the cinnabar field prolongs life and extends years, making one an earthly immortal. If medicine is gathered and primordial lead is drawn from it, golden essence flies behind the elbow. After drawing lead, mercury must be added; without adding mercury, one merely returns essence to replenish the brain—how can true *qi* arise? If true *qi* does not arise, how can the yang spirit be achieved? After adding mercury, lead must be drawn; without drawing lead, one merely refines mercury to supplement the cinnabar field—how can cinnabar transform? If cinnabar does not transform, how can the golden elixir be achieved?

**On Drawing and Adding, Chapter Eleven**
Master Lü says: Gathering medicine relies on the water within *qi*; applying fire borrows the *qi* within lead. Ultimately, lead is drawn to complete the great medicine, and mercury is added to supplement the cinnabar field—what is the principle of "drawing and adding"?

Master Zhong says: In ancient times, the supreme sages transmitted the Dao to the world. The people of the distant past were simple and unadorned, profoundly ignorant—unable to hear of the great Dao.

The principles of heaven and earth’s ascent and descent lie in the interplay of warmth, coolness, cold, and heat. With seasons fixed in their cycles, the year’s divisions are set, revolving endlessly without straying from the Dao—thus heaven and earth endure forever. Likewise, the ebb and flow of the sun and moon’s essence follow the rhythm of dawn, fullness, waning, and newness, their rising and setting unerring. A month’s course complete, their motion ceaseless, never deviating from the Dao—thus the sun and moon endure forever.

Yet as cold gives way to heat and heat to cold, people fail to grasp the principle of heaven and earth’s ascent and descent. As the moon waxes full and wanes, then waxes again, they do not comprehend the sun and moon’s cyclical exchange. Indulging endless desires, they fritter away their finite time. Wealth and splendor—what are they but adornments for life’s fleeting dream? Love and sorrow—what do they amount to but debts carried into the next life? The song not yet faded, suffering arrives; fame and fortune still fresh, youth has already departed. Greed for wealth and goods deludes them into believing they will last ten thousand kalpas; love for children and grandchildren makes them hope for reunion in the next life. Ceaseless craving, vain dreams of immortality—yet they dissipate their primal yang, lose their true *qi*, and only when illness clings to the body do they finally relent; only when the great limit arrives do they at last let go.

The true immortals and supreme sages, pitying their endless rebirth and shared descent into ruin, longed for people to awaken to the great Dao. They began by expounding the principle of heaven and earth’s yin and yang ascent and descent, then drew parallels to the sun and moon’s ebb and flow of essence. Yet still, people failed to grasp the celestial mechanism or fathom its mysteries. Thus, they compared inner medicine to outer medicine, spoke of the impassive to explain the sentient: the impassive is metal and stone—outer medicine; the sentient is *qi* and fluid—inner medicine. The vastness of heaven and earth, the brightness of the sun and moon, the externality of metal and stone, the internality of *qi* and fluid—once gathered, they must be added; once added, they must be drawn. The principle of drawing and adding is the root of creation itself.

After the winter solstice, yang ascends from the earth, and the earth draws out its yin. Greater yin is drawn to become reverting yin; lesser yang is added to become yang brightness. Reverting yin is drawn to become lesser yin; yang brightness is added to become greater yang. Without this, how could cold shift to warmth, warmth to heat? After the summer solstice, yin descends from heaven, and heaven draws out its yang. Greater yang is drawn to become yang brightness; lesser yin is added to become reverting yin. Yang brightness is drawn to become lesser yang; reverting yin is added to become greater yin. Without this, how could heat shift to coolness, coolness to cold? Thus, the ascent and descent of heaven and earth’s yin and yang transform the six *qi*—this is the proof of drawing and adding.

As the moon receives the sun’s spirit, the sun alters the moon’s soul: in the first fifteen days, the moon draws out its soul while the sun adds its spirit, until its essence is exhausted and its light illumines the earth. Without this, how could the new moon become the first quarter, the first quarter become the full moon? The moon gathers yin soul, the sun gathers yang essence: in the next fifteen days, the sun draws out its spirit while the moon adds its soul, until its light fades and its yin soul is complete. Without this, how could the full moon become the last quarter, the last quarter become the dark moon? Thus, the sun and moon’s essence cycles through nine and six—this is the proof of drawing and adding.

From ancient times, true immortals and supreme sages knew what people cherish most: freedom from illness and long life. They refined metal and stone into the great elixir. They also knew what people desire most: gold and silver. They transmuted lead and mercury into supreme treasures. Their intent was for people to grasp the principle. Even impassive metal and stone, with fire times unerring and drawing and adding precise, can extend years and prolong life. How much more so with one’s own sentient body, its true yang *qi* and original unity’s water—knowing the time of union, understanding the method of gathering, accumulating day by day, month by month, *qi* within *qi*, refining *qi* into spirit, to achieve transcendence—would this not be an attainable feat across all ages?

Yet since the teaching of outer medicine arose, though ancient and modern sages have expounded it for the world to hear, people still fail to awaken. Deceiving themselves and others, they extract mercury from cinnabar, use mercury to transmute lead, dry lead to fix mercury, employ mercury to transform copper—heedless of their lives, vainly seeking wealth, mutually praising one another under the guise of loving the Dao, when in truth they love profit and crave alchemical gold and silver. They do not realize that the discourse on lead and mercury is a metaphor for inner work.

**On the River Chariot, Chapter Twelve**
Master Lü says: What is meant by the "River Chariot"?

Master Zhong says: In ancient times, a man of aspiration and wisdom observed floating clouds veiling the sun and conceived the idea of harnessing yin to craft a canopy. He saw fallen leaves drifting upon the waves and devised a vessel to bear objects—thus the boat was born. Watching tumbleweeds swept by the wind, ceaselessly turning, he withdrew to fashion the chariot. Now, the chariot as an object embodies the image of Heaven and Earth in its canopy and axle-tree, its wheels and hubs likened to the sun and moon. The perfected Daoist draws analogy from the chariot: though it travels upon land and turns across the earth, today we speak of the "River Chariot"—and therein lies its meaning.

Within the human body, yang is scant while yin abounds; the places of water are manifold. The chariot thus takes its intent from conveying and transporting, for the river governs the image of abundant yin. Therefore, this River Chariot does not run upon the earth but upon the water—now descending, now ascending, now advancing, now retreating. It is harnessed within the Eight Jewels and gallops through the Four Seas. Ascending to Heaven, it enters Kunlun; when the crossing is achieved, it rushes down to the Phoenix Tower.
