Therefore, the patriarchs earnestly exhort later learners: do not be reckless, nor waste time. When a single breath fails to come, regret is too late! It is better to turn back early and seek the oral instructions of an enlightened teacher. Without doubt, accept them directly, and cultivate this matter with a firm foundation. Obtain the medicine, obtain the elixir, temper it for ten months, shed the mortal coil, and undergo spiritual transformation. The ten kinds of elixirs are indispensable—not one can be lacking.

The above are but general remarks, earnestly admonishing the wise to awaken. Having seen Patriarch Lü Chunyang’s *"Qiaoyao Song"*—its meaning profound, its words incisive, encompassing the great Dao of the Golden Elixir, the three vehicles of the great Dharma, and the ten kinds of returned cinnabar—I could not put it aside, sighing without end. Though I have not yet attained the Dao, I do not conceal Heaven’s treasure. Thus, I have taken the oral instructions on the Golden Elixir personally transmitted by our patriarch and annotated the *"Qiaoyao Song"* verse by verse, clarifying its beginning and end. Though my words are shallow and my scholarship crude, the principle remains unblemished. This is not for the wise alone, nor is it beyond the grasp of the unlearned. I place this preface at the start of the scroll—heed it well and be cautious.

In the eighth year of the Zhengtong era, the cyclical year *guihai*, on the fifteenth day of the first lunar month, this was inscribed by Qian Daohua, the Master Without Blemish of Jade Peak in Gusu.

*Annotations on the "Qiaoyao Song"*
Composed by Qian Daohua, the Master Without Flaw of Jade Peak in Gusu

A drifting wanderer at the end of Han, in the Tang realm—
Thus the *"Qiaoyao"* defies all measure.
Through the unbounded—vertical and horizontal, inverse and direct—
In stillness, non-action; in motion, form.

The Master’s surname was Lü, given name Yan, style Dongbin, with the Daoist name Pure Yang. His ancestral home was in Yongle Town, Zhaoxian Village, Pucheng County, Hejing Prefecture of the Western Capital (present-day Pucheng County, Pu Prefecture). Born into an official family, he entered the world in the fourteenth year of the Tianbao era of the Tang, on the fourteenth day of the fourth month, at the *si* hour. At twenty, he remained unmarried. After passing the imperial examinations, he encountered the Perfected Lord Zhongli of True Yang, who transmitted to him the great Dao. Having completed his cultivation, he composed this *"Qiaoyao Song"*, declaring himself *"a drifting wanderer at the end of Han, in the Tang realm."*

*"Qiao"* means to deliberate—if one’s conduct is not straightforward, it may be *"qiao-ed."* *"Yao"* refers to the lines of the hexagrams, the principle of yin and yang intermingling, the dynamics of stillness and motion, advance and retreat. The worldly, deluded and ignorant, find it difficult to fathom.

*"Vertical and horizontal, inverse and direct"*—whether proceeding vertically or horizontally, in reverse or forward cultivation, all lies within one’s grasp, freely directed. *"Inverse"* refers to the sevenfold-returned elixir, the later-arising method; *"direct"* denotes the way of obtaining the medicine, the great elixir of dragon and tiger, the earlier-gathering method. *"Unbounded"* means that when one’s refinement is perfected, there is no constraint, nor any carelessness or error.

*"In stillness, non-action"*—when entering samadhi, the inner medicine and inner elixir coalesce as the spirit is stabilized and the mind fixed. All entanglements dissolve; the heart guards the elixir field within, the body like withered wood, the mind like dead ashes. One awaits only the first stirring of yang within the body, the union of heart and kidney, the inner husband and wife, when essence and nature merge as if in the great void. Thus it is said: *"A thousand sages seek his traces in vain—his whole being hides within the great void."* Upon emerging from samadhi, heart and kidney return to their places, and one feels two or three drops of clear spring water descending into the Yellow Court. As the ancients said: *"When yin and yang have consummated their union, a single drop falls into the Yellow Court."*

*"In motion, form"*—this is the principle of yin and yang, inverse and direct. One guards against danger, weighs risks, knows when to advance or retreat, discerns ascent and descent, distinguishes host and guest, ensuring no error in either. Without disturbance in motion, without desiccation in stillness—this is the foremost task in elixir refinement, hence it is stated first.

He drinks wine, he eats meat—
Yet holds fast to rouge and flowers, cutting off lust.
He practices Chan, sings lewd songs of rouge and powder—
While upholding precepts, his belly ever full of wine and meat.

The true cultivator values not the fasting of the mouth, but the fasting of the heart. *"Fasting of the mouth"* means abstaining from wine and meat; *"fasting of the heart"* means cutting off lust. If one’s nature and life are clear, and lust is severed without transgressing the precepts, what need is there to abstain from wine and meat? Thus the Patriarch said: *"He drinks wine, he eats meat."*

Rouge and flowers are the domain of lust—how much more to *"hold fast"* to them! Yet the adept, though beautiful sights may appear before his eyes, remains undisturbed in heart. Moreover, in the refinement of the returned elixir, there is the joy of the union of infant and maiden—how could he still crave the filth of rouge and flowers? Thus the Perfected Master, refining within, forever severs the dust of desire. His pure and tranquil heart abides in desire yet is not desirous, dwells in the world yet is not stained by it. Temporarily resting in the ground of freedom from defilement, he shall realize the body of the Dharma King.

*"Practicing Chan, singing lewd songs of rouge and powder"*—Chan is the practice of purity, while rouge and powder are the words of lust; the two are incompatible. Yet he who practices Chan while singing such songs—scripture says: *"A lotus blooms in fire—how rare! To practice Chan amid desire is equally rare."* Thus the Immortal Master, practicing Chan and singing lewd songs, forgets all appearances. Moreover, he wishes the world to recognize that his resolve is firm, his footing steady. There is no harm in blending with the world’s radiance.

Concealing his actions, silently refining, strictly guarding the root of life, meticulously upholding the precepts of his nature—what need is there to abstain from wine and meat?

Form is medicine, wine is emolument—
Amid wine and form, unbound.
Only through flowers and wine did he awaken to longevity—
Drinking wine, wearing flowers, gods and ghosts weep.

*"Form is medicine"*—within the maiden of sixteen, there lies the treasure of true gold, the medicinal substances of hun and po. *"Wine is emolument"*—destined by past causes, it also aids the flourishing of the Dao. *"Drinking wine all day without intoxication, wearing flowers without losing them"*—thus amid wine and form, there is no constraint.

The Master said: *"Now that I have attained the Dao and become an immortal, it is through flowers and wine that I achieved long life and enduring vision."* By drinking wine and wearing flowers, refining the self and upholding the heart, he committed no error. The six thieves and the three corpses’ ghosts naturally vanished, no longer able to run rampant—hence *"gods and ghosts weep."*

Do not break precepts, do not transgress lust—
Breaking precepts sinks the true suchness of nature.
Transgressing lust destroys the treasure of long life—
Only those who attain it are men of the Dao’s power.

*"Do not break precepts, do not transgress lust"* echoes the earlier *"holding fast to rouge and flowers, cutting off lust."* The foolish and deluded of the world, unaware of refining their own bodies, break precepts and transgress lust. Like a lamp extinguished when its oil is spent, or a man perishing when his marrow is exhausted, many have harmed their bodies and lost their lives. They know only to abstain from killing and stealing, unaware that the true theft and murder occur within—stealing the original yang qi, killing one’s own nature and life. Yet they remain unguarded, sinking into the river of love, their true nature obscured, mired in lust and desire, destroying the treasure of long life—how can they become immortals?

To grasp the method of cultivation, one must rely on the oral instructions of an enlightened master—refining the self, stabilizing the mind, obtaining the medicine, and securing the elixir. Thus attaining long life and enduring vision, the power of the Dao grows firm and strong. Hence it is said: *"Only those who attain it are men of the Dao’s power."*

**Men of the Dao’s power—**
**True idlers—**
*Wine is a fine friend, flowers a companion.*
*Seeking the true man in the willow lanes and flower streets—*
*The true man is but playing in the flower streets.*

Men of the Dao’s power are those who have completed the cycles of elixir-refinement, attained the Dao, and gained its strength—great beings of virtue. *"Wine is a fine friend"* refers to the earth of Kun, the southwest where companions gather, allowing one to drink the immortal wine of no-rice. *"Flowers are companions"* denotes the paired numbers of seven-six, two-seven, nine-two, nine-six—kindred spirits who may join as companions.

Thus, those of great practice enter without hesitation into brothels, taverns, flower streets, and willow chambers, performing the work of refining the self. Hence it is said: *In the willow lanes and flower streets, one may seek the true man.* The true man is indeed found playing in the flower streets.

*Plucking flowers, wearing them, drinking the wine of long life—*
*In the scene of non-action, the Dao naturally flourishes.*
*Let the deluded masses mock and scorn—*
*The immortal flowers and immortal wine are the immortal realm.*

*Plucking flowers, wearing them, drinking the wine of long life*—for the Dao cultivator, having received the master’s oral instructions and begun the work, the furnace must be precisely calibrated in weight and measure, without the slightest error. One must proceed in proper sequence: first, on the third day, the moon emerges at Geng; next, on the eighth day, the moon reaches Ding.

Afterward, on the fifteenth day, the moon reaches Jia. During the work, first use the yang sword to sever the flower’s stem, then with the yin sword drink the wine of long life. One must also know that at the time of the full moon, the water source is clear or turbid, the metal and water arrive in season, and the true man is precisely in position. Plunge into the Yellow Chamber’s earthen crucible, where in the ordinary scene, all entanglements are shed, and one enters non-action—then the true Dao naturally flourishes. The deluded masses of the world, hearing of using the cauldron to refine the great elixir, all mock and slander, deeming it unworthy of pursuit. Thus the immortal master said: *“Let the deluded masses mock and scorn—the immortal flowers and immortal wine are my immortal realm.”* Let the scholar ponder this.

*To this realm, no common guest—*
*Within the joyous cave, boy and girl gather flowers of all seasons,*
*Flower upon flower, the elixir of long life is formed.*

For the Dao cultivator, having gathered the elixir and entered the Central Palace, arriving at this true realm, one is no ordinary worldly guest but truly a seed of immortality. Within the Yellow Chamber, the boy and girl unite in joyous union. One must then temper the fire for ten months, followed by one month of total refinement and one month of spirit emergence—hence the year-long work of the four seasons, *“constantly gathering flowers of all seasons within the cave.”* The internal and external fire-work and qi-cycles must be flawless, so that the embryo of spirit may congeal and transform, called *“flower upon flower, the elixir of long life is formed.”*

*The elixir of long life—pluck the heart of the flower,*
*Layer upon layer, the flower’s pistils bloom in spring splendor.*
*Men do not grasp the principle within the flower—*
*A single secret of heaven’s mechanism is worth ten thousand gold.*

Fearing later students might not understand, the immortal master reiterated emphatically: The elixir of long life must be gathered from the three treasures of the upper crescent within the jade crucible, where jade pistils and golden blossoms unfold in orderly, layered spring radiance. Many in the world blindly cultivate without grasping the principle within the flower, making attainment of the Dao difficult. If by past good fortune one encounters a true master who reveals the celestial mechanism step by step, it is like a pauper gaining treasure, like the sick obtaining medicine, like a prisoner granted pardon, like the dead restored to life—worth more than ten thousand taels of gold. Even if one possessed ten thousand taels, they would eventually be spent, but having obtained this true method, its wondrous use is inexhaustible.

*Give thanks to heaven and earth, feel gratitude for the empty void—*
*To have met the immortal master is to meet one’s ancestors.*
*Whispered in the ear, the profound and wondrous instruction,*
*Raised to the first peak of Penglai.*

After attaining the Dao, the immortal master sighed in gratitude for the protection of yin and yang, heaven and earth, and the empty void, having met the True Yang Emperor Lord, who was like an ancestor. The Emperor Lord whispered in his ear, transmitting heart-to-heart the oral instructions of the golden liquid returning elixir, lifting him to the first peak of Penglai. This refers to the upper crescent crucible, hence the metaphor of the first peak. Let the scholar examine this carefully.

*The first peak is an immortal thing,*
*Where only golden blossoms and jade pistils arise in the indistinct.*
*Mouth to mouth, the transmission leaves no written record—*
*One must possess a firm spiritual root and marrow-bones.*

The first peak refers to the White Tiger of the Dui Palace of the same kind. Within this thing, only golden blossoms and jade pistils are produced, capable of generating the indistinct. The ancestral masters dared not commit it to bamboo and silk, requiring only oral transmission. To attain the Dao, one must also possess marrow-bones of a firm spiritual root, for only then can the great medicine of the golden elixir be accomplished.

*Firm marrow-bones refine the spiritual root,*
*Petal upon petal, peach blossoms in the cave’s spring.*
*Sevens of the White Tiger nurtured in pairs,*
*Eights of the Green Dragon total one catty.*

The lines on firm marrow-bones refer to the great elixir of Dragon and Tiger, the great medicine of the golden elixir, which can refine one’s spiritual root—this is the Green Dragon. The third line refers to the work of refining the self with fire, requiring the exchange of crucibles for refinement, which may be called the spring breeze and fluid essence within the cave of petal-like peach blossoms. The “sevens of the White Tiger” refer to the two-sevens crucible for refining the great elixir. If one obtains eight taels of true gold from the upper crescent White Tiger and half a catty of true mercury from the Green Dragon, the two eights combine to form one catty of the great medicine. The medicine of the eight-eights Green Dragon can also assist the yin path.

*The true parents deliver to the original palace,*
*Wood Mother and Metal Father, their natures inherently gentle.*
*Within the twelve palaces, the toad’s radiance appears,*
*Moment by moment, the earthly soul descends and the celestial soul arrives.*

The true parents refer to the great medicine of the golden elixir, this supreme treasure delivered to one’s original palace. Wood Mother and Metal Father are wood-mercury and metal-lead, their natures harmoniously united. Guarding the Central Palace’s earthen crucible, within the twelve hours, circulate the fire and retreat the tally, likened to the appearance of the toad’s radiance in moonlight. Moment by moment, firm resolve is needed to guard the sun’s soul and moon’s spirit, sublimating them within the cinnabar field, like the union of husband and wife—never to be parted even for an instant. Only then can the sacred embryo congeal, and the Dao be accomplished.

*When lead is first achieved, mercury is first born,*
*Within the jade crucible and golden tripod, not yet refined.*
*One husband and one wife unite with heaven and earth,*
*One boy and one girl join with Qian and Kun.*

“Lead is first achieved” refers to gathering the three true essences of the upper crescent’s moon spirit into one’s cinnabar field, called the initial achievement. To restrain one’s true mercury, the mercury is like the beginning of new life. One must then refine it in the jade crucible and golden tripod, the two qi intermingling, like the union of husband and wife, following the principle of heaven and earth’s yin and yang. The union of male and female, the ordinary proceeding and the sage reversing, aligns with the Dao of Qian and Kun’s opening and closing. Only by not losing this fire-work can the elixir’s head congeal.

*Geng must be born, Jia must be born,*
*When Jia and Geng are born, the Dao begins to sprout.*
*Pluck the root of heaven and the marrow of earth—*
*The white snow and yellow sprout naturally grow.*

To generate *Jia* is to allow the *qi* of *Jia*-Wood’s mercury-fire in the East to give rise to the metal-water of the White Tiger in the West. When *Jia* and *Geng* are born, it is the dragon swallowing the tiger’s blood and the tiger inhaling the dragon’s essence, the two *qi* arising and the sprout first germinating. Day by day it grows, ever new and ever renewing.

The gathering is the turning mechanism of the Dipper’s handle. The "root of heaven" is one’s own single entity, taking the "marrow of earth" from within that other entity. If one achieves this—first gathering, then arising—ascending and descending, warming and nurturing, with fire-work unerring and unlost, then white snow and yellow sprout will naturally grow to maturity, congealing within the cinnabar field, as a man conceives a child.

*Lead must be born, mercury must be born,*
*When mercury and lead are born, they are refined in one place.*
*This is not the union of essence and fluid—*
*It is the essence of heaven and earth, the sun and moon’s true power.*

That lead must be born means the *qi* of true metal at the waxing crescent enters one’s cinnabar field to generate true mercury. When lead and mercury give rise to each other, they are refined together in the earthen crucible. All bones are ordered, and all spirits obey the command. This refining is not the lustful union of desire but the natural process of heaven and earth, the true essence of the sun and moon—a treasure of *qi* without form.

When the Yellow Dame makes a perfect match,
Timing must be exact, the oral transmission passed down.
The eight trigrams and three primals rely entirely on mercury,
The five phases and four images cannot be without lead.

The Yellow Dame is the true earth spirit of *Wu-Ji*, the spleen’s deity, the intent of the two persons. If the two *qi* are harmonious and metal and wood are not estranged, they will swiftly unite in perfect harmony, merging into one, congealing without dissolution. To gather the elixir’s medicine, one must rely on the true master’s oral instructions, the subtle and wondrous timing without error. Only then can accomplishment be achieved; without the true instructions, one will instead incur great harm.

The eight trigrams are *Qian*, *Kan*, *Gen*, *Zhen*, *Xun*, *Li*, *Kun*, and *Dui*. The three primals are the three vehicles and three mysteries of the Dao. That all relies on mercury means that in refining the fire-work of the self, one must ensure true mercury is without flaw, entirely dependent on mercury’s steadfastness.

The five phases are metal, wood, water, fire, and earth: *Jia*-Dragon in the East, *Bing*-Phoenix in the South, *Geng*-Tiger in the West, *Ren*-Tortoise in the North, and the intent-earth of the Yellow Dame at the center. These four images and five phases are the bodies of self and other, the two *qi* of dragon and tiger, yin and yang, water and fire. Only by seeking the true unity of lead can the great work be accomplished.

*Lead gives rise to mercury, mercury gives rise to lead,*
*Seizing the power of heaven and earth’s transformations.*
*In the profound and obscure, life arises from the indistinct,*
*From the indistinct, a mass congeals.*

That lead gives rise to mercury means using lead to restrain mercury; that mercury gives rise to lead means mercury and lead harmonize. Thus it is said, "Seizing the power of heaven and earth," the transformations of yin and yang, lead and mercury. The profound and obscure are the two entities of yin and yang; life arising from the indistinct is true lead and true mercury, the sun’s spirit and the moon’s essence. From the indistinct, a mass congeals—yin and yang’s two entities, refined and congealed without dissolution. This is the principle of mutual consumption and the fire-work, where the divine elixir of the central palace may congeal into a mass.

*Nature must be empty, intent must be focused,*
*Do not let the monkey and horse wander carelessly.*
*When the flower’s dew first opens, beware of disturbance—*
*Lock it in the earthen crucible, do not withdraw or add.*

That nature must be empty means an empty mind. That intent must be focused means letting go of all concerns, not clinging even to the slightest, tightly guarding the central yellow chamber with single-minded devotion. Do not let the monkey and horse wander carelessly means the cultivator of the Dao must lock the heart-monkey and tether the mind-horse, not allowing them to roam freely.

When the flower’s dew first opens, beware of disturbance means that once the elixir enters the abdomen and true mercury is subdued, it is like the first opening of a flower’s dew—easy to gather but also easy to scatter. One must be vigilant against any disturbance. The practitioner must work diligently, subduing the heart and severing thoughts, without the slightest negligence, guarding life with care, embracing and protecting the cinnabar field until the divine elixir congeals. Thus it is said, "Lock it in the earthen crucible, do not withdraw or add."

In the jade crucible, the civil fire refines,
Within the twelve hours, only guard the One.
At this time, the Yellow Way unites yin and yang,
The three natures return to the original palace without leakage.

In the jade crucible, the civil fire refines refers to the Dao of refining form with jade liquid, nurturing with the civil fire, the moment of the *Ditian Tai* hexagram’s bathing. The cultivator, within the twelve hours, must focus the mind on the One, intent fixed on the cinnabar field. From *zi* to *si*, the six hours of kindling the fire; from *wu* to *hai*, the six hours of withdrawing the tally. Yin and yang unite, water above and fire below. The three natures of metal, water, and fire are preserved as one, gathered into the original palace without leakage. Only then can a man conceive a child, a husband become pregnant.

When *qi* moves, the true fire refines,
Do not let the *xuan*-pearl leave the sacred hall.
Add to the fire-work with caution against danger—
The *ninth of the first* is the hidden dragon, not to be refined.

When *qi* moves, the true fire refines means closing the breath to circulate true *qi* internally, the fire-work of fetal breathing, not allowing the *xuan*-pearl of lead and mercury to wander, lest the congealed elixir scatter again. For when the inner elixir enters the abdomen, it is like clouds and mist. True *qi* circulates within, refined by true fire, the union of heart and kidney, not to be separated even for a moment.

The external crucible’s fire-work, in its withdrawal and addition, must be guarded against danger with utmost care, lest negligence bring harm upon oneself. One seeks to refine the elixir for longevity, but if it is lost at this stage, one will instead shorten life—this must be avoided. At this time, the key is to understand the internal and external fire-work, the sequence of the *Zhun* and *Meng* hexagrams, without error. From *zi* to *si*, the six hours of kindling the yang fire; from *wu* to *hai*, the six hours of withdrawing the yin tally. Thus it is said, "The *ninth of the first* is the hidden dragon, not to be refined"—this is the fire-work of nurturing.

The ebb and flow of fire, the transformation of the *daogui*—
Across the great earth, yellow sprouts grow in abundance.
Within the reckoning of the Five Phases, one yang arises;
The twenty-four *qi* array the feast of pearls.

The adept, knowing only the ebb and flow of internal and external fire-work without the slightest error, first obtains the elixir of the *daogui*, which transforms into yellow sprouts and coalesces into the pearl of the elixir. This occurs within the reckoning of the Five Phases, where the Great One contains the true unity of *qi*, the seed serving as the origin of the elixir. Thereafter, ten months of fire-work are applied, one month for total refinement, and one month for the emergence of spirit. The twenty-four *qi* of the year’s method augment the power of the divine medicine—thus it is said, “The twenty-four *qi* array the feast of pearls.”

When the fire is sufficient and the reckoning complete,
The medicine is then formed—
Soon come the cries of dragons and the roars of tigers.
Of three leads, only one lead is attained;
The golden fruit and immortal sprout have yet to manifest their form.

If the adept achieves the full reckoning of internal and external fire-work, the divine elixir coalesces, and within the body, the union of husband and wife naturally gives rise to the cries of dragons and the roars of tigers. Yet in gathering the three grades of the great medicine’s origin, only one lead is truly received and employed—like tasting the flavor of the golden fruit or immortal peach, its transformations and manifestations possess inconceivable spiritual potency. With the fire-work of nurturing unerring, the infant emerges—this is no ordinary birth for a man.

Reinstall the furnace, reestablish the crucible—
Riding the tiger, mounting the dragon, one departs the mortal realm.
As the essence of the sun first appears and the radiance of the moon congeals,
The two eights unite in *ren* and *bing*.

In the method of refining the elixir, if one possesses great root and capacity, having accomplished the great elixir, the elixir is moved into the upper cinnabar field. A wondrous furnace is then set anew, dragon and tiger unite, essence and radiance congeal, and the two bowstrings’ *qi* are realigned, uniting *ren*-water and *bing*-fire. With water and fire in harmony, the marvel of the re-created divine elixir arises. As the *Four Hundred Characters* states: “In a year, a child is born; each one may ride the crane.”

Dragon-mercury coalesces, tiger-lead forms—
A journey of but a foot to Penglai.
The lead of *kun* and the mercury of *qian* are the ancestors of the golden elixir;
Dragon-lead and tiger-mercury are most spiritually efficacious.

In the initial refinement of the golden liquid’s returning elixir, dragon-mercury and tiger-lead are essential as the ancestral foundation of the elixir. In the fire-work of nurturing, dragon-lead and tiger-mercury are likewise required—this is the method of gathering what was previously received, most crucial for the spiritually efficacious fire-timing. The scholar should seek a true teacher and not squander a lifetime in vain.

The *Cantong Qi* states:
Fifteen for gold’s reckoning,
Water’s number is the same.
Before the furnace, fix the weights—
Five parts water, with some to spare.
These two are taken as true,
Gold’s weight as in the beginning.
The second is thus excluded,
Fire and two accompany it.
The three substances contain and receive one another,
Their transformations like spirits in form.

Grasp this principle, and the Dao is then accomplished—
Thirty thousand divine dragons guard the crystal.
The timing is set, the days and hours clear;
Devotion lies solely in intent and reverence.

If one of great cultivation comprehends the principle of the golden liquid’s great returning elixir and the method of immortals begetting immortals, the Dao may be fully realized. The crucible is reestablished, with gold as the embankment—thus it is said, “Thirty thousand divine dragons guard the crystal.” One must also clarify the timing, focus the mind in vigilant attendance, and understand the principle of gold generating fifteen ounces of water. The fourteenth chapter of the *Cantong Qi* is most explicit; knowing this is the detailed Dao of “drinking the *daogui*.”

When black lead has passed and pure truth is gathered,
A single clash settles great peace.
The three vehicles transport treasures of pearls,
Delivering them to the precious treasury, naturally spiritually efficacious.

If one knows the fifteen ounces of gold and how much water it generates, the true principle must be understood. When the black lead has passed and the water’s source is utterly pure, within it true gold generates two parts water—this alone is truly usable. By method, it is gathered, and the bellows and furnace are securely sealed. The clash must settle into great peace, and the three vehicles of the three grades of the great elixir are employed to transport it into the central palace’s treasury. The ten thousand spirits obey commands, and without being spirit, it naturally responds as spirit.

Heavenly spirits protect, earthly deities welcome—
The union of *qian* and *kun*, the essence of sun and moon.
At the tiger’s roar, the dragon emerges from its cave;
Phoenixes fly and phoenixes dance, issuing from the golden city.

Heavenly spirits protect, for my true mercury seeks true lead. Earthly deities welcome, for their true lead seeks my true mercury. Only when the two intentions harmonize can yin and yang unite in fusion. One must know the moment when the tiger’s roar signals the arrival of true lead, swiftly commanding the azure dragon to emerge from its cave, wielding the flying spirit-sword to gather it. The *qi* of phoenixes enters my earthen crucible within the golden city to form the elixir.

Cinnabar matches, mercury settles—
A cascade of red radiance arrays the Great Clarity.
Along the pool, golden light bursts forth;
Mercury-fire flows crimson into the imperial capital.

Cinnabar matches: within the human body, accumulated essence transforms into mercury, and when mercury endures and solidifies, it becomes cinnabar, which pairs with true lead to form the origin of the elixir. Mercury settles: the mercury of the lower bowstring, eight ounces evenly balanced, completes the pound of the great medicine. Thereafter, the transformations within the body resemble red radiance rising on all sides, arrayed within the Great Clarity. Then, the true lead of the furnace-fire reverses its flow, ascending to the Mud Pill Palace, like golden light enveloping the body. Mercury-fire flows as pearls, descending into the golden chamber and yellow room, entering the imperial capital.

Dragon and tiger unite, externally maintaining fullness—
The saintly walks, the spirit flies within the precious vase.
In a single hour, the golden elixir is accomplished;
Ascending to the golden gate, purple clouds arise.

That tiger and this dragon, the *qi* of the two bowstrings, unite in the fusion of water and fire, contending and maintaining fullness. The transformations of spiritual potency, the saintly walking and the spirit flying, occur within the body’s precious vase. In a single hour, the origin of the elixir coalesces above, ascending to the golden gate of the Mud Pill Palace and the purple court, where true *qi* is reborn, circulating throughout the body without obstruction.

The immortal peach ripens—pluck and partake,
As the myriad transformations pay homage, heaven and earth rejoice.
With fasting and vigil, await the birth of the solitary Yang;
Then advance to circulate the Zhou Tian, aligning with the *Can Tong* principle.

When the immortal peach ripens, the nine-six cycle of the *xuan* pass is complete, the moment when metal gives birth to water and clarity arises—this is the peach’s ripening. It is time to act, to enter the chamber and apply effort to gather it, placing it within the earthen crucible. The myriad transformations pay homage, the body’s alchemy naturally unites, like husband and wife in joyous union. If one seeks this treasure, one must first establish an altar, purify the mind, and maintain fasting and vigil. As the solitary Yang is about to arise, metal births radiant water; when its source becomes utterly clear, seize the moment to act, advancing to align with the *Can Tong* principle. Within a single hour, the golden elixir is assured—once attained, it is eternally possessed.

Align with the *Can Tong* principle to refine the golden elixir;
Water and fire steam through the hundred passes.
Nurturing the embryo for ten months, the divine elixir coalesces—
How could a man’s pregnancy be a trivial matter?

To *align* (*can*) is to match the body of heaven and earth’s transformations, the pivotal moment when the two—lead and mercury, the *qi* of self and other—resonate. To *unite* (*tong*) is to employ the mutual completion of like kinds, merging the workings of Yin and Yang’s alchemy. Only by deeply understanding this principle can one grasp the workings of refining the golden elixir. Rising and falling through the *Tun* and *Meng* hexagrams, water and fire steam through the hundred bones, opening the hundred passes. Nurturing with inner and outer fire, after ten months the embryo is complete and *qi* is full—thus a man gives birth to a child, a husband becomes pregnant. How could this be a trivial matter?

The inner elixir is accomplished, the outer elixir is achieved;
Within and without connect, harmonizing in joyous union.
Together they form a single purple-golden pill—
Transforming and soaring, enduring as heaven and earth.

The inner elixir’s accomplishment lies in the central palace’s earthen crucible, where the divine elixir is nurtured. The outer elixir’s achievement comes from obtaining the externally derived golden elixir, the two merging to form a single cinnabar-red golden pill. With the fire’s work connecting them, harmonizing and uniting, the sacred embryo takes shape, the infant manifests. Transforming and soaring, enduring through heaven and earth’s ages, one becomes a true person.

The elixir entering the abdomen is no ordinary matter—
The Yin form is stripped away, transmuting into pure Yang.
Ascending in flight, transcending as a guest of the Three Clarities,
With name fulfilled and merit complete, one reaches the heavens above.

Through deep cultivation, the elixir enters the abdomen, uniting within and without, unlike the common world. Day by day, the Yin form is stripped away, transmuting into a body of pure Yang. Ascending in flight, transcending, one becomes a guest of the Three Clarities. Only when merit is complete and the Dao is perfected does one’s name reach the heavens above.

A guest of the Three Clarities, riding the jade tones of the phoenix chariot,
Together they mount the phoenix, soaring into the Great Void.
Such carefree joy and bliss—
Roaming the three realms, most pure and wondrous.
Above the Great Void, the perfected cultivator,
Bright and complete, without a single thing.

The guest of the Three Clarities refers to one who has accomplished the golden fluid’s great return elixir and perfected the Dao. Riding the phoenix chariot of jade tones, they enter the Great Void and the celestial rivers, roaming the three realms in carefree ease. This is the perfected cultivator, bright and complete in the great Dao, without a single thing to encumber them.

Without a single thing, only the Dao manifests—
From the five directions emerges the true person’s visage.
Immortal boys and girls welcome with colored clouds,
In the Palace of Five Lights, the true decree is transmitted.

Without a single thing means the perfected one has emptied all entanglements. Unattached to phenomena, only the eternal Dao is clearly manifest. The true *qi* of the five viscera, each revealing its original color, emerges from the five directions as the true person’s visage. At this stage, with merit complete and the Dao perfected, the infant appears, a body beyond the body. Immortal boys and girls welcome them to the Penglai Three Isles, to the Palace of Five Lights, where the true official decree is transmitted, and their name is recorded in the immortal register.

"Voice-hearers" are those who learn by hearing the Dharma from a teacher and attain awakening; "Pratyekabuddhas," also called "solitary awakened ones," are those who awaken to the twelve nidānas and attain the Dao—these are the two vehicles. The true decree is transmitted, speaking of profound matters—
It is merely the true lead refining mercury’s essence.
Voice-hearers and Pratyekabuddhas dissolve like frost;
External paths and asuras recoil in shock.

After attaining the Dao and receiving the true decree, one transmits the daily practices and methods of cultivation. The Dao of the true one speaks of the profound matters of refining lead and mercury. If voice-hearers and Pratyekabuddhas hear this, they dissolve like frost; external paths and asuras, upon learning of the dual cultivation of man and woman, recoil in shock. Thus it is called the hard-to-believe Dharma.

Touching dry bones, they instantly take form—
Trusting the Dao, the ladder to heaven is as level as one’s palm.
The nine generations of ancestors attain liberation—
Who would envy the fleeting glory of wealth and honor?

One who can cultivate the true Dao, firmly establishing the foundation, obtaining the medicine and the elixir, is like touching dry bones and instantly restoring their form, becoming an immortal of eternal life. Thus one trusts the sagely Dao. The three-inch ladder to heaven is possessed by all, present before one’s eyes, as level as the palm of one’s hand. After attaining the Dao, the nine generations of ancestors all achieve liberation. As for the world’s wealth and honor, they are but morning dew—who would envy them?

Seek the resolute, find the worthy—
Together they stabilize the furnace and crucible, transforming the mortal embryo.
If one is stingy with wealth or hoards treasures,
Ten thousand immortals will refuse to come.

The ancient immortals, cultivating and refining, received the true oral instructions and authentic methods from their teachers. They required both wealth and Dharma to succeed. If one lacks resources, one must wander the four seas, seeking true and resolute individuals, wise and worthy talents. Mutual trust and alliance, swearing oaths before heaven and earth, they stabilize the furnace and crucible together, obtaining the medicine and the elixir, mutually accomplishing the work. This is the other providing wealth while I provide the Dharma—wealth and Dharma equally offered, without distinction.

If one is greedy for wealth, stingy with treasures, and miserly,
Even the highest immortals and transcendent beings will refuse to depend on or join them—hence it is said, *"Ten thousand immortals will refuse to come."*

The cultivator of truth does not speak carelessly—
For every careless word, Heaven will deduct ten thousand kalpas of dust-like eons,
The Way remains unfulfilled,
And from the seven orifices, blood will gush forth.

The immortal masters, moved by deep compassion,
Fearing that worldly minds remain deluded and unwilling to believe or practice,
Utter this solemn vow to earnestly exhort later learners:
*"I am a cultivator of truth, unlike the common and vulgar,
I dare not speak even a single word falsely to deceive the world.
If I utter even one careless word to mislead later generations,
I shall incur Heaven’s punishment—
Ten thousand kalpas of dust-like eons without attaining the Way,
Afflicted with grave illness, blood gushing from the seven orifices."*
The immortal masters make this solemn vow, so fervent is their desire to deliver others!
How can learners not take heed!

The impoverished adept makes a resolute vow—
Determined to lift and guide all worldly beings,
To join together in the immortal assembly of Penglai,
Where the torments of the mortal realm never cease.

The immortal masters, calling themselves "impoverished adepts,"
Make their vows with utmost sincerity,
Resolved to raise and lead all ordinary folk,
To enter the path of eternal life,
To gather in the immortal assembly of Penglai,
And become the seed of immortality.
Yet if one does not believe, sinking into the river of desire,
Drifting into the sea of craving,
Trapped in the cycle of rebirth,
Within the mortal realm’s fiery pit,
Enduring ceaseless torment.

The worldly life is brief—ponder this well—
While within the cave’s realm, heaven and earth endure, sun and moon stretch long.
With steadfast resolve and苦心, in three to five years,
Across a hundred thousand myriad kalpas, life knows no bounds.

Worldly beings, failing to attain the true Way,
Live scarcely a hundred years, and even seventy is rare.
All must inevitably face death.
Knowing life is short, they yet willingly await death,
Refusing to turn toward the Way.
But if, in the quiet of dawn’s pillow,
One reflects alone—
That the ancient immortals and all buddhas were once human, too,
And through cultivation achieved transcendence—
Then one should swiftly take up the task,
Seek the oral instructions of an enlightened master,
And practice the immortal method of long life and deathlessness.
Following the master’s guidance,
With unwavering resolve and苦心,
One refines the great returning elixir of golden fluid.
When merit is complete and the Way perfected,
One becomes an immortal,
And across a hundred thousand myriad kalpas,
Life endures as boundlessly as heaven and earth.

When the sacred Way is realized and true constancy revealed,
Tigers and rhinos, blades and weapons can no longer harm,
Water and fire, dragons and serpents bring no injury—
Clapping hands in the celestial palace, one laughs with joy.

These practices are truly wondrous—
Yet when entrusted to others, who would accept them?
Foolish disciples cling to desire and wealth in death,
So immortals refuse to bestow their light.

The true and ultimate Way does not discriminate—
How could it favor high or low, rich or poor?
Even princes and nobles, if they seek the Way,
Must first shed worldly splendor, temper their sharp edges,
And sever the tangle of distractions.

If anger remains unremoved and pride unchanged,
One falls into the sea of birth and death, trapped in the wheel of rebirth.
Though gold and jade pile mountain-high,
They are but worldly treasures, destined to fade—
Not the eternal treasure of long life.
Immortals regard them with cold laughter, unworthy of notice.

Fame is not true nobility—only the Way is supreme.
From sage to sage, from worthy to worthy, the lineage endures,
While those who wear gold at their waists, ride proud steeds,
Are but fleeting as dust in a sunlit crack.

Dust in a crack, sparks from stone—
Why fix the heart on such fleeting things?
Yet they endure in bitter torment, unmoved by calls to return,
Striving for profit and fame like a boiling cauldron.

Stone-sparks—like the fire struck from stone, the human body is not meant to last. Yet the common folk, lost in delusion, drown daily in the turbid flow of worldly toil. From dawn to dusk, their karmic consciousness drifts in boundless confusion, the Eight Sufferings searing them without end. Thus do the Immortal Masters, through countless scriptures and discourses, urge cultivation. But worldly beings, burdened by heavy karma and deep transgressions, refuse to turn back. They vie for profit and fame like a boiling cauldron, willingly enduring torment—truly, they are the walking dead.

Like a seething cauldron, they sink forever,
Lost in the Way, deluded by truth, their karma rooted deep.
Yet if one levels the thorns in the heart,
The celestial mechanism may then be revealed.

Worldly folk cling to the snares of the mundane, rushing to and fro like a bubbling pot, never at rest. Thus they lose the Way and stray from truth, drowning in the sea of karma. This is the retribution of past lives and present sins—so deep are the roots of their transgressions that returning to primordial truth becomes impossible! Only those with the bones of immortals and the affinity for the Dao, upon hearing the teaching, awaken at once. They level the brambles in their hearts, steel their resolve, and vow unwaveringly to attain the Way, never wavering or regretting. To such as these, the celestial mechanism of creation is revealed in full, the subtle oral instructions carefully transmitted, that they may cultivate and realize the fruit of celestial immortality, resolving the great matter of life and death.

The mandate must be transmitted; the nature must be awakened—
Entry into sagehood, transcendence of the mundane, lies in your own hands.
Few tread the path to the Three Pure Ones,
While many jostle at the gates of the beastly realms.

The Immortal Masters solemnly clarify the great matter of the life-foundation—this is no trifling affair. One must steel the heart, make a blood-oath, and pledge before the highest sages and worthies, devoting the heart and swearing to heaven before transmission. Thus, the mandate must be passed by a master. The nature must be awakened: the teaching directs one to directly investigate the original source, truly contemplate and verify, clearly perceive one’s own nature, and radiate light through the body. Thus, the nature must be awakened by oneself. Only through the dual cultivation of nature and life can one succeed, entering sagehood and transcending the mundane—all through one’s own cultivation and realization. Yet alas, worldly folk refuse to believe and accept, turning away from cultivation. They cling only to the seven emotions and desires of the world, willingly falling into the ranks of the beastly, unable to escape. Hence it is said: *Few tread the path to the Three Pure Ones, while many jostle at the gates of the beastly realms.*

To the worthy and good, heed this warning—
Do not yearn for worldly ties.
The mechanism of nature and life must be guarded well.
If either is lacking, no fragrance will bloom;
Clinging to the waves of worldly dust, you will lose the path.

The Patriarchs repeatedly exhort the worthy and virtuous: do not long for worldly ties—love for wife and children, greed for profit and fame. Only the mechanism of nature and life is worth guarding; do not neglect or doubt it. You must cherish life and seek liberation from the suffering of birth and death. If you cultivate only one and neglect the other, it is like a withered branch—no fragrance will bloom, no flower or fruit will form. Clinging to the waves of worldly dust, you will lose the true gate of the great Way.

To cultivate nature alone, not life—
This is the foremost illness in cultivation.
To cultivate only the ancestral nature, not the elixir—
For ten thousand kalpas, the yin spirit will struggle to enter sagehood.

The Immortal Elders, in their compassion for later learners who take the wrong path, do not know the true Way. They cling to emptiness and non-action, abandoning wives and children, retreating to the mountains to cultivate, sitting in stillness until the heart turns to ash, blindly practicing without insight—mistaking this for seated meditation. Such foolish ones suffer from the foremost illness in cultivation. The poison runs deep; even the finest physicians and miraculous medicines cannot save them, and they are fated to die. Like those iron-spined Arhats who reach the Pratyeka-buddha stage, attaining a thousand years of samadhi, they may project a yin spirit but cannot enter sagehood! Without cultivating the golden elixir, the true Way cannot be achieved.

According to the Buddhist sutras, the first fruit, Srotāpanna, is called the "Stream-Enterer," having already entered sagehood. By the fourth fruit, Arhat, they are said to fly and transform, abiding in longevity, moving heaven and earth. The Pratyeka-buddha vehicle surpasses the Arhat, though it is slightly inferior to the Bodhisattva vehicle—entering the realm of sages but not yet perfected. As for those who fully awaken to the principle of true emptiness and the nature of the heart, life is encompassed within it, and they are called the Greatly Awakened Golden Immortals. Thus did the Perfected Zhang Ziyang say: *"I have attained the secret not transmitted by Bodhidharma or the Sixth Patriarch."* Therefore, Lord Fu You expounded the *Eight Grades* and *Three Grades* sutras, profoundly illuminating the principle of the unity of the Three Teachings. Yet he feared that worldly folk would only know how to cultivate nature and not life, failing to reach the stage of exhausting principle and fulfilling nature to attain life. Hence, he earnestly warned them. If one entirely denounces the Buddhist Dharma, knowing only how to cultivate nature and not life, how does this align with the verse Lord Fu You presented after his awakening at the encounter with Huanglong: *"Ever since I met Huanglong, I realized my past efforts were misdirected"*? Later learners must not misunderstand this!

To master the life-school but neglect the ancestral nature—
Like a mirror stand without a precious mirror.
To live as long as heaven and earth, yet remain a fool—
Holding the reins of family wealth without true control.

Some learn the oral instructions of the life-foundation from the Immortal Masters, clinging to partial views. They cultivate the life-foundation firmly but do not awaken the ancestral nature, failing to see their original face. This is like having a mirror stand without a bright mirror. They do not know the wisdom of the nature-school, the way of transformation, transcendence, spiritual projection, and samadhi. Though they may live long, they lack wisdom—like a fool in the world who possesses a fortune of ten thousand gold but has no mastery over its wondrous use.

When nature and life are dually cultivated, steadfast and true—
Riding the Dharma-boat across the vast waves of the ocean’s depths,
Seizing the dragon’s head alive and whole—
Only then will you know the master craftsman’s skill is no empty boast.

The cultivator, having thoroughly investigated and awakened to the nature, refines the inner medicine, resolves the root of life, gathers the elixir’s essence, harmonizes and nurtures it. The inner and outer fires are flawless, without deficiency, danger, negligence, or loss.

Thus in dual cultivation, morning and evening alternate—*zhun* and *meng*—advancing and gathering, twofold in function, truly steadfast and true. Just as riding the Dharma-boat across the vast waves of the ocean’s depths, one transcends the three disasters and eight difficulties, the nine perils and five sufferings, seizing alive the green dragon’s head within the sea. Only in this true realm does one realize that the ancient master craftsman’s skill was no empty boast, no false semblance, nor devoid of true efficacy. Even if one were to grind one’s bones to powder and shatter one’s body, it would be difficult to repay the profound grace of the ancestral masters. Later learners should heed this well and not squander their time in vain.

Where annotations within the text did not align with the original ode’s intent, they have been revised—yet only to the extent that they accord with the ancestral meaning.

*Qin Yuan Chun* Annotations
By Zixu Liaozhenzi Xiao Tingzhi Yuanrui

The Sevenfold Return Elixir.
Fire’s generating number is two, its completing number seven.
*Return* means ascending from below; *revert* means descending from above.
Some say: wood is three, metal four, their sum seven—hence "sevenfold return," a fine interpretation.
For metal and wood are the parents of water and fire, the ancestral roots of the Five Phases, the foundation of the reverted elixir.
To take "tears, saliva, fluids, essence, qi, blood, and marrow" as the sevenfold return is a grave error!
Master Yunfang’s verse says:
*"Seven yin substances all in vain—
If these you take as elixir-seed,
How then ascend to Jade Capital’s domain?"*
The *Purple Court Classic* states: *"What use are seven yin things?"*

The reverted elixir has many names: Great Elixir, Inner Elixir, King’s Flask Elixir, Crimson Snow Elixir, Radiant Cinnabar Elixir, Dragon-Tiger Great Medicine, Ninefold Divine Elixir, Sovereign of the Cosmos, Divine Talisman White Snow, Tortoise Essence Phoenix Marrow, Hare Marrow Raven Liver, Primordial Essence—yet all are but the conjoining of true lead and true mercury, never mere common lead or mercury, nor mineral, herb, or any substance with form.
Mercury is ninefold true mercury; lead is sevenfold true lead.
Only these two are the true qi of Heaven and Earth, the purest essence of sun and moon.
Externally, they mirror the images of Qian and Kun; internally, they align with the workings of creation.
They give life and take it, become tiger and dragon, embodying profound meaning as they act as husband and wife, continuing the ancestral line as father and son.
Once these two flavors are understood, their dual natures must be known:
Through the matchmaker, male and female harmonize; through the mother, descendants grow.
The sages’ utmost secret—steadfast and true—
For elixir-cultivators, one must seek it within oneself alone!

First, one must refine the self and await the proper time.
The Dao is not far from man—common folk use it daily yet remain unaware!
Refining the self is the way of refining form: splitting open the primordial chaos, cleaving the vast obscurity, gathering the essence of the true one, embracing the primordial qi to lay the foundation of the elixir.
One cannot force transformation with unsuitable elements, as the *Cantong Qi* states:
*"Swallows do not birth phoenixes,
Foxes and hares do not nurse horses.
Kindred types yield results with ease;
Unrelated kinds defy all art."*
The Master of Golden Flower Grotto replied to the Mount Taishi adept:
*"Accumulate the yang soul, dissolve the yin soul,
With yang soldiers drive back yin bandits.
The eight trigrams intermingle, the Five Phases clash,
Return to the root and restore life—
The elixir blazes forth as essence refines form.
Not mere cinnabar or stone—
Some mistake refining the self for refining earth."*
His words are also fine, for the medicine arises in the southwest, the Kun earth.

The crucial point is knowing the time—if the moment is lost, by what seasonal sign does Heaven and Earth generate the myriad things? By what means does the qi of yin and yang give birth to dragon and tiger?
Between the waxing and waning of the moon lies the creative power of the timely moment; at the union of Kan and Li lies the work of the instant.
In this subtlety, nothing is not oral instruction.
When the first true yang stirs, the midnight hour lingers long.
*"The cosmos rests in your hand,
The ten thousand things arise within your body."*
The Master of Piling said: *"To refine the elixir, seek not winter’s advent—
Within the body, the first yang stirs of itself."*
Within the timely moment lies the work of the hour; within the instant lies the work of the moment.
The lead cauldron glows warmly, its light piercing the curtain.
The cauldron is the crucible of creation’s lead; *warmly* means the fire must not falter—only through gentle nurturing does the elixir form.
As the Master of Piling said: *"Keep the golden crucible ever warm with broth,
Let not the jade furnace grow cold with fire’s neglect."*
The curtain is the eyes—Master Yunfang has the line: *"Close the door, lower the blind, silently observe."*
Where the work is applied, the divine radiance shines brilliantly, penetrating the curtain.

Creation’s forces contend, dragon and tiger unite.
When creation’s forces contend, the dragon’s cry summons clouds, the tiger’s roar stirs wind.
One must make the water-tiger seize the fire-dragon, so they may unite.
The *Mirror of Entering the Medicine* says:
*"Lead-dragon ascends, mercury-tiger descends—
Drive the two, let them not escape."*
If the fire is applied untimely, tiger and dragon fail to unite, lead and mercury scatter and flee.
Master Ziyang’s verse says:
*"The white tiger of Western Mountain rages wild,
The green dragon of Eastern Sea defies all bounds—
Seize them with both hands, make them still,
And fuse them into a lump of purple frost."*
Seizing them with both hands means only to ensure their union, that they may congeal into treasure.

Advancing the fire’s work at the Cowherd and Weaving Maid.
Fire is the true essence of the Great Yang—it has a name but no form.
Thus the *Cantong Qi* states: *"Having obtained true lead, true fire is still elusive—
How lightly can one speak of it?"*
Why does fire arise within water?
Kan belongs to water, yet within Kan lies true yang—this is true fire.
When dragon and tiger unite, metal and wood merge, then true fire blazes at their center.

The work of advancing the fire involves methods of hardness and softness, civil and martial, with precise measures and standards. At the double-eight threshold, the six-one seal ensures stabilization. Following the hexagrams and lines, tracing the clepsydra’s flow, resolving *Zhun* and *Meng*, discerning *Pi* and *Tai*, distinguishing the two crescents, discerning the new and full moons—from *Fu*’s beginning to *Kun*’s end, from dawn’s rise to dusk’s cessation—thus do yin and yang unfold and retract, metal and water harmonize.

Should the fire’s timing falter, with unseasonable rains or droughts, scorching heat in deep winter, or bitter frost in midsummer, the Metal Palace will see cinnabar and mercury fall into discord. Within the crucible, locusts swarm; the Metal Tiger and Wood Dragon seethe; the Kan man and Li woman flee. All this arises from misapplied fire, causing the numinous mercury to scatter. As it is said: *"The slightest deviation invites regret and loss; a hair’s breadth of error prevents the elixir’s formation."* How can one not be cautious?

The Cowherd and Weaving Maid at the *Wei* position mark the time for this work. By the Winding River’s banks, one sees the moon’s radiance, flawless and bright, with a crow in flight. The human small intestine, coiled nine times in twelve bends, is called the Winding River. The moon governs the medicine’s function—its flawless purity marks it as the supreme treasure. The crow in flight signifies yin containing yang.

Liu Haichan’s verse says:
*"How often has the crow alighted in the osmanthus bough?"*
And again:
*"Crow flies, hare stirs not."*
An ancient poem reads:
*"A crow flies into the hare’s palace."*
All express this same meaning.

At that moment, one drinks the *daogui* of one’s own making.

When proceeding with the work of union, one begins by gathering from the earthen crucible and drinking it. Thus *The Mirror of Entering the Medicine* states: *"Drink the* daogui*, recognize the earthen crucible—only then may one speak of the* daogui*'s subtleties."* And who would believe that a child is nurtured from nothingness? The Way of Returning Elixir is none other than generating being from non-being, gradually gathering and refining until the sacred embryo is formed—transforming the insubstantial into substance, nurturing the infant to completion. Master Zi Qing’s verse says:
*"How many times the world has made men laugh—
A man, too, may conceive a child.
When one’s own essence and blood unite in congress,
The husband and wife within the body—how wondrous!"*

Discern the clarity and turbidity of the water’s source. *The Scripture of Purity* states: *"Heaven is clear, earth is turbid; man is clear, woman is turbid. Clarity is the source of turbidity."* There is no other reason: yang is clear, yin is turbid. The light and clear floats above—this is true mercury; the heavy and turbid sinks below—this is true lead. A single thing with two uses—how could one not distinguish clearly the Way of clarity and turbidity, ascent and descent?

Wood and metal are separated by distance. Wood resides in the east, in the positions of *jia* and *yi*; in form, it is the Azure Dragon; in the hexagrams, it is *Zhen*, the eldest son of *Qian*, mother of fire, wife of metal, the maiden in blue, the green-eyed one, the Azure Dragon of the Eastern Sea, the sap of wood. Metal resides in the west, in the positions of *geng* and *xin*; in form, it is the White Tiger; in the hexagrams, it is *Dui*, the youngest daughter of *Kun*, mother of water, husband of wood, the youth in white, the white-haired elder, the White Tiger of the Western Mountains, the essence of metal. Separated by the positions of *mao* and *you*, they have no means of meeting—only by entrusting the Yellow Dame as matchmaker may they become one. Master Zi Yang said: *"Wood and metal are separated, with no cause to meet—
They must rely on a go-between to draw them together."*
Only then does wood generate fire, metal generate water, and water and fire share the same abode—thus metal and wood unite! Without a teacher’s guidance, this matter is difficult to know.

The great medicine of the Golden Elixir has been transmitted but once in ten thousand kalpas. The *Sacred Writ of Jade Casket* has led eight or nine out of ten scholars astray. The oral instructions of sagely teachers have been passed down heart to heart through the ages. Without heart-to-heart transmission and oral teaching, even with the talents of the Three Heroes or the wisdom of the Ten Sages, no amount of conjecture will enable one to proceed and form the sacred embryo. As the saying goes:
*"Though your wisdom surpasses Yan and Min,
Without a bright teacher, do not guess in vain.
For the Golden Elixir has no oral formula—
Where then shall you form the numinous embryo?"*
Liu Haichan’s verse says:
*"This Way is manifest—
Why then do you recklessly speculate?"*

The Way of the Golden Elixir is truly difficult to know without encountering a true teacher. The essentials of the Dao are subtle, the celestial mechanisms profound. *"The Great Dao is formless, yet it gives birth to heaven and earth;
The Great Dao is passionless, yet it moves the sun and moon;
The Great Dao is nameless, yet it nurtures the myriad things.
I know not its name—perforce I call it the Dao."*

*"Vast and obscure, within it there is feeling;
Vague and indistinct, within it there is substance.
Invisible when seen, inaudible when heard,
Untouchable when grasped—
From nothingness it generates being.
The celestial mechanisms are profound,
The mysteries unfathomable."*

*The Scripture of Yin Conformity* states: *"Heaven has five thieves—those who see them prosper.
Those who know and cultivate them are called sages!"*
Unless one thoroughly understands yin and yang and deeply penetrates the workings of creation, how can one cleave open primordial chaos, gather the root of heaven and earth as parents, and lay the foundation for the great elixir? Split asunder the vast expanse, take the pure essence of yin and yang as the foundation of the great Dao, assemble the Five Phases, harmonize the Four Images. Gather the Three Flowers atop the head, so that the single qi does not darken; direct the Five Qi to return to the origin, so that the yang soul does not scatter. Roam freely in the boundless obscurity, come and go within the indistinct and vague, move and transport, shift the spirit to the yang abode. When the work is complete and conduct perfected, one attains the rank of celestial immortal.

Moreover, the Way of the Golden Fluid Returning Elixir has but one gate—how could it be mentioned in the same breath as lesser side methods? Begin swiftly, for even now it is too late. Of the thousand scriptures and ten thousand treatises, none speak of the initial work of proceeding—only oral instructions transmit it. At the outset, one moves the bellows and keys of qian and kun, gathers the *daogui* of kan and li, and gathers the spirit of the entire body into the Heavenly Valley. There, one nurtures it, so that spirit and qi return to their root—this is called *"returning wind to merge, tightly securing the root."* This is the Way of guarding the True One. *The Scripture of Dragon and Tiger* says: *"The spirit chamber’s upper and lower crucibles—
Transformation lies in your hands."*
Thus the Perfected of the Orthodox One discoursed on the sword of the green snake, and the Old Man of Western Shu attained the subtleties of the golden hammer.

Lü Dongbin called it the "fire staff," while Kongtong of Qingcheng said the sword is not the Dao. These all exhaust traces and signs, dissecting without foundation. Without the initial work of proceeding, mere discourse on the Golden Elixir will never succeed! An ancient song says: *"The sage discerns the intent of Creation’s work— / Hands grasp sun and moon, placing them in the furnace."* *The Scripture of Yin Conformity* states: *"The cosmos lies within your hands, / The myriad things are born within your body!"*

To study without encountering a true master is to meet no one; to meet one without diligence is to remain a lesser ghost. Laozi said: *"The superior person, hearing the Dao, practices it with diligence— / The immortal’s path can only be cultivated by humans."* An ancient saying goes: *"Immortals are but mortals made."* Know that the wheel of rebirth turns swiftly, and karmic retribution is inescapable. Wealth and honor are but fleeting schemes. Proceed with haste—even now it is too late.

The path to Penglai relies on the fulfillment of three thousand deeds, then one strides upon the clouds to return. The three isles of Penglai are the immortal mountains upon the sea. Within the human body, too, there are three isles of Penglai: the crown is the Upper Isle, the heart the Middle Isle, and the kidneys the Lower Isle. Master Zi Qing’s poem says: *"Within the human body lies a Penglai of its own."* The three thousand deeds are the count of *"nine years embracing the One."* When the nine years of work are complete, some may divide their form and scatter their shadow, or move between existence and non-existence; some may ascend in lightness to wander afar, hidden or revealed at will; some may exchange their bones to become immortals, roaming the isles of Penglai; some may be summoned by the Supreme Unity to dwell in the Central Continent—each according to the depth of their merit and conduct.

*The Kiln’s Unfired Song* says:
*"When nine years of work are fully passed,
The form remains in the world, unaware of spring.
Suddenly the Heavenly Gate shatters at the crown—
A true person emerges with great spiritual power,
And immortals come to offer their congratulations."*

*The Seal of the Unity of the Three* states:
*"When the Dao is accomplished and virtue perfected,
One conceals oneself to await the time.
The Supreme Unity then summons,
Relocating one to the Central Continent.
When merit is complete, one ascends,
Receiving the register and the chart."*

Master Peng’s commentary says:
*"The Supreme Unity True Lord is the overseer of inner refinement.
When mortals first attain the Dao, their names are engraved on golden tablets,
And in this continent, they receive the register and chart,
Thus gaining ascension."*

*Linwu Shanren Quanyangzi Yu’s commentary on "Spring in Qin Garden"*

The Sevenfold Return Elixir.
Seven is the number of fire. In the method of elixir refinement, one first casts the red into the black to generate the medicine. Once the medicine is obtained, fire is then applied to refine the black into red, thereby forming the elixir—hence the name "Sevenfold Return Elixir." This does not refer to the seven hours from *yin* to *shen*. As Zhang Ziyang’s *Wuzhen Pian* states:
*"The Metal Duke is originally the son of the Eastern House,
Sent to the Western Neighbor to lodge and take form.
Recognize and call him home to nurture in your dwelling,
Pair him with the Maiden of Cinnabar to forge kinship."*

This is the meaning. For the practitioner, one must first refine the self and await the proper time. The *Li Sao: Yuan You* says:
*"Do not disturb your soul with clamor,
For it will naturally align.
The singular qi is most numinous—
Preserve it in the midst of night.
Be empty to await it,
Before all action."*

This is what it means to refine the self and await the time. The key lies in withdrawing the gaze and returning the hearing, remaining utterly still, concentrating the spirit in the Great Void, without a single stray thought. After a moment, the spirit enters the qi, and qi unites with spirit—then the true breath naturally settles, and numinous clarity arises, all within the span of an instant. As Shao Kangjie’s *Xiantian Yin* says:
*"If asked about the precelestial, there is not a single word,
Yet postcelestial work requires effort."*

The method of the elixir is the same. Gathering the medicine in the precelestial is nonaction; applying fire in the postcelestial is action. They cannot be treated as one and the same.

**The First Stirring of Yang**
Bai Ziqing’s *Zhuyu Ji: Dansui Ge* says:
*"To refine the elixir, one need not seek the winter solstice—
Within the body, a single yang naturally arises."*

But how does one know when the single yang stirs within? It is in the instant between breaths, when *xun* opens and the heart awakens—that fleeting moment of indistinctness. At this time, one fans the bellows and stokes the fierce fire, so that true lead emerges from *kan*, and the river chariot does not dare to linger, carrying it to the summit of *qiaoqiao*. Only then can it become the Return Elixir. As Shao Kangjie’s *Huanghu Yin* says:
*"In the indistinct, yin and yang first transform,
Swirling and coiling as heaven and earth begin to turn.
Amidst this, a fleeting radiance appears—
How can mere words capture the work?"*

Without penetrating insight into the transformations of yin and yang, who could comprehend this?

**The Endless Night of the Midwatch**
The midwatch is the midnight hour of *zi*. The *Zhouyi Cantong Qi* says:
*"Embracing the primal in the Void and Danger,
One disseminates essence at the hour of *zi*."*

It also states:
*"Between the dark and the new moon,
The tally aligns and moves at the center."*

This refers to the moment before midnight on the thirtieth day, the threshold between the dark and the new moon. If applied to a single day, then every night before the hour of *zi* is this threshold, not limited to the midnight of the thirtieth day. The *Wuzhen Pian* says:
*"The sun and moon meet once every thirty days,
Exchanging time for days—this is the divine work."*

Its meaning is clear. The *lou* (water clock) has both inner and outer aspects. Internally, it is the breath’s exhalation and inhalation. As Xue Zixian’s *Fuming Pian* says:
*"This heart is like embers beneath chaff,
In silent sitting, one hears the dripping of the water clock."*

Externally, it is the actual water clock. Some may question the *Wuzhen Pian*’s line:
*"Know that the great hermit dwells in the marketplace,
Do not seek solitude in the deep mountains,"*

unaware that in the mountains, lamps and water clocks are hard to come by. Others may object, citing Chen Niuwan’s *Cuixu Pian*:
*"If one says the water clock is unreliable,
They have not grasped the mystery—no medicine will form."*

Yet it also says:
*"Gaze at the sundial by day, watch the water clock by night."*

How contradictory! In the early stages of refinement, when skill is not yet mastered, one may err, so an external water clock is necessary to mark the proper time. But once skill is perfected and the elixir field is seeded, essence arises at its appointed hour, and the spirit knows the time. Even in sleep, one awakens without needing to be roused—what need is there for a water clock then? "Endless night" describes the unbroken continuity of its dripping. Within the body, this is the ceaseless flow of true breath—let it not falter, just as the water clock’s flow is unbroken.

**The Warm Lead Cauldron, Light Piercing the Curtain**
The cauldron is the lower elixir field. As the hour of *zi* approaches, yang qi subtly stirs below, hence the warmth. The curtain refers to the eyes—lowering the gaze resembles a drawn curtain. When the elixir field holds medicine and yang qi rises, it penetrates the space between the brows, casting light. This is like a candle in a room: the light shines through the window, but the brightness is not from the window—it is from the candle. Some, upon first witnessing this, may marvel in astonishment, but if the heart stirs and the spirit scatters, how can the elixir be achieved?

**The Rushing of Creation’s Forces**
"Rushing" refers to the end of *kun* and the beginning of *fu*. At this moment, a jade chime sounds, and the twin caves open. The *Fuming* says: "Both sides ascend together, sharing a single pound." This is the time.

**The Mating of Tiger and Dragon**
The *Cantong Qi* states:
*"The dragon calls to the tiger, the tiger inhales the dragon’s essence.
They feed upon each other, mutually devouring."*

In elixir-making, the key is for heart and breath to depend on each other, so that qi gathers and spirit congeals, mating to form the medicine. Chen Chaoyuan’s *Yuzhi Shu* says:
*"If the yellow and black do not mate,
How can yang fly from beneath *kan*?"*

Thus, only when yin and yang mate and the elixir field holds medicine can fire be applied.

**The Fire Phase of Ox, Dipper, and Rooftop**
Ox, Dipper, and Rooftop are the directional markers of the fire phase within the body.

The fire-phase practice begins at *zi* and initiates movement at *yin*, just as heaven’s living things take form in the womb at *zi* and emerge at *yin*. The *Cantong Qi* states: “It begins in the northeast quarter of *Ji* and the Dipper, then revolves rightward, spewing forth the wheel and spitting out the sprout.” The *Cuixu Pian* says: “There is a path where mother and child part at birth—its marvel lies in the tail of *Ji*, the Dipper, *Niu*, and *Nü*.” This shares the same purport. Some interpret *Niu*, *Dou*, and *Wei* as “still perilous,” citing the *Wuzhen Pian*: “Grasped in both hands, it is called dead,” to elucidate this point—another valid explanation.

At Qujiang, the moon’s radiance appears pristine. The *Cuixu Pian* says: “On the southwest path, the moon’s radiance is bright; the great medicine returns, born from this place. I recall an ancient poet’s line: *At Qujiang’s banks, the magpie bridge spans.*” The ancients took the small intestine’s nine coils and twelve bends as Qujiang, while later adepts identified it as the space between nose and mouth—both interpretations hold. Yet *Cuixu* further clarifies its meaning through the southwest path, rendering it profoundly clear. The southwest corresponds to *kun*, and *kun* is the abdomen. When the medicine arises in the elixir field, yang qi ascends, alighting upon the eyes and emitting light. Thus, from the eyes to the navel, the entire path gleams with empty whiteness, luminous as the moon’s radiance.

There is a crow in flight. This “crow in flight” signifies the union of heaven and earth within the body, the merging of *kan* and *li*, as the two qi intermingle in harmony, coalescing into a single dewdrop that flies and alights in the elixir field. Chen Xiyi’s *Zhixuan Pian* says: “A crow in flight enters the osmanthus palace.” The *Cuixu Pian* states: “The red lotus holds its pistil; the dewdrop congeals into jade, flying into the flower pool as pearl after pearl.” The *Yujihuanyuan Pian* says: “One who comprehends this principle will see a single drop fall into the Yellow Court.” Bai Ziqing’s verse reads: “Now that I’ve pierced the golden crow’s mystery, it flies into the jade toad’s cavern.” All express this same meaning. At that moment, one naturally imbibes the *daogui*.

Medical texts speak of the "square-inch spoon" and the "blade’s tip," referring to the merest speck—nothing more than the corner of a knife’s edge. The phrase "imbibes it oneself" means traversing the Three Palaces, descending into the mouth, which aligns with the *Wuzhen Pian*’s "shedding the embryo to enter the mouth, the body attains sagehood." The principle is one and the same.

Some may doubt: if the embryo has already been shed, why does it re-enter the mouth? They thus assume the elixir comes from without, swallowing external substances, straying far from the Dao. Yet does not the *Cuixu Pian* say: *"Gather it, refine it—not for a moment’s pause; a single qi, vast and boundless, courses through the Three Passes. The Three Passes’ ceaseless flow draws forth a white meridian, ascending to the Mud Pill Palace. Above the Mud Pill, the Purple Gold Crucible; within the crucible, a lump of purple gold, transmuting into jade nectar that streams into the mouth, its fragrance and sweetness suffusing the tongue."* Could this ever come from outside oneself? Who would believe that a child is nurtured from nothingness?

The Great Dao of the Golden Elixir is utterly simple and effortless, generating being from non-being, nurturing the infant within. Saliva, essence, fluids, qi, blood—these may serve as stepping stones, but they are not the elixir’s treasure. Scholars, confined by narrow views, cling to preconceived notions and refuse to delve into the elixir texts. Even if a true adept seeks to enlighten them, who would believe?

The *Cuixu Pian* states: *"A marvel that draws laughter time and again—now even men can conceive! Their own essence and blood unite; within the body, husband and wife are wondrous indeed!"* For "husband and wife" are but alternate names for yin and yang—no true couple exists. Yet some, fixated on the notion of "mending bamboo with bamboo," insist on "supplementing man with man," turning to the perverse arts of the Three Peaks. How could they ever trust that the Golden Elixir is a path of pure non-action, generating being from non-being?

Thus, clinging to action gives rise to being from non-being, while non-action emerges from within being—each proceeds in its proper sequence. Distinguishing the purity of the water’s source has already been discussed. One view holds: *"Heaven is pure, earth is turbid—such is creation."* Another: *"Draw the pure, discard the turbid—unceasingly refine."* Now, regarding the "purity of the water’s source," let us examine the term "water source." As the *Yi* says, *"Heaven’s One generates water,"* whose position lies in the north, where the eight waters converge—hence the name "water source." The *Cuixu Pian* declares: *"Urge the hundred meridians to return to the source."* This is its meaning.

Above is pure; below is turbid. Initially, above and below intermingle as one. Over time, they gradually settle, gradually clarify—once pure, the supreme medicine arises within. Liu Haichan’s *Huánjīn Piān* speaks of *"water congealing into amber,"* which is this very process. As for the notion of "retaining the pure and discarding the turbid," that is another matter.

In my commentary on the *Cantong Qi*, I wrote: *"In form, it resembles ash and earth, like dust settling on a bright window."* This has been explained in detail.

**Wood and Metal in Separation**
Within the body lies a single substance, divided into two: the floating is Wood, the sinking is Metal. One to the east, one to the west—hence their separation.
